articleText:
THE MORETON BAY COURIER.

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1846.

THE time, we trust, is not far distant, when the venerable gentleman who is nominally the Representative of the great electoral district of Gloucester, Macquarie, and Stanley, will mark his sense of duty to his adopted country and his consti- tuents by tendering his resignation.* An allusion to the privileges and duties we shall be shortly called upon to exercise, will not, therefore, be out of place.

Thanks to our magnificent district, thanks to the wealth and energy of an enterprising and intelligent community, our franchisial claims are no longer in- significant. From the small number of twelve votes, given by the electors of Stanley at the time of Mr. McLeay's re- turn to the Legislative Council, the elec- toral roll prepared by the Chief Constable in April last showed that there were then resident in the county fifty-seven persons

entitled to a voice in our Colonial Assem-

bly. And so considerable has been the influx of population during the present year, that their number has since greatly

increased.

The possession of an estate in freehold in lands or tenements, situate within the district, of the clear value of £200, above all charges and incumbrances, or the occupancy of a house rated at a rent-value of £20 a-year, constitutes the electoral qualification. This possession of estate, or house tenancy, must, however, date at

least six months before the date of the last

registration. Voters must be of full age — and British subjects, either by birth, naturalization, or holding letters of deni zation. Emancipists, who have received free or conditional pardons, are also en- titled to vote, when otherwise qualified.

The electoral list is prepared yearly, between the 10th March and 10th April, by the Chief Constable, and is delivered by

him to the Clerk of the Bench. The Act

"to provide for the division of New-South Wales into electoral districts, and for the election of members to serve in the Legis- lative Council," directs that the clerk shall "fairly transcribe" the list, and affix it to

the walls or door of the Court House for

seven clear days, from the 13th to the 20th April — a time amply sufficient to allow of all errors, both of intromission and omis- sion, being discovered. Two days are allowed to voters, whose names are omit- ted, or who object to the claims of others

to have their names retained on the elec-

toral roll, to give due notice to the Cleric

of the Bench. Lists of all claims and

objections are then prepared, and hung up

on the outside of the Court House from

the 22nd April to the 1st May. The Police Magistrate, who in this matter oc- cupies the position of an alderman in the municipal towns of Sydney and Mel- bourne, and who is usually nominated as the returning officer by the Governor, appoints a day, between the 1st and 15th May, for the holding of a Court of Petty Sessions, or Registration Court, to revise the roll. Ten clear days' notice having been given, the Police Magistrate, assisted by other magistrates as assessors, hears and decides upon the various claims and objections, and directs the list of voters to

* Since the above was in type, we have received the last Sydney newspapers by the Tamar. We observe that Mr. McLeay met with a serious mis- hap on the night of the 25th ultimo. Returning from a ball given by Sir Charles and Lady Fitz- roy, his carriage was upset by a blundering coachman, and, we regret to state, one of his ribs and his collar bone were fractured. When the Tamar left Sydney, his medical attendants had not pronounced him out of danger.

be amended accordingly. In its amended state, it is forwarded by the Clerk of the Bench, on or before the 1st June, to the

returning officer ; and. forms the electoral roll for the twelve months ensuing,

The Act provides that when a seat be- comes vacant, a writ shall be issued by the Governor, directed to the returning officer, fixing the day of nomination, and in the event of the election being con-

tested, the day of taking the poll. The election must take place within thirty days of the date of the writ, which must

be returnable from Moreton Bay, not later than twenty-eight days afterward. In all the other districts, except Port Phillip, writs must be returned within fourteen days.

The 28th clause enacts, "That on the day of nomination, which shall be the day of election named in the writ, the return- ing officer shall preside at a meeting to be holden at noon, and shall declare the purpose for which such meeting is held ; and if there be at such meeting no more candidates proposed than the number of members to be returned, the returning officer shall declare such candidate or can- didates to be duly elected, and make his return accordingly ; and that in the event of there being more candidates than the number to be elected, the returning officer shall call for a show of hands separately in favour of each candidate, and after such show of hands, shall declare the person or persons on whom the election has fallen, and shall return the same accordingly, unless a poll be demanded by one of the candidates, or by not less than six electors on his behalf, and on such demand being made for a poll, the polling shall com- mence, as nearly as may be, at nine o'clock in the forenoon of the day ap- pointed by the Governor in the writ for taking the poll, and no poll shall be kept open later than four of the clock in the

afternoon."

The 32nd clause enacts, "That as soon as may be practicable after the election shall have been held, the returning officer shall openly declare the state of the poll,

and declare the name or names of the

person or persons who may have been duly elected ; and in the event of the number of votes being equal, he shall by his casting vote decide the election."

Acts deemed to constitute bribery are various. The giving of money, or any other article whatsoever, cockades inclu- ded, the holding out to an elector any promise or expectation of profit, or making use of any threat, or intimidating him in any manner; supplying him with meat, drink, lodging, or horse or carriage hire, or conveyance of any kind ; paying him a sum of money for joining in a proces- sion ; keeping open, or allowing to be kept open, any place of entertainment, whether refreshment be distributed or not ; the giving of any entertainment at any place whatsoever by a candidate, to any number of persons, with a view of in- fluencing their votes — are all held to be acts of bribery, and the candidate commit- ting any one of them, on proof thereof be for the Court for the trial of disputed elec- tions, is disqualified from holding a seat in the Council until the next general

election.

THE NEXT GENERAL ELECTION ! Before that takes place a new era may have dawned upon the colony. The principle of taxa- tion by representation — our inherent pri- vilege, of which we have now little more than the sound and shadow — may be in reality conceded to us ; and, the franchise being extended to the great bulk of the holders of colonial property, the squatters — our Legislature will then really become a Representative Assembly. The present Council, and the Act, which gave it birth, will at no far distant date expire together. We cannot for an instant suppose that the Act which succeeds it will perpetuate its blundering injustice. The palpable absurdity will surely not much longer exist of conceding the elective franchise to the pettiest householder in the pettiest town, and denying it to the tenant of the Crown, who reckons his wealth by thou- sands. Of one thing we may be assured : until justice is done in this matter to the squatters, the people of Moreton Bay can never hope to possess a requisite degree of influence in the councils of the colony.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1846.
snippet: THE time, we trust, is not far distant, when the venerable gentleman who is nominally the Representative of the great electoral district of Gloucester, Macquarie,

articleText:
To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,—In your paper of the 3rd instant, under the head of " The Constabulary," you have given insertion to a misrepresentation of the conduct of Constable McCrohon on his arrival, as I conceive you acquired your information from a resident in this town, who, under the pretence of giving you a facetious morsel for your readers, gratified the worst of feelings of himself and clique, by getting you to publish a series of falsehoods, to injure McCrohon in the estimation of the Magistrates ; but being well aware of your anxiety (as a caterer for public instruction and amusement) to re- fute any false statements which may be inadvert- ently inserted in your journal, I beg to hand you a true version of this matter, which can, if, re- quired, be verified by affidavit.

On the arrival of McCrohon at Ipswich, a man, named Samson-who has a wife and child-craved

permission from McCrohon to remain a day or two in a building attached to the Lockup-a part of which Magrath occupied-as he (Samson) could not get a place to put his family in. McCrohon replied that they might stop for a day or two if his colleague was agreeable. Magrath subsequently assented ; but mark the result : a private infor- mation was sent to the Magistrates, that Magrath was turned out by McCrohon to make room for these people ; but, on enquiry, it was proved to be false, as Magrath never left the occupation of his usual quarters ; but the truth was not made known in time to prevent McCrohon's dismissal from the situation of District Constable,—so that he was punished for his humanity to these destitute per- sons, although I admit he had no right to give the permission to occupy the place, it being the property of the Crown.

With respect to the visit of McCrohon to the Doctor's, as stated in your article, the facts were that McCrohon went to Doctor Dorsay's, to en- quire were Furber lived-as I am informed--for the purpose of hiring his team to draw up his (M'Crohon's) goods; and this visit enabled your corresponent to be facetious at the expense of his

veracity. But your informant's well known pro- pensity of taking large potations of gin—in pro- portion to his corporation, which is no small one it is probable he had, when writing the article in question, attributed McCrohon's visit to the Doctor to the want of what is called by drunkards " the doctor," i.e., a glass of gin, eggs, &c.

I am, Sir, your obedient servant,

FAIR PLAY.
heading: To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.
snippet: SIR,—In your paper of the 3rd instant, under the head of " The Constabulary," you have given insertion to a misrepresentation of the conduct of Constable M'Crohon on his arrival, as I conceive

articleText:
To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,—I observe in your last number that you have favoured your readers with some remarks relative to the ferries, and the appropriation of the funds

derived from them.

I quite agree with you that it is high time we were up and doing in this matter. The wit of man could devise no tax more opposed to common sense and sound policy, or better fitted to retard the progress of a young and struggling com- munity, than the abominable ferry imposition, to which you have recently drawn our attention. It is at once a tax upon communication and a direct tax, the most odious and unpopular of all kinds of taxation. Its effect has been, as every one amongst us too well knows, to render the three settlements of Kangaroo Point, North Brisbane, and South Brisbane, as isolated and as separate in their aims and interests, as if they were ten miles distant from each other, instead of only being separated by the river Brisbane. Cease when it may, its fame must remain as long as the history, " the owre true tale," of Sir George Gipps' misrule and political treachery endures.

Our late ruler, while visiting this part of the colony, and prior to the sale of land in what is now South Brisbane, - pledged himself to the inhabitants that the ferry should be retained in the hands of the Government - a public convenience main- tained at the public expense. No sooner, however, did the land-bubble burst - the goose die " which laid the golden eggs" - no sooner were a number of allotments sold on the south bank of the river, than the Government put up the ferry to auction to the highest bidder ; and a tax was imposed of 2d. on foot passengers, 6d. on horses, and 5s. a ton on goods.

What will strangers at a distance say when they learn that a resident here, walking from one end of the town to the other -- from South Brisbane to Kangaroo Point - and back again, must pay a toll of EIGHTPENCE ; if on horseback, TWO SHILLINGS AND EIGHTPENCE ; and for a ton of goods, if taken the same way, ONE POUND ?

Is not this monstrous ? Can anything be more unjust ? Could anything be devised more suicidal of the very object at which it aims - the creation of

revenue ?

What is the conduct of Government ? By sell- ing land on both sides of the river, it splits the town up into sections, and creates natural obsta- cles, and then - yes, then ; will it be credited ? - taxes us for its own stupid and miserable blunder- ing. This is truly a notable way of raising a revenue, and right worthy of the policy of the man with whom it originated.

But what is the amount that accrues to the revenue from this source? A paltry £160 or £170 a year. To get at this, the Government coolly consents to our being in reality taxed to the

tune of about £1000 !

The whole matter, absurd though it be, is too serious to be treated with ridicule. And we have

borne the infliction so long, (with murmuring, it is true), that invective would now be out of place. The present Government, however, will surely never sanction the perpetuation of any such in- justice, if it is rightly represented to them. But if we coolly sit down, and pay so iniquitous a tax without marking our disapprobation of it, save by an occasional John Bullish grumble, then of course

we have none save ourselves to blame. Our late

Governor took advantage of our weakness and helplessness ; he acted towards us as, I trust, no Governor will ever dare to do again. Sir Charles Fitzroy, however, is not responsible for the acts of his predecessor ; and in representing this griev- ance to him, we shall, I feel convinced, represent it to an, impartial third party.

Let us, therefore, be up and doing. Let us show that we have not forgotten our rights and privileges as British subjects—rights and privi- leges inalienable, the birthright of every partici- pant in the benefits of the Constitution. Shall we, because this is a small matter, comparatively, remain spiritless, and dead to such barefaced in- justice ? or shall we not rather show by our con- duct that we are ever ready and prepared to resist oppression, even though that oppression consist in the peddling, narrow-minded, unprincipled ex- tortion of Sir George Gipps ?

I have heard that a Memorial to His Excellency

and the Executive Council will obtain all that we desire. I trust that but a short time will elapse before such a document, signed by every man, woman, and child, in the place; is forwarded to head quarters.

" TWO PENCE, IF YOU PLEASE."
heading: To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.
snippet: SIR,—I observe in your last number that you have favoured your readers with some remarks relative to the ferries, and the appropriation of the funds derived from them.

articleText:
DR. LEICHHARDT.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,-Having just arrived from Darling Downs, I have satisfaction in being able to communicate a few particulars respecting Dr. Leichhardt and party, which, perhaps, may not be uninteresting to your readers.

The adventurous explorer arrived on the Downs on the 5th instant, and after visiting several of the stations, left on the 7th for Laidley Creek, to meet Mr. Mann, who was expected to be on the road with the supplies that arrived here by the steamer. He was to get several head of fat cattle from Laidley, which had been presented to him by J. P. Robinson, Esq. When the Doctor left the Downs, it was not his intention to visit Bris- bane. The stock that he had brought overland consisted of a large flock of goats (380, I believe,), and sixteen mules, which were depasturing on Mr.

Bracker's station until the Doctor's return ; when that took place, the party intended to proceed to Jimba, their final starting place. The Messrs. Leslie and Messrs. Campbell, had each presented

Dr. Leichhardt with twelve fat wethers.

I am sorry that I should so far have forgotten your valuable paper as not to have taken notes, so as to furnish you with more details respecting the movements of the expedition party. It is more than probable, however, that some one will be found, able and willing, to supply the deficiency before your next publication.

In the meantime this short epistle will acquaint the friends of Dr. Leichhardt of his safe arrival on the Downs. He is in good health, and looks much better than the last time he was there.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J.G.

e_!_
heading: DR. LEICHHARDT. To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.
snippet: SIR,—Having just arrived from Darling Downs, I have satisfaction in being able to communicate a few particulars respecting Dr. Leichhardt and party, which, perhaps, may not be uninteresting

articleText:
To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,—You appear to have been led into error by some interested party respecting the circumstances that occurred in South Brisbane on Thursday week, which I hope, in common justice, you will permit me to correct ; as such statements may do me con- siderable injury if allowed to go uncontradicted. The following are the facts :—

Darker was permitted by me to remain, on suf- ferance, in my house until the amount due to me was paid according to agreement. He failed to do so, and then became my tenant, I then dis- trained upon his goods, and they were removed to my own room. In attempting to recover the pro- perty, thus distrained, by force, the unfortunate occurrence took place, which I sincerely regret, and for which I am ready to make every atone- ment in my power.

Requesting the insertion of the above,

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

CORNELIUS HUGHES.
heading: To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.
snippet: SIR,—You appear to have been led into error by some interested party respecting the circumstances that occurred in South Brisbane on Thursday week, which I hope, in common justice, you will permit

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, JUNE 20, 1846.

THE COURIER has been established in compliance with the almost unanimous wish of every resident, of character, pro- perty, and intelligence, in this extensive district. The unfounded impressions that prevail elsewhere respecting the climate, capabilities, and resources, of this portion of the colony, and the absence of those beneficial moral influences which have

their origin in the Press, have long ren- dered a local journal necessary. The commercial importance of the com- munity, indeed, demands its introduc- tion. Churches, schools, stores, shops, inns, dwelling-houses, and erections for various purposes, have rapidly risen ; settlements have become villages ; villages, towns. Our staple articles of export, wool and tallow, have strikingly increased ; and with their increase, fresh incitement has been afforded to industry and enterprize. And as the position of the grazing and trading classes, who form the bulk of our infant society, has im- proved, and population has augmented, prosperity has educed requirements that can only appertain to an advanced state of society. Perhaps none is so urgent as that which we aim to supply.

We commence our labours at a crisis highly interesting and important. Our home and colonial dynasties are happily changed. The weight of tyranny, mis- representation, and neglect, under which the colonists have long, bitterly, and un- ceasingly complained, is about to be re- moved. Instead of men, whose tenures of office were marked by carelessness of

the welfare of those entrusted to their

control, strong prejudices in favour of their own too often hastily-formed opinions, excessive obstinacy in adhering to them when once expressed, and queru- lous impatience of their contradiction, rendering their admitted great talents

worse than negative in their influence on our destinies, Ministers have wisely substituted a Secretary of State, and a Governor, whose past careers justly en- title them to our confidence and respect.

In Mr. Gladstone we recognise one who, in true liberality of feeling, in just and comprehensive views of political economy, in thorough acquaintance with the whole system of our commercial and colonial policy, and in freedom, at least so far as known to the public, from all pre- conceived and pet schemes, promises to administer the affairs of the Colonial Office in a widely different manner from that in which they have been hitherto conducted. There are few statesmen of the present day who have risen so rapidly in public estimation, and few who give fairer promise of rising still higher. Sir Charles Fitzroy has also been tried and proved, and on his coadjutancy, we pre- dict, our Colonial Minister may safely depend in carrying out whatever measures of conciliation and concession he may deem necessary to restore public confi- dence, and destroy a growing spirit of dis- affection. Such measures are indeed urgently needed. The great stay of our social fabric, the Pastoral interest, is fluctuating and unsettled: the all-impor- tant question of Colonial policy, the tenure of Waste Lands, is not yet deter- mined; and all classes are anxiously awaiting those farther modifications of Mr. Hope's Bill, necessary to enable it to

realise the views and intentions of its framer. On the other hand, the odious pound-an-acre minimum is not yet blotted from the Statute Book, nor its place sup- plied by a law based upon the common- sense principle that land is not worth more than it is capable, in ordinary seasons, of returning, together with a fair rate of profit, to the buyer. In addition, therefore, to " facts based on figures," strong, energetic, and unceasing demon- strations, are yet necessary on the part of the colonists, to induce Her Majesty's ad- visers to recognise the simple axiom, that the progressive prosperity of the colony, and its consequent importance to the British empire, do not depend upon the mere sums directly realised by selling its public lands, but mainly on the develope- ment of the lands' capabilities : and that our true interests are conserved, only so far as this principle is received. A high or a low nominal price can never affect the real value of land. That value is deter-

mined solely by the inducements it pre- sents to the capitalist. To place a reserve of twenty shillings upon land, in many places not worth one, is therefore opposed to the simplest economical principles, an- nihilates the land fund, and is a stretch of power as unwise as it is arbitrary and unjust.

The land fund, too, is still withheld from the control of the people's repre-

sentatives. We have the mortification of

seeing this highly important branch of revenue squandered by a herd of over-paid official drones, in a manner that too plainly bespeaks them ignorant of our wants, and careless of our welfare.

View it in what aspect we may, the great vexata quœstio of Public Lands is disfigured by unconstitutional abuse; and it behoves every well-wisher of the colony to agitate unceasingly until the whole system is swept away to make room for a

better.

Adequate representation—he conces-

sion of the elective franchise to owners of live stock, as well as to those whose capital is vested in the soil,—and correlative to this, the extension of the representative element in our Legislature, are subjects of the last importance. The powers of the Legislature require to be more distinctly defined: of this our readers will find ample proof in the debates of last session : a boundary must be fixed, which even the Governor of the colony will not dare to pass without the consent of the people.

District Councils (the frozen vipers,

over whose monstrous birth their anxious

author watched, only to see them trodden under foot by those in whose bosoms he sought to thrust them, or, if received, with fangs extracted, powerless to wound, and objects of derisive pity) are unknown amongst us. The growing importance, however of our chief town, and the district contiguous, renders us, in common with the colonists at large, anxious to witness either their modification or their total repeal.

Turning from political, to moral and social topics, we solicit attention to the vital necessity of a comprehensive scheme of National Education. The future cha-

racter, as well as the future prosperity of the colony, depend upon it. The recent Census informs us that a numerous native

race is fast springing up throughout the

colony, thousands of whom are approach- ing to manhood without even the elements of education. It is appalling to think that in a few years, the great bulk of the population of our rural districts may be composed of persons, whose ignorance will unfit them for anything beyond bare

manual labour, and render them adepts only in vice and immorality. A speedy

and effectual remedy for this lamentable state of things must be provided by our Government; if they wish the land to be filled with a virtuous and intelligent po- pulation. And the only remedy, we believe, which will effectually meet the peculiar circumstances of the colony, is a GENERAL SYSTEM OF EDUCATION—a system which will aim not at the advancement of sectarian interests, but at the inculcation of sound morality and virtuous habits. A system of this kind, we feel sure, would command the approbation and support of all the liberal and enlightened portion of the community. To obtain it, and when obtained, to aid in carrying it into active and extensive operation, we intend to give our cordial and earnest endeavours.

A regular and sufficient supply of labour stands foremost among the topics to which the limits of our address preclude us from adverting. In further elucidation of our views and principles, we assure our readers that our conduct will be ever in-

fluenced by a due regard of what we may conscientiously deem the true interests of our constituents and of the colony. We eschew sectarian controversy, as unsuited to the character and objects of a news- paper. Claiming for ourselves the right of private judgment, we willingly concede a similar right to every man. He, in- deed, who by means of the Press seeks to foster bigotry and promote the strife of sects, is society's worst enemy—its most dangerous foe.

The exposure of private turpitude may sometimes preserve public integrity intact. In such a case we shall not be slow to speak out. Private acts, however, are alone fit subjects for newspaper comment when they are inimical to the happiness and well-being of society.

As a local journal, it will be our great object to make known the wants of the community; to point out the most eligi- ble field presented to capital and enter- prise; to rouse the apathetic, to inform the ignorant, to infuse animation into struggles for political and social rights ; to unite the whole moral feeling and intel- ligence of the sphere in which we move ; to transmit truthful representations of the state of this unrivalled portion of the colony to other and distant parts of the globe; to encourage every enterprise that will tend to benefit it, and in general to advance its interests, and promote its prosperity.

In addition to domestic news and ad- vertisements, the COURIER will contain an interesting epitome of Home, Colonial, and Foreign intelligence, as well as judi- cious notices of all topics of interest in science and literature. These, together with the promised contributions of several gentlemen of education and talent, whom we expect to number among our corres-

pondents, will, we hope, render this journal worthy of public support.

THE RACES.

THE Annual Meeting of the Moreton Bay Racing Club, took place at the Race Course, New Farm, on Tuesday and two following days in the past week. The attendance on the course was not only numerous but boasting more than an average of respectability. The sun shone brightly, and, judging from the happy faces of the holiday folks, it was evident that all came there to enjoy themselves, and to take part in the amusements. The greater part of the assembled throng con- sisted of pedestrians, who like ourselves, chose to make use of that far-famed animal known as Shanks’ mare for the occasion. There was a goodly number of the fair sex dressed out in holiday attire, which with the bright costumes of the gentleman-jockeys, gave a most animated appearance to the scene. It only wanted a band of music to add to the harmony of the proceedings, and make the mirth and excitement complete. Some of the booths were gaily decorated with flags; others with drapery; while the less am- bitious were ornamented with the pro- ductions of nature, which gave them a rustic appearance. The spread at the se- veral tables was very substantial, and ample justice was done to the many good things provided for the visitors. Our friend “David” at the Victoria, as usual,

got a large share of patronage. Our limited space will not permit us to enter

more at length into small matters; so we shall proceed to state the results of the different races, premising, however, that we do not constitute ourselves in- fallible judges of the merits of any par-

ticular horse.

The BRISBANE TOWN PLATE, for all horses; weight for age; heats once round and a distance.

Toby . . . . . . . . . . . . (Berkely) 1 0 Splinter . . . . . . . . . . (Bigge) 2 0

The horses were led to the ground in good racing trim, although Splinter was, if anything, rather too finely drawn for carrying heavy weight. At the first burst Splinter took the lead, and succeeded in getting an inside berth; a beautiful race then took place for about half a mile, when Toby headed him. At the distance post, Toby was about a length ahead of his competitor, and maintained his advantage to the end of the race, beating Splinter by about two lengths. A charge of foul riding was brought against the rider of Toby, and the Stewards having heard evidence, pro and con, decided that it had been substantiated. Toby was accordingly adjudged to be distanced, and Mr. Bigge became entitled to the stakes. The time occupied in going over the ground was one minute and thirty-four seconds.

The MAIDEN PLATE, for all horses under five

years that never won public money; weights for age; heats once round.

Princess . . . . . . . . . . . . (Burgoyne) 1 1 Tamerlane . . . . . . . . . . . . (Whitting) 2 2

Princess was brought out in excellent condition, and excited universal admiration. At the start the filly took the lead, followed by Tamerlane, who appeared to be held hard by his rider. Half way round the course, Princess was considerably ahead, and evidently had it all her own way, for she won the first heat easily. In the second heat Princess maintained her maiden reputation, and came in a winner by about two lengths.

The WELTER STAKES, for all horses carrying 12 stone; three times round the course.

Harkaway . . . . . . . . . . (Berkeley) 1 1 Dermott McFig . . . . . . . (Hawkins) 2 2 Job . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . (Burgoyne) 3 3

Harkaway took the lead, followed by Job, with

Dermott close at the heels of the latter. Dermott

then passed Job ; and at the distance post the three were in a line about four lengths from each other, Harkaway still leading. In the second round bets were freely offered in favour of Hark- away, and eventually he came in an easy winner. This race excited a good deal of interest.

The day’s sport closed with a Hack Race, which was won by Dairyman, beating five others.

SECOND DAY.

HURDLE RACK, for all horses; weight for age: twice round, over six leaps, 3 feet 9 inches high.

Dermott McFig . . . . . . . . . . (Bigge) 1 Artful Dodger . . . . . . . . . . .(Furber) 2 Harkaway . . . . . . . . . . . . (Berkely ) 3

Harkaway took the lead, at a rattling pace, but baulked at the first leap, and Artful Dodger, in fol- lowing his example, unseated; Dermott cleared it beautifully. Harkaway having been got over, took the second leap, and made up for lost time. Dermott then cleared the third leap; but Harkaway again refused, and threw his rider with fearful force against the hurdles. This mis- hap placed him hors de combat, and Dermott came in the winner. Some time elapsed before Artful Dodger and Harkaway could be remounted ; and the former came in second, having taken his other leaps without difficulty.

HACK HURDLE RACE, for untrained hacks; catch weights, post entrance, over three leaps 3 feet 3 inches high.

Dairyman . . . . . . . . . . . . (Burgoyne) 1 Cantab . . . . . . . . (Sandy, black boy) 2 Strike-a-light . . . . . . . . . . . . (Furber) 3

Dairyman took all his leaps in his usual gallant style, and came in an easy winner. The rider of Strike-a-light got a fearful spill at the first leap, and Cantab, in baulking at the third leap, turned a complete sommerset over the ropes, fortunately without any serious injury to poor Sandy, who immediately remounted, and cleared it beautifully amidst the plaudits of the company. A subscrip- tion was shortly afterwards entered into by the gentlemen present, and the amount was handed over to him, by way of encouragement, for his spirited conduct.

A most amusing hack hurdle race then took place between Parnassus and Dandy, the former ridden by Mr. Hawkins, and the latter by Mr. Campbell. At the second leap, Dandy refused and threw his rider. Mr. Hawkins on witnessing this untoward event, pulled up his horse, and coolly waited until his friend Colin had picked himself up and remounted. Dandy then took the second leap, followed by Parnassus, to the third fence, when both horses refused. After several attempts Dandy was go over, and Parnassus im- mediately followed, too late, however, to win the race, the persuaders having been applied by Dandy’s rider with admirable effect.

A Hurry Skurry Stakes was then run for, when Peter Jackson was the successful competitor.

THIRD DAY.

The PUBLICANS’ PURSE, for all horses; weights for age; heats twice round. Three horses only were entered for this race, and, with shame be it recorded, only one horse started. It really reflects anything but credit upon our sportsmen to allow

the stake to be won without a contest.

The LADIES’ PURSE, for all horses; weights for age ; heats once round.

Baronet . . . . . . . . . . . .(Furber.) 1 1 Princess . . . . . . . . . (Burgoyne) 2 2 This race excited considerable interest. Baronet

took the lead and won both heats easily. In the first round it soon became evident that Baronet had more speed and stamina than the filly. The Princess was over-weighted for this match, and although the racing was not first rate, the judges prognosticated highly of the future performances of this filly. We may add that the horses were well ridden. The decision as to the right of the stakes has been deferred, as it was alleged that Baronet’s age was not correctly entered.

The TALLY-HO STAKES, for all horses carrying eleven stone ; three times round the course,

Harkaway . . . . . . . . . . .(Berkeley) 1

Splinter . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . (Bigge) 2

This was decidedly the best contested race of the day, and excited great interest among the “turf- ites,” Harkaway reflected much credit on his trainer, and his performances have constituted him a leading favourite—indeed he will give any horse in the two districts “ his work, to do.” Du-

ring the race Splinter disputed every inch of ground with him, but he came in a winner by about two lengths. The first round was per- formed in one minute and forty five seconds.

The BEATEN STAKES, for all horses beaten at the meeting ; weights for age ; once round the

course. Three horses started.

Job . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .(Burgoyne) 1 Artful Dodger . . . . . . . . . . .(Furber) 2 Tamerlane . . . . . . . . . . . . (Whitting) 3

Job took the lead, with Artful Dodger close at his heels. Tamerlane had an indifferent start. The running was between Job and Artful ; it was neck and neck for some time, but on nearing the distance post Job forged ahead, and finally won the race by about a length, to the astonishment of some of the wisest of the knowing ones, who expected Tamerlane would have won.

The HACK STAKES, for untrained hacks ; catch weights ; post entrances. Six horses started.

There was a false start at the commencement of this race, in consequence of some unauthorized officious individual giving the word " off." Three horses that were in advancement round the course their riders probably not being aware of what had occurred ; two of them did not venture to

start again. The stakes were won by Dairyman, ridden by Mr. Burgoyne.

The HURRY SKURRY STAKES were won by Mr. Andrew's chesnut horse, beating five others,

No serious accidents occurred to mar

the pleasures of the sports, and every thing passed off exceedingly well. The Stewards, as well as the Clerk of the

Course, gave general satisfaction. The, Race Dinner took place on the 28th ult., at the Victoria Hotel, and we under- stand the entertainment was first rate-the worthy host and hostess having spared neither expense nor pains in making a display suitable to the festive occasion.

SIR GEORGE GIPPS. " In ruining our constitution,

Sir George has spoilt his own.

Atlas, 6th June.

HIS EXCELLENCY'S illness has assumed an alarm- ing aspect. The less sanguine among the medical fraternity of Sydney pronounce his recovery as more than doubtful ; and all have concurred in advising his immediate departure from the colony. His Excellency, Lady Gipps, and suite, are pro- bably, by this time, on board the good ship Palestine, on their way to England.

With Sir George, in health, the head of the Government, we had, in common with the colo- nists, many quarrels ; for his administration has been marked by many errors, and the effects of his disastrous and blighting policy will be long severely felt not only around us, but throughout the whole colony. The time, however, has ar- rived when declamation should give way to sober, temperate discussion. His government now forms matter of history. Deprecating his measures, we feel pity for the man ; and we cannot but regret that he has wasted his health and energies in vainly combatting a power to which even the most despotic and irresponsible must succumb. Scattered and dispersed, or if concentred, only formed into contending sects and parties, denied all participation in the management of their affairs, as was the case with the colonists on His Excellency's arrival-scarcely even a whisper of disapprobation reaching his ears through the medium of the old nominee Council,, whom he ruled and swayed as he pleased-it is not to be

wondered at that in secret he undervalued the

colony and the colonists. He knew not the might that slumbered within them ; nor did he contem- plate the possibility of rousing them to united, indignant resistance. That there was a limit, however, to their forbearance, which even he could not pass in safety, he has, unfortunately for himself and for the colony, long since dis-

covered.

To the contemplative, the striking change in Sir George's political creed, affords matter for re- flection. He came amongst us, a professed liberal, redolent of all those delightful theories of universal freedom, toleration, and progressive equality, of tener, alas ! found in theory than in practice. A few years of irresponsible authority, exercised over a people apparently incapable of unison, or of estimating the consequences of his acts, ren- dered His Excellency the veriest stickler for pre- rogative. Arbitrary and despotic in his own government, the rights of the Crown usurped the attention which the boasted liberal had before de- clared due to the rights of the people.

His government, however, is at an end. Re- gretting the decay of his health, we rejoice at his departure.

CUSTOMS.

THE Sub-Collector of Customs for this port, W. A, Duncan, Esq., well-known from his long connection with the Sydney press, arrived by the Tamar on Saturday last. A gentleman named Thornton, who has been appointed landing-waiter and tide-surveyor, is expected to arrive by the return trip of the steamer. The department will be completed by the addition of a tide-waiter and coxswain, and a boat's crew of four men.

The establishment of a Customs department at Brisbane will prove highly beneficial to our mer- cantile friends. Moreton Bay is now a port of entry and clearance. Goods for home consump- tion, on which duties are payable, can be brought here in bond and stored in the Queen's-warehouse, for any period not exceeding three months ; after which, if not released, the law directs that they shall be sold at auction, to liquidate the store-rent and duty. It is, however, the wish of the au- thorities to be as lenient as possible in such a case ; the Inspector of Colonial Customs having,

some time since, strongly urged upon the Home Government the necessity of declaring Moreton Bay a FREE WAREHOUSING PORT. This, perhaps our readers are aware, requires the sanction of the Lords of the Treasury, and an order signed by the Queen in Council.

Mr. Duncan has entered upon the duties of his office. The business of the Customs, at present, is transacted at his temporary residence in Queen street, North Brisbane. It will, however, be shortly removed to the building now occupied as the Commissariat store. Owners of boats are re- minded that unless they take the precaution of

registering them on or before the 15th proximo, they will incur the penalty of forfeiture. We be- lieve that all necessary information on the subject can be obtained on application to Mr. Watson, Custom-house agent.

EXPLORATION. Dr. LEICHHARDT has met with a reception from the colonists characteristic of the Anglo-Saxon race—a reception befitting his high merits, and doing honor to their public spirit and liberality. The brave, energetic and simple-minded traveller has become the lion of the day. Public-meetings have been held, congratulations have poured in on all sides and from all classes, his portrait adorns the window of every print shop in the metropolis, and excellent maps of his discoveries, accompanied by his own modest narration of his journeyings and sufferings, are to be bought at every book-stall. As a proper sequence to all these manifestations, subscription lists have been opened throughout the whole colony-from the distant south, to the farthest northern limit to which our enterprising stockholders have yet penetrated. When these are completed, it is sup- posed that the amount of contributions will not fall short of fifteen hundred pounds. In addition to this, Mr. Cowper, the member for Cumberland, was to move in the Legislative Council on the 9th inst., that an address be presented to the Governor stating the Council's high sense of the Doctor's ability, perseverance, and intrepidity, and inti- mating its willingness to vote £1,000 as a reward for the exertions of him and his party in the cause of science, and for the important services rendered by them to the colony. The motion will of course be carried without division. A pe- tition to His Excellency, expressive of the same sentiments, was also in course of signature in Sydney.

The sum which will be thus shortly placed at Leichhardt's disposal is to be appropriated to a purpose truly noble—a purpose worthy of the man whose high courage, elevation of soul, and enthusiasm in the cause of science, led him to undertake a task pronounced to be hopeless by the most sanguine and enterprising among an enterprising people. If this, his recent great achievement, has rendered his heroic daring and high emprise the subject of the utmost wonder and admiration in the minds of us all, ranking him in the first rank of travellers, his name proudly conspicuous amidst the names already inscribed on the deathless roll of fame, what will attend the successful issue of his projected un- dertaking, with which in magnitude of conception and difficulties to be overcome the journey to Port Essington is not to be compared ! His hands, strengthened by the liberality of the colonists, the Doctor purposes to start from Moreton Bay, and proceeding to the northward, trace

the rivers which flow into the Gulf of Car-

pentaria to their sources ; then, taking a north-westerly course, traverse the borders of the terra incognita, supposed by Eyre to be a vast desert, by others an inland sea ; a problem, which, if Sir Thomas Mitchell be un- successful, will remain for him to solve. [The result of Sturt's expedition, the character of the country so far as known, the fact that all portions of South Australia and of New South Wales, unprotected by coast ranges, are subject to pe- riodical hot winds, either from the N. or N. W., without any other assignable cause than currents of air passing over vast tracts of heated country, incline us to the former supposition.] After making the north-west coast, which the Doctor proposes to do, he will take the most practicable direct route to Swan River, his whole course form- ing, as it were, the arc of a circle. His arrival at Brisbane, with a more numerous and better appointed party than his last, prepara- tory to starting, may be expected in about six months hence, or sooner, if possible. Heaven speed and prosper him on his way.

As far as is yet known, the expedition of Sir Thomas Mitchell has not been attended with any results requiring remark. His expedition at the out- set was somewhat retarded by an unexpected want of water in the Bogan, by many of his working bullocks becoming useless, from the effects of bad and scanty feed, and by the consequent necessity of procuring others in their stead. We fear that Sir Thomas and his party will have already suffered much from the recent calamitous drought. Private letters were received from him in Sydney on the 30th ultimo ; they do not contain any news, not even the latitude and longitude of the place where the letters were written. He had re- ceived the despatches forwarded last March, an- nouncing Dr. Leichhardt's return.

We cannot quit the subject of Exploration, without remarking on an unfair attempt by an able Sydney contemporary, to render Leichhardt's distinguished success the basis of sundry dis- paraging allusions to Captain Sturt, the published account of whose expedition must be yet fresh in the minds of our readers. The cases are not parallel. Sturt did all that man could do, under

the circumstances. For several hundred miles

from the farthest point to which he penetrated -- lat. 24° 30', long. 138 °—he passed through a country wearing an unvarying aspect of barren, hopeless, unmitigated sterility-sterility aggra- vated by a lengthened drought-vast sandstone wastes, without grass or water, whose appalling solitudes were unrelieved by either vegetable or animal life. Any man ungifted with Sturt's per- severance, skill, and coinage would have shrunk from the task he took upon himself. In his re- treat from that terrible desert, never before tra- versed by man, he had to journey distances of forty, seventy, and, on one occasion, of one hun- dred and five miles before he could obtain water, and then only on the surface, and in quantities so small, that, in a country of such aridity and high temperature, and consequent rapid evaporation, a few days later would, so far as human know- ledge can foresee, have rendered his retreat im- practicable. Not even the iron hand of sickness subdued his lofty purpose, and high determination.

* The Rev. W. B. Clarke, in a recent commu- nication to the Sydney Herald, expresses his opinion that " Sturt's desert, Leichhardt's expe- rience of little or no rain, even in the tropics, Sir T. L. Mitchell's sufferings from want of water, and the state of the colony generally, prove this to have been a year of drought parallel with the season of 1826-7, and certainly adding another link to the chain of facts for establishing an at- mospheric cycle of nineteen years."

The warm welcome he received upon his return, proves how high the people of South Australia valued his exertions. They, at whose cost the expedition was undertaken, were not dissatisfied ; and the subsequent appointment of the worthy Captain to the office of Registrar-General, was one of the most popular acts, ever performed by

the South Australian Government.

" 'Tis not in mortals to command success,"

but, we hope, when next our contemporary seeks by his able pen to aid exploratory science, he will be candid enough to admit, that Sturt did his

best to deserve it.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, JUNE 20, 1846.

THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1846.

LAND SALE.

ON Wednesday, the sale of town and suburban lots of Government Land took place at the Court House, North Brisbane. There was a numerous attendance, and the following was the result ..

No.

9. Ipswich

10. Ipswich

11. Ipswich

12. Ipswich

4. North Brisbane.

6. South Brisbane .

7. South Brisbane .

8. South Brisbane .

9. South Brisbane.

10. South Brisbane.

11. South Brisbane .

15. South Brisbane .

16. Wooloroo.

TOWN LOTS.

p. Price. Amount.

32..£0 12 0.. £19 4 0.

32.. 0 11 0.. 17 12 0

32.. 0 6 6.. 10 8 0.

32.. 0 12 0.. 19 4 0.

SUBURBAN LOTS.

0.

£273 7 5 Purchasers.

John Kent.

Sarah Connolly.

John Kent.

H. J. E. North.

John Stevens.

William Fitzpatrick.

William Fitzpatrick.

Jn. Slack and P. Jackson.

Thomas Boyland.

In trust for F. A. Lamb.

John Harris.

John Stevens.

There was a good deal of competition for several of the lots, particularly for the Ipswich ones, which fetched high prices. There was no offer for the land in North Brisbane, which is to be attributed to the incorrect and injudicious statement of the Colonial Secretary in the Legislative Council, on the 14th instant, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, to the effect that Brisbane could not long be the commercial town for this district, in con- sequence of the bar which prevented ves- sels of any size coming up the river. The Colonial Secretary also stated that the Police Magistrate was at present en- gaged in fixing the site for the new town, which is not the fact ; and, we believe, no instructions have yet been sent to him for that purpose. We deprecate state- ments of this kind, because they are cal- culated to do a great deal of harm to existing interests ; they are productive of much mischief, and tend more than any- thing else to put a stop to improvements. So strong was the feeling against the Government, that no one attempted to bid for land in North Brisbane, and while such misrepresentations remain unex- plained, we are quite certain that they will not be able to dispose of another acre in the township. We are aware that there are conflicting opinions with respect to Cleveland Point as an eligible site for a town ; and, without expressing our own opinions on the subject, we shall merely state, that several very intelligent and practical men ridicule the idea of making that place the port, on account of the vast outlay required for the erection of a proper jetty for shipping wool and other produce. Cleveland Point may possibly turn out to be a good roadstead, but as it has not been accurately surveyed, we are, at present, entirely in the dark with respect to its capabilities as a secure harbour.

We have more than once seen the mis-

chief, the downright evil growing out of the habit of exaggerating and misrepre- senting in general for the purpose of ad-

vancing, selfish and singular interests, and we set these facts before the Govern- ment, to prevent, if possible, recurrence to a practice the tendency of which is to encourage speculation, and to injure the properties of individuals who have been confiding in, and simple enough to place reliance on, the promises of such a reckless and headstrong Governor as Sir George Gipps. Want of space precludes us from making any further remarks at present.

QUARTER SESSIONS.

WE observe with great satisfaction that in the estimate of the expenses of the establishment for the administration of justice, provision is made for holding Quarter Sessions in this town, and that an allowance of fifty pounds for the Chairman, and thirty pounds for the Clerk of the Peace, has been fixed as the amount of salaries. It is intended to

assign the duty of Chairman to the Po- lice Magistrate, and the Clerk of the Bench, who are already in the receipt of salaries, and thereby saving expense.

The establishment of a Court of Quar- ter Sessions for this district, has long been a desideratum, and the time has at length arrived when it has become abso- lutely necessary for the prompt adminis- tration of justice. Hitherto, owing to the great expense of prosecutions for mi- nor offences, and the disinclination of parties to appear against persons who

have made themselves amenable to the

law, many of the delinquents have been permitted to escape scot-free, again to renew their depredations. It is said that the Court will be open for the trial of offenders about the commencement of the ensuing year.

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1846.

SIR CHARLES FITZROY'S first speech to the Legislative Council has more than satisfied public expectation. It is, to use the language of Mr. Wentworth, " unlike any- thing in the shape of an address from the Governor" heard by the Representatives of the People before. It is, in our humble judgment, exactly what, under all circum-

stances, it should have been. " There is in it," says the Sydney Herald, " so much of the simplicity of truth-so evi-

dent an earnestness to win the confidence

and meet the reasonable expectations of the community-so entire a freedom from all pre-conceived impressions-so prudent a determination to await the teachings of local experience-that, for our own part, we augur from it everything that a mild and equitable Government can contribute

to the public prosperity.'' With this we fully coincide. The occasion which eli- cited it was, too, one of no ordinary diffi- culty ; there were so many grounds of contention, so much of embarrassment, betwixt the Government and the people of

the colony-so much required to be con- ceded, and much it was requisite to main- tain-the affections and confidence of the

colonists, on the one hand, to be regained, and; on the other, the true dignity of the

Government to be conserved-that to de-

vise a course which would remove all op- posing difficulties was a task of no or- dinary magnitude, and its successful ful- filment by Sir Charles abundantly proves

his capability of performing the duties appertaining to the high office which he

holds.

The Land question-the great source of our wealth and our misfortunes, our perplexities and our prosperity-has judi- ciously been passed over by his Excellency. He has resolved to see and judge for him- self, and to obtain his knowledge at first hand; By acting up to this resolution, Sir Charles will, we venture to assert, gain far more sound, valuable experience in one brief twelvemonth than did Sir George Gipps during the whole of the eight years in which he held sway over the colony. One

of the worst foibles, indeed, of the latter, was to view his first impressions, often hastily conceived without sufficient data, as axiomatic, and as infallible guides to proper policy-when, in truth, they were but Wills o'the Wisp ensnaring him at every step into some unlucky, and for us,

unfortunate blunder. He who teaches should first be taught-he who governs should first know the people for whom he would legislate ; and if Sir Charles Fitz- roy has not, as the Maitland Mercury asserts, the talents of his predecessor, neither is he, to all appearance, so prone to dogmatize or to assume from impulse.

His first acts are full of promise. His restoration of tolls, Courts of Request and

Insolvent Court fees to the revenue, from which they were abstracted by Sir George ; his reply to the Council's address respecting the absurd Tariff Bill that has recently -passed the Legislature of Van Diemen's Land; his anxiety to co-operate with the Council in obtaining communi- cation by steam between England and the colony ; the proposed abolition of wharf- age rates, and the better regulation of the coasting trade, which are among the first measures of his government ; together with his easiness of access, and his de- declared intention to inform himself of the

state of the colony by actual inspection, must be highly gratifying to every well wisher of his adopted country.

Chosen by a Ministry whose enlightened policy has earned for them the admiration of the world-adhering to the same system of political science - capable, as Sir Charles appears to be, of ascending above the petty routine of official business, and taking those comprehensive views without which no man can ever hope to govern this colony successfully, and want- ing which, Sir George Gipps, in the words of a contemporary, " acted rather as the head clerk of the colony, than as the pre- siding director of its important affairs," we see every reason to augur well of his Excellency's administration.

CONVEYANCE OF MAILS.

AMONGST those acts, rich in, promise and in performance, which already distinguish the new from the old vice-regal dynasty, is the proposed extension of the govern- ment postal communication to several of the squatting districts-against which, it is well known, Sir George Gipps set his face. With few exceptions, applications from districts " beyond the boundaries," for the establishment of posts, were met with decided refusals ; and, pursuing his characteristic policy, one refusal formed the ground for others. Taxed-over- taxed though they were-the squatters were, in many instances, compelled to incur the additional expense of running private mails, or else submit to great inconvenience-the revenue losing, of course, much more than would have sufficed to pay for the extension of mail conveyance, wherever it was required, throughout the colony. This penny-wise, pound-foolish system is, however, we are glad to find, not recognised by Sir Charles Fitzroy.

We observe, in the advertisement for tenders, just issued, for the conveyance mails for the year commencing on the 1st January next, that, besides other branch mails proposed to be established in va- rious parts of the colony, there is a mail from Armidale, New England, to Alford's Inn, Darling Downs, once-a-fortnight ; by which, the interval in the overland line of postal communication between Maitland and Brisbane, as well as between Port Macquarie and Brisbane, will be filled up. This is as it should be, and we do not doubt that in a very short time the branch will more than repay itself.,

No alteration, apparently, is intended to be made in the mail now running from Brisbane, via Ipswich, to the Downs Inn the advertisement the present time " once- a-fortnight" is adhered to; Means of communication so protracted, between places only eighty miles apart, compel many persons to forward letters requiring despatch by private hand. We should,

therefore, be glad to see the time altered

to " once-a-week."

En passant, it is generally believed that the Post-office Commissioners, ap- pointed by the British Government, and who visited the colony last year, have

resolved to recommend the establishment

of a uniform rate of postage throughout

the colony. Bearing in mind the fact that the Post-office revenue of Great Britain, for 1845, was four-fifths of that obtained previous to the abolition of the former system and the adoption of Mr. Hill's, we feel sanguine that any such recommendation will be favourably lis- tened to both by the Home, and the local

Government.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1846.

articleText:
THE

MORETON BAY COURIER.

SATURDAY, JULY 4, 1846.

LABOUR.

IT is of the very last importance that we should have an adequate supply of labour. Settlers, with their flocks and herds, have rapidly increased, and this district, which so very recently echoed only to the soli- tary foot-fall of the wandering savage, now exhibits all the signs of civilization : two towns, and villages in course of for- mation ; a steamer plying on the river ; Custom-house, and all other et ceteras, indicate its future prosperity and progress. With all these advantages, however, we shall never be able to develope the bound- less resources of this fine country, unless we have a more copious supply of emigrants than private individuals can furnish. An effort must be made to pro- cure labour, and that without delay.

There are two reservoirs from which a supply of labour might be obtained—New Zealand and Van Diemen's Land. We are informed, on the best authority, that owing to the disturbed state of the former, and the consequent insecurity of property,

a considerable number of useful labourers might to be induced to emigrate to this place, where a happy revolution would be effected in their condition, and where they would be well remunerated for their ser- vices. The cost of passage would be about four pounds per head. From the latter place—a less pure source—labourers can also be procured, at an expense of two pounds per head. The season for lambing is fast approaching, and it is estimated that upwards of four hundred extra hands will be required for the different stations. We believe that the sum of two hundred pounds has been subscribed for the pur- pose of importing labourers, but it is quite certain that unless a larger amount be raised shortly for the same object, there will be a fearful increase of wages throughout the two districts.

Our limited space does not permit us to dwell on the want of energy displayed by some of the Squatters—the lukewarmness on this vitally important subject that pre- vails among others—and the apathy of many respecting their true interests : they must, however, exert themselves to procure men, for it is idle to expect, while the labouring population is fully employed on the railways, that emigration from England, on a sufficiently extensive scale, will be resumed for the next two years.

Not only do we affirm that emigration from the places we have pointed out pre- sents to us our only resource, but that all must immediately combine, and that effectually, to obtain the necessary sup- ply of labour, or our position must gradu- ally and portentously deteriorate.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, JULY 4, 1846. LABOUR.

articleText:
To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,-I beg to draw your attention to the 62nd clause of the English Act for the amendment of the Poor Laws, which enacts- "That it shall and may be lawful for the rate-payers in any parish, and such of the owners of property therein as

l O iii '. di *' ii

L

'shall, in manner hcreinbéforc,mcntioncd (45), have required their names to bettered in the rate books of such parishes respectively as entitled to vote as owners, assembled at a meeting to be duly' convened and held for the purpose, after puhlic

notice of the time and place of holding such^ meeting,,and the purpose for which the same'Ms' intended/to'be held, shill have been giveniinWke ,iianner4as notices of véstry meetings are'publfshed and given, to direct*:-that such'Sumtor sums of money, not exceeding half the average yearly rate for the. three preceding years, as the said owjners and rate-payers so assembled at such meeting may think proper, shall be raised or borrowed as a fund, or in aid of any fund or con- tribution for defraying the expenses of the emi- gration of poo "persons having settlements in such parish, and" willing to emigrate, to'be paid out of, or charged upon, the rates raised or to be raised for the relief of the poor in such parish, and to be applied^ under and according to sucli rules, otders, and regulations as the said commis- sioners shall in that behalf direct : provided always, that no such direction for raising money for such purpose as aforesaid shall have any force or effect, unless and until confirmed by the said commissioners, and that the time to be limited for the repayment of any sum so charged on such rates as aforesaid shall in no case exceed the period of five years from the time of borrowing the same : provided also, that all sums of money so raised as last hereinbefore mentioned, and advanced by way .of loan, for the purposes of emigration, or such proportion thereof as the said commissioners shall by any rule, or regulation from time to time direct, shall be recoverable against any such per- son, beingabove the age of twenty-one years^who or whose family, or any part thereof, having con- sented to emigrate, shall refuse to emigrate, after such expenses shall have been so incurred, or having emigrated shall return, in such and the like manner as is hereinbefore (46) provided with respect to relief, or the cost price of relief, given or considered to be given by way of loan to any person, his wife or family."

I consider that the foregoing is well worthy of promulgation through the medium of the Press ; and it is more than probable that many of the Poor Law Guardians are ignorant of the powers given 'to thenVof relieving the poor, and the parishes to which they are a burden, by this clause. The poor are unquestionably ignorant of the great de ,mand for theid.1bourini.he30 colonies, and'Icon .ccive that it is the bounden duty of tile Guardians to make it known to them, and should they be willing, to forward them to a country where their

labour would be available.

Could you not draw the attention of the Squat- ters to this matter,or rather the District Associa- tion. Let the latter body draw out a statement of the want of labour here, and the remuneration given to labourers of all classes, and publish the same by way of advertisement-drawing the attention of the Boards of Guardians in England thereunto, and to the clause 62. At the same time let them forward a copy of your invaluable paper to the Editors of the leading metropolitan and provincial journals, calling on them to do their duty to their starving countrymen, by making known the high rate of wages to be had in this colon /, and the means by which they can be for-

warded luther. - - -,, , "

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

C. W. P.

[Our esteemed correspondent will observe by an article which appears in another part of this journal, that the Government are now in treaty with the several Boards of Guardians to effect the object alluded to. It is very probable that many of the Boards will avail themselves of the offers of Government, and defray the expenses of passage of poor persons to this colony.-ED. JW. B. ft]

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1846.

The Cornubia steamer arrived at the mouth of the river on Wednesday, having on board his Honor Lieutenant-Colonel

Barney, (late R.E.), Lieutenant-Governor and Superintendent of North Australia, A. C. G. Darling, Captain Perry, the Deputy Surveyor-General, Dr. Silver, A. C. Surgeon, forming the Surveying Staff, en route to the new colony. Capt. H. H. Brown also accompanies the expe- dition. The party visited Brisbane on the following morning, and returned the same day, with the exception of Captain Perry, who proceeds overland with Mr. Burnett, A. S., with the intention of tracing the Boyne from its source to its embouchere, which is supposed to be either in Bustard Bay, or Rodd's Bay, at Fort Curtis.

The steamer will proceed to the north- ward with Colonel Barney, who intends, in the first instance, to examine the above mentioned harbours, and should either be found eligible as the site of the capital of

the new province, that locality will be chosen in preference to any other. King, the Deputy Pilot, who went to Bustard Bay (Port Wilmot) with Mr. Oxley, in the year 1825, before Moreton Bay was

was ascertained by Mr. Oxley that there

is anchorage in Bustard Bay for fifty ves- sels, with seven fathom water at the

entrance. He went up a large river for five or six miles, apparently navigable, and which in all probability is the Boyne. Near, the beach, a large fresh water lagoon was found. It is well known that Port Curtis is a good harbour, safe, and acces- sible at all seasons of the year. There is little doubt, therefore, should the land in the neighbourhood of these places be suitable for cultivation, one or the other will be selected as the site of the proposed settlement. One thing is certain—the capital will not be at Wide Bay.

We understand that upwards of three thousand prisoners will be sent to the new colony immediately after the site has been determined on. They will be under a probationary term of twelve months, dur- ing which period they will be employed in building stores, wharves, hospital, &c. Each vessel will bring out a supply of

stores for twelve months for the number of souls on board ; and all the provisions and implements of husbandry will be placed in charge of D. A. C. G. Connel, assisted by a storekeeper, issuers, clerks, &c. At the expiration of their period of probation, the prisoners will be at liberty to proceed to any of the Australian colo- nies, and enter into engagements. Should they choose to remain, they will be en- titled, according to the proposed regula- tions, to as much land as they can culti- vate, for the term of three years, rent free ; and if, at the end of that time, the occu- piers of such lands be desirous to purchase, they will be permitted to do so by pre- emption of sale, at £1 per acre, payable in ten equal annual instalments. Settlers wishing to emigrate, may purchase lands in the new colony, at auction, at the minimum upset price of £1 per acre;

we are not informed whether the same

indulgence with respect to payment will be granted to them.

The prisoners are, moreover, to be fur- nished with cattle, sheep, and implements; and with this view the Government herds and flocks now at Moreton Bay will be

sent overland as soon as the site of the

colony is fixed.

Such being the conditions and regula- tions under which the new colony is about to be established, it is of the utmost im- portance that not only a good situation, but the best situation, should be selected —the one combining the greatest number of advantages with respect to security, soil, supply of water, and facilities for

external and interior communication. An

injudicious selection will retard the pros- perity of the colony for years. The most important features in the proposed regu- lations are the assignment of land to the prisoners, and the liberal terms on which it may be purchased by them. Such policy will be highly conducive to the success, and rapid developement of the resources, of the province. Should the views as promulgated by the Government be carried out in respect of the disposal of land to the probationers, they will be productive of the most important conse- quences to this colony ; and we venture to predict that the absurd and infamous £1 per acre Waste Land Act will not survive the next session of the Imperial Legislature. "Coming events cast their shadows before," and we venture to assert that its doom is already sealed ; and that

it will be blotted from the statute book

ere another year shall have elapsed".
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1846.
snippet: THE Cornubia steamer arrived at the mouth of the river on Wednesday, having on board his Honor Lieutenant-Colonel Barney, (late R.E.), Lieutenant-Governor
