articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1846.

In our last number we expressed our opinion that the Government, by exact- ing a higher price for land in this colony than better land is fetching in other places nearer to the great European markets, had rendered waste lands for agricultural pur- poses unsaleable, and that the whole sys- tem of -Sir George Gipps -was an error in political economy, and that his regulations have been productive of the most baneful effects to this district in particular.

When we reflect upon the number of persons who annually emigrate to these colonies without any definite views as to their ultimate proceedings, and also find that the greater portion of those who em- bark in agricultural and pastoral pursuits scarcely know a ploughshare from a hay- fork, much less a Leicester or Southdown sheep from a Merino, it is more surprising to find so many become extensive and successful flockmasters, than to hear oc- casionally of persons who are said to be disappointed in their expectations respect- ing the country of their adoption. Now

as the settler must look for his income

from the profits of his capital, he will naturally invest his money in the most lucrative business. He will, of course, if he lays it out in agricultural or pastoral pursuits, ascertain what the return of profit is likely to be. Should his taste lead him to attempt the cultivation of land, he will find that the impediments which now discredit our local adminis rat.on are insurmountable ; that the high price of land in the neighbourhood of the townships, is an obstacle not to be over- come by the most enterprising. Whereas if the Government would adopt a different system-if they would even put up the suburban and country lots at one pound per acre (their utmost value), hundreds of acres would find purchasers, and the nucleus of an agricultural population would be formed-persons who would convert the wilds into animated scenes ; for with good land at a moderate price,

there can be no doubt there is still an

ample field for the profitable employment of capital ; that small farmers with mo- derate means, combined with industry and perseverance, as well as those whose only capital is honesty, sobriety, and in- dustry, may find a realization of those hopes which cheered them on leaving their native land, and who will, with proper management, meet with that suc- cess which the soil and climate of this part of the colony ensure them.

Almost all our reflections on statistics, the geography of the world, the growth and decline of different states, and the condition of mankind in general, lead us to acknowledge the necessity, and hence the wisdom of God, that the whole earth should be replenished, and that population should spread over the entire surface of the earth. This is now being accom- plished, and when we consider these things, it appears to us of less consequence as to the part of the globe on which we are to finish our days, so as that we do not consider ourselves out of the presence of Him who fills the universe, and who is always to be found the best friend, into whatever part a man may be exiled. If we could sincerely realize the conviction, we should little regret the loss of country, convinced that at these antipodes we shall, as it regards our final destination, be no more strangers on earth, than at the place

of our birth.

Considerations of these higher impor- tant things than worldly affairs, may re- concile (as they ought to do) many persons who, from necessity, are obliged to leave their native shores ; and were it not for

this exigency, great part of the world, might remain a desert, as undoubtedly, our country would be at this day, had not its present inhabitants been originally exiled or driven from the mother country, or tempted by the aspect of this, to seek a refuge and a home in its uncultivated forests. The colonists are continually opening out new prospects of adventure, and are forming fresh sources of trade and traffic, while they tend to spread civiliza- tion and social virtue, as well as endeavour to impart knowledge to the rude and un- lettered denizens of the Australian wilds. They who have the spirit to encounter emigration, will often render benefits to their descendants, which the utmost exer- tions, pains, and privations could not have accomplished in their native country.

Experience teaches us that population more than keeps pace with the improve- ments in land ; and years frequently elapse before waste grounds can be brought into a productive condition. The only way to promote extensive agriculture is to hold out strong inducements to persons with small capital to settle in those districts where agriculturists are most required. Let them select from fifty to one hundred acres each, as may be suitable to their means, and let it be leased to them for seven years, when the farms could be sold at the market price-that is for what they would fetch

-and allow the tenant a sum out of the

purchase money for his improvements, in the event of his not being able to buy the land himself. A plan like this, if pro- perly carried out, would produce a great change - its advantages to this district .would soon be made apparent. In the course of a few years, we should be ena- bled to grow sufficient corn for our own support. The money which now is sent out of this district, annually, and which

at the lowest calculation amounts to

£10,000, would be spent here-would cir- culate amongst us for our mutual benefit, and give stability to commercial operations.

During the discussion of this question in the Legislative Council, Mr. Robinson brought under the notice of the House certain propositions which had been pub- lished in 1844 by Mr. Lowe, under the title of " Rent better Sale," which he said were strangely contrasted with the opinions expressed by Mr. Lowe in 1846. In sup- port of the position, the honorable member

for Auckland then said

Because in every new country profits are high, and capital scarce ; in such a country, therefore, it is especially necessary to tax profits rather than capital.

Because the principle of buying lands, not for the sake of what they contain, but of the Govern- ment run they command, gives an unjust mono- poly to the purchaser, and an undue influence to the Government ; and yet no one has ever thought of buying lands in New South Wales on any other principle.

Because it is a sound maxim in finance, never to raise money till you want it ; capital increases fast in the hands of an industrious people; but slowly, or not at all, in those of a Government.

Because a steady income is far more valuable to a state than a large sum of ready money, the effects of an imprudent outlay of the one being much less pernicious than of the other.

Because, if the State be anxious to raise a sum of ready money, this can always be effected by allowing the grantees to redeem their rents at a reasonable number of years' purchase.

Because there is no necessary connexion between emigration and the sale or letting of land ; but there is a necessary connexion between emigration and the general welfare of the colony ; the expense of emigration, therefore, ought not to be defrayed out of the revenue arising from lands, which may be greater or less than the sum required, but out of the general revenue of the colony of which that land revenue should form a part.

Because a revenue arising from rent offers much better security for the loan proposed to be effected for the purposes of systematic colonization than one arising from the sale of land, since the one is paid out of interest and the other out of principal.

Because people will much more readily buy up land on speculation, than pay a yearly rent for it.

Because the recent instances of Canada, and of the Church and School Lands in this colony show, that small capitalists prefer renting to buying.

Because the whole capital of each settler would thus be left at his disposal, and permanent im- provements be proportionably rapid.

And again, with regard to the matter of the political effect of such a system on a

nation :

Because it is not true that whatever the colonist gains in the bargain, the Government (that is the colony) loses. It is the interest of the colony to dispose of its waste lands on the easiest terms consistent with the requisite adjustment of labour nd capital, If the money be left in the colonist' pocket it can always be extracted by taxation ; if once raised and recklessly spent, who can re-

call it ?

Because it is of no importance to the community whether these lands are in many or few hands ; but it is of importance to the community to retain its capital, to lighten its taxation, and to make the wilderness useful to the support of man.

Because that Mill, in his first volume of his History of India, and in his Political Economy, and also Mr. Ricardo, and Adam Smith, are

favourable to this plan of raising a revenue ; and because it is believed that there is no authority against it.

Because the Ryotwar system of India, the Land tax of England, and the agrarian laws of Rome, show that this system readily coalesces with every form of Government, and therefore that no political change need be feared from it.

After reading the foregoing proposi- tions, will it be believed that the same man who wrote them now repudiates all

occupation of waste lands except by pur- chase. Every man is certainly entitled to change his opinions-to modify them at any time he may think proper ; but there is a limit to which every one should be confined, and more particularly that man whose abilities necessarily give him much influence in political affairs. When we see the honourable member for Auckland rush from one extreme opinion to another, without giving any satisfactory explanation, we can only at- tribute the change to an aberration of mind-an eccentricity of intellect which is no excuse for that to which he pleaded guilty-his former inexperience in poli- tics. Mr. Lowe is not a safe guide, and as he has changed his opinions once on this question, it is more than probable he will do so again. We shall be proud to record them, should our sur-

mises turn out to be well founded.

We are ever ready to encounter all fair and reasonable hazards in giving publicity to wrongs suffered by persons in the two districts ; but, at the same time, it must be acknowledged that we have arrived to that state of things wherein truth should display an unshrinking courage, and, in announcing facts, or denouncing acts of injustice, no one should invest himself with the panoply of concealment. We, therefore, wish our correspondents would subscribe their real signatures, and we shall expect in future that those who would have us, as public journalists, fight their battles, will share in the responsi- bilities which may attach to their com-

munications.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1846.
snippet: IN our last number we expressed our opinion that the Government, by exacting a higher price for land in this colony than better land is fetching in other places

articleText:
THE

MORETON BAY

COURIER

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1846

OUR humane Government recently for- warded to this district at the public ex- pense, an aboriginal black who had un- dergone a term of incarceration of three years on Cockatoo Island. With a mul- titude of European vices grafted on his native ferocity, his presence in this dis- trict is already disastrously felt. Led on by him, the Brisbane and Pine River tribes, have become so daring in their depredations, that no person now ventures to trust himself unarmed beyond the pre- cincts of the town. The late frightful tragedy, with its somewhat farcical ending,

is scarcely over ; yet our local columns of to-day record another revolting outrage. And this with scarcely an effort being made to inflict such punishment as might serve effectually to prevent the commission

of similar atrocities.

Are there no means of checking so

fearful a waste of human life ? Shall a

handful of miserable savages, secure in the supinity of our rulers, go on adding victim to victim, robbery to robbery, until their thrist for blood and plunder, growing by

what it feeds on, becomes so enormous that we must either flee like cowards from

the land, or sweep them from existence. It is useless-worse than useless-to bring

the cumbrous panoply of constitutional law to defend us from the aggressions of those who know not, and cannot be made to comprehend the civil defences with which we have hemmed in our lives and

properties. To do so, is to bring one of our most sacred ordinances into contempt -to perpetrate a solemn mockery, and giv- ing the blacks confidence in our apparent weakness, peril the lives of our distant and isolated friends in the interior.

We know enough of the aborigines to

be aware that, as is customary amongst

almost all savages, all projects of love or war, all expeditions of an unusual nature, are first debated by the whole adult males of a tribe. Consequently, according to our law, to every outrage committed upon the whites they are all accessaries-a class

of criminals whose punishment is often well nigh equal to that of their principals

in crime. But in our Courts of Justice

the evidence of a black is barely admissi- ble, and where all are participators, and unlikely to betray each other, we have nothing but moral conviction to guide us in ascertaining the degree of guiltiness of a whole tribe. And even could this be

legally ascertained, on undeniable proof, what would be our remedy ? It is a glorious privilege of every British subject that, before he can be tried, he must be capable of understanding the objects and process of legal investigation, and the nature of Trial by Jury ; and unless he is capable of comprehending these he is

treated as an idiot-as an infant, rather to be protected by the law than visited with its terrors. In such a position stand the blacks-their perceptions limited by their senses, incapable of forming aught like an abstract idea, but few amongst them approach that degree of knowledge and intelligence without which guilt, in the eye of the law, cannot exist !

And this is British Justice ! Justice to the hardy sons of Britain who are en- gaged in transforming a territory, before waste and unprofitable, into one of her most flourishing and important dependen- cies. This is national consistency ! A jealous sense of honour is incessantly leading our statesmen to regard the acts of individuals as the acts of the nations to which they belong, thereby endanger- ing the welfare and happiness of civilized

millions. But the crimes of a tribe of sa-

vages, whom no kindness can conciliate, are treated as the crimes of a single indivi- dual, and his equally guilty compeers are suffered to escape ! To use an expression of a celebrated Frenchwoman (addressed to a statue of Liberty) with a change of phrase, " Oh, Justice, Justice, what ab- surdities are perpetrated in thy name !"

Seriously, solemnly do we ask, what is to be done ? Because the question is surrounded with difficulty, are we to re- main without protection, waiting to be cut down like ears before the sickle-

bound hand and foot by the terrors of a one-sided law, which in our relations to the blacks, threatens instead of protecting

us ? Either the authorities will have to

shut their eyes while we take the law into our own hands, or they must afford us that protection which was erewhile the

glory and safeguard of every Englishman throughout the world.

DR. LEICHHARDT and his party, that " band of brothers," as they have been happily termed, intend starting from Jimba, Darling Downs on the 1st proxi- mo. The Doctor, we are sorry to learn, is unable to visit Brisbane ; his anxiety to reach Peak Range before the summer rains set in, leading him to use every possible personal exertion to expedite his departure. He is said to be in high spirits, and well satisfied with the de- meanour and fitness of those who are about to accompany him.

Leichhardt's inabiliiy to come amongst us, will form matter of general regret.

The number in Brisbane is small indeed

who are unprepared to do honour to his worth and high-mindedness. Gladly would we have seen him face to face, have again heard the tones of his voice, ere he engaged in a task, the fulfilment of which, attended with no ordinary dangers, demands the highest exertion of mind and body. Visit Brisbane or not, however, we are sure that our readers will not the less regard the man who has al- ready done so much-and will, we hope, do more-to add to our knowledge of the resources of Australia.

As an explorer, Leichhardt already stands in the first rank. He has proved himself to be possessed of that attribute without which no traveller can ever hope for fame or success-great moral courage -courage of the highest order, that enabled him, during his late expedition, to make light of dangers, hardships and privations, before which the mere physi- cally endowed, however brave, would have succumbed-courage akin to that lofty spirit which animated Park, Led- yard, and other " heroes of undying name ;" which led the first to venture amidst savage hordes, through lands over which Rapine and Pestilence struggled for dominion, to become fa- miliar with every kind and degree of re- pulsive wretchedness, in order that he

might follow the course of that mighty stream whose gloomy banks at last re- ceived his bones, his grave unhonoured, but his memory embalmed in a nation's gratitude. May the fame, but not the fate of Park, be Leichhardt's. " God prosper him" is the prayer of the whole colony-from east to west, from north to south ; for wherever there are kindled minds, wherever hearts beat high at the sound of generous and gallant deeds, wherever homage is rendered to genius and courage, there must the name of Leichhardt be loved and honoured.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1846.
snippet: OUR humane Government recently forwarded to this district at the public expense, an aboriginal black who had undergone a term of incarceration of three

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1846.

THE Renewal of Transportation-the in- troduction of an abundant supply of cheap labour-are essentially necessary to the future rapid prosperity of this colony, for whoever attentively considers the social State in this country and the present con- dition of the employers and the employed,

will find that owing to the great scarcity of labourers, wages have risen to such a height that stock-keeping, except in peculiarly favoured localities has well nigh ceased to be profitable : that while the employer is put to his wit's end to pay his shepherds, the latter are daily increas-

ing their demands upon his pocket ; and instead of performing their duties better, as they ought to do when they are highly remunerated, we find them careless and insolent-idle and knavish-bolting from the stations in every direction-knowing well, as they do, that hitherto there has been but little chance of competition in the labour market. We hail, therefore, with satisfaction the proposal of the Se- cretary of State, as announced in the des- patch, which we published in our last number, to renew transportation to these

colonies. It will be seen by that docu- ment that he brings forward the question in a manly and straightforward manner, leaving it to the colonists to decide whether it be desirable or not at the present junc- ture. Under these circumstances, we take advantage of the opportunity now afforded us to express our views and opinions on the subject.

We believe that nearly all the squatters, and a majority of the merchants and traders in the two districts, coincide with us in opinion that the introduction of convict-labour, under certain conditions, is highly desirable. In discussing this question, it should be borne in mind, that Government has permitted the colonists to take advantage of the probation system in Van Diemen's Land, and that for the last sixteen months, the most objectionable characters have found their way from that place to this colony. In point of fact, -we now have transportation in its worst shape, without any of the benefits deriva ble from it. Would it not, therefore, be better to take the labour offered to us

direct from England? Undoubtedly it would ; and the time chosen to effect this vast revolution in our labour system is opportune-it is one of prosperity, when employment is abundant and remuneration good. There are abundance of provisions, and ample means to pay the labourers when they arrive. And to crown all, the skill and capital of our spirited stock- holders and merchants are both employed in extending the field of home produce, and in rendering what is already in oc- cupation, or under tillage, more produc- tive. Let us learn experience from the past. The discontinuance of the trans- portation system with forced labour, a few years back, helped to introduce the wedge which split asunder the tree of colonial wealth. Revive that system,-let us have cheap labour, and prosperity, un exampled in the previous history of this

colony, will most assuredly follow.

We are not of those who would wish to see transportation renewed, if it were practicable to get free labour, and plenty

of it. Such, however, is not the case ; there is no chance of emigration to this

colony taking place ; nor is there any probability of our obtaining an adequate supply of labourers from any other source than that evidently determined upon by the Home Government. Our wants are immediate, and the difficulty of satisfying them is increasing every day. We believe that the evils of the forced labour system, have been greatly exaggerated, and that the moral pollution, so much talked about as being apparent in every community where convicts are placed, is more ima- ginai y than real ; for it is quite certain, and daily experience proves the truth of our assertion, that the standard of morality is the same now as when the transporta- tion system was in its zenith. Employers

know well that ticket-of-leave men make the best servants. It is another well-known

fact, that the higher the wages, the more troublesome the men become, and the less regard they have for character. It is quite a mistake for mechanics to suppose that the introduction of convict-labourers

will injure them. There is very little doubt that the convicts, when they arrive, will be widely and remotely dispersed, and be sent away into the interior, where the contaminating influence of idlers in the towns will not reach them. In order to work out any reformatory scheme, it is absolutely necessary that the scheme and the bond should be amalgamated as much as possible, to prevent that aggregation of vicious persons which has hitherto been found so prejudicial to the probationers and other classes of prisoners in Van Diemen's Land. Beyond the boundaries of location, there will be but little in- ducement for these men to be dishonest. It is there they will have an opportunity of throwing off old habits, and acquiring new ones Habits of reflection will be superinduced which, if they are not thoroughly depraved, must lead to amend- ment of life, and allure them insensibly to become useful members of society.

Another important point should not be lost sight of, and that is the equalization of the sexes. It is not necessary to enter at length into the reasons why such should be the case ; they must be obvious to every well regulated, and reflecting mind. The free and freed adult males are already in excess in the colony, and unless females are introduced contemporaneously with males, no system for their reformation can be ultimately successful. If a due proportion of free women, of good cha- racter, could be sent out, so much the better, as their humanizing influence would be of the greatest benefit in re- straining such of the convicts, as became entitled to marry, from recurring to vicious

courses.

If the Government will consent to bear

their fair proportion of the expenses at- tendant upon the renewal of transportation to these colonies, under the conditions above mentioned, we must say that few questions have throughout appeared to us more free from difficulty and perplexity. Should any of the convicts be employed on the roads, Mr. Gladstone says, that "'opportunity will be given for the closest inspection, for subjecting the whole dis-

tribution of the time of the men, and all their habits to a rigid discipline, and for applying to them the agency of systematic and effective religious instruction." With these assurances, we think the colonists ought to be satisfied. The Home Go- vernment have already made proposals to the Poor-law Guardians, with the view of ascertaining how far they would be dis- posed to mortgage their poor-rates, that the parish unions might be released of their paupers ; and if some arrangement could be effected so as to provide an in- termixture of free and prison population for this colony, as well as the new colony to the northward, a grand step will have been made in systematic colonization equally beneficial to both countries. Here we have a wide extent of territory prepared for all the purposes of civilized life-well adapted either for agricultural or pastoral pursuits. Our great want is a labouring population. Let then the starving inmates of the workhouses, and the abandoned profligate of the peniten- tiaries, wend their way hither, and they will soon be converted into industrious and substantial yeomen.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1846.
snippet: THE Renewal of Transportation—the introduction of an abundant supply of cheap labour—are essentially necessary to the future rapid prosperity of this colony, for

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1846.

Come, bright Improvement ! on the car of Time, And rule the spacious world from clime to clime.

" STEAM COMMUNICATION" has already be

nefited Australia to an extent that can

scarcely be over-estimated. It has brought together interests before isolated-facili- tated intercourse-economised labour

given assurance of certainty to the trader, and a sense of security to the common-

weal - and, it may be added without fiction or extravagance, annihilated space and achieved a noble victory over Time. But, great and important as are these re- sulting advantages, they are but light in

the balance when weighed with those, which the application of steam to our in tercourse with England will produce.

The enterprise, enthusiasm, energy, and perseverance of one man have rendered steam communication from England to Australia something more than a pet theory of visionaries, impracticable of

realization. His exertions to effect an overland route to India, are even now re- cognised, and their effects gratefully ac- knowledged by the people of the colony. An officer in the East India Company's

service, at a former period of his eventful life, and often proceeding from India to England, Lieut. Waghorn, the individual to whom we allude, felt the irksomeness as well as the cost and danger of a voyage round the African coast ; and his active

mind soon began to dwell on the possi- bility of performing the trip with greater expedition. Perceiving the advantages

that would result from an overland route - -a route that would more than realise

the ambitious conceptions of the ancient Pharaohs-for many years he laboured to

establish it ; and at length, alone and un- aided, in the face of difficulties from which almost any other man would have shrunk, having secured the confidence of the

Egyptian Pasha, Mehemet Ali, and formed houses of agency at Suez, Cairo, and Alexandria, and caravanseras in the de- sert, having effected commercial relations with the Arabs, " the freebooters of the wilderness, the descendants of Ishmael," having expended a large fortune and se- riously injured his constitution, the gal-

lant officer was successful.

The overland route to India, as then established, was travelled in thirty-four days, passing from Bombay to Aden, from Aden to Suez, from Suez, across the desert,

to Cairo ; thence to Alexandria, and, across the Mediterranean, to Marseilles, through France to Boulogne, and on to London.

Charged from time to time with des- patches, Lieut. Waghorn long maintained the character of the first Courier in the World. But great as were the advantages

produced by his exertions, he was far from satisfied. " Rather suffered than allowed,"

says a late English writer, " to go through the French territory, impeded at best in- stead of being aided, and looked upon with suspicion rather than admiration, he has felt, while he has borne the intelli- gence of England's victories in the East, and especially of the subjugation and ransoms of China, that he was a messen- ger of a power which, whatever the jea- lousy and malignity with which it is viewed, and however they were increased by its recent triumphs, ought no longer to be under the humiliating obligations to winch it has been subjected in the progress of its despatches from its eastern empire."

The expression " humiliating obliga- tions" is advised. Arrived at Marseilles, the narrow-minded jealousy and meddle- some inquisitiveness of the French Go-

vernment had rendered it an essential condition of the mail's transit, that papers containing the gist of the Indian news should be delivered up ; and of these an abstract was made, and forthwith des- patched by express to Paris. Alive to the effects that might, in an emergency, arise from this prior possession of the Indian intelligence, whatever its character and im- portance, and indignant at the obstructions to his progress, arising from the annoying

series of official forms to which he was

subjected, Lieut. Waghorn resolved, if possible, to get rid of a system so tho- roughly un-English by treading out ano- ther path from the Mediterranean to his own land. To his eagle eye it soon be- came apparent that by landing at Trieste, in the Austrian territories, and travelling direct to Ostend, this might be found, and a saving of two hundred and fifty miles might be effected, with- out even touching on the possessions of France. Receiving no encouragement from his own government, and having to allay the prejudices and to excite hopes of great ultimate advantage in the minds of the governments of other countries, he spent two years in making the necessary arrangements. His experimental trip, by the new line of route, in spite of many unlooked-for obstacles, was completely successful. Landing at Dwina, at a short distance from Tresta, he reached Inspruck, the capital of the Tyrol, in twenty-seven and a-half hours ; at the same rapid rate he passed through Kempten, Ulm, Worms; and Brenstel ; thence by railway to Man heirn. Here he embarked on the Rhine, intending to proceed to Cologne, but the steamer in which he was, meeting with a disaster when off Bingen, he landed on the opposite bank. The Prussian and Belgian governments affording him every assistance, he quickly reached Ostend, crossed the Channel to Dover, and arrived in London by railway, his entire journey from Bombay occupying twenty-nine days. His subsequent trips have been performed in twenty-six days.

Shortly previous to the acceleration of the overland mail, steam communication, was extended from Bombay, by way of Ceylon, to Sincapore. The line of steam- ers having thus been brought within 4500 miles .of Sydney, the friends of the Aus- tralian colonies, in England, conceiving that its extension thither might be effected without any momentous expense, and with great resulting benefit, drew the attention of Lieut. Waghorn to the subject. To shorten the communication between these great wool-producing dependencies, these wealthy consumers of her manufactured goods, from an average of one hundred and ten, to sixty days, would, they readily perceived, be to knit them in a double bond of union with the parent country. A meeting attended by many influential capitalists and others connected with the trade and interests of these colonies, was accordingly held in London, on the 18th April last, to receive Mr. Waghorn's opi- nion. He began by observing that twenty years of his life had been diligently em- ployed in effecting steam communication between England and her eastern depen- dencies. At present, a great part of his object was effected. He had therefore confined himself to the latter part of the route, and he proposed to go by Sincapore to Australia. The distance between the points was 4,450 miles, and the way which he advocated was from Sincapore to Bally, from Bally to Port Essington, thence to Wednesday Island, and on to Port Jackson, thus making four stages of the distance. The government, he stated, would readily afford support to the un- dertaking, as they were anxious to esta-. blish a steam navy in Australia ; but they approved alone of the route he proposed, believing that no other was at present practicable.

The Hon. Fiancis Scott, our Colonial Agent, having moved the meeting for an expression of its approval of the line suggested by Lieut. Waghorn, one or two persons present objected to the route via Singapore, and commended that by Panama. Sir George Larpent, the chairman, in order to preserve unanimity, altered the motion to the effect that the meeting highly approved of the establish- ment of steam communication with Aus- tralia ; and in its amended state it was carried without dissent. A committee was then appointed to take measures for establishing the line, and to obtain such assistance as the government might be willing to render.

Following this, we are glad to observe that a meeting of many of our leading mercantile men was held in Sydney on the 27th ultimo ; to adopt an address to His Excellency the Governor and a me- morial to the Legislative Council, praying for their co-operation in the establishment of steam communication between Aus- tralia and Great Britain.

The line proposed by Lient. Waghorn needs, we believe, but little alteration to become the best that could be devised. Wednesday Island, wanting hands to work its coal, unfitted for a port of refit and supply, could not answer the end de- signed without a vast expense. This error, however, practice would soon re- medy. Moreton Bay, possessing as it does every requisite-capable of supplying provisions, coal, spars, and the means of repair, in case of disaster, lying, too, in the direct track to Port Jackson, offers claims to be numbered amongst the stop- ping-places, that cannot be overlooked. It might, indeed, with advantage, be made the port of final destination ; a crack steamer being specially retained to carry on the mail to Sydney, the Sincapore

vessel would have abundant time to refit

and prepare here for sea before receiving the return mail.

Who can rightly determine the degree of influence which the projected line must have upon Brisbane's welfare ? From a distant dependency, far removed from the track of British ships, it will, in the order of communication, be brought nearer to England than any other commercial set- tlement in Australia. Its short and genial winter, delightful spring and autumn, and temperate summer-devoid of the sudden variations which usually form the greatest

drawback to Australian climature-must

offer paramount inducements to the shat- tered constitution of the Anglo-Indian. Its trade direct to and fro, its communi- cations with England by the new route occupying not more than fifty-six days having intercourse with Sydney only as the seat of government : all which will be the events of a few years : the conse- quent enhancement of its commercial and social importance is well nigh incal-

culable.

* In his speech Mr Scott did ample justice to the importance of the Australian colonies. " He would not hesitate to assert," he said, " that the boundless plains of Australia would be productive of far greater wealth than the mines of Mexico and Peru. He believed that the difference between the value of the trade with foreign countries and that with the colonies was but little known, and he would, therefore, take the opportunity of con- trasting the value of those several trades now earned on with countries comprising one fourth of the population of the globe-a population, in- deed, not less than 160,000,000. He found, then, Prussia took 6d. a head of our goods and manu- factures ; the countless millions of Russia took 8d. a head ; France, 1s. 5d. a head ; the United States of Germany, 3s. 10d ; and the United States of America now took 5s. 8d. a head ; but he should observe that, before the United States ceased to be a colony of this country, it took £1 a head. But what was the case with the colonies ? Why, Canada takes £L 15s. a head, the West In- dies take £2 17s. 6d. a head, and at one time New Sonth Wales took £10 a head, though now it had declined to £7 10s. ; and the whole average of the consumption of the colonies was £1 14s. 6d. a head ; and he found that this country absolutely furnished, on an average, as much as 1s. a head to every inhabitant of the globe. In 1840 -the Australian colonies took as much as £2,630,000 worth of the produce and manufactures of this country ; while, from all the world beside, they took only £385,000 among a population of 1,300,000. On an average of the last five years the number of ships inwards was 605, with a tonnage of 141,000, and of those cleared out wards was 130,000 ; though during the last year, these numbers declined respectively, to 417 ships inwards, with a tonnage of 87,000, and 569 ships outwards, with a tonnage of 109,000. On an average of the last five years the imports had been £1,895,000, although last year they had declined to £931,000. The exports, during the same period, had been £ 1,158,000, but last year £1,223,000, giving employment, one way or the other, to upwards of 3,000,000 of indi- viduals. During the year 1844 no less than 13,500,000 lbs. of wool had been imported into England alone."
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1846.

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1846.

The necessity of a Bank to give security and facility to our commercial transactions, -the benefits that would result from its establishment-were pointed out in the

second number of this journal. Our re- marks excited general attention, and their

justice was everywhere felt and acknow- ledged. "WE WANT A BANK," indeed. Fluctuating currency, embarrassed and cumbrous interchange, the necessity for occasionally resorting to the clumsy ope-

ration of barter, restricted credit which, engendering distrust, often makes the man of wealth to suffer with the man of straw, and, vice vena, producing uncertainty, allows the unsubstantial speculator to oc-

cupy the position, for a time, of the man of means-our whole trade, in short, bound as with bonds of steer within the narrow limit to which the want of a sound and sufficient circulating medium confines it :--these, and numerous other contingent inconveniences have caused our men of business, stockholders, tradesmen and la-

bourers-in fact all classes--to echo our assertion, " We want a Bank."

Why is the want unsupplied ? Are our capitalists no longer emmoved by the spirit of enterprise ? Does the recollection of the late commercial crisis, and its atten- dant disasters, still hamper their activity ? Anxious for gain, do they yet hover on

the brink of adventure, afraid to advance,

unwilling to recede ? Proper caution is commendable : had Banks and Loan Com-

panies always observed it, many a deserving colonist, who is now a beggar, with broken energies, would have remained useful, prosperous, and happy. But caution, the direct extreme from past extravagance, may be carried too far. The man of appre- hensive mind, who sees a highwayman in every bush, excites our pity and contempt The Company that, with full coffers, hesi- tates to introduce a Bank into Brisbane, until some keener and more adventurous rival set it the example, will certainly have forfeited all claims to our confidence and support.

We have lately witnessed so much em-

barrassment and loss from the want of a

local Bank-evils, which are every day augmenting-that we cannot avoid re-

curring to the subject. In inviting the attention of the Colonial Banking Com- panies to the fitness of Brisbane to sup- port sucn an Institution, this community seek no one-sided bargain ; for a banking capital, if judiciously managed, would yield as high a rate of remuneration in

this, as in any other part of New South Wales. This is capable of demonstration. The expense of a branch Bank in Brisbane

would be-say :-

Cashier and Managing Director.. £300

Clerk.........100 House rent........ 50

Stationery, postage, &c....... 50

Five hundred pounds in all. The gross transactions falling within the scope of a Bank during the ensuing twelve months, would probably amount to £120,000 ; for this a circulating medium of £6,000 would amply suffice. This medium or currency might consist of notes, -with a small part, say £500, in coin. The notes would of course be based on the ascer- tained stability of the parent Bank, and we would possess a safeguard against their excessive issue by being enabled to pro-

cure in lieu of them bills on Sydney or England. Coin, indeed, would be scarcely required. Our colonial system of banking resembling the system that has been so successfully acted upon in Scotland, it would be no deviation from its principles if notes issued by our local Bank were, based, not on so much coin within its strong box, but on the credit and stability of the shareholders. The Dr. and Cr. account would, in such a case, stand

thus :-

Gross profit on discounts, inter-

change, &c, of £120,000, say

2 per cent.*. £2,400

The current expenses, as before .. £500

Interest on £500, silver and cop-

per coin, say at 8 per cent......40

There wouild therefore be a balance of income over expenditure of £1860, up- wards of 300 per cent, on the actual capital invested.

The profits of the second and succeed- ing years would of course be much greater. With a vast tract of country, the extent and capabilities of which are not yet known-with a thousand and one oppor- tunities for the profitable employment of capital, presented by the peculiar features of this portion of the colony-with vast sources of wealth, yet hidden, wanting only the judicious operations of industry and capital to reveal them-it would in- deed be presumptuous in us to attempt to assign bounds to that expansion of our commerce which must quickly follow the establishment of a local Bank

Perhaps, it may be said, and said justly, that its establishment depends in some measure upon ourselves ; that " Hercules will not help the waggoner, unless he be- stir himself ;"that we should urge, not once but continually, such truthful ac-

counts of the importance of this and the

contiguous districts, of the extent and ac- tivity of our commerce, upon the attention of our great Austral capitalists, as will

* We have estimated the profits as low as two per cent, in order that we may not be suspected of a wish to exaggerate. We believe, however, that they will be nearer four per cent.

t

d (

a

C ti ti h h

is

SG

St W

lai ho tti

an

serve to place the subject in its true light,

Over caution and incorrect information, seem at present to be the great obstacles in our way. The Union Bank, one of

our great Anglo-Colonial Institutions, has, as our readers are aware, recently extended a branch to Portland-a town of not more than half the importance of Brisbane, and with a district behind it very limited. And why has the Union done this ? Simply because the good people of Port- land had acted energetically and sen- sibly. Recognising the simple, self evident fact, that the wealth and position of any of the more recently occupied dis- tricts of the colony can at no period be ascertained save by actual inspection that their onward progress is so rapid as to forbid the experience of one year form- ing a criterion by which to judge of their position and claims even in the year succeeding-the Portlandites put their shoulders to the wheel : they desisted from their exertions to obtain a Bank only when arrangements were being made

for its establishment.

Let us, therefore, bear this in mind. Let those amongst us, who, from oppor- tunity and ability are best fitted for the task, leave no stone unturned to secure a boon coveted by all classes of this com- munity.

UNDER the head of " Management of the Waste Lands," an able letter appears in a recent number of the Port Phillip Herald, written by Mr. Colin Campbell, a stock- holder in the district of Geelong. The colonial public generally are indebted for the publication of the clear and compre-

hensive views which the writer has formed upon this highly important question.

Mr. Campbell commences by laying down the broad proposition, that the Waste Lands of the colony do not belong to the

Crown in the same sense as the lands of

the Duke of Devonshire belong to him- that they are not the private property of British royalty, acting through its repre- sentative here, independently of the Lords and Commons who represent the people of England, and of our Legislative Assembly, who represent the people of this colony. Since a fund has been derived from these lands, no part of it has been applied to the purposes of the British Crown, in the

strict sense of the word. It has been wholly expended upon the colony itself, in the shape of improvements and immi- gration.

Nor are the Waste Lands subject to the jurisdiction of the Crown in virtue of its prerogative. If they were, why require the interference of the British Parliament, as in the case of Lord Stanley's Act and Mr. Hope's new Bill ?

In order that concord may subsist be- tween the Crown ad the people, neither should have independent interests or pos- sessions which might be turned into means of mutual oppression. If the Crown in itself made private acquisitions to any extent, the consequences might be dangerous to liberty. If, in our case, Crown Lands, so called, were strictly the property of the Sovereign, the anomaly would arise of a portion of the British people being under the jurisdiction of what is only one branch of the Imperial Legislature. A principle embracing such a state of things, so adverse to the consti- tution and law of England, Sir George Gipps endeavoured to maintain. He persisted in asserting that although the lands of England have passed out of the hands of the Sovereign-yet the lands Majesty is in the position of William the Conqueror before he parcelled out Eng-

land to his followers. But, although subjects of the British Crown, we are not utterly dependent upon it, for the constitution and law of England are as binding on the prince as on the peasant - in fact, property in land is only stated to derive its origin from the Crown, because it must have some source and the Crown is the key- stone of the great constitutional ediface. We are part and parcel of the British people, and should be subject to the same

principles as those on which England is

ruled.

But the fact is, (says Mr. Campbell), there are lands here held in private by no one, but ad- ministered by the Governor here, and by the Colonial Secretary to the British Parliament at home, without any acknowledged and consistent principle. We are justified however, in holding that they are held by the Crown, acting for the people, for all their acts are supposed to be for the people. We are justified, also, in claiming the application of the same principles to ourselves as are established at home, and the English Parlia- ment not only takes under its special charge the management of the public property and its pro- ceeds in revenue, but they also take a paternal interest in the administration of Crown lands.

The grand principle involved is, that the property

of a people resides in itself ; on this ground every question where money is involved is pecu- liarly, under the control of the representatives of the country. But if this principle is to be co- extensive with the empire, and if a representative

assembly has been granted to New South Wales, why should not that assembly hold the same rela- tive position here to the Governor-as Parliament does in England to the Sovereign?

But the most difficult part of the question now comes, viz. :-Are these Crown lands to be con- sidered imperial or colonial property ? Although

unalienatcd the reventue derived from them has been given up to the exclusive benefit of the colony itself, for England learnt too severe a lesson in her struggle with America again to as- sume the use of what her children had acquired in

other parts of the world. Can this revenue be conceded, and yet the source of it be reserved ? Can the parent expect at mature years to enjoy the prospective youth and vigour of his child ? And ought a colony, deprived of the immediate resources of the mother country, to be deprived

also of the new inheritance which it has made for

itself ? Shall the anomaly exist of the colonial lands being subject to a popular as well as regal jurisdiction at home, and yet being excluded from the control of the people of the colony itself through their representatives ? The functions of royalty may be delegated far more easily than

those of a deliberative assembly, whose province is to form a judgment ater free discussion. And can a small place like this expect its local interests to be discussed with zeal and attention by an

English Parliament, in whose eyes we are com-

paratively a cipher ? But what is little to them, to us is everything.

The great principle of British freedom in that there shall be no taxation without representation -and if this applies to the proceeds of public wealth, it must equally apply to the public wealth itself. If England claims in her imperial capacity the property in Waste Lands here, she has a right to apply to imperial purposes the income which they yield to the produce of their sales. Will she venture to do so ? Can we be represented there at a distance of half the circuit of the globe ?

The deductions then which I would make from these premises is, that the Waste Lands of New South Wales belong to the colony itself as a floating capital ; that they cannot be managed consistently with English principles except under the control of the representatives of the people in the colony ; and that thus the British empire will receive most benefit, for they will be made more valuable and more productive under local, than under distant management; and if the colony be treated as part and parcel of the empire, its prosperity can- not fail to be communicated to every other part of the common system.

Our limited sheet precludes our notic- ing, for the present, the concluding por- tion of this letter. It contains an exposi- tion of the actual position of the squatters, and the rights withheld from them. The writer suggests that " a key to this puzzling question ''-i.e., the judicious and permanent regulation of the squatting lands-will be found in the Constitution ; and asserts that a departure from its prin- ciples has kept the colony in " a turmoil of uncertainties ;" and that a return to them will surely restore the colony " to that order and security which they are the means of maintaining throughout an empire." Coinciding, as his opinions on this momentous subject do, in a great measure, with our own, we will shortly take an opportunity of adverting to them at length.

articleText:
To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,—I perceive in your last number an article headed “Sly Grog Selling,” in which Mr. Con-

stable Higgins figures very considerably. I beg to inform you, that under that worthy official’s very nose, two sly grog shops are now taking every farthing that is spent in this town ; in fact, so notorious is the circumstance, that every man, woman, and child, in the town, knows it ; but as the Bridge (little Ipswich, as mine host of the

St. Patrick facetiously calls it) is under the parti- cular patronage of Mr. Higgins, no such irregu- larities are carried on there. It requires an active constable to put a stop to this crying evil, and if Mr. Higgins does not attend to his duties, I think the Magistrates ought, in justice to the publicans and public, appoint a fit and proper person to the

situation.

As I have always considered that the public press is one of the means of putting down these pests, I take the liberty of sending you the above, in the hope that you will be pleased to notice it in your next. My neighbour (Mr. Thorne, inn- keeper) feels so annoyed, that he says he may as well shut up his house, if things are allowed to proceed as at present.

I am, Sir,

Yours obediently,

PUBLICOLA.

Ipswich. 21st July, 1846.

N.B.-Of course, I do not wish my name to appear appended to the above, but I shall always be ready to verify the same if required.-P.

articleText:
To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,—On looking over the Census Returns for the County of Stanley, contained in your last Satur- day’s paper, I perceive it is therein stated, that we have amongst us no fewer than 14 clergymen.

Now, as this announcement, without some ex- planation may tend to mislead, and might possi-

bly be the means of preventing some pious and worthy Protestant clergyman, who might be so minded—and of whose services our community stands so much in need at present—from coming to dwell amongst us, it may be as well to state that there are only two clergymen ministering in the district—one Roman Catholic, and one Pro- testant of the Church of England : the latter of whom not having any residence in the town, and having to make frequent tours of duty among the Squatting stations, can only come in occasionally on Saturday nights, perform service on Sunday morning, and start off again to his labours in the Bush either immediately after service, or on Mon- day morning.

The remaining twelve must therefore, I suppose, include the clergymen composing the Roman Catholic Missionary Establishment at Dunwich, and the individuals belonging to the defunct Ger- man Mission at Eagle Farm ; the former of whom have gone to Sydney, en route to the South Sea Islands, the establishment having been broken up : and the latter, become graziers and market-

gardeners.

A BRISBANITE.
heading: To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, AUGUST 15, 1846.

Improvements in penal science—the best means of reforming her criminals, must ever form a moot-point in England's po- lity. Human nature, human frailties,

preclude any defined, abstract system, which will alike apply and succeed in every phase and condition of society. In the body politic, as in the body corporate, the best physician is he who aims at pre- vention rather than cure—who seeks not so much to magnify the terrors of the law, as to elevate the character of the people. The schoolmaster must, in truth, occupy that place in the estimation of the state which is too often assigned to mere physical instruments ; harsh and cruel legislation, which by brutalising educes greater ills than it avails to check, nor dungeons, nor the lash, arrest the progress of crime half as successfully as the sim- ple and easy elevation of the public mind.

An attentive perusal of the volumious, correspondence that has taken place on the subject of the contemplated Colony in Northern Australia, between Sir James Graham, the Treasury Board, the Governor of Diemen's Land, and the ex-Secretary for the Colonies, Lord Stanley, has left us hesitating between two opinions. We know not whether to assign to the noble Lord the honor due to a high-minded philanthropist, ardently intent upon add- ing to existent inducements to repentance, upon affording increased opportunities of retrieval of his position, to erring man or to stigmatise him as a keen financier, to whom promises are bootless, covenants are as straws, when they stand in the way of economical reduction. The arbi- trary, self-willed, capricious spirit that occasionally evinces itself in his despatches to Sir Eardley Wilmot-his cool enun- ciation of propositions which reveal the haughty stickler for prerogative, " THE RIGHTS OF THE CROWN," and which could only be conceived by one in his nature essentially a tyrant—must, we fear, bear us out in asserting that if good result from the formation of the contemplated colony, it must be taken rather as the in- cident than as among the coveted objects of Stanley's policy.

The formation of the new settlement is

the natural sequel of the great penal scheme, which has obtained in Van Die- men's Land since the month of November

1842, known as the Probation System, and which in a great measure owes its origin to the noble Lord—a scheme which, however successful as a preliminary mea- sure, or superior to the assignment system which preceded it, is yet of itself insuffi- cient for the great end designed, and in- competent to replace the convict in the full possession of those social rights which he had forfeited by his crimes. Its leading principles* are, sound religious and secu- lar instruction, strict seclusion, rigid dis- cipline, and transition punishments of a nature and for a period to be determined by the convict's own good conduct. Classes, consisting we believe of six in- dividuals, are formed ; and in order to create that sense of mutual responsibility requisite to induce habits of mutual su- perintendence, every member is held ame- nable not only for his own acts but also for the acts of his class-fellows. In pro- portion to the behaviour of the whole class is the probatory period under- gone ere its members are emancipated, and eligible for private service. And when emancipated, the government stipu- late on their behalf that their wages shall not be less than suffice for a comfortable subsistence.

The Probation System would, without doubt, have worked well and satisfactorily,

• Lord Stanley classes these principles under six heads. 1st. The necessity of preliminary se- clusion. 2nd. A graduated scale of punishments, decreasing in severity. 3rd. Such transition of punishment to depend on the behaviour of the convict. 4th. The reward of all good behaviour, by immediate relaxation of punishment, and the more ready admission of his claims to pardon. 5th. That each convict's claim to indulgence or pardon shall be estimated by a record of his course and habits of life reduced to numerical notation. 6th. The subjecting of every convict, from the commencement to the close of his pro- bationary career, to a systematic course of reli- gious, moral, and industrial education.

had not a state of things occurred which could not have been foreseen, and which unfortunately opposed serious obstacles to its success. We allude to the late com- mercial crisis. Credit sank to a low ebb, commerce diminished, enterprise was for the time annihilated, and the energies of the colonists were drooping and depressed. While the capital of the country and the field for its employment diminished, prison labour was poured into the island in excess. The operations of capital and industry being narrowed within certain limits, redundant labour only served to increase competition, and, without en- larging the market, to reduce price. Scarce and dear labour had previously accompanied high prosperity, and now, in remarkable contrast, cheap labour and improved means of access and transit be came co-existent with acute general dis- tress. Withal, too, many of the idle and

dissolute were without employment, and reduced to plunder in order to subsist. Crime, and consequent insecurity of life and property, augmented. As might have been expected, therefore, in such an untoward state of things, every ill that colonial " flesh was heir to," was stigma- tised as resulting from the penal scheme of Lord Stanley.

So long as the farmers of Van Diemen's Land obtained ten, fifteen, or twenty shil- lings a bushel for their wheat, so long as

its stockholders sold toothless ewes at

twenty-five shillings a-head, and its merchants enjoyed an extensive and pro- fitable monopoly of trade—so long as the island was the granary of Australasia, and South Australia and Port Phillip eagerly purchased its surplus live stock, transportation did not excite even a soli- tary murmur. But when those great con- sumers became producers, when they not only virtually shut out the sister colony from their own markets, but undersold her in her own-when the Southern Austra-

lians, instead of buying her wheat at ten shillings, offered to sell grain equally good at half-a-crown—when fat sheep could be purchased at Port Phillip for one-fourth of the price formerly paid for her own lean, scabby crawlers, grievances were dis- covered where none were before supposed to exist ; and as the manufacturers of England have been but too prone to stig- matise Corn-law protection as an unmiti- gated evil, so did the Van Diemonians trace all their ills to transportation.

Far therefore be it from us to assert

that the Probation System has failed, or that, under other and more favorable cir- cumstances, it might not have proved the most efficient reformatory scheme that ever emanated from an English Minister. But

to enable it to realise the views of its framer, and to ensure its success, it was requisite that the colony should be able to find private employment for as many convicts as were likely to become free for years to come. To its inability to do this, may be ascribed the overthrow of his calculations, Of the classes who obtained remission of punishment, few were able to support themselves ; and even of these a great proportion were con- tinually falling back on the Government for necessary subsistence—a proportion augmented by every fresh importation of prisoners. Listless dependence on the pub- lic purse, habits of indolence and apathy were induced ; the efficacy of pardons, or of relaxations of punishment as incentives to good conduct were impaired ; and a mass of persons of every variety of character and capacity, and of good and ill desert, were reduced to one general level, and were compelled to associate as fellow work- men in the same pursuits : the best exposed to the contaminating influence of the very worst. In order to remedy evils so se- rious, convicts conditionally pardoned were allowed, by an order dated February, 1845, to seek hire in the neighbouring colonies. But the additional demand thus created for their services was, in the first instance, exceedingly small. How to de- vise employment for the increasing surplus labour, of a nature suitable to the eman- cipist, economical to the government, and best promotive of the interests of the Empire, became a matter of serious con-

sideration.

At this juncture a plan of colonising North Australia, which we believe origi- nated in a suggestion of Dr. Lang to a Committee of the House of Commons, in 1837, and which was subsequently recom-

mended by Sir Richard Bourke in a dis- patch of the 25th October, 1838, and frequently adverted to as a practicable scheme by other witnesses, was revived. It at once received the favourable con- sideration of Lord Stanley. No other way of escape seemed open, from the difficul- ties that surrounded the question, While on the one hand a large number of eman-

cipated convicts were thrown for support upon the government in Van Diemen's Land, on the other, the home government were pledged not to renew transportation to New South Wales. A colony in North Australia therefore offered an easy and safe solution of the difficulty—and opened up another and more certain outlet through which the labour of a dependent and worse than unproductive population might be turned to profitable account. The northern boundary of this colony was permanently fixed at 26° south latitude, and a new colony planned which should extend from thence to Cape York, about 10° 40' S., and run westward to 141° east longitude, which latter also forms the western boun-

dary of New South Wales. This, our readers are aware, includes the mag- nificent discoveries of Leichhardt.

Northern Australia is not to become a model colony. For some years after its formation it cannot advance beyond the state of a labour depot from which em- ployers may draw as many hands as they please. So long indeed as they maintain, as servants, the emancipated convicts, at- tempts to people the new settlement will not be made. Its formation, however, will supply an effectual check to the spirit of listless dependence on the go- vernment into which many of these latter too readily fall. To every such person will be tendered the alternative of finding an honest subsistence elsewhere, or of migrating to a colony where an easy main- tenance will be placed within his reach.

The classes of persons of which the population of Northern Australia will in the first instance consist, will be 1st, offi- cials, a detachment of troops, and a branch of the Customs ; 2nd, convicts who have passed a probatory period at Penton- ville ; 3rd, the unemployed emancipists of Van Diemen's Land ; and 4th, a large portion, if not the whole, of the female convicts sent from Great Britain. The sending out of convicts' wives and chil- dren will also, it is anticipated, be a measure often resorted to by Poor Law Unions on grounds of economy.

The intended position of the first settle- ment is not known. Its formation, and the appointment of the whole official staff, except the Superintendent, is entrusted to Sir Charles Fitzroy. The excepted office is stated by the Sydney journals to have been already conferred on Leut.-Colonel Barney, formerly at the head of the ord- nance department in this colony, at a salary of £1500 a-year. The other appointments are to be made as far as possible from those persons whose employment in cer- tain offices appertaining to the existing convict department will, on the contem- plated reduction of these offices, give them claims to compensation.

We will shortly recur to this interesting subject.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, AUGUST 15, 1846.
snippet: IMPROVEMENTS in penal science—the best means of reforming her criminals, must ever form a moot-point in England's polity. Human nature, human frailties,
