articleText:
THE Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, AUGUST 22, 1846.

To the plan of isolation considered as a scheme of

moral reform, the first and most obvious objec- tion is, that it has already been tried to some extent at Norfolk Island, and that the result of

that experiment is not such as to encourage a renewal of it on a much larger scale.

In the state of isolation, there can be no prevail-

ing tone of moral sentiment, but such as is the spontaneous growth of a convict society. It will be destitute of those opinions and of those feelings which must be, more or less, engen- dered by the close vicinity of a population by

whom personal morality, and the virtues of public and domestic life, are respected and cul-

tivated. Few men are so abandoned as to be

entirely proof against the healthful contagion of such habits, and of the principles by which

they are sustained. To belong to a community, by the higher and more numerous portion of which truth, decency, and integrity, are hon-

oured, and religion held in reverence, must be a great, though an indirect blessing, to the most abject, and the most unworthy of its

members.

Nor would the influence of the governing body in

such an isolated position supply this salutary impulse. Convicts must live under an energetic, prompt, and formidable government. Every such government tends strongly and inevitably to abuse, and the only effective corrective of such abuses is the censorship of public opinion

as expressed through, the ordinary popular channels.—Despatch of Lord Stanley to the Governor of Van Diemen's Land.

The southern part of North Australia being but

two degrees nearer the Equator than Moreton Bay, may be expected to possess a great resem- blance to that settlement in climate, and to par- take of the general salubrity which has hitherto been found to characterise the whole of the shores of New Holland, with the exception per- haps of Port Essington, which is within the Tropics, and only twelve degrees south of the Equator. It is a region in which men may live, without danger, under canvass, or in huts, during the gradual erection of more costly buildings. It possesses vast tracts of land covered with timber, but, in common with the

rest of New Holland, is traversable in every direction without the necessity for forming roads. It is ascertained to be rich in natural productions, and susceptible of culture by Eu- ropeans with almost every article for the growth of which the powerful action of the sun is requisite. It is, moreover, the only remaining part of the east coast of New Holland in which a field could be opened for the enterprise of such

pardoned convicts as may be unable to obtain lucrative situations elsewhere.

Lord Stanley contemplates the gradual and pro-

bably the slow formation of the new colony.— So long as the pardoned convicts might be able to earn an independent subsistence, either in Van Diemen's Land, or in any other of the

existing Australian settlements, his Lordship would not propose to transfer them to North Australia ; consequently, if the existing embar- rassments in Van Diemen's Land should be otherwise surmounted, the plan of the projected colony would languish, or would perhaps never be brought into operation at all. But on the opposite, and, as Lord Stanley apprehends, much more probable supposition, North Aus- tralia would be a resource by means of which Van Diemen's Land would find relief from difficulties otherwise threatening ruin to the existing free colonists, the waste of public treasure, and a continued degradation of the character of the pardoned offenders. It would be a resource of which men of energetic minds and habits would gladly avail themselves. Letter from J. Stephen, Esq., to C. E. Trevelyan, Esq.

The foregoing clearly indicate the inten-

tions of the Home Government with re-

gard to the new settlement. Northern Australia is not, as some of our contem- poraries persist in styling it, a penal co- lony. The emancipated convicts, landed there, clothed and fed at the expense of the British Government, are to all intents and purposes free subjects—free to migrate to any portion of the Australian colonies, in which they can obtain an honest live- lihood. Employers of labour may select servants, from Tropical Australia, equally as from Van Diemen's Land. And every capitalist who may adventure thither will be, and be regarded, as a valuable addition to its infant society.

The Waste Lands Act will not take effect in North Australia. The reason of

this is obvious. The great feature of the new colonizing scheme is, that lands shall be assigned to the settlers, for culture, in order that they may be enabled to main- tain themselves. They will have no pro- perty in the soil. Their interest therein will cease, when they cease to cultivate. To assign lands on such a tenure, and to supply the necessary capital to the occu- piers, in the shape of food, clothing, and tools, will, we need scarcely say, be alto- gether contrary to the spirit of the Act in question. It is therefore precluded from coming into operation. No hindrance or opposition to the progress of the squatting interest needs, however, be feared. Our hardy pioneers may safely follow the promptings of enterprize, even to the very walls of the Northern Capital. They will not be checked in their career, but will occupy their merited position in a country which Nature has clearly designed for a pastoral community.

The project of forming a new colony in Northern Australia has engaged the

attention of the Home Government since

the beginning of the year 1844—not, however, in the first instance, as a sequel of the Probation System of Van Diemen's Land, but of the assimilating reformatory scheme which came into operation about the same period, at Pentonville—a scheme which originated in a recommendation of the Inspectors of English prisons. The projected colony was the natural effect of the necessity which existed, of devising

some medium state between the strict

punishment of the prison, and a state of absolute freedom and consequent probable reversion by the expirees to former as- sociations and crimes. On the first inti- mation of the Government's intentions, with regard to these men, obtaining pub- licity, Mr. W. H. Yaldwyn, a Port Phillip stockholder, then residing in London, im- mediately wrote to the Home Secretary stating his willingness to receive twenty- one into his service ; and as the evident and natural inference to be drawn from

Mr. Yaldwyn's letter, was, that many of his fellow colonists would be equally willing to hire them if opportunity were afforded, of doing so, Ministers resolved upon sending a ship-load to these colo- nies ; to be formed either into a separate settlement or labor depot, or to be distri- buted amongst the settlers of any district in which their services might be in de- mand. Lord Stanley, in announcing the conclusions thus arrived at, to Sir Eardley Wilmot, in a despatch dated 27th July,

1844, also remarked as follows :—

Her Majesty's Government regard it as indis- pensable that provision should be made for the maintenance, in a state of freedom, of that par- ticular class of convicts whom I have designated as exiles ; and that they should be exempted not only from the severe lot of other convicts, but as far as possible from the temptations incident to an habitual association with them. For this purpose we are willing to incur every unavoidable expense.

We think, however, that the expense ought not to be great. These are persons of whom we have every reason to believe that they require no parti- cular restraint or costly superintendence ; and in the extensive territories of the Crown in Australia it seems scarcely doubtful that such persons could either find adequate employment at a sufficient rate of wages, or, by forming a settlement apart, earn their own subsistence by the cultivation of

the soil.

Each of them has been instructed and will be found moderately skilled in some mechanical art. This may at once facilitate their obtaining em- ployment, or the formation of a separate settlement. His Lordship further suggested the ne- cessity of a conference between Sir George Gipps, Sir Eardley Wilmot, and Mr. La- trobe, " provisionally to decide on the best mode of providing for the reception and employment of these persons ;" and in

obedience to his wishes their Excellencies and His Honor resolved upon meeting, to consult upon the subject, at Launceston.

The ship Sir George Seymour, having on board 176 exiles, 91 ticket-of-leave holders, and 78 passholders, left England in the month of November following.

The exiles were destined for the projected

settlement ; the two other classes were to be placed under the surveillance of the Government of Van Diemen's Land. In

a despatch dated Oct. 1844, advising Sir Eardley of the vessel's intended departure, the ex-Secretary writes :—

But in the contingency to which I have ad- verted, of the formation of a labor depot to be re- cruited by prisoners sent from this country as exiles, not as convicts, the necessity may arise for creating and maintaining offices for the control and government of such an institution. I refer it to the discretion of yourself, Sir George Gipps,

and Mr. Latrobe to determine what those offices should be, and what should be the rate of remu- neration. It is superfluous to insist on the neces- sity of incurring no expense beyond what may be requisite for the efficient discharge of this duty. But as far as it is possible to form a judgment at this distance, and in the existing uncertainty as to the course which may be taken, I think that it may probably be necessary to employ three offi- cers ; that is, a superintendent, an assistant su- perintendent, and a religious instructor ; one of the two superintendents being a medical officer, and acting also in that capacity.

Contemplating the possibility of such arrange- ments, Mr. Hampton has offered to serve as su- perintendent and surgeon at £700 per annum for the first year, and at £600 per annum for each following year. Mr. Boyd has offered to serve as assistant superintendent at £200, and Mr. Cairn- duff, at the same rate, as religious instructor.

Each of these gentlemen stipulates for being further provided with food and lodging, in kind, or by a commutation in money at such a rate in either case as the local government may think reasonable. They are all well aware that the formation of the settlement at all is uncertain, and that the continuance of it is precarious.

If the plan of forming a depot of labour should be adopted, it would be of great importance to prevent the members of it from acquiring a pro- prietary title or claims likely to ripen into such a title to any lands which, in their character of exiles, dependent on the Government, they may cultivate for their own support, or even to the crops growing on such lands. The fundamental principle of every such settlement should be, that it is the temporary receptacle, not the permanent abode, of its inmates, and no opportunity should be lost of inculcating that principle, or of en- forcing the observance of it.

The necessity of a conference to decide upon the disposal of the exiles, was, as many of our readers are aware obviated by an application made to the local Go- vernment by the stockholders of the Gee- long district. The latter at once saw the ad- vantages to be derived from securing these men as laborers, in preference to an equal number of probationists from Van Die- men's Land. Their request that the exiles might be landed at Geelong was of course gladly acceded to ; for in acceding, the Government knew that they were satis- factorily carrying out the wishes of Ministers upon the subject.

The exiles, since their sojourn at Port Phillip, as a body have distinguished themselves for morality and good-beha- viour ; and from, the knowledge of me- chanical arts imparted to them at the Penitentiary, have proved very useful in all kinds of labor requiring the exercise of ingenuity. Although less in point of number than the Probationists, it cannot be doubted that this class of men will, socially speaking, be of far more impor- tance in the degree of influence which even they must possess on the destinies of the new colony. Convicted of slight offences

and selected on that account from the

mass, they are subjected, during periods extending from fifteen to twenty-two months, to the beneficial influences of strict seclusion, rigid discipline, and reli- gious and industrial instruction. As a large proportion of them are educated, habits of reflection are more easily su- perinduced ; and a taste for moral plea- sures more readily implanted in their minds, than in the minds of the more

ignorant and brutalized. Originally better in most instances than those transported to Van Diemen's Land—subjected to a system of discipline which, if not excel- ling in conception, has yet the advantage of being far more successful in execution

than the Probation System, these men, it cannot be disputed, are much more to be desired, whether as laborers or colonists.

Mr. Hampton, the surgeon-superin- tendent of the Sir George Seymour, in his report to Sir Eardley Wilmot, gives the following gratifying account of those

entrusted to his care :—

Sunday schools were established specially for the religious instruction of the convicts, and were evidently more valuable in consequence of the at-

tendance being altogether voluntary. One hun- dred and ninety-eight of the prisoners attended these schools with much diligence, and there is every reason to believe, much profit.

Divine Service was performed morning and evening every Sunday after the embarkation of the convicts ; the Church of England service and a sermon being read each time. The morning services were conducted by myself, the evening by the religious instructor. To improve the prison- ers' minds, as well as to increase their self-respect and estimation of each other, a certain number of the most intelligent were selected, and encouraged to deliver lectures to their fellow-prisoners in the evenings, on instructive and interesting subjects ; and many of these lectures, as well as the attentive manner in which they were listened to, would have done credit to similar meetings of free men having much greater pretensions.

Among the subjects selected by the lecturers, I may mention—The advantages of education—The use and abuse of music—Comparative anatomy— English history—The origin of names—Universal history — Astronomy — Poetry — Ornithology — Characteristics of the human race—Circulation of the blood —The duties of domestic servants—Ar- chitecture—&c.

A weekly newspaper was proposed, edited, and carried on by the prisoners in a highly cre-

ditable manner.

As an opinion prevails very generally that the separate system in force at Pentonville Prison weakens the mind, and often causes insanity, I feel bound to state, in the most emphatic terms, that it did not produce the slightest mental imbecility in any of the 345 men under my charge, and that, in my opinion, their minds were in a much more healthy state than is usual amongst ordinary convicts, or even any similar number of men of

the same station in life. The only mental effect I observed has been already noticed, for want of a better term, as the loss of gregarious habits.

The only punishment found necessary during the voyage was putting five men in solitary con- finement for short periods.

During the time these men were under my charge I was generally amongst them from day- light until after sunset, and never heard one make use of an oath, or even intemperate language ; never saw any quarrelling or fighting, but, on the contrary, they had in general a quiet, sub- dued, thoughtful manner most pleasing to observe, and calculated to inspire the greatest confidence in their good intentions.

Of their state of education on debarking, Mr. Hampton gives the following interest- ing summary :—

Reading—

Read well............ 182 — tolerably............114

— imperfectly......... 48 — scarcely at all....... 8

— not at all............. 0 Writing—

Write well........... 38 — tolerably........ 79

— imperfectly...... 214

— scarcely at all..... 8 — not at all............ 5 Arithmetic—

Can do the higher rules.... 104

— to proportion............. 82 — all the compound rules....... 64 — all the simple rules.......... 64 — to multiplication....... 18

— to addition............... 11

— scarcely or none at all...... 5

We cannot conclude without a passing notice of the canting, mawkish sentimen-

tality which appears to influence sundry of our contemporaries in their notices of Northern Australia. They inveigh against the bad faith of the British Government, and denounce the new colony as a great artery through which the diseased hu- mours of a feculent society are to be con- veyed amongst us. But in what has bad faith been displayed ? We, the colonists of New South Wales, rush into the labor market of Van Diemen's Land, eager competitors for the services of its expirees, endeavouring to outbid each other in tempting offers of good wages and abun- dant rations. We bring them to our shores, at our own expense, amidst mu- tual gratulations. The people of Port Phillip have done this, and more ; they have petitioned the local Government that all incoming cargoes of exiles may be landed amongst them. And yet we coolly turn round, and blame Ministers for contemplating what must in effect, if our words do not belie our deeds, fa- cilitate our views—for aiming to form a labor depot, from which these men may be readily transferred to us without trouble or expense of agency ! Our own act is ratified—an act resulting from the irre- sistible laws of necessity, and the effect of practical good sense—and, forsooth, the finger of pious horror must be uplifted, and we must stand aghast at what is enormity in the British Government but commendable in ourselves ! Away with such hypocrisy ! Cheap and abundant labor is an essential adjunct of our pros- perity ; and the instinct of self-preserva- tion must urge, as it has already urged us, to avail ourselves of it, wherever it can be obtained.

articleText:
To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,— For the information of the " squatting world," I forward you a note of what I believe to be an effectual cure for sheep, bitten by the native dog, and which you may possibly consider worthy of publication.

The experiment I found to answer in one instance, and it has been tried by a neighbour, who also found the plan efficacious.

Last month I had twenty sheep badly bitten— having found corrosive sublimate blue stone, &c., to have failed in several instances—I dressed these sheep in the following manner :— In the first instance, I opened the wound with the knife as far as possible ; I then soaked a piece of tow or wool in turpentine, to which I set fire, and applied the same, when burning, to the wound. I may as well remark, that I allowed the wool, saturated with turpentine, to burn to a cinder in the wound.

I dressed eighteen sheep out of the twenty—one very slightly bitten, and which I did not think necessary to dress, died—and another, which was seriously worried, I left to its fate; but the eighteen

dressed recovered. I mentioned this fact to a

neighbour, who, the following week, had an op- portunity of testing its merits : for having dressed ten sheep in the above manner, they all recovered. I have heretofore considered the bite of a native

dog fatal. Let me recommend those who may try the experiment, not to be afraid of using the knife.

I am, Sir, your obedient servant.

C. W. P.
heading: To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

articleText:
THE

MORETON BAY COURIER.

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1846.

We recollect having heard a story of an ill-natured schoolboy, who was a greedy gut ; and who on being asked for a portion of a very large cake which had been sent to him as a present, refused to share it with his companions, saying, " I never give to those boys who ask, and those who don't ask don't want. " This is a tolerably apt illustration of the relative position of the inhabitants of Moreton Bay

and the Government. Since the settle- ment has been established, Government has derived a very considerable revenue from the sales of land, rental of public buildings, office fees and fines, licenses, and ferries, the proceeds of which have been sent to Sydney, and expended for the benefit of other districts to the neglect and injury of our own. And why is this ? Expound Mr. Colonial Secretary and Mr. McLeay ! Oh, says Mr. McLeay, Govern- ment seldom give to those who ask ; oh, says the Colonial Secretary, you have never asked, and, therefore, you don't want." True 'tis a pity, and pity 'tis 'tis true. They are both right, and between the two stools we have fallen to the ground. Arise, then, ye Brisbanites, shake off the languor that has prostrated your energies. It is high time that you should understand your real position demand your rights, and be prepared to maintain them. Our more immediate business, however, is with the ferries, and the appropriation of the funds derived from them.

The Act of Council, 2 William 4th, No. 12, enacts that it shall and may be lawful for the Governor to appoint places where tolls and ferries may be established or continued. The object of the Act, as stated in the preamble, is to make pro- vision for the raising of funds towards making, repairing, and upholding public roads and bridges in the colony. The

seventh clause fixes the scale of fees at

ferries, which is as follows :

s. d.

For every foot passenger. 0 2 For every horse, mare, gelding, ass, or

mule, drawing or not drawing. 0 6 For every gig, dray, or cart, with two

wheels only. 1 0 For every waggon, carriage, or other

vehicle, with four wheels. 1 6 For every ox, or head of neat cattle, not

exceeding ten in number. 0 4 For every ox, or head of neat cattle, being

more than ten in number. 0 3

For every sheep, lamb, pig, or goat.. 0 01/2 It is not lawful for any person, save the ferrymen duly appointed under the Act, to employ on hire, or for fee or reward, any boats for the conveyance of passengers or goods, within one mile of the place where a ferry is established, except in case of flood or fire, in the pursuit of felons, or other urgent and unavoidable necessity, under penalty of twenty shillings for each

offence,

Now we should not quarrel about the scale of fees, provided only one ferry were established in Brisbane, and the proceeds were devoted to local improvements. But there being two ferries, one from North to South Brisbane, and the other from North Brisbane to Kangaroo Point, it is of the utmost importance either that the scale should be reduced one-half, or, that the whole of the sum netted at auction should be expended for the benefit of the inhabi- tants. What conceivable right the Go- vernment has to go on extracting a large amount of ferry money annually from our pockets, and applying it to other than purely local purposes, such as the im- provement of the roads and bridges, we are at a loss to conjecture. Loud and un- ceasing complaints are made by the in- habitants in consequence of the expensive and restricted medium of communication between the three places. For instance, if a person residing at Kangaroo Point wishes to transact business in South Bris

bane, he has to pay eightpence to the Government, for the glorious liberty of crossing the river in the licensed imposi- tion ferry boats. We maintain that it is the duty of Government to remove obsta- cles of this kind, for internal commerce should not be interrupted by such op- pressive tolls, or by restrictive regulations. They should expunge from the statute- book every clause which in its effect tends to fetter the operations of the trader, without giving him .a corresponding ad- vantage. It requires no argument to demonstrate the pernicious results that accrue to a trading community, and more, particularly to a young community, from exorbitant tolls. When too high, they obstruct that intercourse which they were originally intended to promote, and are of the inhabitants of that locality where,

unhappily, they are exacted. We feel assured that the residents would cheerfully pay moderate dues, provided the funds were devoted to local purposes. As yet, Government has failed of making any provision whatever for the construction of roads and bridges in the district. This neglect is to be attributed to our own supineness in these matters.

The time is fast approaching when the ferry tolls will be let by auction for an- other term not exceeding twelve months. We propose that a public meeting be called for the purpose of memorialising the Go- vernment on the subject. Let application be made to the proper authorities to ap- propriate the funds, hereafter to be col- lected, for the construction and repairs of the roads and bridges, and towards the effecting of other improvements in the districts. It has been suggested to us that the money should be placed at the disposal of the District Association, when that body shall have been re-organised, and a new chairman appointed. At present the office of chairman is vacant, the gentleman who filled it having resigned on account of not being a resident in the town. We have good authority for stating that the Government are disposed to comply with our wishes in respect of the ferry tolls ; but it is not very likely they will help us, unless we evince a disposition to help

ourselves.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1846.

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1846.

INDIAN LABOUR.

With regard to the moral habits of the Coolies, Mr. Friell states that they are not inferior to the Europeans ; and, consider- ing the disadvantages under which they labour, superior to the immigrants from Great Britain. Drunkenness is a vice not

practised amongst them. The climate has improved rather than injured the constitu-

tion of the Indians.

We perfectly agree with the author that they should be employed at stations where there are no Europeans, excepting those required as bullock-drivers. We believe that this plan has been carried out at Mr. Friell's station, on the Stuart River, and experience has proved that the exclusive system is the best, as it prevents the Indian from being tampered with by the European.

In selecting labourers in India, it is re- commended that the Hindoo should be preferred to the Mussulman ; but the Gurraree, or Bheree Wallah and Gwallahs (shepherds and cowherds), are decidedly the best class, as they are ready-made to their trade. These men can be readily procured, as thousand's are to be seen loitering about the Emigration offices in Calcutta, ready to ship on almost any terms. It is essentially necessary, how- ever, that great care should be taken in the selection ; for their future success in this country will depend entirely upon the agents' choice of men. With regard to the expense that must be incurred in pro- curing them, it is calculated that the cost of passage will be .... £10 0 0 The fee for engaging them,

including provisions for the

voyage and clothing, each 2 5 0 Other incidental expenses, do 1 15 0

£14 0 0

Upon a large scale, it is considered that £8 per head for passage (without provi- sions) would amply remunerate the ship- owner, as the voyage can be accomplished, at the proper season of the year, in two

months.

We have no doubt that the statements of the author are correct, for his observa- tions are evidently written in the spirit of candour and of truth. He has, however, entirely failed in convincing us that Coolie labour is to be preferred to that from Europe. So urgent, however, is the demand for labour in this district, that we think it is probable many of the employ- ers are favourably disposed towards the introduction of Coolies. We doubt very much, unless Government countenance the importation of such labourers, (which they are not likely to do), whether the result of individual exertions will turn out satis-

factorily. Of one thing we feel quite confident-unless they are kept apart from Europeans, no advantages will ac- crue from this description of labour. There are many reasons why they should be kept separate from the Europeans. In the first place, any attempt to amalgamate them could not be effected so long as there exists an inequality of wages between the whites and the Indians on the same station. Every employer knows well that this inequality is one of the most fruitful sources of discontent even among the Europeans. The labourer who is paid less wages for the same kind of work than, his fellows, becomes dissatisfied from a sense of inferiority, and will never make a good servant. Uniformity of wages must be maintained, or the system cannot work well. In the next place, the experiment cannot be successful, unless there be some

thing like an equalisation of the sexes ; and we apprehend that the expense of in- troducing the wives of the Coolies with their own husbands, would be so great that few employers will be found able and willing to attempt it. Mr. Friell does not recommend the introduction of women, because, he says, no native carries his wife with him wherever he may proceed to seek his fortune. She is left in his village, and he returns to her. We differ from the author in this view of the subject, and maintain the opinions we have already expressed.

On the whole, we are of opinion that

Mr. Friell's account of the results of

Coolie labour is deserving the attention of the squatters, who, of course, are the parties more competent to judge as to its expediency than ourselves. Some may prefer this description of labour as a matter of taste ; but we think that few, after perusing the pamphlet now under consi- deration, will he disposed to employ it in preference to that about to arrive from Europe.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1846. INDIAN LABOUR.

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1846.

PERHAPS no movement that ever had in this colony the support of a large body of rational beings has caused greater excite- ment than the movement against the re- vival of transportation-against the intro- duction of an improved system of convict labour. Shorn of its few plausibilities, the whole affair presents such an aspect of the ridiculous, that the general mass of the colonists do nothing else than laugh at it ; and somewhat recovered from their indiscreet earnestness, and having exer- cised a little reflection, the movers begin to perceive that the whole affair will come toppling over with the weight of its own absurdity, and are now preparing them- selves for a more rational course than the one urged upon the colonists by the public meeting held in Sydney a short time ago, This ebullition of feeling had its origin, it seems, with persons upon whose mental vision suddenly burst the glaring convic- tion that the Government were about in-

flicting on a body of people one of the greatest nuisances that had ever been per- petrated since, the days of Aristotle. A meeting was forthwith called, and was attended, of course, by those persons inimical to the revival of transportation. We have carefully perused the speeches on that occasion, and however we may respect the motives of the parties who delivered them, we have sought in vain for any substantial reasons for their outcries, or for their denunciations against those employers of labour who entertain contrary views. It is not our intention on the present occasion to comment on the fallacies and puerilities promulgated at that meeting ; it is sufficient for our purpose to know that it turned out a com- plete failure. There was scarcely a man, whose opinions usually have any weight with the colonists that attended it.

The Report of the Transportation Com- mittee was brought up on the 31st ultimo ;

it is founded on the evidence of such men

as -Mr. B. Boyd, Dr. Dobie, Mr. Duguid, Major Childs, Mr. J. P. Robinson, Mr. Miles, Commissioner of Police, Mr. C. D. Logan, Mr. Timothy Nowlan, and Mr. E. S. Hall, gentlemen who from their wealth, in- telligence, and practical experience of the wants of the colony, are fully entitled to our respect, and whose opinions will ne- cessarily have great weight both here and in England. It is not in our power to

furnish our readers with even an outline of the voluminous documents presented to the Council by the Committee. We shall merely offer a few remarks on the Report

itself.

The Committee have recommended that Mr. Gladstone's plan for the revival of transportation should be accepted on the following conditions-and upon no other :

1st- That no alteration shall be made in the Constitutional Act 5 and 6 Victoria, c, 76, except with a view to the extension of the elective prin- ciple. -

2nd-That the transportation of male convicts be accompanied-as a simultaneous measure-with the importation of an equal number of females, to consist of female convicts as far as they exist, and the balance to be made up of female immigrants.

3rd-That, as a further simultaneous measure, such transportation be accompanied with an equal importation of free immigrants, as nearly as pos- sible in equal proportion as to sexes.

4th-That the wives and families of all convicts receiving permanent or temporary indulgencies, should be brought, and count as part of this free immigration.

5th-That no fewer-than five thousand male convicts be annually deported to this colony.

6th-That the convict establishments properly so called, such as Norfolk Island, Cockatoo Island, ironed or road gangs of criminals under colonial sentence, &c, &c, be maintained as heretofore at the cost of the British Treasury.

7th-That two-thirds of the expense of police, gaols, and the criminal administration of justice, be paid by the Home Government, but that on the relinquishment of the land fund, and all other revenues or droits of the Crown to the appropria- tion of the Governor and Council, the whole of this branch of convict expenditure be assumed by the colony, with a view to aid the British Government in defraying the cost of the free immigration stipulated for in the second and third conditions.

8th-That in order to ensure due permanency and efficiency in the regulations to be provided for the government and discipline of convicts, the sole power of making such regulations be vested in the Governor and Legislative Council, saving entire the Royal prerogative of mercy.

The description of convicts, in the opinion of your Committee, the colony should agree to re- ceive from the mother country, on the above con-

ditions, are :-

1st-Young delinquents who have committed first offences after little or no probation.

2nd-Convicts who have committed graver, offences, after a probation considered adequate to the crime ; the probation meant being probation under the separate system.

3rd-Convicts at the commencement of their sentences, who have committed various crimes.

4th-If any convicts be received from Van Diemen's Land, convicts with tickets-of-leave.

The foregoing propositions are well worthy the attention of every well-wisher of his adopted country. Should the terms be accepted by the Government, we feel satisfied that the very men who are now so

violently opposed to the introduction of

.convict-labour will be the first to avail

themselves of it when it reaches our shores.

We shall recur to this subject in a future

number.

RAMS.-On Saturday, seventy five pure-bred Merino rams, the property of the Messrs. Leslie, of Canning Downs, were landed from the steamer. They have been selected from the flocks of Mr. Macarthur. Owing to the long passage made by the steamer, they arrived in rather poor condition. One of them died on board. They have been forwarded to their destination.

LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.--The Council was prorogued on Saturday the 31st, until the 15th December next, by His Excellency the Governor, in person. Further particulars in our next.

STATE OF TRADE AND THE WEATHER: During the week we have had very heavy falls of rain, which has filled all the water-holes in the neigh- bourhood of the town. All retail trade has been

in consequence, rather dull, purchasers not caring to venture out, unless, for absolute necessaries. The storekeepers are complaining at the present time of afflictions for which there seems no ready cure. One class complains that the unfortunate statement of the Colonial Secretary, alluded to at the public meeting, has annihilated all their hopes of doing business, and stand behind their counters sickening with hope deferred ; the fall in wool also having rendered the patronage of the squatters as barren as priests' charity. A second class com- plains that their accounts (among which, by the bye, are our own,) " come in awful ;" meaning, we presume, that either they do not come in at

all, or very slowly. They must, however, cheer up ; there are good times in, store for us yet.

COURT OF QUARTER SESSIONS.-We stated some time ago it was expected that a Court of Quarter Sessions would be established in Brisbane on or about January next. We have since learned that,

notwithstanding the vote of the Legislative Council making provision for the salaries of the neces-

sary officers, the Court cannot be opened in con- sequence of the Jury Act not having been extended to this district. It is also a matter of doubt whether, the Police Magistrate can act as Chair- man, unless a special Act of Council is passed for that purpose ; as we have always understood that a Chairman of Quarter Sessions must be a bar-

rister of three years' standing. Perhaps some of our legal friends will enlighten us upon the point, if our opinion is erroneous. A Court of Quarter Sessions for this district is very much wanted and the sooner the impediments to their being established (whatever they may be) are removed, the better for the inhabitants.

BUOYS, CHAINS, AND ANCHORS.-We observe by the Government Gazette of the 13th instant, that tenders will be received at the Colonial Secre- tary's Office until twelve o'clock of Monday the 30th, November for supplying one iron-bouy, 8 feet by 6 feet with a beacon ; two iron buoys 7 feet by 5 feet ; fifteen fathoms of 5/8 inch chain,

and two mushroom anchors for each buoy with swivels, and shackles. The tenders to be endorsed "Tenders for Buoys, &c.," may include the ex- pense of conveyance to Moreton Bay, or the articles only. They are intended for the northern entrance to the Bay.

TITLE DEEDS.-The undermentioned deeds have been transmitted from the Colonial Secre- tary's office to that of the Registrar General for enrolment, under the provisions of the Act, 7 Vic, No. 16, to be forwarded by him through the Surveyor General to the Colonial Treasurer, by whom notification of their receipt at his office will be made to the grantees by letter, after which they will be delivered on application, viz. :-David

George; Peattie and Catherine Savary as tenants in common, 36 perches; North Brisbane, lot 1 ;

William Sheehan, 36 perches, ditto, lot 6 ; John Ocock, 37 perches; South Brisbane, lot 11 ; Ditto, 37 perches, ditto, lot 12;. Martin Byrne, 32 perches, Ipswich, lot 13 ; John George; 32 perches, ditto, lot 14 ; Henry Wade, 32 perches,

ditto, lot 15 ; Ditto, 32 perches, ditto, lot 16. Deeds dated 12th September, 1846.-Government

Gazette, Nov. 13.

SYDNEY AND COLONIAL MARKETS.-Several loads of wool of this season's clip had arrived in Sydney, but at present prices are nominal. It is said that owing to the fall in England, fortunes will.be lost on last year',s purchases. On.the 13th instant skins were sold at 4 1/2d., 4 3/4d., and 6d. per lb., and are fully 20 per cent, less than last week.

Tallow is to be purchased at former rates. Flour has fallen, and may now be purchased at £14 per ton, first quality ; £12 for seconds. Wheat is from 4s. to 5s. 6d. per bushel. Hides were fetch- ing from 8s. to 9s. 6d. each; The price of cedar

ranges from 12s. to 14s per 100 feet;: and hard- wood is from 8s. to 9s. per 100 feet. The prices of sugar, tea, brandy, and: rum have not varied since our last report. On the 30th ult., at Hobart Town wheat was sold at 5s. 6d. to 5s. 9d. ; flour was £14 per ton. At Launceston oh the same date, wheat was quoted at 5s. per. bushel. The gum sent from South Australia to London realised from £40 to £44 per ton. On October 27, wheat was sold in Adelaide at 7s. to 7s 2d.; fine flour

£18 to £20 ; there was every prospect of an abundant and early harvest.

TICKETS-OF-LEAVE.-A general muster of the

tickets-of-leave, for the district of Moreton Bay, will be holden before the Police Magistrate, at

Brisbane, between the 1st and 14th days of, Januay, .1847, inclusive. All persons residing at a distance from Brisbane, will be allowed to

muster by forwarding their tickets-of-leave through their employers. INTESTATE ESTATES. - Creditors under the intestate estates, of William Thompson, late of Tent Hill, and William Southey, late of Brisbane, deceased, are to prove their debts before the Master in Equity, at the Supreme Court House, in Sydney, on or before Tuesday the 15th day of December next, in default they will be peremptorily ex- cluded from all benefit accruing from the estates of aforesaid persons deceased.

WAGES.-Extract of a letter received from New England :- October 28.-Sheep farming will

not be worth following if we are to give the wages ; the men are now asking. We are entirely in their power. It is really ludicrous hiring men just now; They boldly ask 14s. per week and a full

ration, and if you show any hesitation in acceding to their terms, they just tell you they will go

elsewhere. Whilst I was absent, -------- could not get a soul at the station to grind wheat, being told that, as long as they could get 14s a week shepherding; they would not go to the mill to grind, at 2s. per bushel ! So that on my return there was scarcely a grain of flour on the station. I can assure you it is all very well to say you will not hire this man or that, but now we are only

too glad to get men at all. God knows what wages will be going by and by ; if they go on

this way much longer we shall all be ruined. Extract from another letter from the same district, of date October 22 ;- Wages given to men now vary from 12s. to 20s. per week. I am giving 14s., and cannot get men to stop for it. The bullock-drivers demanded £ 1 per week before they

would take the drays to-----; Sydney Herald,

November 12.

ASSAULT.-At the Police-office, on Tuesday, one of the soldiers belonging to the detachment stationed in the town, named Gill, was brought before the Magistrates charged with having assaulted a woman named Massey, wife of a brickmaker, while crossing the river in the ferry boat on the previous day. The case was proved against him, and he was fined 20s., and costs, which penalty was subsequently mitigated to 10s.

This is the first complaint which has been brought against any of the soldiers since they have been in Brisbane, and we trust it will be the last. They should bear in mind that they are placed here to keep the peace-not to break it.

THE GOVERNOR.-We learn from the Maitland Mercury that His Excellency is now on his tour in the midland districts. He arrived at the vine- yard and seat of H. H. Macarthur, Esq., on the 9th instant, where a large party was invited to meet him. His Excellency left on the 11th inst., and proposed to make the Twenty-mile Hollow his first stage, to reach Hartley on the following day, and on the next he was expected to honour William Lawson, Esq., of Macquarie Plains, with his company.

TWENTY-FIVE POUNDS REWARD OR A CONDI- TIONAL PARDON.-Whereas it has been repre- sented to His Excellency the Governor; that Mr. Andrew Gregor and a female servant in his em- ployment, have been recently murdered by the native blacks, at the Pine River, in the Moreton Bay district :-Notice is hereby given, that a Re- ward of Twenty-five Pounds will be paid to any free person or persons who may secure and bring to justice the murderer or murderers, or if a prisoner of the Crown, application will be made to Her Majesty for the allowance to him of con- ditional pardon.- Government Gazette.- [We notice with satisfaction the foregoing announce- ment, and trust that immediate steps will be taken by the authorities here for the apprehension of the murderers. It will be seen by our advertising

columns that a further reward has been offered, to be paid out of the funds raised by private sub- scription for the capture of Horse Jemmy, the principal in the murder of the late unfortunate Mr. Uhr, on the Brisbane River. We take ad- vantage of the present opportunity to suggest the propriety of a sum being contributed towards the general fund by the relatives of the deceased, and feel assured that the parties to whom we refer will perceive the necessity for this being done with promptitude. There is a very strong feeling on the subject, but we have no desire to comment further upon it. We hear that very few persons residing in the country, who have put down their names, have as yet forwarded their subscriptions to the Treasurer. This is not as it should be, and we trust that they will pay up without further de- lay, as that gentleman cannot reasonably be ex- pected to advance the necessary funds out of his own pocket.]

PORT CURTIS AND THE BOYNE.-Since the ar- rival of the Cornubia, we have gleaned a few more particulars respecting the northern coast. The steamer put into Bustard Bay, where there is no shelter tor shipping, it being apparently a large flat, with nine feet water close in shore. On land- ing, the party found a large fresh water lagoon near the beach, but no indication of the vicinity of any river. They then visited Rodd's Bay,

about ten or twelve miles to the southward of Port Curtis, which is a very fine harbour, and easy of access. The country was very hilly and openly timbered, but no fresh water was found near the shore. When the steamer went into Port Curtis, they found a tide running at the rate of six or seven miles an hour, and on passing through the heads, anchored in one of the finest harbours hitherto known on the Australian coasts, with room enough for the British fleet to manouvre. The depth of water varied from two to eleven fathoms. Colonel Barney and party went into every creek they could find, and landed on several islands, but, we regret to add, that in these places also their researches for fresh water were fruitless. The banks of the creeks running into Port Curtis are thickly covered with mangroves, as well as the shores of the Bay. A great many of the natives were seen ; one of them asked for flour ; they had evidently been in communication with white people before ; and it is more than probable that come of the numerous whaling vessels occasionally put into Port Curtis for spars. Numerous pieces of timber were observed strewed about the beach in the harbour, which, doubtless, were portions of wrecks that had drifted in with the tide. It is very much to be regretted that the party was compelled to return without having solved the problem respecting the outlet of the Boyne River. A gentleman of great practical experience has given it as his opinion, that the large body of back water rushing through the entrance to Port Curtis might occasion the strong tide which the steamer experienced. We are not sufficiently well acquainted with the subject to controvert this opinion. We have good reasons, however, for thinking differently. It will be in the recollection of many of our readers, that some few years back, a man named Bracefield, who escaped from this place when it was a penal settlement, was disco- vered, with the blacks by Mr. A. Petrie of this town, when he was on a boating excursion in the neighbourhood of Wide Bay. Mr. Petrie being anxious to obtain information respecting the rivers on the coast, questioned Bracefield about the Boyne when he was told that a very large river disem- bogued about, as near us he could judge, fifty miles to the northward of Wide Bay ; that its mouth was near the base of a very high conical mountain, (Query-Mount Ovens ?) standing in solitary grandeur, and which could be seen from a great distance inland. Now it so happens, that a mountain similar to that described by Bracefield was seen near the coast at Port Curtis, and there is every reason to believe that the river alluded to by him is the Boyne. Moreover, Bracefield stated that the tide was very strong at the mouth-a fact which has since been confirmed by experience. It is more than probable that, if Colonel Barney had been made acquainted with these particulars, the result of the expedition might have turned out more

favourable.

APPOINTMENT.-His Honor the Chief Justice has been pleased to appoint Robert Little, of Moreton Bay, Esquire, a Commissioner of the Supreme Court of New South Wales.

NEW MAGISTRATE.-His Excellency the Go- vernor has been pleased to appoint Henry Hughes, Esq., of Gowrie, Darling Downs, to be a magistrate of the territory and its dependencies.

THE BARAMBA CREEK.-As everything relating to the Boyne River and its tributaries, now being, rapidly stocked, is highly interesting and impor-

tant, we subjoin the following particulars respect- ing a splendid tract of country to the north-east

of Mr. Friel's station at Burrandowan, on the banks of the Boyne. The Baramba is the native name of a very large creek which runs in a pa- rallel line with the Stuart River, and which flows into the Boyne about forty miles below the Stuart. The country on the banks of the Baramba is clothed with the richest grass and herbage, and it has been already ascertained that five smaller creeks pour their waters into its ample basins. The discoverer of the Baramba, Mr. Russell, named it the Gulf Stream, from the circumstance of his having come upon a large and apparently deep sheet of water, with banks of perpendicular rocks, upwards of 150 feet high ; presenting to the eye a truly romantic and wild specimen of Australian scenery. The country in the neigh- bourhood of this gulf is very rugged and broken, rendering it difficult to traverse On horseback. About fifteen miles from the source of the Baramba at Craig Range, is Messrs. Borthwick and Oliver's new station, and, we believe, those gentleman have good reason to be satisfied with the country they have selected for depasturing their flocks and herds-it is well adapted for both. The nearest

station to Messrs. Borthwick and Oliver is that of Messrs. Ferriter and Uhr, who have lately sent a large number of sheep there. Mr. Corfield, who has a temporary station between the runs of the parties above mentioned, intends removing his flocks to beyond the station of Messrs. Ferriter and Uhr, immediately. From the last out-station to Brisbane, the distance, as the crow flies, is about 150 miles, and it is generally supposed that a good road to Messrs. Graham and Ivory's, or Mr. Bal- fours stations, might be found without much dif- ficulty. Should this be accomplished, the distance from the township to the confluence of the Ba- ramba will not exceed 170 miles. About fifty miles from its source, the creek is about thirty yards in breadth, and the water, which flows over a sandy bed with innumerable mud-flats, richly grassed in dry seasons, is described as being very soft, .and admirably adapted for sheep-washing ; in fact, the water in this part of the country is of the best and purest quality. Several of the water-

holes are upwards of a mile in length, and very deep. The ridges are sound, and lightly timbered with broad-leaved dwarf iron-bark and apple-tree. There are also numerous apple-tree and gum flats, but these localities are not so well adapted for grazing purposes. As it usually happens, the heads of the creeks have been found to be the most eligible spots for stations. The distance between the Baramba, or Gulf Stream, and the Stuart, is about twenty miles ; and from the Ba- ramba to the coast, it is supposed to be about sixty or seventy miles. A gentleman recently arrived from the Baramba informed us that they have had but little rain there lately ; there was, notwith- standing, plenty of water everywhere. The natives have not made any attempt to molest the new settlers. We learn that upwards of sixty thousand sheep from the southward are on their way to the Boyne ; and there is every probability that after the shearing has been completed, a grand rush will be made for the newly-discovered country by our enterprising and adventurous squatters.

A West Indian contemporary publishes this pithy and unquestionable axiom :

The man that in the world would rise, Must take the news and advertise.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1846.
snippet: PERHAPS no movement that ever had in this colony the support of a large body of rational beings has caused greater excitement than the movement against the

articleText:
THE

MORETON BAT COURIER.

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1846.

It is admitted by all the opponents of the transportation system, that there is an urgent demand for labour-that it is ab- solutely necessary we should be supplied from some source ; and yet amongst all those persons who are so clamorous against it, not one has pointed out any feasible plan whereby our wants can be adequately relieved. Some, it is true, have proposed that a loan should be raised in England to meet the cost of free immigration ; but we would ask where is the security to come from ? Will the capitalists in the metropolis come forward at their own personal risk and give that security ? We opine not. They have had quite sufficient experience as regards the withdrawal of the trading capital of the colony for emigration purposes, some few years back, to admit of their entering into any such engagements in future. Even allowing, for the sake of argument, that monied men were willing to co-operate with the squatters-the great employers of labour in this colony-where are the labourers to come from ? Surely the pseudo moral- ists and philanthropists at the Market street meeting must be grossly ignorant of

the real state of the labour market-in England, or they would not have at- tempted to oppose the introduction of convict-labour under the terms proposed by the Legislative Council. It is a posi- tive fact, that the depression in the value of shares in railways now being con- structed in England, is to be attributed to the scarcity of labourers. In a recent number of the Railway Chronicle, it is stated that if Parliament were to pass one fifth part of the Railway Bills during the session, the construction of many of them would be impossible, owing to there being

no hands to work them. The article to which we allude shows so clearly the state of the labour market in England, that we have extracted the following for the in

formation of our readers :-

We have obtained returns from about 500 miles of railways now under construction, and we find that on them there are now employed 29,000 men and 3000 horses. This amount comprehends one-fourth part only of the lines now in progress of construction ; therefore we may assume 120,000 men and 12,000 horses are the total number em- ployed. The wages paid for these men and horses is £500,000 per week,or £26,000,000 per annum, directly expended on railway wages.

This consists of wages merely for men directly employed on the line. Half as much again is expended indirectly on labour, preparing rails, chairs, stocks, &c, for the line, and on land and other materials as much more.

We have stated that on 500 miles we have re- turns of 29,000 men and 3000 horses employed. But this is not the proper quantity required for the labour. We have before us the engineers' returns, by which we find that they require, in order to complete the work in time, an additional supply of nearly 20,000, or that 48,00.0; men and 5000 horses are the proper numbers that should be employed. Moreover, we find that these addi- tional men must be had in order to do the work already stipulated. These additional men cannot be obtained, and the very attempt to obtain them would merely have the effect of enhancing the cost of the present hands, without materially in- creasing the supply.

We see, therefore, that the present supply of hands is deficient-that any attempt to increase the supply would fail, because it would enhance prices beyond all possibility of profitable investment. We do not believe, as an eminent engineer has stated, that present prices are 50 per cent, dearer than this time last year. This is an exaggeration. Prices are however, kept down only by the wisdom which has hitherto moderated the demand to the means of supply. Let us have an injudicious in- crease of demand, and prices will at once become preposterous.

The prospect, therefore, of bringing into the railway labour market, which already makes a demand of £26,000,000 per annum, a demand of 40, 50, or 100 millions, with which we are now threatened, will simply be to paralyse all means of exertion-to bring to a stand-still all the lines in progress, as well as those in prospect. The effect on the prosperity of the country will be two-fold-an unprecedented demand for money, a general paralysis of labour. The labourer will be striking for all wages and no work ; the specu- lator steering on all expenditure and no returns. The work will stand still, but interest of expendi- ture and remunerating investment will go on. Bills become due with even greater certainty than dividends.

With these facts staring us in the face, it is the height of folly to expect that emigration can be resumed, for several years to come, on a sufficiently extensive scale to supply our increasing demand for labour. The Home Government knowing that the want of labourers is sensibly felt throughout the United Kingdom, are not likely to resort to the bounty system, when the population is already more than fully employed on railways, and in the agricul-

tural districts.

From the evidence of the witnesses ex-

amined by the Transportation Committee,

we learn that the number of labourers

immediately required by the colonists is upwards of 10,000. To introduce this number into the colony, it would require the sum of £200,000, being a fourth part of the specie in all the banks, and equal to the whole circulating medium. To send that sum of money out of the colony would be a suicidal act, and would be attended with the greatest inconvenience, and perhaps ruin, to many of the em- ployers of labour.

It is not our intention to dwell on the

immense importance of our having a con- tinuous stream of emigration to these shores-it must be obvious to every one ; and we consider that those persons who so pertinaciously endeavour to throw obsta- cles in the way of its accomplishment, are guilty of the most egregious folly-they are men who, like the Puritans of former times, would " hang a cat on a Monday for killing a mouse on a Sunday." It must not be supposed however, that the assemblies which have been got together for the consideration of this important subject, have been of the nature of public meetings ; besides being meagrely attend- ed, they have all been of a character pre- cluding all possibility of discussion. In fact, the speakers treated it as a moral and religious question, and not as what it really is, a question for the political eco- nomist to decide. It is all very well for people in towns, who know little or no- thing about the bush, to prate about the contaminating influence of this class of men and the other : such speeches may have the effect of frightening old women and children, but they will not take well with " children of a larger growth." These meetings are, therefore, worthless, as an indication of public opinion ; they are, however, of great value, as showing the utter imbecility and helplessness of the anti-transportation party. Such is their feeling against the introduction of convict labour, that they are startled, be- wildered, and .angry-afraid of everything and everybody-afraid of the Government

-afraid of the Council-afraid of Mr. Wentworth, and, above all, afraid of themselves. Of course, they are unani- mous in abusing the pro -transportationists ; but they do not seem to agree any farther.

Among the mass of valuable evidence, upon which the Report of the Transporta- tion Committee is founded, that of Mr. Boyd is best deserving of attention. His opinion is decidedly in favour of the re- sumption of transportation, under the condition that the men should be landed

at Portland, Twofold Bay, and Moreton Bay-thus avoiding the large towns, where their labour is not so urgently re- quired, and where they would be in dan- ger of renewing their former habits Mr. Boyd bears testimony to the usefulness and good conduct of the ticket-of-leave holders in his employ, and says that he would greatly prefer that class of men, unless the future selection of, immigrants are of a character different to what he has

been accustomed. We coincide entirely with this opinion, and to prove that it is correct, we Have only to refer to the general good conduct of persons of the same class in this district. In the two districts, there are at the present time 231 ticket-of-leave .holders, and during the

last twelve months,, not one has been de- prived of his privilege, nor has there been one conviction, as far as we know, for felony or misdemeanour. We would strongly recommend that the labourers, when they arrive here, should be provided

with some document similar to a ticket of-leave, and that it should be registered by the Bench of Magistrates.

We learn from the evidence of Mr. Sprott, of Port Phillip, that the Emigra- tion Society, at Geelong, have imported, during the last two years, upwards of 700 expirees, or persons with conditional par- dons-they were the refuse of Van Die- men's Land, are great vagabonds, and a

wretched class of men. The Pentonville

Exiles, on the contrary, have turned out to be the best class of men the settlers have ever had ; and, as a body, superior to the immigrants sent from home. About 280 have been landed, and they have proved a valuable acquisition to that district. The Exiles are a young and hardy class of men, ranging from eighteen to twenty eight or thirty years of age.

Similar testimony has been furnished by the other witnesses ; and yet, in the face of all these facts, we find that some of the colonists are objecting to the importa- tion of picked and well-behaved prisoners from England, at the expense of the Home

Government ! We have to deal with

facts, and not to combat against shadows. With an efficient police force beyond the boundaries, no danger to life or property need be apprehended from the introduction of semi-penal labour into the districts, as some few visionary alarmists seem to an- ticipate.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1846.
snippet: IT is admitted by all the opponents of the transportation system, that there is an urgent demand for labour—that it is absolutely necessary we should be supplied

THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, JULY 25, 1846.

OWING to the crowded state of our columns, we have been compelled to leave out what

is usually termed the leading article, to make room for subjects of great local in- terest. We had intended to make some remarks on the Census, but they are una- voidably postponed until next publication.

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1846.

AT the close of the first quarter of its existence, the Courier offers its salutation to its numerous readers, and the families where it has been a frequent, and, it is to be hoped, not unwelcome visitant.

The rapid progress of society in civili- zation and the arts, the speedy communi- cation and frequent intercourse subsisting between these colonies and all parts of the globe, their vast extent and steady ad- vancement, the busy enterprise of its centre of power and intelligence in England, furnish materials far ampler than heretofore for the weekly journalist to accumulate, condense, and arrange. It is the intention of the proprietor of the Courier, therefore, to keep pace with the exigencies of the times, by furnishing occasional supplements, so as to compre- hend the extended boundaries of informa- tion. The great difficulty experienced

throughout the colony in procuring sup- plies of paper, has prevented the proprietor from permanently enlarging the journal ; but he hopes to be enabled to do so at the end of the year, should the support, which he anticipates, be afforded to him.

In discussing the ever varying topics of the day, we have endeavoured to give the most correct version possible of every event, but distance, and various other circumstances, render this sometimes diffi- cult ; for, we believe, nothing can be more injurious to a paper than to promul- gate falsehood. We shall apply the philosophy of truth to every subject, con-

vinced that our efforts in the end will be crowned with success. Another cardinal principle in the conduct of this paper we shall endeavour to maintain, is the right of private thought and action, the un- biassed expression of our opinions, re- strained only by the proper bounds of moderation, and of what we hold to be truth. If thus we can support the good cause in which we are engaged, it shall, have our support, but no further. A more fleeting and fickle popularity may, per- haps, be won by greater subserviency to party and to local prejudices, and to evanescent interests and influences. Such times-serving management we have striven to avoid, and to that course we purpose to adhere. For we feel confident that no

good cause can be usefully aided by such means ; that any influence which a journal can exert, to be useful and respected, must be voluntary and unfettered. The only

alliance which we have been desirous to maintain, and which it is our continued endeavour to perpetuate, must be founded on agreement of principle, on similarity of sentiment between the public writer and intelligent men in other stations of life, to whom it is his business to com- municate information, and between whom and the journalist there is consequently fostered that reciprocal good understand- ing and goodwill which, on our part, we desire at the end of this, our first quarter, sincerely to express to all who, during the period it has been in existence, have favoured the Courier with their honourable and valued support.

AUSTRALIAN BEEF.

" WE can never look beyond the colonial market for consumers of our beef," is a common cry with a class of men happily and aptly termed croakers, who, we are sorry to say, are somewhat numerous even in New South Wales. These look upon anything like improvement with horror,

and can never be convinced of the bene- ficial effects which flow from well-directed

enterprise, while it is possible to be scepti- cal. , If an intelligent, far-seeing colonist, deviate from the path, long-trodden, of established usage, and disregard the set form of legitimate enterprise-their united tongues clamour at what they, forsooth ! term his folly. His daring conveys a

tacit condemnation of their own want of

spirit and activity, and they both predict and wish his failure. Thus, we remember, the cultivation of the vine was derided

the export of hides--the making of gela-

tine-the manufacture of tweeds-the

refinement of sugar. Boiling animals to obtain their fat, was stigmatised as wanton waste ; and as for salting beef for expor- tation, ask a croaker:-" Sir," he will answer you, " our natural grasses have no substance ; our beef must be eaten fresh; or it is worthless. The antiseptic pro- perties of salt certainly prevent putrifac- tion, but dry up at the same time both fat and juice." Such an opinion was cer- tainly fortified by the result of the first shipments to England : badly cured and badly packed, when they arrived the con- tents of the casks were fit for nothing but manure. That this, however, was not a fair test of the qualities of Australian meat, both colonial and home experience have since abundantly proved. Our en- terprising townsman, Mr. John Campbell, has at this moment salted beef in his possession, which he cured two years ago, and which is even now perfectly juicy and sweet. And shipments home have been made, from various parts of the colony, which have been lately advised as profita- ble. The secret lies, in proper curing and packing ; and no man, unless thoroughly acquainted with these, can prudently engage in the salting of meat, either for

home or colonial markets.

We feel much pleasure in quoting the subjoined from a Port Phillip contem-

porary :

Messrs. Watson and Wight shipped several tierces of Port Phillip beef (killed and cured under their superintendence) by the William Stoveld, in May, 1845, and their speculation has been crowned with the following highly satisfactory advices, dated 25th March, from their London brokers, respecting the complete success of the export :

" We have to report upon the casks of beef, and we regret the party we employed, who is considered one of the best judges in the market, has deferred giving it, so as not to admit of our sending it by an earlier opportunity. It appears that the quality is excellent, equal to American, which, after many difficulties, is in high favour, and is gradually supplanting the Irish. It is likely the Australian beef will have to undergo the same severe ordeal to establish its character, but will eventually be able to compete with its rival. The present price of American beef of similar quality is from £4 2s. 6d. to £4 4d. per tierce of 304 lbs." These facts

clearly prove that such objections as the length of the voyage, and the heat of the wool ships (nearly the entire freight of the Stoveld being composed of that staple) are no serious obstacles to the healthy arrival of the meat, if carefully cured. The above-mentioned firm have, we learn, im- proved upon their former method of curing beef for the home market. We sincerely trust that such is the fact, as, without some outlet of greater extent than we at present possess for our surplus stock, or in the absence of a commensurate supply of labour to preserve it, the grazier will be com- pelled to look solely to his wool, and even restrict the growth of that commodity to a certain limit.

THE SYDNEY POST OFFICE.

AN injudicious, though well-meant prac- tice, obtains at the General Post Office. Mails for Moreton Bay are made up and despatched by every vessel in the trade, from the Tamar, steamer, down to the paltriest timber tub ; and sometimes we receive intelligence of letters in transitu that do not arrive for weeks afterwards. This is often productive of serious incon- venience and perplexity, important docu- ments expected by the steamer, being forwarded by a trumpery sailing-boat, which is perhaps wind-bound at an inter- mediate port for a fortnight.

No necessity exists for sending mails by sailing crafts. The Tamar performs her trips with regularity, and her voyage to Sydney and back seldom occupies more than twelve days : ensuring as much cer- tainty and quickness of communication as we can, at present, reasonably expect. We hope, therefore, that the Postmaster general will see the propriety of directing that in future all letters and newspapers shall be forwarded by the steamer.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1846.

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1846. THE UPSET PRICE OF LAND.

On the 25th of September, in the Legis- lative Council, Mr. Lowe brought forward the resolutions of which he had given notice respecting the present Upset Price of Land, which were :

1. That the raising the upset price of land, first to 12s., and afterwards to £1, per acre, has

rendered waste land unsaleable.

2. That while this price is maintained, the squatting question can never be settled on a just and satisfactory basis.

3. That the upset price of land ought to be reduced to a sum not exceeding its value.

With the first and last of these proposi- tions we entirely agree, but with regard to the second our opinions widely differ. Mr. Lowe in his very eloquent speech on this vitally important question, argues against the leasing system on the ground that the lessees would sub-let, and the lands would be covered with such tenants, and that when their leases expired the Government would have to turn them

out. Mr. Lowe is evidently desirous of checking the growth of squatting, and talks of dangers to arise from the leasing system, which never had, and probably

£. s. d.

2

8 1

never will have, existence. The price of land has little to do with the squatting question, and any reduction in the price could not affect the interests of graziers, any more than it would those of other classes of colonists. . The occupation of Crown Lands by license is essential to the well-doing, and even the existence of the pastoral community. If the price of

land were, reduced to-morrow, there would still be the same, necessity for squatting, and we look upon any attempt to check it as a suicidal act, as far as the accele- rated progress of the colony is concerned.

The real grievance the colonists have to complain of is the enormous price of the town and suburban lots of lands, as fixed by Sir George Gipps, whose impo- litic regulations-whose wretched misrule —caused land sales and emigration almost entirely to cease. It is a well-known fact that the price of one acre of land in this colony is ten times as dear as one at the Cape of Good Hope, and yet one acre there, is, according to a report-fur-

nished to the Government, worth three in Australia. . In order to draw a contrast, we shall state the upset price of land in the following colonies :-

Lower Canada.... 0 4 11 Elsewhere in ditto. 0 3 3 New Brunswick..... 0 2 8

Nova Scotia .......... 0 1 9 Newfoundland.... 0 2 0 Cape of Good Hope ... 0 2 0

Australia...... 1 0 0

From which it appears that the greater the distance from home, and, of course, the greater the risk and expense of transit, the dearer Crown Lands become. The author of " Six Years' Residence in the Australian Colonies," says, the reason why land is so dear in this colony is to be attributed to the following cause :—

When the Whigs were in power, they granted a large portion of New Holland to certain of their supporters, under the designation of South Aus- tralia.—At that time land was selling in Australia at half-a-crown per acre ; but at this low price the job would not be a profitable one. The upset price of lands was therefore raised to £ 1 per acre ; and in order to put all Australia on the same footing, the upset price of Crown lands was raised to the same exorbitant and ruinous rate in the old co- lonies. The consequence has been, that land sales have all but ceased ; and in order to prevent more disastrous results, the Government were obliged to pay the debts of South Australia, and take the management of the colony into their own hands. This scheme had been concocted by a theoretical visionary, called Wakefield, and was styled the self-supporting principle, but, like other bubbles, it burst. The Governor of Western Australia compared the result of this hair-brained scheme to that of a man riding at full gallop, when suddenly the horse stands still, and the rider is thrown over his head. Land sales and emigration ceased.

The present absurd price of land in the neighbourhood of the townships in this District, has tended more than any- thing to retard our prosperity, and yet we find the system of high rates is still continued, and that land is only doled out in small quantities, to create compe- tition and to enhance its price.

We shall recur to this subject in our

next.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1846. THE UPSET PRICE OF LAND.
