articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, JULY 13, 1843.

THE NEW COLONY.

IN the House of Lords, on the 3rd March, Lord Stanley made the following remarks respecting the new colony that is shortly to be established to the northward :-" The Government to which he had belonged had thought proper to appoint an addi- tional colony to the north of the colony of New South Wales, beyond the limits assigned to that colony, the new colony not being too near the tropics to prevent its being a healthy colony. It was in- tended that a number of those convicts who had reached the most advanced, that was, the lightest stage of penal discipline, should go to that colony, where they would be furnished with provisions for a limited period, and also a portion of land. They would also be permitted, if they thought proper, after a certain interval, to emigrate to the adjoining colonies, and become the servants of the outlying popu- lation of those colonies. The class of convicts who would be sent to this new colony would be those who, when they arrived there, would be in the position of having received a conditional pardon."

Should the foregoing plan be carried out, it cannot fail of benefiting the free settlers in Van Diemen's Land, because it will relieve them of a great portion of the con- vict population, for whom they have no employment ; at the same time the parti- cular advantages likely to accrue to this district, will be immediate and important, inasmuch as we shall be able to procure adequate supplies of labour, and also an outlet for our surplus stock, in the shape of salt provisions. There is one part of the plan, however, which is highly ob- jectionable, and that is the giving land to the convicts, thus placing them in a much better position than men of virtuous cha- racter. It would be offering a premium to vice, and tend more than anything to lower the standard of respectability among the free settlers. Moreover, we look upon such a scheme as quite impracticable, because Government would have to supply them with agricultural implements, as well as stock, for it is not to be supposed that men in their position will be possessed of the requisite capital to enable them to carry out the mistaken views of such spe - culative philanthropists.

With regard to the place where the new colony is to be formed, all the reports agree in stating that it will not be within the tropics. So little is known of the coast to the northward of this port, that it is impossible to form an accurate opinion re- specting the eligibility of any particular part as a site for the new settlement. It will, no doubt, be minutely surveyed be- fore Government decide upon a subject of such magnitude. It has been stated that there was a probability of the new colony being established in the neighbourhood of the Boyne River, which is supposed to fall into Rodd's Bay at Port Curtis, about one hundred and eighty miles from this port. This place is the natural outlet of most extensive and beautiful tracts of country ; and we should be sorry to see a penal settlement formed there, because it might possibly be the means of prevent- ing the squatters, at some future period, from taking advantage of its known ca- pabilities as a shipping port. Thirteen stations have already been taken up on the Boyne River and its tributaries, and it is more than probable that in the course of another year upwards of forty stations

will be formed there.

Whatever plan may ultimately he adopted in forming the new settlement (not strictly penal), we hope and trust the labour of the convicts will be made useful as well as productive ; and that the interests of the future free population will not be lost sight of.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, JULY 18, 1846. THE NEW COLONY.

articleText:
" THE GIPPS TESTIMONIAL."

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,—Directly I sees that 'ere modest advertise- ment of our respected Sub-Collector, you may be sure I went the whole hog in the matter—for he was a rum'un the late commanding officer of the colony ; that's a fact.

I say, Mr. Editor, only think of some of these here people wishing to persuade us that we didn't like glorious old George. By Goleys, it's a shame.

I asked one of these chaps for a subscription t'other day-to stump up for the testimonial, you know. Well, what d'ye think he said.

" Why," said he, " if you asked me to give my

mite in aid of the erection of a monumental em- blem of the selfishness, injustice, and caprice of Sir George Gipps, I would cheerfully do so. But such is not required. No. Broken hearts, ruined fortunes, lost energies, the death of hopes, dearest and best, and closest allied to man's ex- istence, the confusion of our social elements, with a long train of lamentable, inevitable results, too plainly attest that neither in this; generation nor the next, will his misrule be forgotten. What ! shall I libel myself and run counter to public feeling by adding to those who outrage common decency by beslavering and testimonializing. I am an Englishman, sir ; not a degenerate time- server. Give me my bark-hut and independence; let those, who will, belaud the grossest political prostitution."

After all, he's a good customer, and pays fairly (you may take his order with safety), so my dander didn't riz, as it would, if he had been a glass-o'- water-and-a-tooth-pick-cove. So I said he was

mistaken.

" Mistaken," he bawled out-and now he was in a rale pelter-" mistaken in the character of a Governor who recklessly broke the most solemn of compacts, entered into between the colony and his predecessor, who played the part of a peddling land jobber, who did all he could to foster unsound credit and extravagant speculation, to transform the Representative of Majesty into a greedy chap- man and our capitalists into land sharks ; who aimed to reduce the most important class of our co- lonists to crouching serfs, without either the power or the will to resist oppression ; who raised up contemptible oligarchies from among the dregs of the people; whose greedy exaction of dormant and forgotten quit-rent claims ruined hundreds of deserving families ; who recognised base ser- vility, recommendations from Ministers, or the ties of blood or friendship, as the only claims worthy of notice in filling up the various public offices ; whose talents were never conspicuous save in making a case out against the colony ; whose

District Councils-whose-whose-"

Seeing he had fairly run himself out of breath, I just took him up in my quiet way,

" Well," said I, " old fellow, that's all very fine -you coughs-but who cares about all that 'ere. That's what we call his public character, and all that sort of thing. By Goleys, if a Governor is wanted, give me a man who sets an example of economy to the people-who gets five thousand a year and lives upon one-who, when he gives a party, goes round the town and buys up all the stale pastry at half-price, and gives lots of cheap Cape. A man who's quite moral, too ; who's never seen drunk in the streets, and is fond of his lawful wife ; who kills his own mutton ; im- ports his own wine and carriages, and almost everything else, direct from England ; pays his tradesmen's accounts in butter and cheese, made by convict labour at Parramatta Domain ; and whose own gifted and venerated consort-God bless her-keeps the key of her own fowl-house, sets her own hens, and sells the surplus eggs. Give me an economical, sober, steady man, like this, fit either for a shepherd or a governor, and I don't care a button for your politics and public

stuff."

But he only laughed, and called for another glass of brandy and water. So I went to the till, and counted the coppers-

There was just 11¾d., which I beg to state will be paid to the order of the Sub-Collector, on ac-

count of the Testimonial.

Your admiring subscriber,

XXX

East-street, Ipswich,

17th August, 1846.

P.S.-Hope you will give a list of names. At present, we have only heard of the following

£ s. d.

First official gentleman.... 5 0 0

T'other official ditto.... 3 0 0 The Experiment, in consideration of a

bad road to Limestone....0 1 0 The puntman, ditto.....0 0 6 The Brisbane ferryman, in considera-

tion of the monopolised and restricted

means of communication between N.

and S. Brisbane.....0 1 0

The Kangaroo Point ferryman, ditto.. 0 0 6 The importers of hay and corn, in con-

sideration of no agricultural lands

having been sold....... 0 0 3¼

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1846.

WASTE LAND BILL.

THE Bill to amend the Act for regulating the Sale of Waste Land, introduced by Mr. Hope into the House of Commons at the close of the last session of Parliament, as our readers are probably aware, did not proceed beyond a first reading. A copy has since been forwarded by Lord Stanley to Sir George Gipps. It would be pre- mature to offer any decided opinion upon the Bill in its present shape, as the details are very vague and undefined. The views of Government, however, have been made known by Lord Stanley in his despatches, which are explanatory of its intended operation.

The Bill as originally introduced was designed to effect four objects, viz :—To remove any doubts which might be enter- tained of the power of the Crown to grant leases of unsold waste land ; to remove a similar doubt as regards the reservation of minerals ; to establish a fixed annual pay- ment by way of agistment for all stock depastured on unsold Crown Lands, in lieu of rent or fee for a depasturing li- cense ; and to appropriate the whole pro- ceeds to be raised under the Bill to the

same purposes as those to which the pro- ceeds of sales are devoted by the original Act, 5 and 6 Vic. c. 36.

The first clause of the Bill empowers the Governor to grant leases for seven years at an annual rent, such leases to contain clauses of forfeiture, and provisoes

for re-entry for non-payment of such rent, or for underletting or assignment of

the whole without leave first obtained from the Governor ; the lease thus for- feited to be offered by public auction to the highest bidder. During the continu-

ance of such lease, however, it will not be lawful for the Governor to sell the re- versionary estate expectant upon the de- termination of such lease without the consent in writing of the lessee, or other party to whom the lease may then belong. By this clause, it appears, the Governor may or may not, as he sees fit, put up

leases to auction.

The second clause provides for the re- servation of minerals for the use of the Crown. Lord Stanley, however, in his des- patches intimates that provided a fair royal- ty be preserved to the Crown for the benefit of the public, Government would not ob- ject to vest in the grantees and purchasers from the Crown the right to the minerals.

The third clause proposes to repeal sec. 17 c. 36 of 5 and 6 Vic. relating to the granting of licenses for the occupation of waste lands under certain conditions, and for felling timber on such lands. This will not affect any license that may have been granted previously to the day when the Act comes into operation.

By the fourth clause the Governor is empowered to grant licenses for occupation of waste lands for twelve months, or for felling, removing, and selling timber. The reduction of the former upset price of occupation licenses is left to the dis-

cretion of the Governor.

The fifth clause specifies the penalties to be enforced for unauthorized occupation

of Crown Lands.

It is proposed by the sixth clause to grant licenses to occupiers of waste, lands without fee or payment of the same, and in lieu thereof to levy a capitation tax of one penny for every sheep, and three pence for every horse and head of horned

cattle.

The seventh clause enacts that when any waste land beyond the Boundaries shall have been occupied by any person under license for a period of not less than five successive years, then next preceding, the Governor may lease such lands to such persons for seven years, at such an annual rent as may be fixed by the Governor and the Executive Council, without offering such lease by public auction to the high-

est bidder.

The remaining clauses relate, to the appropriation of proceeds for agistment, rent, &c., and other matters which it is not necessary we should particularize.

The corollary from the foregoing is, that the present annual licenses will be continued without fee, and a system of agistment will be adopted with a capita- tion tax on the stock, the proceeds of which will form part of the land fund of the colony, to be appropriated to the pur- poses of emigration.

Secondly—That persons who may have been in possession of their runs five years will have a seven years’ lease granted, at a rental to be fixed by the Governor; such lease to be exempted from auction, and their stock from the capitation tax.

Thirdly—That the Governor may or not, as he sees fit, authorize the occupation of Crown Lands under a seven years’ lease with or without auction, and give it to the highest bidder. This may affect all persons who have not held licenses for their runs the specified term of five years.

Such then is the analysis of the Bill introduced into the Imperial Legislature. We learn from Lord Stanley that it is

not the intention of the Government to supersede any system already in operation, but only to add to the modes in which the occupation of unsold Crown Lands can be permitted. The Bill does not go far enough into detail, and is objectionable in every respect. The power of the Go- vernor is not to be controlled by the Co- lonial Legislature, and in point of fact, he may do just what he pleases with the Crown Lands. No clause has been intro- duced to define the powers of the Com- missioners, the reason assigned being that by the adoption of the system of agistment the grounds of complaint regarding the extent of their powers would be removed, which we deny. Let not the stockholders be misled by the imaginary liberality of Government in granting licenses without fee or payment under the proposed system of agistment. So long as the Governor possesses the power of fixing any rental he may think proper, we apprehend they will derive but little advantage from the new measure : Lord Stanley, indeed, hints pretty broadly “that the rent ought to be large in proportion to the advantages conferred by the granting leases without exposure to competition.”

We are not prepared at present to enter more at large into this subject, nor is it necessary that we should do so. Sir

Charles Fitzroy is daily expected, and on his arrival we shall be made acquainted with the policy of Government respecting this vitally important question. He has been invested with large powers—let us hope that they will be exercised for the

good of those over whom he has been placed by his Sovereign to govern.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1846. WASTE LAND BILL.
snippet: THE Bill to amend the Act for regulating the Sale of Waste Land, introduced by Mr. Hope into the House of Commons at the close of the last session of Parliament,

articleText:
CLASSIFICATION OF CONVICTS.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir.—As your have entered with much apparent interest into the question respecting the revival of transportation to this colony, and as your pages are liberally opened to the public, whilst you wisely abstain from giving their opinions the weight of your concurrence ; I wish to draw your attention, and that of your readers, to the neces- sity of some more strict classification of the con- victs than has hitherto obtained, and without which the punishment of transportation must continue to be, as it has always been, a mere game of chance. I hope that no person will mistake my meaning, and suppose that I am an advocate for lenity to educated convicts, merely because they are such : on the contrary, l have had painful opportunities of knowing that an overwhelming majority of that description of persons are bad and dangerous men, who only use education and ability as aids to fraud and chicanery, and who therefore need a strict and

vigilant control, even more than their more openly

criminal fellows. But offenders sometimes appear at the bar of justice, and may be convicted of crimes punishable by the present laws with trans- portation, yet the infliction of that punishment in

It is not difficult to illustrate my meaning. A

youth of sixteen—perhaps in a merchant's office— seduced by the superior display of the gay con-

nexions, which even at that early age he may form in a large city, aud tempted (if I may be pardoned for using a word so hacknied in the palliation of crime) by the facilities afforded him of dishonestly increasing his means of expenditure, commits a breach of the trust reposed in him, or in some other way offends the criminal law. God forbid that I should complain if that law punishes him, or if those whose confidence he has abused deem it their duty to prosecute him as an example. It may be, indeed, that in some instances the very sight of the paraphernalia of a Court, the cold and impassable Judge, the grim officers of justice, the prisoners' dock, and the myriads of eyes around, all fixed upon him, would be sufficient of them- selves to reform the loose principles of a mind not not yet systematically vicious, and that if now pardoned he would sin no more ; but such lenity would be in every way objectionable ; it is just and proper for the well-being of society, as a terror to guilt, and as an encouragement to virtue, that he should surfer for his crime—but the punishment should be proportioned to fits capacity of feel- ing it. His offence may perhaps subject him to the severest penalty, save death, known to our laws, and he is accordingly adjudged to transpor- tation for life—" the Court awards it, and the law allows it."' At the same assize, or session, fifty others may be convicted, and the whole fifty may have been known from their childhood to every police officer in the kingdom as arrant thieves ruffians, whose creed is robbery—whose very pre- sence is contamination, and amongst whom; even MURDER is spoken of, not in subdued and whisper- ing tones, but with all the confidence of free- masonry : yet such are the " fellow-convicts" of the wretched criminal I have supposed ! Picture to yourself, if you can, the long hours of heart bursting agony he endures in gaol-the fettered progress to the hulk : chained to him on one side is a veteran receiver of stolen good, grown grey in his trade ; and on the other, a house-breaker and would-be murderer, whose prevailing regret is, that he did not " finish" his victim. Perhaps the unhappy boy may think it strange that none of these wretches should be so severely punished as himself !—but he soon forgets to draw com- parisons, in the contemplation of his own misery.

Let me pass over the hulk and the transporta- tion ship,—let me imagine that he survives the horrors of both. He has at length learned the folly and the madness of shunning intercourse with those around him—he finds not one sym- pathetic mind in all that crew of demi-fiends, yet it is best to cultivate their acquaintance, and thus avoid their brutality. Weary of the bitter scorn and infernal contempt with which his professions of previous honesty are received, he declares that he has been, like them all, a plunderer from his cradle : thus only can he hope for their forbear- ance—at best they look upon him with suspicion and distrust—his very language is not theirs, and he must adapt his tongue to their ferocious blas- phemies, and his mind to their villainous ideas ; this task may be difficult, but the voyage is a long one, and his teachers are many. Arrived in New South Wales, he is most probably assigned to the service of some person possessing already scores of convict slaves ; he has now, of course, ample opportunities of completing the education he has begun, and it is not unreasonable to suppose that a new set of ideas soon replace those which be im- bibed in his childhood, and that he grows sullen and desperate, It could scarcely be expected that the gaol or the hulk would possess the virtue of transforming him into a skilful shepherd, or an athletic labourer ; and his master, in true colonial phrase, will soon inform him that " Jack so-and- so (who has broken out of half the gaols in Eng- land) is worth a thousand like him." Here then is another example held up for his imitation, and he follows it : the consequences are obvious, he adopts the crimes of his associates, but lacks the cunning of their experience. His life afterwards is too horrible to dwell upon,—it may be ended by suicide, the lash, or the gallows : either result is natural, and some one of them is almost inevitable.

Suppose, however, we look at the bright side of the picture ; it may be his lot (for God knows it is a lottery) to meet with some kind and noble minded being who has sufficient discrimination to pity him, and sufficient generosity to sacrifice his interest in his slave to that feeling. Many such there are, and honored for ever be their names : but in the evolutions of fortune's wheel it will rarely occur that such a convict obtains such a master. Under the benign control of this good spirit his hopes may revive ; the evil influence of his late companions is soon lost in his recollections of happier days. Separated by the kindness of his patron from the contamination of such society, he becomes a sorrowful, but not a bad man ; his bitter tears for lost happiness are mingled with bright hopes and high resolutions for the future ; and though he painfully feels his present degra- dation, he also feels its justice, and consoles him- self with the anticipation that when he shall have paid the penalty of his offence, he may again hope for the sympathy of his kind, and the friendship of his equals. Years roll by, and the bonds laid upon him in the days of his youth may be broken at last in his middle age ; the brightest and best years of his life have been passed in shame and disgrace—even now his sentence of perpetual banishment remains, and he knows that he can never see again the green fields of his home. Yet he has redeemed himself at length from the hateful name of " Convict," and he turns to his fellow-man in the hope of the same mercy which has been extended to him by his sovereign. Oh! vain and foolish hope !—every eye is averted from him-the hand of friendship, outstretched towards him in acknowledgment of some congenial thought or feeling, is convulsively closed and snatched away when he confesses what he has been ; those even who are his inferiors in every respect save this one alone, affect horror at the bate suspicion of his acquaintance : some kindly but unreflective being may endeavour to cheer him-by pointing to Mr. A. or Mr. B., persons who having served sentences of transportation, have become rich and influential :—he cannot answer, for his heart

is too full ; if he could speak he would say that those men were of a different stamp, to himself— that they have no one feeling in common with him—and that many of them have only been weaned from dishonest courses by becoming con- vinced of their impolicy. His great hope was to redeem himself from the name of his disgrace. but he now finds that such hopes are futile ; of what avail would wealth be to him to counter-

balance the frightful isolation of his position ?

none ! and with shuddering horror, he at length sees that, despite his long years of suffering, he is a convict for ever !

It may be urged in answer to this, that all society should draw a line of distinction between the innocent and the guilty ; but will any person assert: that such exclusion is equally felt by all classes of convicts ? The desperate thief by pro- fession, even although reformed in this colony, would laugh in your face if you pitied him be- cause he was excluded from the society of good men ; he is accustomed to such treatment, and cares for no better company than persons of his own tastes and habits ; but the trembling penitent who would rather die than herd with them, and who is scornfully repulsed by those towards whom, from old associations, his heart warms, must be an object of compassion to the most callous : who shall guess the agony of thought to which he is doomed night and day throughout the dreary blank which remains of his miserable existence ?—the utter hopelessness of all before him !—energies withered by inaction—and talents, perhaps, with no object worthy of their employment. But death is his best friend, and comes to him at last.

This, Sir, is no overdrawn picture, such things are—then why send offenders of this description to a penal colony ? The system of probation, adopted with so much success in England, is pe- culiarly applicable to such cases; solitary im- prisonment, varying in duration with the nature of the offence, would be the most just and effective punishment: and if banishment must follow, let it not be as it has been. For the sake of that

mercy which we all hope for hereafter, let the un- happy victim of his first crime have one oppor- tunity of retrieving his fame, and do not send him forth with the foul and blighting name of " Convict" clinging to him like a leprosy for ever. Let the past be forgotten ! the ill already done no mortal legislature can repair ; but they have the future in their power, and as I fear that such cases as I have alluded to form but a very small proportion in the bulk of convictions, the adoption of a more merciful course to such of- fenders cannot materially affect the general system of transportation, which, with some modifications, and with the above exceptions, is calculated to reform the criminal while it greatly benefits the country of his banishment. Without reference to the education, connexion, or plausible manners of the offender, the most strict inquiry should be instituted into his former character and pursuits —so that the erring school-boy may never during the course of his punishment be exposed to the contaminating influence of the practised criminal, or to the odium of having been his fellow.

I am painfully sensible of the weakness of this voice from the wilderness, but if, it could reach those to whom providence has committed the charge of these things, it should not now be silent. On some future occasion 1 may address you upon the subject of classification amongst those who should be sent out as convicts-a

matter also of deep interest, and of paramount necessity.—I am, Sir,

Your most obedient servant,
heading: CLASSIFICATION OF CONVICTS. To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

articleText:
THE

Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1846.

THE WASTE LANDS ACT.

In the House of Lords on the 6th August, Earl Grey, the new Secretary for the Colonies, stated that it was intended to proceed with the Crown Lands Bill, " with

certain anendments, which he had to pro-

pose in Committee." This Bill was in-

troduced in the House of Lords in June last, by Lord Lyttleton, late Under- secretary for the Colonies, and it now appears that the new Ministry are desirous of having it passed during the present session, with certain amendments ; but what they may. be is not known. As the Bill at present stands, it is even more ob- jectionable than the one brought into the House of Commons by Mr. Hope, at the close of the last session of Parliament, an abstract of which was given in this jour- nal on the 11th July last. As soon as Mr. Cunninghame, the Port Phillip dele- gate, became acquainted with its provi- sions, he lost no time in communicating with the Home Government, and as the letter which he then addressed to Mr. Gladstone forcibly and clearly points out

the evils that will result from this mea-

sure, should it be passed into a law, we re- print it for the information of our readers in the bush, reserving our own remarks until another opportunity. The following

is the document referred to :

82, New Bond-street, London,

3rd July, 1846.

Sir,-Having accidentally learnt a few days ago that Lord Lyttleton had laid on the table of the House of Lords, on the evening of the 25th ult., a Bill, relating to the management of the waste lands in the Australian colonies, along with cer- tain despatches and other documents relating to that subject, and having since had an opportunity of perusing these documents, I now do myself the honour to address you on the Bill in question. This Bill seems to be nearly similar to the one introduced into the House of Commons on the 8th

of August, 1845, and it appears from the printed despatches that that Bill after being read a first time, was transmitted to Sir George Gipps for his remarks and corrections, and that subject to the alteration suggested by him, that Bill met his ap- proval. But it further appears, from the date at which the Bill was received in New South Wales, being the 4th January, 1846, (a period when the Legislative Council was not sitting, and would not re-assemble for two months afterwards), that no time or opportunity has yet been afforded for receiving the opinion of the Legislative Council upon it. I feel deep regret that a measure of such vital importance to New South Wales should have been re-introduced into Parliament on the strength of Sir George Gipps's approval, without pausing for the expression of the opinion of the colonists thereon, through their legal representatives,-a haste, the more to be regretted, since the almost unanimous condemnation, by the colony, of the previous measures and propositions of his Excel- lency on the same subject would have led us to hope for such delay as would have admitted the opinion of the colonists to be heard on the sub- ject,-this, however, has not been granted.

In the absence, therefore, of any such formal ex- pression of the sentiments of the colonists of New South Wales, I venture, both as a colonist, recently arrived from Australia, and in fulfilment of the mission, with which I have been publicly entrusted by the inhabitants of Port Phillip, to offer the fol- lowing remarks on this Bill :-

Passing over for a moment the two first clauses, I find that the 3rd, 4th, 5th, and 6th clauses re- enact in almost similar terms, the clauses as to license and assessment which are contained in .the Colonial Act, 2nd Victoria No. 27, and which form the present squatting system, I confess my surprise to find it thus proposed to re-enact, with all the benefit of a British statute, a system which, after having been in operation for ten years, under two stringent Colonial Acts, has been generally admitted to be injurious not only to the pecuniary interests of the colony, but to the far higher in- terests of morality and religion.

The Bishop of Australia, in a document dated 30th September, 1844, and read in the Executive Council, says, in reference to this licensing sys- tem, " the Government was therefore accessary to the evils which were springing up, in consequence of no one having a sufficient interest in what he held, to make him surround himself with the com- forts of religion and domestic life, or to introduce the institutions and ordinances on which the moral and religious improvement of communities depend."

It was with the avowed object of remedying the admitted evils of this system that Sir G. Gipps framed his " Recommendations" of 3rd April, 1844. As the latest petition from the colonists asks for a better system of tenure of the Crown lands than is given by this system-as the Legis- lative Council has clearly pointed out the great evils of the present tenure-as the Bishop has not, to my knowledge, withdrawn the eloquently ex- pressed opinions I have already quoted, as the

moral and religious ills it has given birth to-and as the Governor still expresses his wish for a better system of tenure of the Crown lands, I am at a loss to discover any sufficient grounds for thus perpetuating, under the solemn sanction of the British Parliament, a system, the evils of which are thus universally admitted and condemned. In one important particular; I find that the New Squatting Bill diners from that which it is to su- persede ;, in this way, that while the Colonial Act provides that the assessment raised should be ex- pended on the payment of the Crown Land Com- missioners, and the support of a rural police for the protection of the interior-an expenditure ne- cessarily under the controul of the local legisla-

ture-the new Bill adverts the assessment to

other purposes, and places it under the controul of the Lords of the Treasury, which would thus necessitate the levy of another tax upon the squatters for the payment of a rural police.

I turn now to the first clause, which permits, the Government to grant leases for seven years ; but premises that all such leases shall be offered by auction to the highest bidder.

For several years past the squatters have ear- nestly petitioned her Majesty and the British Par- liament to grant them a better tenure of their runs : but it can scarce be supposed that they will accept, as any compliance with their petitions, this proposal to sell off their homes-rude and humble as they may be-to the highest bidder. The effect of the loss of his run on the prospects of the squatter, I cannot better describe than in the words of the Colonial Secretary, Mr. Deas Thom- son, who says, in his evidence before the Land Committee, page 81, "To deprive a man of his station may be to deprive him of the very means

of existence."

But I beg, Sir, that it may not be supposed that the only argument of the squatters against being sold off by auction, is an argument of ad misereccrdiam. He claims relief on the grounds

of justice, from being obliged to compete at auc- tion for the right of occupation of a run, which he has discovered, defended, and improved; and which he has so discovered, defended, and im- proved on the faith that he was to be permitted, on payment of the license fee and assessment, to occupy it until it should be sold in tire regular progress of the colony.

He has invested a large capital in sheep and sheep-farming necessaries, on the faith of such a tenure. The Local Government has stood by, and has seen and encouraged such investments, well knowing the faith and belief on which such investments were made. And I confidently, Sir, put it to yourself, whether, with justice, Govern- ment can now-without object to itself-without gain to the colony-without advantage to any class-turn suddenly round on the squatter and and eject him, or endanger his ejection, from a run, the loss of which will depreciate, almost to annihilation, the capital and personal property thus placed upon the land, under the auspices of

Government itself.

Passing over the second clause, which does not

affect the squatting question, I now come to the seventh clause, which gives the Governor the power " if he should see fit" to grant seven years' leases of improved homesteads, without auction, at such rent as he may fix. Permit me, Sir, on this clause to remark, though doubtless intended as a boon to the squatter:s, it confers really no boon at all. First. Because no case of a home- stead, however long, or at however low a rent, can be of any value unless accompanied by a cor- respondingly long lease of the run attached to it, and without which the homestead would be rather a burden than a benefit. Second. Because this

Bill does not confer any right on the squatter to demand a lease, but only a power in the Governor to give it if he thinks fit. Third. Because it gives to one of the contracting parties-viz , the Government, which has a monopoly of the article contracted for,-the right of naming the sum to be paid, with a power of enforcing its own terms, by putting up the run to auction, if these terms are not accepted;

The result, then, of this examination of the Bill appears to be. that it continues the annual licensing system, which has been clearly proved to be adverse to the best interests of the colony ; adding, besides, to its present evils, by a heavier taxation, and by the absence of any control of the local legislature. That in reply to the peti- tions of the colonists for a better tenure of the waste lands (which means a tenure more inde- pendent of the will of the Governor for the time being), the first and seventh clauses of this Bill have been framed, which, under the name of con- ceding a.lease, add fourfold to the powers of the local executive, enabling it now, not merely as before, to raise the annual payments upon the whole body of the squatters, but also to press every individual in detail ; ejecting one from his run by auction, forcing an arbitrary rent from another, under the dread of being sold off, and thus controlling, under its absolute will, a class of capitalist tenants who, for birth, education, and enterprise, are unequalled by any body of tenants in the British Empire.

Under such a system, all will be doubt, uncer- tainty, and distrust, capital will be withdrawn, and capitalists will retire from an occupation which they can no longer pursue with profit, and leave a colony which they can no longer inhabit with independence,

It is unnecessary for me to comment on the details of a measure, the principles of which seem to me so entirely objectionable ; but I beg to draw your attention to the fact, that besides the danger to which this Bill would expose the squatters, if it were passed into a law, it would appear from the last sentence of a private despatch of Sir. George Gipps, dated 12th January, 1846, that they are still threatened with a compulsory purchase of

their homesteads.

For the objections to this compulsory purchase, I beg leave to refer you to the paper 1 had the honour of transmitting to you, on the 19th June

last.

* * * * * * * * *

I find I have omitted to remark that the Bill now before Parliament contains no clause for ex- tending the elective franchise to the occupants of the waste lands, and thus leaves the colony in the anomalous position of having its most wealth producing and most intelligent class entirely un-

represented.

I have the honour to remain, Sir,

Your very obedient and faithful servant,

ARCHIBALD CUNNINGHAME. To the Right Hon. W. E. Gladstone, Colonial Secretary, &c.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1846. THE WASTE LANDS ACT.

articleText:
THE

MORETON BAY COURIER

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1846.

INDIAN LABOUR.

A PAMPHLET on the " The Advantages of Indian Labour in the Australasian Colo- nies," from the pen of P. Friell, Esq., has just issued from the Sydney Press. Mr. Friell, it appears, has been induced at the request of his friends to furnish proprietors of stock with an account of

the practical results of Indian Immigra- tion, as exemplified by the conduct of the Coolies employed by him on his station at Tent Hill, in this district. The author premises that the opinions he has formed

are based upon a very close observation of the character and disposition of the

natives of India, during his long resi- dence in that country ; and also upon the peculiar and anomalous position, owing to the technicalities of English law, in which the employers and importers of this description of labour are at once placed on the arrival of the Coolies in this colony.

Mr. Friell says, that the native Indian is alvays suspicious of kindness, and that centuries of oppression have effaced even from their language any term by which they can express a sense of gratitude to

their benefactors. The lower castes are not guided by a sense of common honesty, even in their dealings inter se, and yet such is their appreciation of British cha- racter and British rule, that they will confide to an European what they will not entrust to any of their own blood ; this naturally leads them to look up to him whenever they find themselves in difficulties, which"" they are unable,

from their innate weakness of charac- ter, to surmount. As individuals, how- ever, they are becoming daily aware of the glorious uncertainty of the law, and weigh, with instinctive acumen, the

chances in their own favour, whenever they may have made themselves obnoxious to its penalties. In fact, it is this very uncertainty, which induces them to urge complaints against their employers in this country, in order that their agreements may be cancelled, and themselves set at liberty, to seek employment at higher

wages.

With regard to entering into agree- ments with Coolies, Mr. Friell says

That every native of India leaves his country predetermined that no contract shall be binding on him on his arrival at his destination, unless it suits his convenience. Hence the endeavours to obtain something more favourable than the stipu- lated terms, and as he does not understand English, or will at all events deny all knowledge of the language in which this agreement in all probability is written, he at once falls back upon the oft repeated, and as he thinks the unanswer- able plea, that the agreement was never explained

lo him, that he knows nothing of its contents, that a verbal promise was made previous to his quitting his country to the effect, &c. Then follows the real demand he had predetermined to make, on arriving at his destination, should circumstances

render it desirable to do so, and that without re- ference to, or in total disregard of, any previous agreement. The usual argument of a native of India, when unable to obtain the exact terms he may wish or demand, is-" Never mind, brother, let us go, and if we cannot mend the matter in the Police Court, on our arrival, we shall at all events have our bellies filled at another's expense, while here we are starving."

We fear that all this is too true It was

only the other day we witnessed the in-

difference two of the Coolies exhibited when

sentenced to be imprisoned by the Brisbane Bench. It was quite evident that it would have been useless to reason with them

respecting the impropriety of their con- duct, Headstrong and self-willed, they .appeared determined to follow their own

course regardless of such punishment as the Magistrates had power to inflict. Mr.

Friell continues--

This plea of Ignorance, so generally urged, as regards the terms of agreement, I do not hesitate to state is totally unfounded. In a word, I would venture to ask those who oppose the immigration of Indian labourers, if they really believe that any number of men can be put on board a. vessel from India for a distant voyage, without their being informed of every item of their agreement?" I am certain, if they will take the trouble to make them-

selves acquainted with the native character, they will at once pronounce the thing impossible in the present state of India. When selecting, to bring here with me my Indian servants, about twenty five in number, out of several hundred starving in Calcutta, the first question I was asked was, " What will you give me ?" and when at length matters had been adjusted, and the agreement presented to them for signature or mark, 1 never found one of them willing to touch the pen until the contents had been explained to his satisfac- tion. They will submit the corresponding copy of the agreement to other interpreters than the person engaging them, before putting their mark; but, unfortunately our own laws, and the peculiar idiosyncrasy of our officers, are the sources from whence flow the most, if not all, the inconvenience that has been, and is likely to be experienced in the importation of Indian labour. Our public officers appear predisposed to believe that in every case where an European and native of India are concerned, " the man of colour," " the poor in- nocent Hindoo," must be an oppressed party. The European mind is not prepared to find (until after repeated lessons of experience) that the Indian can be capable of the nicest subtlety, and thus comes to the question biased. The result need not be told : the line of argument I have heard from Benches in this country would produce rebellion in the best disposed Indian servants in the world ; nor can I look upon it in any other light than a premium (no doubt unintentional) for Indian dis- honesty.

Mr. Friell then instances several striking cases, which occurred at the Supreme Court in Calcutta, in illustration of the evils that arise from these " delicate hair-

splitting distinctions" in the administra- tion of law, which pervert and hinder the due course of justice between the two races--the European and the Indian.

Mr. Friell is of opinion that it will be hazardous to introduce Indian labour on

a large scale unless the Legislative Coun- cil frame laws that will make it compul- sory on the Coolie to fulfil the engage- ments entered into in his own country laws in the making of which due allow-

ance is made for the difference between the two characters. If this could be ac-

complished, he is confident that no labour in the world will give greater satisfaction than that of the Central and Upper Pro- vinces of India, provided it be for pastoral purposes, and under European supervision.

He recommends --

That an officer of Government should be ap- pointed, competent in every way to adjudicate in all Indian cases on the arrival of these people in the colony. It would afford protection to masters as well as to servants, and disabuse the Indian native of the idea that he can tamper with agree- ments, and be a gainer by so doing, under the high rate of wages common here. Amongst us there are some who are deeply interested in a dis- ruption between the Indian and his employer, whose livelihood is made to depend upon litigation in the absence of a language common to the par- ties and the Bench-hence it may be justly feared that the obligations of moral principle are lost sight of when advice conies to be administered from such quarters.

With regard to the management of Coolies, Air. Friell advises that they should be , employed as shepherds and watchmen, but not as agricultural ser- vants ; they are unfit for such employ- ment, and do not like it. As shepherds they answer better than Europeans, pro vided they are placed under the super- intendence of one who thoroughly un- derstands their character, habits, and disposition. One thing, says Mr Friell, should be strictly enjoined, the non-ob- servance of which may produce a general revolt at the station, and that is- the overseer should not expect a high degree of moral conduct and patient endurance of hard work, which he would expect

from others more alive to their moral

responsibilities. The incessant finding fault will soon wear out Indian patience, and the moment he finds that he cannot

give satisfaction he loses his energy, and his self-respect.

The wages given to the Coolies at the Tent Hill station are at the rate of 4 rupees, or 8s. per month ; to boys, 2 ru- pees, or 4s. ; and payment is made in silver at the expiration of each month ; which practice, however, has been found inconvenient, and quarterly or half-yearly payments are recommended-but whatever period may be agreed upon, "punctuality is expected, to prevent discontent, and, to an Indian mind, suspicion." The Coolies save four-fifths of their wages, the re- maining fifth being expended at the store on the station. They are engaged for five years, and at the terminations that period Mr. Friell is bound to send them back to their own country, unless their agreements have been cancelled, on ac- count of misconduct, by the Magistrates. The expense would probably be about £5 to £7, varying according to number.

The ration demanded by the Coolies on leaving their own country is as follow :

1 'Rice or flour..,...._ 7 lbs. weekly

Dholl ...... 1 3/4 "

Onions .... O 1/2 " Salt ......... 1 1/2 " Turmeric, or curry powder.. 0 1/4 "

Chilies. 0 1/2 "

Mustard Oil .... 0 1/4

If the above mentioned articles cannot be readily procured, the following may be substituted, viz.. :-

Beef or mutton. 7 lbs. Flour or rice ... 7 " Maize meal, or vegetables equiva-

lent thereto ..... 2 "

Salt ... 1/2 " To which is added a quantity of hookah stuff, valued at about 6s. per 80 lb., as an indulgence, to be withheld should they misconduct themselves. They do not ex- pect either tea or sugar as portions of their ration, such articles being looked upon as luxuries, which they have not been accustomed to. Their clothing should consist of a warm jacket, cap, and trow sers ; a pair of blankets for the winter months ; and light materials in the sum- mer, such as calico. To these two pair of strong shoes should be added, if the nature of the country should require it.

We shall recur to this subject in our

next.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, DECEMBER 19, 18[?]6. INDIAN LABOUR.
snippet: A PAMPHLET on the "The Advantages of Indian Labour in the Australasian Colonies," from the pen of P. Friell, Esq., has just issued from the Sydney Press.
title: {'id': '14', 'value': 'The Moreton Bay Courier (Brisbane, Qld. : 1846 - 1861)'}

articleText:
THE

M o r e t o n B a y C o u r i e r.

SATURDAY, JUNE 27, 1846.

WE WANT A BANK !

" I have heard it asserted, that the trade of the city

of Glasgow doubled in about fifteen years after the first erection of the Banks there ; and that

the trade of Scotland has more than quadrupled since the first erection of the two public Banks at Edinburgh. * * * * * Whether the trade, either of Scotland in general, or the city of

Glasgow in particular, has really increased in so great a proportion, during so short a period, I do not pretend to know. If either of them has increased in this propor-

tion, it seems to be an effect too great to be

accounted for by the sole operation of this single cause. That the trade and industry of Scotland, however, have increased very

considerably during that period, and that the Banks have contributed a good deal to this increase, cannot be denied."—Smith’s Wealth

of Nations.

BRISBANE numbers amongst its residents a class of persons, who flourish in young,

as well as in old communities—a class

who wait upon enterprise, or accelerate disaster—a class only prominent in a youthful and imperfectly organised society, whose members are gifted with energy, fortitude, and enterprise, or in that in whose bosom are to be found the

symptoms of decay. In short, money- lenders,—those who, unlike Signior An- tonio, do not

Lend out money gratis ; and bring down

The rate of usance here with us in BRISBANE.

—MERCHANT OF VENICE. (New reading). Amongst us, these persons are a recog- nised, and, for the present, an indispensa- ble element of our society ; their services are often needed and obtained, although, it must be owned, their reward is some- what large. Twenty per cent. is, we are told, the rate of discount charged on a good order drawn upon a mercantile house in Sydney, which, on an average through- out the year, is cashed, and the proceeds

returned to the discounter within fifteen

days after falling into his hands. This, on a rough calculation, we find to be at the rate—hear it, ye who know not Jeremy Bentham, and who look upon usury and usurers with all the horror of your grand-

sires—of FOUR HUNDRED AND EIGHTY PER CENT. PER ANNUM !

Let it not be understood that we wish to censure either usurers or the practice of usury. We hold that every man is en- titled to employ his capital or his industry as he pleases, provided that he does so without breaking the laws, and without injury to the peace and good order of society. That our money-lenders and

?????? a rate

of interest, suicidal of their occupation, and oppressive to those who may have recourse to them, is apparent from the fact that all classes are anxious for the establishment of a Bank of Brisbane, in order that the tax now imposed upon the operations of their capital and industry may be removed.

The recent great accession of sheep and cattle from other parts of the colony, the increased demand in Sydney for our pine and cedar, warrant us in estimating our exports,—which mainly consist of wool, tallow, and timber,—for the coming season, at £120,000. Half of this sum, at the least, will fall to the share of the labouring population, and will be invari- ably received in orders, drawn by their employers on their men of business in Sydney. These orders, as invariably, will fall into the hands of our merchants, trades- men and discounters, and be transmitted

by them to their agents in the metropolis,

who usually collect and remit the proceeds at a charge of two-and-a-half per cent. The rate of discount upon orders at Brisbane, varies from a moderate charge for risk, delay, and expense of collection, to 20 per cent. : the first entering into the prices of goods taken in exchange, the latter being demanded by our recognised usurers. Taking ten per cent. as an average, the sum of £6,000 will thus, during the coming season, be lost either by the labouring classes, or their em-

ployers.

By lowering the prices of provisions, and all other merchandise, by lessening the cost of subsistence, by reducing the amount of wages paid by masters, and at the same time increasing the actual remunera- tion of labour, a sufficient and steady medium of circulation, secured by the

operations of a bank, would be productive

of benefits too apparent to need remark. If the advantage that would thus result

is great, those that would accompany its extension of the commerce—of the field for the employment of our capital and industry, are yet greater. The transac- tions of a merchant or storekeeper in Brisbane, for instance, are limited by the amount of his quarterly returns, and that portion of his capital which he is at pre- sent compelled to keep as cash in hand, and which is, in fact, so much dead stock, being altogether unproductive. But were a Bank introduced, not only would that cash in hand, or dead stock, be added to his circulating capital, but he might safely and prudently obtain advances from the Bank, in the shape of bills discounted and a cash credit, equal to, and secured by, his whole bona fide property. His trade, there- fore, according to sound business prin- ciples, and the dictates of common sense, might be legitimately doubled, without his overstepping the bounds of judicious and commendable speculation. And the re- mark thus applied to an individual, might

be extended to the whole mercantile com-

munity.

The amount of capital withdrawn by the Anglo-Australian Banks from circu- lation in these colonies, " during the panic," is very large—that, by the Union Bank alone, being £606,673 ; and this

sum the Home Directors have declared

their willingness to re-apply to colonial purposes, whenever eligible opportunities may offer for its investment.* We feel convinced, therefore, that the advantages of Brisbane only require to be known to secure its participation in the benefits of banking institutions. The proofs of its commer- cial progress, which it will be our duty to record, will, we doubt not, excite general attention. In the colonies, its importance begins to be recognised. Every vessel arriving, brings an accession to its popu- lation. At present, indeed, Brisbane scarcely gives promise of its future great- ness. Surrounded by soils which now lie waste, but which only require the hand of industry to yield returns highly re- munerative, it commands a noble river, navigable a distance of seventy miles ; the banks of which, clothed with the pine, the cedar, the caoutchouc, and a great variety of valuable trees, also abound with coal, and much other mineral wealth. Already a town of considerable note, Brisbane must eventually become the outlet to an im- mense tract of land, yet unoccupied, well fitted for pastoral and agricultural pur- poses ; and its position must render it, when declared FREE, a port of refit for all foreign whalers frequenting our northern whaling grounds. In short, look where we may, we behold capabilities requiring but industry and capital for their develop- ment ; on all sides, are signs of encour- agement, and the hand-writing on the wall is plainly to be seen,—it is,

PROGRESS.

There can be no doubt that the Com-

pany which is first to step forward, and relieve us from our present confused and imperfect operations of trade, by the institution of a Bank, will in all future time, under judicious management, in spite of competitions, deserve and possess in a superior degree the confidence of the community. EXPLORATION. A LETTER has been recently received by a gentleman in Brisbane, from Dr. Leich-

* " The very large proportion of the bank's capital which is now in this country, will be in readiness to meet the legitimate wants of banking facilities, which an improved state of trade will necessarily produce, and from the high standing which the bank has attained, the directors enter- tain no doubt that, possessing as it does the con- fidence of the colonial community, it will derive in a proportionate degree the advantages of return-

ing prosperity."—Extract from the last Report of the Home Directors of the Union Bank.

( January, 1846. )

hardt, in which he briefly sketches his contemplated route. He proposes to start from Moreton Bay in October or Novem- ber next. His first course will be north- ward, as far as the River Mackenzie ; he will then, as we before stated, trace the rivers running into the Gulf of Carpen- taria to their sources ; from these he will endeavour to make the rivers running into Cambridge Gulf, always keeping to their heads, with a view of reaching Swan River. He intends, if possible, to ascertain the

northern limits of the Desert. The Doctor will take with him a number of cows in calf, and with calves, in order to secure a supply of milk ; and he has sent to several ports in the Indian seas for mules to carry the baggage and provisions of his party.

WASTE LAND BILL.

A COPY of Mr. Hope's Bill, " to amend an Act for regulating the sale of Waste Land belonging to the Crown in the Australian Colonies, and to make further provision for the management thereof," was a few weeks since officially received by the Governor. In our next, should space per- mit, we intend to offer a few remarks on this vitally important measure.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, JUNE 27, 1846. WE WANT A BANK!
snippet: "I have heard it asserted, that the trade of the city of Glasgow doubled in about fifteen years after the first erection of the Banks there; and that the trade of Scotland has more than quadrupled

articleText:
THE

MORETON BAY COURIER.

SATURDAY, AUGUST 8, 1846.

THE RESERVOIR.

The necessity for the inhabitants of North Brisbane taking immediate steps to obtain a more copious supply of pure water is generally admitted ; and, as a preliminary attempt to effect this object, we would earnestly advise that application be imme- diately made to the Government through the authorities here, to reserve that portion of land in the township, where the Re- servoir is situated, being section 22, be- tween George and Albert streets. In our opinion, this part ought to have been reserved when the township was laid out ; and it is a matter of surprise that Sir George Gipps, when he gave directions to Mr. Wade for its survey, did not do so. It is not, however, too late to remedy the blunder, and our fellow-townsmen should

at once bestir themselves in the matter.

No measures for the improvement of the salubrity of the town can be complete without an ample and cheap supply of water, not only for street cleansing, but in the dwellings of the poor, being first secured; and every year's postponement by the inhabitants, of this urgent public duty, will only render the object more

difficult to be achieved.

We have no doubt but that the new Governor will accede to the wishes of the inhabitants, when a representation is made to him on the subject. But as this is essentially a local matter, the cost of put- ting the Reservoir in repair, cutting con- duits for the conveyance of water, and fencing it in, will have to be defrayed by the inhabitants ; and on this account, we should deeply deplore any apparent indif- ference, or want of unanimity amongst them. We know how difficult it is to rouse people to work out a plan of this kind, but the advantages to be derived from it are so obvious, that we are sure no impe- diment will be thrown in the way by the authorities in bringing about an arrange- ment satisfactory to all parties. It is clear, that it has not been from deficiency of inclination, but from absolute want of means at their command, that the work has not been undertaken before this.

Several intelligent persons, whose opinions are entitled to deference from their past experience, and practical knowledge of the wants and circumstances of the town, have expressed themselves in favour of the project, and are ready to render every assistance in carrying it out.

We conceive that our suggestion might be of much benefit to the inhabitants, and, especially, that their operating harmoni- ously together to effectuate the plan we have thus briefly sketched, would conduce materially to the good of the town.
heading: THE Moreton Ba[?] Courier. SATURDAY, AUGUST 8, 1846. THE RESERVOIR.
snippet: THE necessity for the inhabitants of North Brisbane taking immediate steps to obtain a more copious supply of pure water is generally admitted; and, as a preliminary

articleText:
THE BENEVOLENT SOCIETY.

THE Annual General Meeting of the members of this Society was held at the Court House, North Brisbane, on Tuesday last, for the purpose of electing the annual committee, and auditing the accounts. The members present were:- Captain

Wickham, R.N. Dr. Ballow, Dr. Cannan, T. Adams, Esq., Captain Coley, Mr. John Richard- son, Mr. W. Kent, Mr. R. F. G. Phelan, and

Mr. Gill.

Captain WICKHAM, President, said, the Society had been of much benefit to the district. Their object was to relieve the poor, the distressed, and, the aged ; and although the income of the Society at present, was small, eighteen individuals had, been relieved, which was quite sufficient to prove, its utility. It was true, and he very much re- gretted the fact, that the contributions from the various stations in the two districts had been con- fined to three or four charitable individuals, and he would mention the names of Bracker, Leslie, and Hodgson, who had taken great interest in the welfare of the Institution. It was but fair that the settlers generally should come forward and subscribe, as the greater number of persons who had received relief were their servants. These men in coming down from the bush, indulged in vicious habits on the road, and when sickness overtook them came to Brisbane for relief. It was highly desirable that some arrangement should be made with the settlers, to induce them to raise contributions from the men at their stations, and remit the amount to the society, which could easily be done with the consent of the servants. He had no doubt, when the circumstances to which he al- luded were made known to the masters, they would become answerable for the cost of the medical

treatment of their servants.

A person named Wise enquired whether in the event of his subscribing the sum of £1 annually, he would be entitled to relief ; when he was in- formed that the subscription money would only entitle him to recommend a person for relief, not necessarily qualify the donor to receive any benefit from it otherwise, as the object of the Society was to afford relief to paupers only. Mr. Wise finding he was not to have the privilege of recommending himself, declined to become a subscriber.

The TREASURER announced that the balance in hand amounted to £41 1s. 5s.

The following resolutions were then submitted : 1st. Proposed by Captain WICKHAM, and se- conded by Captain COLEY—“That Mr. Richard- son and Mr. W. Kent audit the accounts of the Society, up to the 30th day of June last.”—

Carried.

2nd, Proposed by Captain WICKHAM, and se-

conded by Captain COLEY—“That a statement, showing the actual state of the Society, be published in the next number of the Moreton Bay Courier, with an appeal to the benevolent feelings of the public, and also to show the number of persons who have already received assistance from the Society.”—Carried.

3rd. Proposed by Captain COLEY, and seconded by Mr. PHELAN—“That Captain Wickham, Mr. Richardson, and Dr. Cannan, be appointed to act as the Committee for the quarter ending the 2nd Tuesday in October.”—Carried.

4th. Proposed by Mr. ADAMS, and seconded by Mr. PHELAN—“That the books being audited by the meeting, that a balance of £41 1s. 5s., be found against the Treasurer.”—Carried.

5th. Proposed by Captain WICKHAM, and se- conded by Captain COLEY—“That the Secretary be empowered to get an order-book to the Hospital, and a cheque-book on the Treasurer, to be printed”

—Carried.

The following is a Return of paupers treated, and

paid for by the Benevolent Society, at Her Majesty’s General Hospital, at Moreton Bay, from January, 1845, to July, 1846 :--

In 1845.

1. James McGrath, ulcus ; admitted 14th Jan.,

discharged 7th March.

2. Henry Dodd, paralysis ; admitted 4th Aug.,

discharged 3rd Sept.

3. Henry Dodd, debilitas ; admitted 5th Sept.,

discharged 19th Sept.

4. John Williams, cynanche tonsil. ; admitted

14th Oct., discharged 18th Oct.

5. Isaac Henry, prurigo scroti, admitted 17th

Oct. ; discharged 6th Nov.

6. James Burns, dyspepsia ; admitted 4th Nov.,

discharged 17th Nov.

7. Robert Albert, ulceratio ; admitted 8th Jan.,

discharged 19th Jan.

1. John Standage, rheumatismus.; admitted 15th

Jan., discharged 31st Jan. In 1846.

9. Edward Orr, ulcus ; admitted 23rd Jan., dis-

discharged 5th March.

10. John Williams, rheumatismus ; admitted 24th

Jan., discharged 3rd Feb.

11. John Groves, syphilis; admitted 23th Jan.,

discharged 10th March.

12. John Williams, suppressio urinœ ; admitted

7th Feb., discharged 21st March.

13. Edward King, scorbutus; admitted 13th Feb.,

discharged 7th March.

14. Thomas Ingram, pyrosis; admitted 24th

Feb., discharged 28th March.

15. George Horne, gonorrhea; admitted 11th

March, discharged 27th March.

16. Dominick Bulger, fistula urinatis; admitted

5th April ; discharged 12th April.

17. David M‘Indo, phthysis pulmonalis; admitted

25th May, discharged 12th April.

18. Henry White, rheumatismus et bubo ; admitted

13th July, discharged 12th April.

This Society was established in the year 1844, and is under the management of a President, Treasurer, Committee, and Secretary. The an- nual subscription is one pound, and any subscriber contributing thirty pounds in one year becomes a life member. It originated from motives of pure bene- volence on the part of several influential inhabitants of Brisbane, and now it must be classed amongst the truly valuable charities of the town. During the two years it has been in existence, much practical good has been done to suffering humanity. It is the most deplorable feature in the condition of the working classes of this colony that they make no provision, either for themselves or their families, against failure of employment, sickness, or death. The result of such a state of things is, that they have never more than a thin partition between the state of poverty and plenty. When afflicted with disease, many amongst them are quite helpless, and they then are compelled to seek gratuitous medicine as well as medical attendance. The habitual drun- kard deserves no commiseration at our hands ; but the old, the infirm, and the sufferers from casualties, can receive charitable assistance without sacrifice of true manly dignity ; and it is for the benefit of such persons that the Institution has been established ; to such persons it has already afforded relief commensurate to its income. Nu-

merically considered, the Society has not that wide and extensive influence which it ought to have upon the public, and which can only be ob- tained by an increase in its funds. Where are those who respond as they ought to the Divine injunction, “Freely ye have received, freely give,” —rich in well-doing—bountiful in alms,—is the title more to be coveted than all empty honours, and is the smoothest pillow for the weary head and heart of declining years. It behoves, then, every person, who has the means, to come forward and support this meritorious charity, else will wealth canker in the garner of the holder, and burden its possessor like Simonds of old. Be it remembered that the object of the Society is to promote the physical and moral well-being of the destitute labouring classes, and that the principles of the Society are classified in a few words of Scripture, “Let all things be done in charity.”
heading: THE BENEVOLENT SOCIETY.
snippet: THE Annual General Meeting of the members of this Society was held at the Court House, North Brisbane, on Tuesday last, for the purpose of electing the annual committee, and auditing the
