articleText:
OPINIONS OF THE PRESS.

NEW PAPER.-We have received the first two numbers of the Moreton Bay Courier, a paper published at Brisbane, Moreton Bay. Its outward appearance is respectable, surpassing the first number of any provincial journal that has come under our notice. It appears to be conducted with skill and moderation, and has at once taken a firm stand on the land question, which it avows can never be settled until the management of the land revenue is vested in the colonial legislature. Its local intelligence is rather scant, but that will doubtless be improved as the conductors become more acquainted with their work. On the whole, we are inclined to augur favourably of the More ton Bay Courier, which will be of great benefit to the district, and we hope yield a profit to the pro- prietor. The second number of the Moreton Bay Courier contains an article advocating, in strong terms, the necessity of establishing a Bank at Moreton Bay. The arguments in support of the writer's case are forcible, and from them it would appear that undoubtedly the establishment of a Bank at Brisbane would be a vast benefit to the community, and would probably be a successful speculation in itself. The rate of discount charged for orders in money is stated at 20 per cent., and as such orders are generally honoured and the returns made in fifteen days, it makes a rate of usury of 480 per cent, per annum. The future amount of deposits is estimated at £120,000, half of which it is presumed will go to the labouring classes, and will be paid in orders drawn by em- ployers on their men of business in Sydney. The expenses charged in Sydney for collecting these orders, &.c, are generally charged at 2 1/2 per cent., while the rate charged by the Brisbane discounter varies to 20 per cent. ; and taking it to average 10 per cent, £6000 per annum is thus calculated to be lost to the labourer or the employer. It is further correctly argued-that a sufficient and steady medium of circulation, provided by a bank, would lower the price of provisions and merchan- dise, and would curtail the expenses of the em- ployer, without infringing on the actual value of the wages received by the labourer. It would also afford facilities for the extension of commercial enterprise, and would prevent the inertia of dead capital-which at present prevails to a large ex- tent The Courier has shown great judgment in thus early directing attention to this important subject.-Sydney Morning Herald.

NEW PAPER.- We have received the first two numbers of the newly-started paper at Moreton Bay. It is intituled the Courier. We have no doubt from its general character that, if conducted with impartiality, the speculation will be one of gratification as well as profit to the proprietor ; and of much benefit to all concerned in the district

-Australian.
heading: OPINIONS OF THE PRESS.
snippet: NEW PAPER.—We have received the first two numbers of the Moreton Bay Courier, a paper published at Brisbane, Moreton Bay. Its outward appearance is respectable, surpassing the first
title: {'id': '14', 'value': 'The Moreton Bay Courier (Brisbane, Qld. : 1846 - 1861)'}

articleText:
LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.

THE BENEVOLENT SOCIETY.

A MEETING of the members of this Society took place on Tuesday at the Court House, North Brisbane. Present :-Dr. Ballow, Dr. Cannan, Mr. Richardson, Mr. W. Kent, Captain Coley,

and Mr. Phelan.

Mr. Richardson (Chairman) having briefly explained the objects of the meeting, the Treasurer announced that the receipts since the last meeting were £23 5s. 9d., and the expenditure £5 17s., leaving a balance in hand of £58 10s. 2d., showing that the affairs of the Society were in a highly prosperous state. During the last month no person had applied for relief.

The following resolution was proposed by Capt. Coley, seconded by Mr. W. Kent, and carried : " That a balance of £58 10s. 2d. be found against

the Treasurer.

It was then proposed by Mr. Richardson, se- conded by Dr. Cannan, and carried : .' That the following gentlemen should act as Committee for the quarter, viz.-Captain Coley, Mr, W. Kent,

and Mr. Phelan."

A man named Aston applied for relief under the following circumstances:--He had been tor some time, he said, in the employ of Messrs. C. and D. Cameron, at Tarampa, and about four months ago had the misfortune to be deprived of his wife, who died leaving three children, one of them an infant in arms. He had endeavoured to place the child out at nurse, but had not succeeded, as no one could be induced to take charge of it for less than eight shillings a week. In consequence of being burdened with the infant, he was unable to procure employment, and considering that the

best plan he could adopt would be to proceed to

Sydney, in order that the child might be admitted into some charitable institution, he now applied to the Society to assist him with a small sum to pay his passage. After some discussion, his case was referred to the Acting Committee to decide upon the matter on the arrival of the steamer. There being no other business before the meeting the members then separated.

SURVEY OF THE BAY. -Owing to the boisterous state of the weather during the week, and the continued rains, Captain Wickham and party have not been able to complete the survey of the different points on the coast. On Wednesday they were compelled through stress of weather to run for the Pine River, where they landed and encamped

until the weather moderated.

THE MAGISTRACY -On Tuesday last, several of the stockholders and other persons from the country were put to very considerable inconve- nience in consequence of their being no magis- trates on the Bench. Tuesday is usually con- sidered a Court-day, and summonses had been issued for the attendance of suitors, one of whom was a gentleman from the Logan, himself a ma- gistrate, who, of course, could not act in a case in which he was personally interested. It is need- less to add that after having been put to great expense, besides the loss of valuable time-doubly valuable at this season of the year-he was obli- ged to return to his station without having ac- complished the object of his visit to town. The only excuse than can be offered for the magis- trates is, that Captain Wickham has been engaged during the week in surveying certain points in the Bay, and was, we believe, prevented by the boisterous state of the weather from reaching town. With respect to Lieut. Blamire, the other resident magistrate, we are not aware of the reason why he did not attend. We trust, how- ever, for the sake of public convenience, that he will see the propriety of attending to his magis- terial duties, whenever the Police Magistrate is unavoidably absent. Verbum sat.

DOGS.-We believe it is not generally known that all licenses for dogs expired on the 30th ult., it will, therefore, be necessary for persons who purpose registering their dogs to do so imme- diately, or they will be liable to be fined. The forms can be procured at the office of this journal.

ESTIMATES.-The following sums for the year 1847, for the District of Moreton Bay, have been voted by the Council :-District Commissioner for Court of Requests, and Registrar, £25 each. Harbour Master, at 4s. 6d. per diem, £82 2s. 6d. ; provisions and clothing for boatmen, £160 ; in- cidental expenses, £40.

POSTAL ARRANGEMENTS.-In consequence of ill health, Mr. Slade, the postmaster, applied a few weeks since for leave of absence for three months. By the last steamer Mr. Slade received a letter from the Postmaster General, intimating that his request would be complied with, and desiring him to instruct Mr. Louis Layard, who has been ap- pointed Mr. Slade's locum tenens, in the duties of his office. Mr. Slade has been upwards of twenty-seven years in the service of Government, and during the whole of that long period has not applied for a single day's leave. Should he return to this place, which depends on a contin- gency, we trust it will be with renovated strength to enable him to resume his multifarious duties.

SALE OF CATTLE.-The herd of cattle the pro- perty of the late E. E. Dalrymple, Esq., consist- ing of 355 head, was disposed of at public auction on Thursday. There was no competition, and the lot was sold to Captain Wickham at £1 per head. Calves under six months were given in.

SALE OF FURNITURE.-The sale of household furniture and other effects, the property of Mr. Slade, took place on Monday. There was a nu- merous attendance of buyers, and the various ar- ticles fetched capital prices.

WAGES CASE.-At the Police Office, yesterday, a person, named Patrick Meham, summoned Mr. John Campbell, of Kangaroo Point, for non- payment of wages, amounting to £6 1s. 3d. The Magistrates, decided that the claim had been sub- stantiated, and ordered judgment to be entered for the full amount and costs, the usual time to be allowed for payment.

BREACHES OF THE HIRED SERVANTS' Act. --

At the Police Office, yesterday, a man, named William Smith, who had been remanded on Tues- day last, in consequence of the non-attendance of Magistrates was again placed at the bar, charged by Colin J. Mackenzie, Esq., of Kilcoy, with having absconded from his hired service on the 3rd instant. Mr. Mackenzie stated that the man had lost 47 sheep, and had overdrawn his account to the amount of £3 18s. The defendant made no

reply to the charge, but pleaded in mitigation of punishment that he had a large family to support. The Bench said, that this was a most flagrant case, and as the defendant had no excuse for his conduct, they should send him to the House of Correction, in Sydney, there to be confined for three months. This case deserves special notice at our hands. As soon as Mr. Mackenzie had ascertained that the man had absconded, instant pursuit was resolved on. Mr. Mackenzie, accom- panied by his superintendent, succeeded in tracing him to the Cunningham's Gap road, and on reaching Reynold's Creek, the object of their search was observed crossing the creek. Being resolved upon his capture, the party dismounted, and the "darbies" were put in request. After some resistance from the fellow, who drew out a pistol, and threatened to shoot them, he was with some difficulty secured, and brought to Lime- stone, from which place he was forwarded by the steamer to Brisbane, and placed in the Lock-up. If all the squatters were to act with equal prompt - tude and resolution, it would operate as an effectual check to runaways from the various stations.

THE HUNTER RIVER.-The broad bed of this river, which for so many months had been little else but a pebbly desert, is now transformed into a wide and noble river. The fresh reached Maitland on Saturday morning, the first ap- pearance being the thickening of the waters from the mud that the stream brought down. This was about half-past eleven, and by one o'clock the river had risen three feet. By the following day the water rose upwards of two feet more, the stream coming down still more rapid and muddy. and having the appearance of very strong thick lye. On Monday it had risen about eight feet. The fishes, too, might be seen in thousands lying sick on the top of the water. Yesterday evening' the river had fallen two or three feet.-Maitland Mercury, September 30.

Colonial Manufactures.-About five years ago the first iron press for a newspaper was manufactured in Sydney, under the superinten- dence of one of the present proprietors of this journal, by Mr. Creighton, engineer ; and after being used a considerable period in their office, for jobbing purposes, was conveyed to Windsor, where for the past two years it has been used not only for jobbing, but to work off the Courier, a weekly paper, established by the proprietors of the Australian, in July, 1844, but now the pro- perly of Mr. G. A. Eager. The press improves, and will continue to improve, for some time to come, the more it is used by the worthy proprietor -one of the oldest members of the Press in this part of the globe. We have now to notice a second press, manufactured by the same engineer, of rather larger dimensions, commonly known to printers as double-crown ; but on the same prin- ciple, with a slight but material exception in the increased length of pull by the bar-handle, which certainly is not an improvement, especially in these times of extraordinary expedition. However, now that we can manufacture hand presses in the colony, we trust our friends at home will send out no more consignments in that line. During the past fortnight the opinions of professed billiard players have been taken upon the excellence of a table, manufactured by Mr. A. Steel, of Castle- reagh-street, which on sufficient evidence we are prepared to pronounce equal to most, and superior to many of the imported billiard tables. Every- thing connected with the table alluded to, is of colonial manufacture, save the cloth, which, al- though we have the raw material, we cannot yet produce in sufficient excellence through a want of the necessary machinery and labour. The bed of this table is of polished colonial marble, prepared by Mr. Patten of Pitt-street, sculptor. If we cannot produce within ourselves all that our cravings demand; it is now very clear that all the reasonable wants of man in this colony, if they are not, can easily be met, if the colonists will but put their shoulders to the wheel-" the wheel of fortune."-Australian.-[The second press al- luded to in the above paragraph is now in use at the office of this journal, and answers extremely well. The whole of the type is of colonial manu- facture, and does great credit to the type-founder, Mr. Alexander Thomson of Sydney ; and we feel much pleasure in informing our readers that this is the first printing-office established in the Southern Hemisphere entirely with colonial mate- rials -Ed. M. B. C]

PIG-SKIN.-Another valuable addition to our colonial products has just been made by Mr. Giblett, of Pitt-street, who has succeeded in ma- nufacturing pig-skins equal to any imported. Australian, September 24.

ADVERTISING.-A very interesting work has just issued from the London press, presenting a concise and highly interesting history of the origin and progress of the newspaper press of the United Kingdom. The volume contains a vast deal of information, respecting the various London and provincial newspapers, and commu- nicates a number of statistical facts, regarding the counties and districts in which they circulate. The peculiar characteristics of every journal are

stated: a valuable section of the work is devoted to the " philosophy of advertising," and we lay before our readers the two rules which the author sets forth for the guidance of advertisers :-" 1. That advertising is of no party." The advertiser looks for notoriety, for publicity-for benefits--

from the expense he goes to in advertising. He should, therefore, not confine his advertisements to those journals which may advocate the same principles he himself professes, but look to that most likely to promote his interests ; unless, in- deed, he advertises for expressly sectarian, or peculiarly party political purposes : and even then, we question whether the full benefit of ad- vertising can be served, by confining it exclusively to papers of the religious or political principles which are sought to be promoted. We should, in such cases, insert our advertisements in papers of opposite opinions : not to the same extent, as in those which took similar views as ourselves ; but certainly we should take care that, the subject to which we wish to give publicity, should be known as well amongst enemies as amongst friends. 2. The second rule to which we should advise adver- tisers to adhere is, in looking at the circulation of the paper to which their attention is directed as an advertising medium, is to regard its quality rather than its quantity. Some of the most widely circulated journals in the empire are the worst possible to advertise in. Their readers are not purchasers ; and any money spent upon them is so much thrown away. A journal that circu- lates amongst the families of the district; one which has the confidence of the monied and re- spectable, classes of society ; one which from its character, is likely to be read attentively by its circle of readers-in their own houses-at their own fire-sides, whilst it also finds access to the news-rooms and libraries of its locality - is a better medium of advertising, with a circulation of 2,000 than another with a circulation of 4,000, that circulation being chiefly confined to inns, public-houses, and beer-shops. The reason is this : readers at home look to advertisements as a part of the contents of the paper in which they may be interested, and almost always refer to them. The same may be said of the frequenters of reading-rooms and libraries-generally men of business, who want to see a number of local journals for the advantage of their business an- nouncements ; but readers at public-houses, it will be found, as a rule, read for the news and the politics, not for the advertisements : a long and close observation warrants us in coming to this conclusion." It would be well for advertisers to keep the foregoing rules in view. They require that their announcements should meet the eye of that class of persons who need the articles offered for sale, and which has the means of purchasing their wares. We have satisfaction in being able to say that this journal possesses these requisites to as large an extent as any provincial paper in tire colony. The quality of its circulation gives it as decided a superiority, as, an advertising me- dium, as its quantity, for it is circulated among the monied and respectable classes in all parts of

Australasia.

A letter from Jerusalem states that in conse- quence of the long continued drought, the water absolutely necessary for a family, cost ten shillings a day.

CUSTOMS ACT AMENDMENT BILL - On the 30th ult., in the Legislative Council, a question arose, upon the consideration of the second clause in this Bill, as to the limits within which vessels recognised as coasters should trade, and it was suggested that the boundaries should be so defined as to exclude the new colony of Northern Aus- tralia. This was objected to by Mr. Windeyer as extremely inconvenient. Many of the settlers, he said, had stock beyond the proposed limits, and received their supplies at Wide Bay, or other ports to the northward, sending their wool in return, and it would be very hard if the vessels through the medium of which this was done were to be considered as foreign traders. Moreover, it did not follow that the new settlement in the north would be a distinct colony, in the strict sense of the term, so as to require that vessels trading from thence should cease to be regarded as coasters. The Colonial Secretary remarked that any new colony which might be founded by her Majesty must be strictly a separate colony from New South Wales, for it was only by erecting a distinct colony that Her Majesty could exercise the power con- ferred upon her in this behalf by the Imperial Legislature ; and although the officer at the head of the Government might be placed under the su- pervision of the Governor of New South Wales, it would be necessary to create a distinct colonial legislature, who might make such provision as they thought fit, so that that House would have no legislative control beyond the limits of New South Wales. He had ascertained that no part of the Government business of the northern colony was to be transacted through his office. Mr. Windeyer then suggested that until different ar- rangements might be made by the Legislature of the new colony, the vessels which traded to the northward between Cape Capricorn and the eastern limits of South Australia should be regarded as coasters, which, after some further discussion, was agreed to.

articleText:
LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.

MEETING.

A preliminary meeting of freeholders, and other inhabitants possessing property in Brisbane, was held at Capt. Coley's store, North Brisbane, yes- terday, to take into consideration the propriety of calling a public meeting of the inhabitants of the district, to decide upon memorialising His Ex- cellency the Governor, respecting the site and erection of the proposed Custom House for the Port of Moreton Bay. The following resolutions were agreed to :

1st. Proposed by Mr. Dowse, seconded by Capt. Coley-" That Mr. Louis F. Layard be requested to act as Honorary Secretary."

2nd. Proposed by Mr. Pickering, seconded by Mr. Phelan-" That a Memorial be prepared to be laid before a public meeting, praying-His Ex- cellency to take immediate steps for the erection of a Custom House at Brisbane ; and setting forth more particularly the advantages of Brisbane over Moreton Bay generally as a shipping port."

3rd. Proposed by Capt. Coley, seconded by Mr. Welsh-" That a Committee to consist of the gen-

tlemen now present be formed, to prepare a copy of the Memorial Resolutions to be laid before the public meeting. Three to form a quorum."

4th. Proposed by Mr. Harris, seconded by Mr. Pickering-." That a letter be forwarded to Capt. Wickham, requesting him to allow the use of the Court House for the purpose of a public meeting on Thursday next."

5th. Proposed.by Capt.. Coley and seconded by Mr. Dowse. That the following notice be forwarded to the Moreton Bay Courier, viz. .'Take notice, that a public meeting will be held at the Court House, North Brisbane, on Thursday next, at twelve o'clock, for the purpose of memo- rialising His Excellency the Governor, Sir Charles Augustus Fitzroy, to erect a Custom House at

Brisbane ; and on other business.' "

(Signed)

LOUIS F. LAYARD

Hon. Sec.

articleText:
PROROGATION OF THE COUNCIL.

The Colonial Secretary having announced on the previous day that the Council would be pro- rogued on the 31st ultimo, a large number of

ladies and gentlemen attended in the body of the House : the gallery also was well filled.

The Speaker having reported to the House that

His Excellency had assented on behalf of the Crown to the Insolvent Estates Administration Bill, the Colonial Secretary laid upon the table a return relative to the expense per head of convicts. Mr. Wentworth brought up the Report of the Committee on Transportation, with the evidence, which was ordered to be printed, in order that the public might have time fully to weigh and con- sider the very important propositions involved in the Report.

Mr. Windeyer moved that the replies to the circular letter addressed to the different clergy of the colony respecting the aborigines, should be printed, which was agreed to.

Mr. Cowper then moved that the petition pre- sented by him against the renewal of transporta- tion should be printed, which was objected to ; and the House subsequently negatived the pro- position.

Mr. Grant withdrew his motion for the printing of a petition on the same subject from the in- habitants of Maitland.

The Speaker then read a Summary of the Bill introduced during the Session :-

Bills initiated, 30. Bills passed, 20.

Bills received Royal assent, 16. Bills-Royal assent reserved, 3.

Bill-Royal assent withheld, 1.

Bills withdrawn, 7. Bills negatived, 2.

Bills incorporated, 1.

PROROGATION.

The Sergeant-at-Arms having announced the approach of His Excellency, the Speaker and principal Government officers went to receive him, and His Excellency was introduced into the House by the Speaker, and having taken his seat and ordered honorable members to be seated, read the following address :

Mr. Speaker, and Gentlemen of the

Legislative Council,

The business of the session having been brought to a close, I have much pleasure in re- leasing you from a further attendance upon your Legislative duties.

The results of your deliberations during the short period of your being assembled will, I trust, prove beneficial to the public interests.

In now taking leave of you for a season, I have to thank you in Her Majesty's name, for the liberality with which you have voted the supplies for enabling me to carry on the service of Go- vernment ; and I especially deem it my duty to express my gratification at the readiness with which you agreed to the supplement in schedule A, for the Expenses of the Administration of Justice, I hope, however, that it, may not be ne- cessary to avail myself of this supplement, as I find there is at present an unexpended balance on schedule B, which can be made applicable to the purpose, and until the whole of that balance is expended, it is not my intention to take advantage of any part of the additional fund which you have so liberally placed at my disposal.

Charles A. Fitz Roy.

October 31, 1846.

His Excellency'came to the House in the usual state, and appeared in excellent health ; and his deportment exhibited the most marked cordiality towards the members of the Council.

His Excellency's address containing no express words of prorogation-the Speaker again took the chair on His Excellency's departure, and the House having no business before it, he remained there till the House was counted out.

The Moreton Bay Courier is published every

Saturday morning. The terms of subscription are 10s. per quarter, payable, in advance : the quarters ending 30th September, 31st Decem- ber, 31st March, and 30th June, in each year respectively. Each advertisement will be charged at the rate of three shillings an inch, and one shilling for every additional inch, each

insertion. The number of insertions must be

specified on each advertisement, or they will be continued until countermanded by a written notice.

Printed and Published by the Proprietor, ARTHUR

SIDNEY LYON at the General Printing Office, Albert-street, North Brisbane, in the Colony of New South Wales. Orders and communications (in all cases pre-paid) to be addressed to the

Proprietor.

articleText:
NURSERY RHYME.

THE ST0RY OF THE REPEAL OF THE CORN LAWS,

" SUITED TO THE MEANEST CAPACITY."

(From Punch)

There was a lady who had 24,000,000 babies, and she wanted to get cheap bread for them, but she could not, because of the Corn Law. So she went to the Lords, and she said, --

" Lords, Lords, repeal this law, or I cannot

get cheap bread for my babies."

Then the Lords said to her, "Pooh! we are the landed interest ; what do we care for your babies ? The Tories to a man will stand by us." So she went to the Tories, and she said,

" Tories, Tories, desert the Lords ; the Lords

wont repeal the laws ; and I cannot get cheap bread for my babies."

Then the Tories said to her, " Madam, we have no objection to eat dirt ; we do it every day ; but at present we are under the orders of the Duke." So she went to the Duke, and she said,--

" Duke, Duke, order the Tories ; the Tories

won't desert the Lords ; the Lords won't re- peal the law ; and I cannot get cheap bread for my babies."

Then the Duke said to her, " F. M. the Duke of Wellington is Commander-in-Chief of the army, but he is neither a maltster nor a miller. All communications to his Grace must be made through Sir Robert Peel." So she went to Sir Robert Peel, and she said,--

" Peel, Peel, speak to the Duke ; the Duke

won't order the Tories ; the Tories won't desert the Lords ; the Lords won't repeal the law ; and I cannot get cheap food tor my

babies."

Then Peel said, " The Tories brought me in, I know, but I should like to rat and cut the snobs. However, as yet, there is no pressure from with- out, there's no great fact to frighten me." So she went to look for a great fact ; and she heard a voice, saying to her, " I am ready to come to your help, if you will only get somebody to form a League, and call me into notice. There's Richard Cobden." So she went to Richard Cob- den, and she said,

" Cobden, Cobden, form a League ; the League

will soon become a fact ; but there's no fact yet to frighten Peel, and Peel won't speak to the Duke ; the Duke won't order the Tories ; the Tories won't desert the Lords ; the Lords won't repeal the law ; and I cannot get cheap bread for my babies."

Then Cobden began to form the League ; the League began to become a fact ; the fact began to frighten Peel ; Peel began to speak to the Duke ; the Duke began to order the Tories; the Tories began to desert the Lords ; the Lords set to re- peal the law ; and so the little lady got cheap

bread for her babies.

THE MORETON BAY COURIER is published every

Saturday morning. The terms of subscription are 10s. per quarter, payable in advance : the quarters ending 30th September, 31st Decem- ber, 31st March, and 30til June, in each year respectively. Each advertisement will be charged at the rate of three shillings an inch and one shilling for every additional inch, each

insertion. The number of insertions must be specified on each advertisement, or they will be .continued until countermanded by a written

notice.

Printed and Published by the Proprietor, ARTHUR

SIDNEY LYON, at the General Printing Office, Albert-street, North Brisbane, in the Colony of

New South Wales. Orders and communications

(in all cases pre-paid) to be addressed to the Proprietor.

articleText:
L O C A L I N T E L L I G E N C E .

NIGHT LICENSES. — At the Police-office on Tuesday, application was made, and leave granted, for the following night licenses :—Mr. D. Bow, of the Victoria Hotel, in North Brisbane, to keep open until two o'clock, P.M. ; Mr. A. Graham, of the Harp of Erin, in South Brisbane, and Mr. Henry Prott, of the Bush and Commercial Hotel,

at Kangaroo Point, to keep open until twelve

o'clock.

THE " EXPERIMENT."—The return trip of the steamer on Sunday last, after allowing for the time occupied in placing beacons in various parts of the river, was accomplished in six hours and a half, so that the result, as far as regards speed, which averaged, seven knots an hour, is highly satisfactory. Her future trips will be made on alternate days in each week, commencing on Monday next. In order to obviate any incon- venience to passengers regularity will be observed in the time of departure from the two townships, notice of which will be given in our next number. It will be seen by our advertising columns, that the Experiment is engaged for the conveyance of a party of pleasure to the Bay to-morrow. The reasonable price of the tickets, and the ac- commodation provided for the table, will no doubt ensure a numerous attendance on board.

FAT CATTLE.—One hundred and twenty-eight head of fat cattle have arrived at Kangaroo Point during the week, for the purpose of being either boiled down or salted ; of this number eighty head are from Messrs. Corey and Taylor's herds, and the remaining forty-eight from the station of Messrs. D. Archer and Co. The whole are very large and well-conditioned.

BREACH OF HIRED SERVANTS' ACT.—At the Police-office yesterday, a man named William George Lewis, in the employ of Mr. John Camp-

bell, at Kangaroo Point, appeared to answer a complaint preferred against him by that gentle- man for disobedience of orders, and making use of abusive and slanderous language, Mr. Adams, who appeared on the part of the complainant, re- minded the magistrates, that this was the first charge that had been brought before them under the new Masters and Servants Act, and he hoped, as it was a very gross case, that they would inflict such punishment as would deter others in Mr. Campbell's employ from following the bad ex- ample set them by the defendant. Evidence having been adduced, the charge was fully proved, and the defendant was sentenced to three months' imprisonment.

CHARGE OF RAPE.—On Thursday, John Curtis, a private belonging to the detachment of the 99th Regiment stationed at Brisbane, under commit- ment for trial on a charge of attempting to violate the person of a child under ten years of age, the daughter of Sergeant Cook of the same regiment, was forwarded to Sydney by the William. He has been some time in custody since his commit- ment, owing to our limited police force not per- mitting the absence of a constable to take charge of him to Sydney ; the Captain of the Tamar having, as might have been expected, declined to become a special constable for the occasion. Ano- ther instance of that " penny-wise and pound foolish" system of which Moreton Bay presents so many examples.

AN INCORRIGIBLE —At the Police-office yester- day, a man named James McAuliffe, whose strange vagaries have obtained for him the sobriquet of the Cranky Cobbler, was placed at the bar, charged with drunkeness and disorderly conduct. McAuliffe is well known as the most noisy individual in the district. He was fined twenty shillings and costs, and in default of payment was committed to the cells for forty-eight hours.

TURTLE.—A very large turtle, weighing up- wards of four cwt., was taken in the Bay on Thursday last. The turtle season has just com- menced. A gentleman who arrived here a few days ago, from Amity Point, informed us that he has seen turtle in the shallow water near Moreton Island of enormous size. He witnessed an at- tempt to capture one of these monsters by the aborigines ; but notwithstanding six of them used their utmost exertions to secure him, he escaped. There are two kinds which frequent the Bay, the hawks-bill and the green turtle ; the latter of which, the most highly prized, can be procured easily. The bad success which has attended the shipments of turtle to Sydney, seems to have rendered the Bay fishermen careless of taking them. We hope, however, that some speculative individual will shortly commence the manufactory of turtle soup, for general exportation ; there is no doubt that his gains would be very considera- ble. Industry and skill would be the only capital required. A person in the West Indies, who car- ries on an establishment of this kind, in which is made what he terms " Turtle Soup for the Million," packed in tins, hermetically sealed, and shipped to England, is realizing an enormous fortune.

BOILING-DOWN.—HORSES.—The fat of a horse, when boiled, becomes an excellent oil, much prized by curriers, and used in various manufactures. It is worth, in the colony, about six shillings per gallon. We trust this hint will not be lost on the owners of those weedy, worthless brutes, which are to be found in such great numbers in the

Middle District.

BREACH OF THE PUBLICANS' ACT.—At the Police-office, yesterday, Mr. Rowland, of the South Brisbane Hotel, appeared to answer an in- formation which had been filed against him for suffering cards to be played in his house on the night of the 23rd instant. Mr. Rowland admitted the offence, and was mulcted in the lowest penalty of forty shillings and costs. The fine was im- mediately paid by the mutual contributions of the gentlemen who had been present on the occasion.

DOGS.—His Excellency the Governor has di- rected it to be notified that the provisions of the Act of Council, intituled, " An Act for abating the nuisances occasioned by dogs in the streets of certain towns and highways in New South Wales," have been extended to the town of Brisbane, in the county of Stanley. An abstract of this Act will shortly appear in the Courier.

ROBBERY.—On Thursday night, last week, an out-building adjoining the stores of Mr. Hampden in South Brisbane was entered by some dishonest person. Fortunately it was empty, and the fellow found nothing portable but the window sash, which he carried off. One of the aborigines was put on the track early in the following morning, but as the footsteps led to a cottage occupied by a person in a respectable station of life, no further attempt was made to recover the stolen property.

CRICKET.—As a finale to the amusements of the race week, a challenge from eleven of the working men of Brisbane to play an equal number of gen- tlemen, for £5 10s. a side, was accepted by the latter, and the match came off on the Terrace leading to the Government Gardens. The gen- tlemen were successful, beating their opponents easily. The stakes were generously handed over to the losing party. Arrangements were made for another match to come off in the next year's

race week.

THE OLD BURIAL GROUNDS.—In reference to a paragraph in our last number we are glad to learn that the inhabitants are in no way to blame for the burnt fence, broken tombstones, and trod- den mounds, which shock the eye of the stranger at the place known as the Old Burial Ground. Those whose remains are interred within it were either Government officials or prisoners of the Crown. The burial-place accessible to the in- habitants is farther removed from the town, and is kept with scrupulous care. Reproach, there- fore, cannot rest with them. We have heard that the Government have once or twice protected the ground with a fence, which has been shortly af- terwards pulled down by the blacks, brought by them into the town, and sold for firewood ; and that those interested therefore consider farther attempts to be hopeless. We trust, however, that one more effort will be made to rescue Brisbane from the stigma which now seemingly attaches to it. The Old Burial Ground is the last earthly resting-place of many an useful and respected public servant—the martyr Stapylton, and numerous others—and should there be any amongst us, who will venture to assert that their remains deserved no better fate, we would ask, Do you wish that, when you die, their fate shall be yours — that the mound over the simple grave to which you may be borne by your sorrowing friends, shall be trampled into a shapeless mass, its tombstone broken and dis- placed, and the few flowering plants which affec- tion had taught to twine around it, uprooted and withered ? To such a question there can only be one reply. We repeat, therefore, that we hope our respected authorities will make another trial once more enclose the ground with a substantial fence. And should any amongst us be heartless enough to encourage the blacks to destroy it, we shall feel it our duty to hold his conduct up to public reprobation. Desecration of the dead is opposed to the practice both of civilized and savage man—the laws of Nature, Necessity, and Society, stand opposed to an act which in its enormity strikes at the best and tenderest feelings of humanity.

WORKING BULLOCKS.—Seven working bullocks belonging to the Survey Department were sold by public auction on Monday last, and fetched two pounds eighteen shillings per head. They were in very poor condition.

BILLIARD LICENSE.—On Tuesday the magis- trates granted a renewal of the billiard license for the room at the Victoria Hotel, with permis- sion to keep it open until two o'clock in the

morning.

HIGHWAY ROBBERY.—We observe by a para- graph in the Sydney Morning Herald, that a few days ago a person named William Horseman, who had lately arrived from Moreton Bay, was knocked down and robbed on the South Head Road, he being at the time in a state of intoxica- tion. It is but right to state, lest any misap- prehension should prevail, that the individual

alluded to is not connected with Mr. Thomas Horseman of Ipswich ; nor is he known to any of the residents here, as we have made many enquiries respecting him.

WILSON'S CAPTURE.—A number of gentlemen, connected with the Clarence River and Darling Downs districts, who were in Sydney at the time the news arrived of the death of Wilson the bush- ranger and the capture of his party, by a party of mounted police, among the ranges at the head of the Clarence River, subscribed the sum of £37. This they entrusted to the Commandant of the Police, requesting that it might be equally dis- tributed amongst his men, as a token of the esti- mation in which their bravery and perseverance are held by the settlers.

RECOVERY OF SMALL DEBTS.—Mr. Windeyer

has introduced a Bill into the Legislative Council, to amend the law respecting the recovery of small debts in all parts of the colony, except the county of Cumberland. It provides, 1st, that Courts of Petty Sessions shall be Courts of Requests, for debts not exceeding ten pounds, with certain exceptions and limitations, which attach to the existing law. 2nd, That a single Magistrate shall have juris- diction up to the amount of forty shillings, or to a higher amount, with the consent of the parties. 3rd, The Clerks of Benches shall act as Registrars, and receive the fees provided in the schedules at- tached to the Act, providing they do not exeeed a certain specified sum in one year. The remainder of the clauses, amounting to thirty-five, are con- fined to the details of modes of proceeding, service of summonses, parties liable, costs how paid, and process of execution—none of which are essen- tially different from the Act now in force, except the service of summons, which is required to be personal.

AUSTRALIAN CONCENTRATED SOUP.—We have met with the subjoined remarks in the city article of the London Observer, of the 28th December. Our readers will, we are sure, participate in our feelings of regret at the oppressive, and, as the Observer justly calls it, the " enormous" duty levied upon a product coming from a British colony, and adapted so especially to supply the British poor with a species of food at once nutriti- ous, palatable, and cheap. If this obnoxious im- post were removed, the demand would be very extensive, for the colony could afford to supply the article at a price which in England would be con- sidered low, although leaving a handsome profit to the colonists. " Since the public notice that has been given of the importation of the Australian concentrated soup, several noblemen and other philanthropic individuals have been desirous of securing a quantity for distribution amongst the poor, which intention is partly frustrated by the enormous duty levied by the Customs, namely, an ad valorem one of 20 per cent., as a manufactured article, which is disproportionate to its value, and when we find that poultry and game of all kinds are brought in from foreign countries at a nominal ad valorem duty of 5 per cent., and principally consumed by the affluent, and the article in ques- tion is exclusively intended for distribution amongst the poor, surely this anomaly should not exist. It is useless appealing to the Customs authorities, for they have no alternative but to levy the duty according to Act of Parliament ; but an article of importation that serves the interest of two parties-our colonies and the poor at home ought to be placed on the more favourable footing by a mere nominal duty being levied."—Sydney Herald.—[Sir R. Peel's new Tariff Bill proposes that the duty on gelatine, in which term concen- trated soup is included, shall immediately " cease and determine." This is a matter of no small importance to our stockholders.—ED M. B. C.]

COLONIAL PRODUCE.—Messrs. Goad and Rigg of London, the eminent brokers, in their annual circular, state that " Australian tallow is now looked upon with alarm by those who have unin- terruptedly swayed the English market for so many years, inasmuch as they can neither ascer- tain the amount of supply nor the precise time when it may be expected, so that all their former calculations are defeated, and instead of being a monopoly, the tallow market is now regulated, by supplies from various sources which cannot be controlled." The total quantity received in England from the colony last year amounted to 3630 tons, which is estimated to have produced gross £146,000, against 68,000 in 1844. The market was in a healthy condition, and the ag- gregate stock of foreign tallow did not exceed 29,879 casks, against 39,398 at the close of 1844. The buyers preferred regularity in the size and weight of the casks ; those weighing from eight to ten cwt, were most approved. Uniformity in the colour and body of tallow ensure it a ready sale, and enables it to compete more effectually with Russian tallow. A considerable portion of the beef tallow shipped had been too highly co- loured, with a weak and greasy body, which only fetched 40s. ; while the good bright or pale co- lour, hard and pure, sold for 42s. With respect

to hides the demand had kept pace with the supply ?????, however, a great defect in them, in consequence of their being much brand-marked, which reduced the value fully ¼ to ½ per lb. Messrs. Goad and Rigg recommend that the hides should be properly flayed, as a badly cut hide would not answer for Loshing, for which purpose a new and extensive channel of con- sumption was opened : a badly cut hide could not be used in that process. The estimated gross value of the hides shipped last year was £52,650. The expenses on salted hides, including freight at 60s. a ton and all other charges, amounts to ½d. per lb. ; the loss of weight by shrinking on the voyage amounts to 3/8d. to ½d. per lb. making the whole cost about 1d. per lb. If the quality, condition, and flaying go on improving, it is considered that they will approximate more closely in value to the River Plate hides ; and even should the market be in a depressed state, they were not likely to fetch less than 3d. per lb. A few samples of horse and also of ox and cow hair have been shipped from Sydney, and it is stated that any quantity that could be sent would meet with ready sale. Horse-tail hair, of eighten to twenty-four inches long and upwards, is worth from 1s. 4d. to 2s. per lb. ; it is valued in proportion to its length and strength ; mixed tails and manes are worth 9d. to 1s. per lb. ; ox and cow tuft hair ranges from 7d. up to 10d. per lb. Horns from Sydney had realized high prices compared with other sorts ; those weighing from 18 to 22 oz. each, if fresh and clean, brought 28s. to 34s. per 123. Hoofs, if whole, clean, and sound, brought from £10 to £12. per ton. Except shank bones, which realize from £7 to £10 per ton, bones and horns cannot be expected to enter into our list of articles of export, until the trade between Moreton Bay and England becomes direct.

IMPRISONMENT FOR DEBT.—Owing to a sad oversight in the Act, passed by the Legislative Council, for abolishing imprisonment for debt,

the jurisdiction of the Court of Requests was not included in its operation. This has been pro- ductive of lamentable absurdities. The poor man unable to pay twenty shillings has his liberty en- dangered ; his neighbour of more extensive deal- ings and larger debts, has had the full benefit of the relaxation of the law. Advantage, however, of this omission, has, we believe, been taken only in the Middle District. In both the Southern and Northern Districts of the colony, the law has been interpreted rather from its evident intent, than its negligent wording. Whether this arises from high moral principle or want of legal know- ledge it is not for us to decide ; we are of course bound to suppose the former. Mr. Lowe has in- troduced a Bill into the Council, during its present session, for simplifying and amending the Act. This Bill repeals the 28th and subsequent sections of the 7th Victoria, No. 19,—" An Act for the relief of insolvent persons, and abolishing im- prisonment for debt ;"—those sections abolishing imprisonment for debt except in certain cases ;

and also repeals the 3rd and 4th sections of the 8th Victoria, No. 15, to the same effect. It then provides—1st, that no person shall be ar- rested on mesne or final process issuing out of any Court of Requests ; and 2nd, that no person shall be arrested on any writ of capias ad satis- faciendum issuing out of the Supreme Court, except in cases of fraudulent concealment, or of

intention to leave the colony.

SOUTH AUSTRALIAN GRAIN. — Advices have been received of the sale in London of a quantity of South Australian wheat, of the Chidham and Talavera varieties, at prices averaging 11s. 6d. to 12s. per bushel. The samples exhibited at the Corn Exchange excited much interest, they were considered of fine quality, and splendid specimens of the capabilities of the colony. A sample of barley from the same colony also attracted much attention, and was pronounced to be equal to any that had ever been seen in the London market.

IMPORTANT — PARTIAL REVIVAL OF IMMI- GRATION.—On looking over a file of Cork papers, we find there is every likelihood of a renewel of immigration, at least on a limited scale. It ap- peared to several members of the Cork Poor Law Guardians, that as there were numbers of stout and able females thronging the County and City Poor Houses, doing nothing, and a continuous tax upon the poor-rate revenues, that their trans- portation to some place where their labours would not only be required, but well rewarded, would be a matter of vast importance to Ireland as well as the Colonies ; the subject so far engrossed their attention, as to have its feasibility discussed at several board meetings, and even a communica- tion opened with Mr. J. Besnard, jun., the cele- brated emigration agent, relative to a pauper im- migration to Australia. Mr. Besnard not only entered into their views, but oven offered to con- vey the female paupers at a low rate of bounty. Accordingly, if we are to credit the Cork Ex- aminer of the 26th November, " a meeting of the Cork Union Board met on the previous, day ; Colonel Bourke in the chair — when a committee of five guardians was appointed for the purpose of carrying out all further arrangements with Mr. Besnard ;" it is, therefore, not improbable that we may have a batch of female immigrants in Hobson's Bay when we least expect them,

P. P. Patriot.

FORCE OF HABIT.—Pari Waringa, a native better known as Jemmy, a young fellow for three years past in the service of Mr. Smith, was charged by the Rev. Mr. Klose, with an assault upon a native girl named Nigarparla, whose father, an aged black, was present; the wife of the accused was there also ; she is the girl who so long lived with Governors Gawler and Grey, but who eloped with Jemmy, since Government-house became a bachelors hall ; she was in native costume— having no other clothing than a kangaroo skin ; and so far from blaming her husband for his in- fidelity, walked off with him in triumph, when the case was adjourned till the next day, on account of the non-appearance of the (so-called) prose- cutrix. This girl presents a curious illustration of the training of the natives. Few attendants at Trinity Church have not seen her habited from head to foot in the manner of the best English servant—what dress more neat and more truly becoming? It was of her that Governor Grey spoke when he assured the Legislative Council that he had in his family a native girl who was " not only as civilized, but as Christianized, as any person in the colony." Arrived at the age of womanhood, she threw aside the clothing which never did and never will become a savage, and is

now (we cannot say again) a wanderer in the woods, the only traces remaining of her civiliza- tion being the plumpness which good feeding in her growing years had given her, and the habit of keeping her hair and her face in order.—

Adelaide Observer.

ASSESSMENT ON STOCK.—From the 1st January, 1839, to the 31st December, 1846, the district of Liverpool Plains paid assessment 16,012 L 17s. 2d. ; New England, 11,133 L. 3s. 6d. ; Port Mac- quarie and McLeay River, 1666 L. 4s. 4d. ; Clarence River, 2400 L. 18s. 1d. ; Moreton Bay, 2308 L. 4s. 5d. ; Darling Downs, 1834 L. 11s 7d. ; Bligh, 5827 L. 7s. 4d. ; Wellington, 7657 L. 5s. ; Lachlan, 7417 L. 4s. 7d. ; Murrumbidgee, 10,897 L. 14s. 6d. ; Maneroo, 13,738 L. 15s.—total, 80,904 L. The sums expended out of the revenue thus collected to pay the salaries of Commissioners, and the expenses of Border Police, &c, amounted to 76,111 L 13s. 7½d. In Port Phillip, the total amount of assessment received during the same period amounted to 39,059 L. 5s.; Western Port and County of Bourke paying 15,157 L. 1s. 6d. ; Portland Bay and County of Grant, 15,157 L. 1s. 7d. ; Murray, 3305 L. 4s. 4d. ; Gipps Land, 1034 L. 11s. 9d. ; and the amount paid for salaries of Commissioners, and the expenses of Border Police and Native Police, was 26,647 L 14s. 4d.
heading: LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.

articleText:
LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.

THE CONSTABULARY.

ABOUT a fortnight since, Mr. Constable McCro- hon, on account of his previous good conduct was promoted to the rank of District Constable, and was ordered to proceed to Ipswich in the room of Mr. Higgins, who was dismissed for gross misconduct. Our Ipswich friends, doubtless, were congratulating themselves that the new official would be of a different stamp to his predecessor— that McCrohon, who had for two long years been a staunch teetotaller, would not again be found guilty of the besetting sin. Their expec- tations, however, were doomed to be disappointed. Mr. McCrohon, as a plain Dogberry, was well enough in his way ; but the moment the covetted

title of District Constable was conferred, he was quite another man. Unlooked-for titles, like un- looked riches, have turned many a man's head, and so it was with McCrohon. On his arrival at the quiet town of Ipswich, Mr. McCrohon was the " observed of all observers ;" the inhabitants flocked to the wharf to catch a glimpse of the great D.C. then, for the first time, come amongst them to assume the onerous duties of his dreaded office. Even the little urchins about the town participated in the excitement, and sung out most lustily for an extra supply of lollys. Mr. McCro- hon suddenly found himself an important per- sonage-a rising man. He was placed there to do something, and something he thought must be done, and that promptly. Elevated as he now was, in more senses than one—thoroughly con- scious of his own power and dignity-one of his first official acts was to turn one of his subordi- nates out of his quarters :—" Arise, arise," said he to his trembling Sub, " go to thy father, and say, I, I, District Constable McCrohon, desired thee to vanish !" Poor Magrath looked, implor- ingly at his superior, but the mandate had gone forth, and budge he must. Having thus im- pressed his " Sub" with an idea of the vast extent of his power, the great D. C., cane in hand, and as erect as " a yard of pump water," took a stroll round the town ; the " Sub" following at a re- spectful distance. Of course, the taverns claimed his first attention, and excited his surprise, which feeling ripened into admiration, after he had paid his respects to the inmates, and had partaken of their hospitality. Mr. McCrohon was received kindly-was treated handsomely, and had he acted wisely might have lived there happy and respected in his station of life, but an overweening conceit of his newly-created dignity, marred all his pros- pects. Having enjoyed himself to his heart's content, he was going home to his lodgings ; a facetious idea struck him, and he proceeded forth- with to carry it out. He thought that it would be a capital joke to call at the Doctor's house, and ask him to " shout." On rapping at the door, he was admitted, and the following colloquy took place :

McCrohon—I say,'Doctor (hiccup), have you got any g-g-gin (hiccup) ?

Doctor—What sort of gin?

McCrohon—Why, any (hiccup) s-s-sort of gin (the last word was whispered).

Doctor—(Good humouredly) I have got oxy- gin, hydro-gin, and nitro-gin, which of the three will you have?

McCrohon—Why, any sort of gin, as I said bef— (the last syllable was inaudible), Any sort of gin, Sir. Mix 'em, mix—a little hot water, and su-su-(hore the worthy D. C. again sung small, and gave a knowing wink).

The Doctor, however, cut short the conversation, by peremptorily ordering the D. C. to leave the house, which the official, to his credit be it spoken, immediately did, and retired to his lodgings, where, doubtless, he afterwards found that the evening's amusement would not bear the morning's reflec- tion. The particulars of his unhappy debut in Ipswich, having become known to the Magistrates, he was immediately summoned before the Brisbane Bench and called upon to account for his eccentric behaviour. On Tuesday, Mr. McCrohon accord- ingly appeared, and in his defence stated that the Magistrates were misinformed respecting his doings at Ipswich. " Sir," said McCrohon, ad-

dressing himself to the Police Magistrate, " I met with hostile feelings on the part of the inhabitants the very moment I put my foot on their shores ; I Sir, have been made the victim of a faction ; I Sir,"—here however he was suddenly brought up, by the Police Magistrate, who stopped his orato- rical display, by informing him, that his turning out Magrath was an act of impertinence beyond the scope of his authority, and that he knew quite enough to convince him, that he (McCrohon) was not a proper person to hold the office of District Constable ; he should, therefore, reduce him to

his former situation, and if he did not conduct himself properly for the future, he would be dis- missed from the force without ceremony. McCro- hon left the office with the air of an injured man.

Dr. LEICHHARDT.—In Sydney, on the 16th ultimo, a meeting of the Leichhardt Testimonial Committee, was held for the purpose of taking into consideration the most appropriate means of pre- senting Dr. Leichhardt with the Testimonial, and closing the business of the Committee, when the Secretary was instructed to pay all claims against the fund, and likewise to call a public meeting of the subscribers on the 21st ult., at the Mechanics' School of Arts, to present him with the testimonial, the amount of which is stated to be £1,520 18s. It was also resolved that the Speaker should be requested to preside on the occasion. The bust of this celebrated explorer, executed by Mr. Abraham, was placed in Mr. Lyons' Long Room, and the likeness is pronounced to be excellent. In his second expedition, Dr. Leichhardt will take with him a number of goats, as well as mules, - the last mentioned useful animals are now in training, and are to have bells suspended to their necks.

COUNTRY MAILS.—Persons desirous of con- tracting for the conveyance of mails from and to Armidale, New England, and Alford's Darling Downs, and from and to Brisbane, and Alford's, via Ipswich, once a fortnight, for one year, from the 1st of January, 1847, are to send in their offers to the Colonial Secretary's office, on Monday, the 9th of November next, endorsed " Tenders for the conveyance of mails."

TICKETS-OF-LEAVE.—The under - mentioned prisoners of the Crown have obtained tickets-of- leave for the district of Moreton Bay, viz. : — James Abbott, Mailand ; George Crosbie, Asia, 11 ; Owen Connors, St. Vincent ; James Cor- drey, Charles Karr ; Henry Caldicott, Stroth- fieldsaye ; John Dwyer, Blenheim ; James Far- rell, Woodbridge ; Michael Fitzpatrick, Blenheim, 2 ; John Fitzgerald, King William ; Stephen Forster, Eden ; James Fitzgerald, Barossa ; Richard Groves, Maitland ; Matthew Ennis, Blenheim ; Hamman Jantjies, Pekoe ; Joseph Junott, John Barry ; Francis Larkin, Pekoe ; Edmund Lally, Neptune, 4 ; Jas. Miller, Pekoe ; John Fenn, Lora Lyndoch ; Kyran Walshe, Clyde ; Hosier Williams, Maitland.

GOVERNMENT CONTRACT.—Tuesday, the 23th ult, was the last day for receiving, at the Colonial Secretary's office, tenders for furnishing from the 1st instant to the 31st December, supplies of "provisions, &c.," required by the Government in this district. By the next steamer we shall be enabled to know the name of the person who has

obtained the contract.

THE NATIVES.—A few days ago, a number of blacks surrounded the huts occupied by the Ger- mans, at Eagle Farm, and forcibly carried off a large quantity of provisions, consisting of flour, potatoes, and other articles. The natives have taken advantage of the pacific dispositions of the Germans, to fleece them on several occasions, and the probability is, they will renew their outrages the first favourable opportunity, "knowing well, as they do, that they are sure to come off scatheless.

A HARD CASE.—At the Police Office, on Tues- day, Mr. McCabe, of South Brisbane, appeared before the Bench, to answer an information laid against him by the Chief Constable, for suffering drunken men to remain on his premises on the morning of Sunday last. The defendant stated that the men entered his house by the back door, all the other doors being fastened, and that he was endeavouring to get them out, after having refused to serve them with liquors, when Constable Ram- say came in. Ramsay admitted that he did not see any drinking going on, nor any preparations for serving the parties who were inside. The Bench mulcted McCabe in the sum of 40s. and costs, being the lowest penalty.

NARROW ESCAPE.—On Tuesday last, an acci- dent happened to Mrs. Geag, wife of Mr. Geag, the market-gardener, residing at Breakfast Creek, which might have been attended with serious con- sequences. Mrs. Geag was proceeding home with her horse and cart, and having arrived at the Creek, took the horse out of the cart, as was her usual custom, with the intention of leading him across-the dilapidated state of the bridge render- ing it unsafe to take any vehicle over. She was going quietly over it, when one of the planks gave way, and the horse losing his footing, was preci- pitated into the water, together with Mrs, Geag, who preserved sufficient presence of mind not to let go the reins, and to hold on by the mane. On reaching the side, the horse was startled by a boy, who had run down to render assistance, and again plunged into the stream, Mrs. Geag still holding

on by the reins and mane. After swimming about a short time, the horse came to the bank, and Mr. Geag having come to his wife's aid, she was extricated from her perilous situation, with only a slight bruise on the knee from the horse's feet. The horse subsequently managed, by a violent effort, to get out of the creek uninjured. The bridge is now quite impassable, and something ought to be done immediately by the Government either to put it in repair, or to erect a new one. Heretofore, not one sixpence has been expended in the formation of roads and bridges in the district ; whatever has been effected has been done by private enterprise, and it is high time some stir should be made in this matter by the residents. They must agitate, or they will not obtain what they are equitably entitled to -- a fair proportion of the amount voted by the Legislative Council for the repairs of roads and bridges throughout the

various districts.

BREACHES OF THE SLAUGHTERING ACT.—On the 22nd instant, at the Police Office, Mr. Martin Byrne, of Ipswich, was fined £5 and costs; for a breach of the Licensed Slaughtering Act. On Tuesday, the information against William Stuart, of Kangaroo Point, reported in our last number, for a similar infringement of the Act, was dis- missed, and a new summons granted.

BREACHES OF THE HIRED SERVANTS' ACT—At the Police Office, on Tuesday, a bullock-driver, named John McDonald, in the employ of Mr. Whitting of Darling Downs, was brought before the Magistrates, charged with neglect of duty and drunkenness on the 27th ult. The case being fully proved, the Bench sentenced him to six weeks' imprisonment in Sydney Gaol.—On the same day, Thomas Harvey, waiter, at the Victoria Hotel, in North Brisbane, was summoned to answer the complaint of Mr. Bow, for having absconded from his hired service, and for insolent conduct. The Magisirates having heard the evidence, adjudged the defendant to forfeit all wages due to him, and his agreement to be can-

celled.

ASSAULT.—On the 29th ult., a person named George Croft, appeared before the Bench on a charge of assault, and for using threatening language to Constable Magrath, at Ipswich, on Wednesday the 23rd ult. The evidence of the constable having been taken, the Magistrates bound Croft over to keep the peace, himself in £50, and two sureties in £25 each. The case, as far as regards the assault was, at the request of the defendant, postponed until Tuesday next, to allow him to bring forward his witnesses to rebut the charge.

DIFFERENTIAL DUTIES.—This Act, which passed the Legislative Council 13th July, 1846, does not come into operation until the 1st April, 1847 ; but it is now understood that it will not affect the importation of cattle and sheep from Port Phillip, or any other part of New South

Wales.—Hobart Town Courier.

AUSTRALIAN HORSES.—We have learnt with considerable pleasure that several of our crack horses exported hence to Calcutta, have found their way to Ceylon, where their fleetness and bottom on the race-course have proved that the horse-flesh of this colony stands superior to the pure Arab. The poet and the musician have united their talents in by-gone days to com- memorate the speed of " My Arab Steed." Now that we find Australian " blood, bone, and beauty" can, without whip or spur, put the Arab and his bold rider to the blush, the Australian poet should not slumber, nor the musican fail in his duty to his adopted country, to compose and to sing in strains of praise the fleetness of the " Australian Steed." His boldness, too, we have read of. An Australian horse, purchased for 1000 rupees by one of the officers who was engaged in the battle of Ferozepore, is reported, ere the first battle commenced, to have " bolted" with his gallant rider, and in his furious course made a breach in the advance line of the Seik forces ; and, singular to relate, both horse and rider returned to their proper position in time to receive the evening's first salute from their great guns.- Australian,

WHEAT.—It is a positive fact, that wheat can now be purchased wholesale in Sydney at a cheaper rate than purchase could be effected in Hobart Town at the latest dates. At Melbourne, too, good samples were quoted at 5s. 6d. to 6s., and first flour at 14l. 10s. per ton of 2,000 lbs.— Australian, August 17.

The tender for 13,000 bushels of wheat to the Commissariat of Van Diemen's Land has been taken at from 5s. 9d. to 6s. 2d. per bushel. Mr. Charles Reid offered the whole quantity (15,000 bushels) at 6s. 5d.

RECALL OF SIR EARDLEY WILMOTT-In our

last we stated as a rumour merely, but it was generally believed in Hobart Town, that Sir Eardley Wilmott was about to be recalled. "We are now enabled to state, from unquestionable authority, that Sir Eardley has been recalled. The name of his successor was not known publicly when the William Hyde sailed from London. Australian, Sept. 17.

CURIOUS VERDICT.-At Launceston, a few weeks since, two men were indicted, the one for stealing a cheque, and the other for receiving it. The jury acquitted the thief, and convicted the receiver. The Launceston Examiner calls the attention of the Judges to this palpably absurd

verdict.

THE LATE SLAUGHTER OF THE CAPE OTWAY BLACKS.-In addition to the information given

in our last number, respecting the deplorable issue, of Mr. Surveyor Smythe's expedition, we are ena- bled to add a few more particulars. Mr. Smythe, with his armed detachment of the Barrabool tribe (which he employed with the sanction of the Go- vernment, to assist him in apprehending an abo- riginal charged with murder), first came upon the traces of the Cape Otway tribe near Mr. Roadknight's station at the Cape. With the ex- pectation of finding the object of their search encamped at the huts, Mr. Smythe's party sur- rounded and made a sudden descent upon the station ; but he had gone away some time pre- viously. The Barrabool blacks soon fell upon his trail, and followed it up with unerring sagacity, until they reached the Eyre River. Here there was an open space of about three quarters of a mile, and the advanced party caught sight of the Cape Otway tribe, quambying on the opposite side of the river. As it was impossible to effect an immediate crossing at this place, without giving an alarm, the whole party struck off towards the beach, keeping under cover of the wood, until they reached the bar across the mouth of the river, where they crossed, wading through the the surf. From thence they passed inland until the Cape Otway tribe were between them and the

river, when they made preparations for a descent upon their prey. Mr. Smythe's instructions were to capture the only surviving male of the tribe, and to spare the women and children. But to expect subordination from savages on the scent of blood, was vain. The blacks led the way in

advance, crawling through the scrub as noise- lessly as snakes, until they reached the top of a rise, from whence could be seen the mia-mias of the tribe below. All was still. There was no one on the look out. One moment of preparation elapsed, and the Barrabool tribe rushed down the hill with such precipitancy, that the Cape Otway blacks had scarcely time to start to their feet ere the assailants' weapons were at work among them. The solitary chief of the devoted tribe fell almost immediately, with seven or eight balls through him. The strife then ceased for a moment, and the women and children might have been saved, had not one of themselves, a young girl, pointed out two old lubras who had assisted at the murders of several white men, and blacks of other tribes ; this roused once more the savage thirst of blood in their assailants, who, throwing away their muskets, and flourishing their tomahawks, finished their murderous work by the destruction of all the women and children (seven in number, we believe) with the exception of the girl who had denounced the others. At this juncture, Mr. Smith came up, and seizing the girl by the hand, saved her from the fate of her companions. This girl

speaks the language of the Colac tribe. She states that the man who was killed, had murdered three white men. She has been brought to Gee- long; and, beyond being somewhat frightened,

she does not seem to be much affected at the awful fate of her relatives. We understand that it is Mr. Smythe's intention to request an examination into the circumstances attending this event ; and that such an examination will take place, is quite certain ; in fact it will be imperatively the duty of the Government to institute inquiry. It would not therefore become us to add to our former re- marks, or to form a premature opinion as to whether blame can be attached to any person, and, if so, to whom - the Government which equipped the party, or the individual to whom its command was entrusted.-Geelong Advertiser, August 29.

GREAT GEORGE THIRD, that kingly clown

And clownly king,-this hole And that, poking his nose in,

As was his wont, good soul Saw apple dumplings on a dish,

Smoking besides much meat and fish

Upon a farmer's table.

He thought them lumps of dough, . But Dobbin cut one open

To find the fruit, and show

The king, who cried, with wond'ring stare, " An apple ! lor ! how got it there P"

Keenly our Landing Waiter

Look'd across the water

Care-worn, as was Lord Ullin

When he lost his daughter.

" Sundries," he mutter'd, " What's that? humph ! " I smell a rat. I'm not a sumph,

" Nor is the Sub-Collector.

.' It must not pass-although " A little package. How came

" Sundries in't, I'd like to know ? " What a handy size to seize on,

" And so find run-goods or-treason !"

The agent of that Co., dear

To each soul in Brisbane,

O'erhcard all this ; and laughing, said .

" This, sir, is not Lisbon, " Nor you Alcalde, coming the hop

" Over us. You're spoiling the chop

" Of a worthy magistrate

" By thus bringing to book " A lot of pickles and sauce

" Much needed by his cook."

" Tush, tush !" the Landing Waiter said,

" Hold your jaw, man. Go bag your head !

" I know my duty. Here goes :

" To crack the nut. No chaff

" I'll stand from anybody

******

Gold-seekers often find but stones.

Beggars for meat may get but bones.

If more you wish to know, pray

Ask the Landing Waiter.
heading: LOCAL INTELLIGENCE. THE CONSTABULARY.
snippet: ABOUT a fortnight since, Mr. Constable M'Crohon, on account of his previous good conduct[?] was promoted to the rank of District Constable, and was ordered to procetd to Ipswich in the room
