articleText:
THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL,

SEPTEMBER 8.

After the delivery of His Excellency's speech, which we published in our last, several honorable members spoke on the adoption of a reply. Among others, Mr. WENTWORTH expressed his deep grati- fication at the speech. It was, he said, so unlike anything, in the shape of an address from the Governor, that had yet been heard within the walls of that house, that he was sure the sentiments it professed, and the tone it breathed, must be matter of earnest congratulation to them all. He would not allow himself to believe that that document could be the mere fume and froth with nothing at the bottom, which had formed the materials of similar addresses hitherto delivered to that house, He, for one, had no doubt from the caution evinced by His Excellency in not entering hastily into measures of importance—from the intention ex- pressed by him of visiting the interior and in- forming himself of subjects of which he at present could know nothing, that His Excellency would endeavour to fulfil the professions of his speech. It was by such a course alone that he could arrive at any knowledge of that most important question,

with regard to the colony, the settlement of which was pending, the Squatting and Crown Lands question.

SEPTEMBER 9,

Two letters were read from the Hon. Francis Scott, Parliamentary Agent of the Council. [The last and most important of these, we will endeavour to find room for in our next.]

A petition from the merchants of Sydney pray- ing the Council to take evidence on the loss, in- convenience, and injustice under which they suffered, from the exercise given to the jurisdiction of the Admiralty Court of this colony, was read

and received.

SEPTEMBER 10.

The SPEAKER read the following message from

the Governor :—

" The Governor transmits to the Legislative Council a copy of an Address which has this day been presented to him by a deputation from the merchants, bankers, and other inhabitants of this colony, whose names are thereunto affixed, praying for his co-operation in endeavouring to establish steam communication between Sydney and Great Britain.

" In submitting this Address to the Legislative Council, the Governor begs to recommend it to their most favourable consideration.

" It is not necessary that he should expatiate on the important and beneficial results that may be expected both to the colonies and to the mother country, should it be found practicable to carry this scheme into effect ; but he begs to a sure the Council that he is willing to co-operate with them to the utmost extent of his power in any measures they may think proper to adopt for the accom- plishment of so desirable an object."

A Bill, introduced by Mr. Lowe, the object of which is, to give clergymen of the Church of England a freehold in their benefices; rendering them less dependent upon the Bishop; was read a first time. The Bishop of Australia intends (Mr. Cowper stated) to ask to be heard at the bar of the House in opposition to it.

A Bill to simplify the law abolishing imprison-

ment for debt, was read a first time.

Mr. WINDETER moved for leave to bring in a Bill to amend the law respecting the recovery of small debts in all places in the colony except the county of Cumberland. The Bill was nearly the same as that he had introduced last session. Its main principle was to give benches of magistrates jurisdiction over actions for debts not exceeding £10. There were various other alterations of the existing law, such as bringing actions of trespass, where the damages did not exceed £10, under the jurisdiction of these Courts, excluding all those cases where the title of freehold came in question.

Leave granted, and the Bill read a first time.

The Council resolved to address His Excellency, praying him to move Her Majesty to disallow an Act of the Legislature of Van Diemen's Land, which imposes a duty of fifteen per cent on the produce of New South Wales imported into that colony. In the course of the debate that took place before the address was resolved upon, the Colonial Secretary, cleverly adapting his ideas to

" things as they are, and not as they have been," or to use a homely adage, " cutting his coat ac- cording to his cloth," made a furious free-trade speech. Sir Charles Fitzroy, the new Governor, is a free-trader-so is the Colonial Secretary ; Sir .George Gipps was an economist, or a protection- ist, as the fit seized him—so was Mr. Thomson. Messrs. Windeyer, Wentworth and Lowe " twitted" the hon. gentleman upon his change of opinions. Mr. Wentworth was " surprised that so earnest a free-trader should not have thought of repealing the duty of 2s. per lb on tobacco." Mr. Lowe alluded to the " Tariff Bill, passed last year, which imposes a differential duty in admitting rum from one country at a less duty than rum from ano- ther ;" and to the " Wharfage Bill, where a duty was imposed on other wharfs, in order that the Government Wharf might be made to pay." Mr. Windeyer spoke of the taxes on tea and sugar.

A Bill to repeal so much of all local ordinances now in existence, as assumes to vest the appro- priation of the ordinary revenue elsewhere than in .the Legislative Council, was read a first time.

Mr. WENTWORTH moved for leave to bring in a " Bill to regulate the sale of fermented and spiritu- ous liquors in the colony of New South Wales."

Leave refused, on the ground that in so short a session as was anticipated, the Council would not have time to dispose of so large a Bill.

The COLLECTOR OF CUSTOMS moved for leave to bring in a Bill to repeal so much of the Act of the Governor and Council, 8 Victoria, No. 16, as provides for the levying a wharfage rate on goods shipped in the colony. The provisions referred to having been found to interfere with the facili- ties of trade, it had been found necessary to re- peal those portions of them relating to goods shipped in the colony.

Mr. ROBINSON called the attention of the Col- lector of Customs to the report of the Committee on Wharfage Rates, in which it was recommended that whenever the revenue would permit, the rates should be abolished. It was a very petty tax, the amount raised last year in Sydney being only £3200, and in Melbourne only £1200 ; and as it has a considerable effect upon trade, it was worthy of consideration whether the wharfage rate should not be abolished altogether now that the revenue is in a flourishing condition.

The Bill was read a first time.

So also was a Bill to remove difficulties in the

disposal, administration, and distribution of In- solvent Estates, which had become necessary in consequence of doubts on the part of some of the legal fraternity as to the effect of titles derived

under insolvent estates.

SEPTEMBER 11.

Mr. BREWSTER moved for leave to bring in a Bill to declare and amend the law respecting the date of Deeds of Grant of Crown Lands. The object of the Bill was to declare that a grant should bear date, not from the day on which it was signed by the Governor, as at present, but

from the time when the land it conveyed had been bought and paid for.

Bill read a first time.

Mr. MURRAY moved for leave to bring in a Bill to amend the Masters and Servants' Act. By a decision which had been lately given by the Syd- ney magistrates, it would appear that men who signed indentures of service in Van Diemen's Land with masters in the colony, were not con- sidered to come under that Act. Mr. Eales, of the Hunter River, had brought a case of this description before the Bench, and they had de- cided that they had no jurisdiction. There were other clauses too, which would appear to be de- fective in reference to this point, even if the in- dentures could be brought under the jurisdiction of the Act. Summary jurisdiction was only given in cases in which the parties appeared before the Bench for some breach of their contract, in their several capacity as masters and servants, and he doubted Whether a breach of these indentures could be brought under these clauses. Another defect in the law which required amendment was, that it provided no punishments for forged certificates, and as these forgeries were growing very common, it was absolutely necessary, if the Act were to be carried out at all, that some punishment should be provided. Another fault in the Act was that it gave the servant a right to appeal to a Court of Quarter Session, in cases of an award made by the magistrates, whilst the master was denied all right to appeal, except in case of a conviction. In the penalties imposed, as far as his experience went, he had found the Act to work well. He would notice two great objections urged against the Act by different parties. The first was, that it gave the magistrates the power to examine both the complainant and defendant on oath, and that this was productive of very serious evils. He, however, did not see that there was anything in this that was not quite consistent with the spirit of the law reforms which were taking place at home, and they had two precedents for it in the law as it at present existed in the colony, for both parties could be examined on oath in the Courts

of Requests, and under the Merchant Seamen's Act, and, under certain limitations, in some actions

brought in the Supreme Court. The other ob- jection entertained against the Act was, the sys- tem of giving discharges, but for this also they had a precedent in the Merchant Seamen's Act, the provisions of which were in their spirit and in- tentions analogous to the Act under consideration. Mr. DANGAR said, when the Bill went in Com mittee he should move several alterations. The first would be to make the penalty for masters en- gaging servants who had not a discharge, much

higher than it was at present. Under the Act it was limited to £5, which was insufficient. The next defect he should propose to amend was that clause of the Act rendering it necessary for ser- vants to obtain a discharge, making an exception in favour of natives and free emigrants who had not been before engaged. The effect of this was to nullify the operation of the. Act, for of course any runaway servant, who applied for service, would, when he was asked for his discharge, say that he was a native, or that it was the first time of his engaging. He should propose that all persons in whose favour the exception in the Act was made should provide themselves with a cer- tificate from a single magistrate, stating who they were. He did not require a certificate from a bench of magistrates, but from a single magis- trate, and there would never be any difficulty in obtaining this.

Mr. ROBINSON was of opinion that the main reason that the Act had not answered expectations was, because there were no Courts of Petty Ses- sions established beyond the boundaries of location, to enforce its operation.

Leave was then granted, and the Bill read a

first time.

Captain O'CONNELL moved for a return of all the horses, cattle, and sheep, sold by auction in the colony of New South Wales, and upon which duty has been paid from the year 1836 to 1845, both years inclusive, specifying the total amount, the average price paid, and the highest and lowest price per head paid in each year respectively. His object in this motion was to add a very important item to that valuable mass of statistical informa- tion, which the talent and industry of the Colonial Secretary, from year to year, brought before them. He thought he might assume that the capital of the colony was principally vested in live stock, and any fluctuations in the price of such stock would be a pretty fair index of the prosperity or depression of the colony. He found there were returns of sales by auction from which this in- formation could probably be compiled.

Question put, and passed.

Council adjourned to the 15th.

SEPTEMBER 15.

The SPEAKER stated that the deputation ap- pointed by the House to present the address of the Legislative Council, praying His Excellency to move Her Majesty to disallow the Bill lately passed by the Legislature of Van Diemen's Land, proposing an ad valorem duty of fifteen per cent. on the produce of New South Wales imported into that colony, had waited upon His Excellency, who had been pleased to inform them that he would forward the address to the Secretary of State, and

would use his own influence with the Government

in support of the prayer of the address.

Mr. BREWSTER moved for leave to bring in a Bill to regulate the practice of the legal profes- sion, as relating to the admission of barristers and attorneys ; and to render both branches of the profession common to both, as was the case in this colony up to February, 1835, when the bar was for' the first time divided. There was no di- vision of barristers and attorneys (Mr. B. said) in the United States, Canada, the West Indies, Van Diemen's Land, and South Australia. The hon. member produced several bills of costs, which he read to the House ; asserting that had the pro- fession been open, the same services would have been

rendered to tho client for one-fourth of the amount.

Quoted from Jeremy Bentham, &c, &c.

Motion seconded by Mr. DANGAR.

Mr. WENTWORTH moved the previous question, which was seconded by Mr. DARVALL.

Mr. LOWE made a very able speech in support of the original motion ; in the course of which he characterised the division of the bar as a "most absurd and useless monopoly - it gave neither talent nor respectability to the profession of a barrister, whilst it shut out those who had both. It increased the expense attendant upon the administration of justice ; and to him it ap- peared that of all taxes the most cruel was the tax upon justice ; for it was a tax upon right. It was a tax upon the poor and weak man, to prevent him asserting his right against the oppression and wrong-doings of the rich and powerful. But if a tax on justice wore bad in any shape, how much worse was it, when it was levied not to go into the public revenue-not to promote the public good, but secure the monopoly of certain emolu- ments to any particular class of men. For what, he would ask, were barristers, but a tax on the administration of justice? There could be no doubt that if barristers were not required, the expense would be lessened. True, there had been some talk about the advantages of the division of labour ; but the fact was, that it required the very same description of learning to make a good attorney as it did to make a good barrister. It therefore was not a division of labour ; it was a multiplication of labour-to create expense. It was not a only a waste of human labour, but a waste for which the community were,' by the mo- nopoly, forced to pay. It could not be defended in the profession of the law, more than it could be in the most familiar callings."

The original motion was passed by 16 to 9 ;

and the Bill read a first time.

The Council,on the motion of Mr. WENTWORTH, resolved to address His Excellency the Governor, praying that he would be pleased to place on the Estimates of Expenditure for the ensuing year, a sum not exceeding £1000, for liquidating the debt due for the erection of a Jewish Synagogue in Sydney ; and a sum not exceeding £200 for the support of a Jewish Minister of religion.

SEPTEMBER 16.

The COLONIAL SECRETARY said that it was not

the intention of Government to enter into any new postal arrangements during the present session, in order to allow time to the Commis- sioners who had been sent out from Home to make their report.

A Select Committee of seven members was ap- pointed to take into consideration the best means of establishing steam communication between this colony and England.

The SPEAKER read the following minute from his Excellency the Governor :--

1. The Governor finds that, on the 9th of June last, his predecessor submitted to the Council an estimate for the year 1847, as well as a supple- mentary estimate for the year 1846. These esti- mates he adopts, and now re-submits for the con- sideration of the Council, with certain alterations and additions, which will be found detailed in the two accompanying statements.

The total amount of the additional estimate for 1847 is, it will be seen, £42,110 17s. 5d. This, at

first sight, will appeal to be a large addition ; but it is to be borne in mind that a portion of it is merely nominal, whilst by far the largest amount of the increase arises from the restoration of the estimates for the Border and Native Police, which were omitted by his predecessor in consequence of the contemplated expiration of the Act, 2 Vic, No. 27. In reality, therefore, this charge will not constitute any actual increase in the expenditure of the colony ; though, as the revenue to meet it has ceased with the expiration of the Act, it will henceforth have to be defrayed out of the ordinary revenue, so soon as the unexpended balance raised by the assessment on stock, and amounting on 31st December last to £17,204, shall have been exhausted. Whether it will be possible in future to provide for this expenditure out of the ordinary revenue, is a question which will require the serious attention of the Government and the Coun- cil ; but in the meantime, with the unexpended balance raised by assessment, and the pressing necessity which appears to exist of affording an adequate protection to the important interests now engaged beyond the boundaries of location, the Governor has not thought himself justified in de- clining to submit to the Council an estimate for this expenditure.

3. The addition caused by laying before the Council the estimates for the Courts of Requests amounting to. £4,560 3 9 and for the Insolvent Courts . .. £1,065 16 3

together ...... £5,626 0 0

is also of a nominal description. The expenses of these Courts will, it is estimated, be covered,, or nearly so. by the amount of fees which will be paid into the Treasury, instead of being applied, as at present, directly to pay the salaries and ex- penses thereby incurred.

4. The Governor has preferred the present course of submitting the estimates of these de- partments to the consideration and revision of the Council, to that which appears has for the last few years been adopted by his predecessor, under the permanent appropriations made by the Acts hav- ing reference to these Courts ; but it is right that the Council should distinctly understand, that, unless these expenses be provided for, he knows of no other source from which they can be de- frayed ; the funds under Schedule A of the Con- stitutional Act for the Administration of Justice, being entirely exhausted by the other expenses properly chargeable thereon.

5. A portion of another item also, is seemingly, though only nominally, an addition to the Esti- mates as originally submitted, namely, the expense for roads, bridges, and ferries, in the County of Cumberland, amounting to £5000, which is at present defrayed from tolls collected under the authority of the Act, 2 W. 4, No. 12, sec. 34 ; but for which it has been thought proper to bring an estimate under the revision of the Council.

6. The present authorised establishment of the

Water Police the Governor is led to believe is not more than adequate for the duties, and he has in consequence adopted it, as more specific in its details, and more satisfactory than that originally proposed.

7. The following statement will show more clearly the nature of the proposed additions to the estimates for 1847, as now submitted :

£ s. d. £ s. d. From the amended estimate of the Water

Police for Sydney and

Port Phillip. 867 17 10

Is to be deducted

The estimate for the same service as ori-

ginally submitted. .. 6Z0 0 0

Leaving the real

addition only.' 217 17 10

If, therefore, from the total amount of the proposed addi-

tions to the estimates

for the year 1847 ... 42,110 17 5

Are deducted for the

reasons assigned- The expenses of the

Courts of Requests.. 4,560 3 9

The expenses of the

Insolvent Courts.... 1,065 16 3

Roads, Bridges, & Ferries, chargeable

on tolls. 5,000 0 0

submitted. 650 0 0

-11,276 0 0

The real addition

will be. 30,834 17 5

Of which £23,073 18s. 4d. is to provide for the Native and Border Police, and which, as already explained, is not a new item of expenditure.

The estimates for these latter services, it will be perceived, have been framed upon the appropria- tions made for them by the Council for the first half of the present year ; the Governor has, how- ever, been induced in same degree to modify them.

It is understood to be the general wish that Petty Sessions should be established beyond the boundaries of location, he has in consequence pro- posed that the sum of £3000 should be appropri- ated for this service in 1847. It has been found impossible to prepare, at present, any more detailed estimate of this expense than that submitted ; but if the amount be voted, the Council may rely on its being expended in the most economical manner, so as to ensure the object contemplated.

9. It has also been represented that, as the duties of the Commissioners will now be in a great measure confined to regulating and aiding in the collection of the license fees, and in other respects acting as guardians of the Crown lands, their re- muneration ought probably to be charged on the Crown revenues. It has, accordingly, been pro- posed, that the estimated charge on the general revenue should be reduced by transferring the amount of their salaries and allowances to the

Crown revenues.

The estimates for the Border and Native Police are, therefore, confined to the amount required for preserving the peace in the districts beyond the

limits of location.

10. The nature of the remainder of the proposed additions which have not been adverted to will readily be understood by the particulars stated in the estimates, and will be explained by the proper officer of the Government when they are brought in detail under the consideration of the Council.

11. With the proposed additions the total amount of the estimated expenditure for the year 1847, is

as follows:

To meet the above amount of estimated expendi- ture, the Ways and Means, on carefully consider- ing the estimates, as furnished by the several heads of departments, with reference to the amount of revenue collected in the years 1843 to 1845, and more especially to the amount actually received in the first eight months of the present year, are estimated as follows :

Government House, Sept. 16, 1846.

The Scab and Catarrh in Sheep Act Amendment Bill, and the Ordinary Revenue Appropriation

Bill, were read a second time.

The COLLECTOR OF CUSTOMS moved for leave to

bring in a Bill to repeal certain parts of the Act of the Governor and Council of New South Wales, 9 Vic,No. 15, and to provide for the better regu- lation of the coasting trade of the colony. His object in moving this Bill was merely to give greater facilities in the shipping and landing of goods in the coasting trade than at present existed, as entries were obliged to be passed for the smallest package at Port Phillip and at Moreton Bay, by the present law ; and such a system proved highly

inconvenient.

Leave was granted, and the Bill read a first time,

THE MORETON BAT COURIER is published every

Saturday morning. The terms of subscription are 10s. per quarter, payable in advance : the quarters ending 30th September, 31st Decem- ber, 3lst March, and 30th June, in each year respectively. Each advertisement will be charged at the rate of three shillings an inch, and one shilling for every additional inch, each insertion. The number of insertions must be specified on each advertisement, or they will be continued until countermanded by a written

notice.

Printed and Published by the Proprietor, ARTHUR

SIDNEY LYON, at the General Printing Office, Albert-street, North Brisbane, in the Colony of New South Wales. Orders and communications

(in all cases pre-paid) to be addressed to the

Proprietor.
heading: THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL. SEPTEMBER 8.
snippet: After the delivery of His Excellency's speech[?] which we published in our last, several honorable members spoke on the adoption of a reply. Among others, Mr. WENTWORTH expressed his deep

articleText:
NEW ZEALAND.

(From the Sydney Morning Herald, Oct. 23.)

We have Port Nicholson papers to the 23rd ultimo. All was quiet in the south. Rangi- haeata was endeavouring to raise a party; but the vigorous proceedings of Governor Grey had had such an effect upon the natives, that even those

hostile to the Government were afraid to exhibit their hostility by any overt acts. A court martial was sitting for the trial of some of the natives, who, after professing to be friendly, had joined the enemy. Two were convicted, one of whom was executed. The presence of the troops had caused a great demand for fresh meat: the con- tract for supplying them was taken at 11¾d., and 13½d. per lb.

EXECUTION OF ONE OF THE REBELS.—The court martial appointed to try the rebels who were made prisoners during the late military operations,

commenced its sittings at the camp at Parramatta Point, Porirua, on Monday morning. The court was composed of the following members:—Major

Arney, 58th Regt., president ; Captain O'Connell, Captain Newingham, 65th ; Captain Armstrong

Captain Reid, 99th ; Captain Laye, 58th Regts. ; and the Hon. W. Yelverton, Royal Artillery. Mr. Servantes acted as interpreter. The prisoners who were confined on board the Calliope, were landed early on Monday morning, and were de- livered over to the custody of the military. The first prisoner tried was Rangihaeata, one of the scouts captured by the Ngatitoas at Pauatahanui, on the 1st of August. This man either is or affects to be insane, and in consequence of the doubt entertained of his sanity has escaped the extreme penalty of the law, but has been sentenced to be imprisoned for life. Martin Luther, whose native name is Wareaitu, and who was taken pri- soner on the march by the militia about the same time was tried the following day. This native was brother to Rangihaeata, and was a chief of considerable influence at Wanganui. He was tried on two counts, the first charging him with having been engaged in the attack on the troops on the 16th June, and the second count with having been taken in arms against the peace of the Queen, and with having joined the rebels under Rangi- haeata. To the latter count, he pleaded guilty. The forms of the court were extremely simple, and appeared to be perfectly understood by the natives. The principal evidence brought, forward was that of the two natives who took him prisoner, and that of two native women, who proved that they had seen the prisoner in Rangihaeata's pah, and that he had acted with Rangihaeata's party. The prisoner admitted the correctness of the evi- dence and was found guilty and was sentenced to be hanged. The prisoner, throughout the pro- ceeding manifested, the utmost; coolness and self possession. He admitted that he made a great mistake in joining Rangihaeata, and has written to his friends at Wanganui dissuading them from engaging in hostilities against the government. He said he was not afraid to die, and only re- gretted that he was not shot or tomakawked in- stead of having been taken prisoner. The Rev. H. Govett, who was in the neighbourhood on his return to Waikanae, on the evening previous to the execution was sent for, and arrived at the camp on six o'clock on Thursday morning, and remained with the prisoner during his last mo- ments. The gallows was erected about three hundred yards from the stockade inclosing the camp, near a long conical sand-hill, and was about sixteen feet high, with a platform raised about ten feet from the ground, and with one end resting on the sand-hill. At eight o'clock the prisoner was led out, guarded by the armed police, and followed by a detachment of soldiers, who formed three sides of a square in front of the place of execution, the fourth side being occupied by the police and the scaffold, which was in the centre. Sentries were posted along the ditch of the camp, who kept the spectators (about twenty Europeans and fifteen natives) at a distance of one hundred and fifty yards from the place of execution. After his handcuffs were removed, the prisoner was pinioned, and was led along the sand-hill to the scaffold. He walked with a firm step, and showed no symptoms of fear at his ap- proaching end, and stood perfectly erect while the fatal rope was adjusted round his neck. Every- thing being in readiness, the drop fell, and the prisoner was launched into eternity : for a few seconds he remained perfectly motionless, and then after a few convulsive struggles life was extinct. No cap was drawn over the face of the prisoner previous to his execution, and the body after remaining the usual time was cut down. From the early hour at which it occurred, the natives belonging to the Taupo pah were too late to witness the execution, having stayed to get their breakfast ; but the greater part arrived pre- vious to the body being cut down, and with the exception of a few of the old men, appeared to concur in the justice of the sentence, and approved of its having been put into execution.—New Zealand Spectator, September 16.

(From the Australian, October 24.)

Intelligence from Auckland to the 16th Sep- tember had reached Wellington by the steamer Driver. At the time of her departure His Ex- cellency the Governor was labouring under severe indisposition. All was quiet in the north.

His Honor the Superintendent of Wellington had issued an order tor the disbandment of the militia in that district, in consequence, as the order states, of " the altered and more pacific state of the country."

The natives between Wellington and Waikanae have a great number of acres of land laid down in wheat. Their crop this season, if favourable, will yield 200 tons of flour. Two or three natives at Waikanae, have a patch of eighty acres, in a block of the finest land, sown with wheat.

BLINDNESS v. SIMPLICITY.—Did you take the note, and did you see Mr. ——, Jack ?" " Yes, sur." " And how was he !" " Why, he looks pretty well, but he's very blind." " Blind ! what do you mean ?" " Why, while I wor in the room, he axed me where my hat wer, and it wor on my head all the while."

" Faix," said Tim Conolly, speaking of his wife's home-brewed treacle beer, which she recommended as better than potheen,—" them that gets the laist

of it is best served."

A NEWSPAPER.—A sheet of paper, about going to press, may be likened to a clean tablecloth put upon the table of a large party, and studded well with provisions from all parts of the globe ; the difference is, one is for the succour and luxury of the body, the other for the sustenance of the mind —this is a newspaper.

The MORETON BAY COURIER is published every

articleText:
COLONIAL.

ISSUE OF DEPASTURING LICENSES.

( From the Sydney Morning Herald. )

Although the Squatting Question will probably stand in abeyance until next year, we ought not to overlook a paper on that subject printed by order of the Council four months ago, containing information never, we believe, so circumstantially made public before.

It is a " Return of all depasturing Licenses in

the several Districts of the Commissioners of Crown Lands beyond the boundaries of location ; distinguishing the names of the occupiers, and the amount paid for such licenses by each indivi- dual, during the year commencing 1st July, 1845, and ending the 30th June, 1846."

The Return does not quite correspond with its title, for instead of embracing the whole year, it reaches only to the 18th of May, and is made up to three different periods, 31st December, 20th March, and 18th May.

As the particulars given to the end of last year may serve to throw some new light upon the re- turn of live stock at the same period, we shall notice it separately. Many persons holding more than one license in the same district, it is neces- sary to distinguish between the number of licenses and the number of graziers. The licenses taken out for the several districts, between the 1st and July and 31st December, 1845, were therefore as

follows :

Districts. Licenses. Graziers. Fees Paid.

Bligh... 122 68 £1,259 Clarence River . 62 54 877 Darling Downs. 24 20 541 Lachlan. 170 136 2,014 Liverpool Plains 176 121 2,703 McLeay River.. 41 33 440

Maneroo . 155 131 2,223 10s. Moreton Bay ... 35 33 592 10s. Murrumbidgee .... 157 146 1,991 10s. New England .... 75 03 1,490 10s. Wellington _ 113 69 1,432 10s.

1130 879 £15,564 10s.

In endeavouring to arrive at an average of the stock depastured under each license, by compar- ing the above return with that given at page 5, of the Colonial Secretary's Book of Statistics, we must bear in mind that the great inequality of the runs, in point of pasturage, water, &c, renders any thing like accuracy quite unattainable. Still, however, as this is the only guide we possess to approximate results, we must be content with it. The averages per license, at the end of the year

1845, appear then to have been about as fol-

lows :-

Horses. Cattle. Sheep. Bligh ... 6 290 1,125

Clarence River . 15 449 2,403 Darling Downs. 18 596 8,765 Lachlan . 14 467 939 Liverpool Plains. 18 1,010 1,884 McLeay River. 18 467 55 Maneroo. 33 873 2,243 Moreton Bay . 17 417 5,444 Murrumbidgee ... 14 606 1,879 New England ...... 19 671 6,628 Wellington... 8 438 1,753 General average. 17 618 2,229

According to these results, the largest number

of horses under each license run is in the Maneroo

district, being 33, and the smallest in the Bligh district, 6 ; the largest number of cattle in the Liverpool Plains district, 1,010 ; and the smallest in the Bligh district, 290 ; the largest number of sheep in the Darling Downs district, 8,765 . and the smallest in the McLeay River district, 55. The average amount paid for each license was about £13 15s. 6d. ; by each grazier, £17 11s. 10d. ; and for each horse, head of cattle, and sheep de- pastured, rather more than one penny.

The number of licenses taken out between the 31st December, 1845, and the 18th May, 1846, added to those enumerated above, make, for the broken period from the 1st July, 1845, to the last mentioned date, the following totals :

Licenses. Graziers.

Bligh . 131 79

Clarence River. 64 56 Darling Downs. 35 30 Lachlan. 184 147 Liverpool Plains. 195 137 McLeay River. 44 35 Maneroo. 173 148 Moreton Bay. 36 34 Murrumbidgee . 177 166 New England. 96 86 Wellington. 117 73

Totals. 1255 . 991

It would thus appear that the district for which the largest number of licenses were taken out was Liverpool Plains; and the smallest, Darling

Downs.

The number of licensed graziers for the year, according to the returns, may be stated in round numbers at a thousand ; but as many of them hold licenses for more than one district, the actual number must be considerably less. We confess this result surprises us. What the present popu- lation beyond the boundaries may be, we do not yet know, but shall soon be informed by the pub- lication of the Census Tables. Taking, however, the population given by the Census of the year 1841, the proportion of licenses is not one in ten ; at the present time it cannot, we should think, be one in twenty.

It is stated in a note on the face of the return, that the returns for the Port Phillip district had not then been received in a complete form. These returns have yet, therefore, to be laid before the Council ; and we would suggest to the Colonial Treasurer, that while he is completing the return in that particular, it would be well to make the general return complete for the year, by bringing it down to the date specified in the address.

PORK.

( From the Hobart Town Advertiser. )

It has been a pretty general complaint against colonial cured meat that it will not keep properly, and in consequence an immense quantity of beef shipped from New South Wales and Port Phillip

was condemned at home. Whether this arose

from the condition of the cattle before being killed, from the salt, the climate, the time of the year, ignorance of the mode of salting, negligence, or a concatenation of some or all of them, we know not, but we are pleased to hear that later shipments have turned out better, and perhaps in time Australian salt beef may rank with that of Ireland or Hamburgh. Meantime we have some doubts on the subject, because it is our firm con- viction, founded on a good deal of experience, that climate has much to do with the proper curing of moat. That to be thoroughly impregnated with salt so as to undergo that chemical combination which prevents decay, without materially injuring the nutritious properties of the meat, there must be a degree of moisture in the atmosphere, com- bined with a temperature so low as to prevent in- cipient putrefaction, yet not so low as to coagulate the pieces of the meat, and thus prevent the proper absorption of the salt. It is well known that in Ireland, where there is more beef salted than in all the world beside, the season is principally confined to two months in the year, which answer these requisites, from the middle of October to the latter end of December, and that the setting in of the frost has an injurious tendency. For this reason we believe that the winter of this colony is better suited to the curing of meat than that of the ad- jacent colonies, and though it is not probable that we can salt beef to any very great extent, there is no doubt that pork can be well and effectually cured, if only the attempt were encouraged at the outset. We know that the curing can be most effectually performed, having seen and eaten some which Mr. Ladds, of Elizabeth-street, salted for a Commissariat contract fifteen months ago. For some reason or other the tender was not accepted, and as we said, of some which he still has, we eat a few days since. The quality and condition proved most decidedly that pork can be cured here equal to that of any country ; we shall not even except Ireland. It was firm, close, sound, thoroughly, yet not over salted, and exhibited that first-rate quality of not boiling out or shrinking in cooking, We think that our small farmers might turn their attention to this subject with ad- vantage. It is among men of this class that the innumerable pigs which supply the navies of England, which form so large an export in every British colony, are reared and fattened. We do not believe that on a large scale, or as an exclusive branch of farming, it would pay ; but as adjunct to the other stock, that pigs might be raised suffi- cient to supply at least our own shipping, thus keeping much of the capital in the colony.

INDIA.

( From the Launceston Examiner. )

By the way of Mauritius we have an important

notice of Indian affairs.

The principal news contained in the Calcutta journals to the 10th May, is an account of a dis- turbance that had broken out in Lahore, arising from a European sentry of artillery severely wounding a bullock with a bayonet. The party to whom it belonged raised a hue and cry, and ran away telling all he met that the Europeans had killed his bullock, and that the city had been polluted. This was of course too readily believed by some Seikhs, and immediately taken advantage of: all shops were immediately closed, and a dreadful riot was the consequence. The insti- gators of the riot, fourteen in number, had been apprehended and sentenced to lose their right hands ; and all the houses that were in the neighbourhood of the scene of action, and from which brickbats were flung, raised to the ground. This for the sake of example.

The Maharajah had paid a state visit to Major Lawrence, the political agent, upon the subject, and here the matter remained.

The other great event in the Punjaub is the continued refusal of the Killadar of Kote Kangra to surrender that fort to the British authorities. The force despatched to take the charge of it was attended by Captain Cunningham and Runjoor Singh, the latter of whom sent in his parwanah to the commandant to give up the place. -It was treated with the utmost contempt, and the mes- senger was kicked out of the place ; the Mahara- jah's order was then sent in, but found no better treatment, a haughty defiance being hurled against the chief, the Maharajah, and the British. A couple of regiments were ordered up to reduce it, under Brigadier Wheeler, and it was not anti- cipated that much trouble would be incurred in the task, though to Oriental attacks the spot had hitherto been considered impregnable. The Dur- bar, irritated at the news, had set on foot a search in Lahore for the relatives of the officers and soldiers garrisoning the refractory fortress, in order to imprison them.

A few days later, in the Delhi Gazette, May 4, we learn that the 44th N.I., had taken possession of the fort of Mulkera, and occupied the town of Kangra, where they were exposed to a constant fire, without any loss. The country people had risen to aid our troops, and a neighbouring Rajah had lent three guns. Major Lawrence was daily expected. Great preparations were making for the reduction of the fortress, already in a state of blockade. The besieged were actively engaged in strengthening their position, by opening new em brazures, defending their magazines from the bombs, and in undermining the ramparts where they were most accessible ; they had given the British force proofs of their skill as marksmen, one of the Seikhs having directed a cannon towards the house in the town, occupied by the Officers for their mess, the second ball traversed the wall and passed over the table, just before the dinner was placed on it. Fortunately, no person was in the room. The beseiged had set fire to several parts of the town, by firing rockets during the night; our troops were obliged to assist in putting it out.

It was reported that Brig. Smith was to take the command of the force against the fort of Kangra.

Sir Eardley Wilmot.-One of the severest reproaches ever cast upon a Governor by those over whom he is placed, has just been inflicted upon his Excellency Sir Eardley Wilmot, by the Midland Agricultural Asssciation of Van Diemen's Land, a society comprising among its members a large number of the most respectable inhabitants of the colony. We learn from the Hobart Town Courier of the 9th instant, that a meeting of the members of this society was held on the 8th inst., " to take into consideration a despatch of his Ex- cellency the Lieutenant-Governor, of date the 1st August, 1845, addressed to Lord Stanley, and published by order of the House of Commons, purporting to be a commentary on the petition of the inhabitants of Van Diemen's Land, against the present systen of transportation, so far as that despatch bears on the credit and character of the petitioners. The interests of the colony, and the usefulness of his Excellency Sir John E. Eardley Wilmot, Bart., as the patron of the Midland Agri- cultural Association." At this meeting various resolutions were passed, quoting extracts from the despatch referred to, and contradicting the state- ments they contain, and the last (which was moved by Messrs. J. Taylor, J. Mackersey, and R. Dry) was in these words-" That this meeting, after a calm, careful, dispassionate review of the despatch, and a rigid investigation of the truth, find that the statements submitted as matters of fact are not

correct, and that the despatch does not comprise a full and fair view of the petition submitted by the colonists to the Home Government, the circum- stances of the colony, or the condition of the peo- ple ; the facts have been concealed, disguised, or modified in such a manner as to mislead the Secre- tary of State, to the great injury of the colony, and in direct violation of the principles on which this Association has been established-namely, the advancement of the community. With the utmost pain, therefore, but as a necessary sacrifice to truth and justice, the members of this Associa- tion are compelled to declare publicly that it ceases to consider Sir John E. Eardley Wilmot, Bart., Patron of the Midland Agricultural Association, and to direct, in accordance with this resolution, that his name be erased from the books of the Society." The proceedings of the meeting are stated to have been conducted in the most calm and decorous manner, and great regret was ex- pressed at the painful position in which the mem- bers felt themselves placed. We think our readers will agree with us that a more severe, and, we are bound to say, a more just censure, was never passed on a Governor.-Herald.

The Moreton Bay Courier is published every

Saturday morning. The terms of subscription are 10s. per quarter, payable in advance : the quarters ending 30th September, 31st Decem- ber, 31st March, and 30th June, in each year respectively. Each advertisement will be charged at the rate of three shillings an inch, and one shilling for every additional inch, each insertion. The number of insertions must be specified on each advertisement, or they will be continued until countermanded by a written

notice.

Printed and Published by the Proprietor, Arthur

articleText:
COLONIAL ABSTRACT.

Coal of good quality had been brought from the neighbourhood of Cape Otway to Geelong —The total population of the district of Port Phillip is stated to be 32,895, being greater than that of South and Western Australia combined.—A branch of the Union Bank of Australia will be esta- blished at Portland in about two months.—An Im- migration Society has been established at Portland. It is proposed to raise funds by a rateable con- tribution on stock, £1 for every thousand sheep, or for five hundred cattle.—The body of a man had been found beyond Mount Gambier, on the Adelaide road, and from the marks upon it is supposed to have been murdered by the blacks. They are very troublesome in that district, having carried off many sheep, and intelligence has been received of an affray between them and the police, in which one of the natives was shot and two wounded.—The registered births in South Aus- tralia in 1845 was 708 ; the marriages 141 ; the deaths 238. The total population 22,320, of which 12,670 were males, and 9650 females.—One hun- dred and fourteen ships and vessels entered the harbour of Adelaide during 1845. The balance of arrivals and departures of persons from South Aus- tralia in 1845 is in favour of the former by 1888. There are forty-one places of worship in South Australia, adapted to accommodate 7020 persons. —In the same province there are eighteen brew- eries, twenty-four flour mills, four foundries, ten malthouses, and eight tanneries.—In 1845 the land sales in 1845 amounted to £52,902 8s.—The whole number of criminal convictions in 1845 was 22 ; and the insolvencies 26.—The inhabitants of the district of the Wellington and the Hutt, New Zealand, are forming themselves into volunteer companies very rapidly. The Te-Aro volunteers muster 150 strong, and the Thomson volunteers about 60 ; there are several other companies, and arms are supplied to the whole by the Government. —The Portland Bay Gazette narrates a horrible instance of savage depravity. One of the black women who frequent Mr. Gibson's station, had a puppy of which she became very fond ; she was constantly lamenting that she could not procure it a sufficiency of delicate food ; in order to supply it, while the males of her tribe were out hunting, she killed her own infant child, in order that the milk given to it might be preserved for her fa- vourite.—His Excellency the Governor has made the following appointments in the Customs Depart- ment, at Twofold Bay, viz. : Hamon Massie, Esq., to be sub-collector, and Edmund Gibbes, Esq., to be landing waiter.—In 1843 the estimated value of the salt meat imported into the colony was £19,286 ; in 1844, £3355 ; in 1845, £5200. The export in 1843 was £13,924 ; in 1844, £18,730 ; and in 1845, £12,163.—A land sale at Port Phillip had realized £3549 16s. 9d.—The Melbourne Argus states that an order had been issued by the local Executive, authorising the offi- cers of the various protectorate establishments to seize and kill for the use of the blacks, all un- branded cattle above the age of twelve months.— The result of Petrel's (the Port Phillip race horse) repeated defeats had reached Port Phillip, and created a strong feeling of disappointment.

RIDING AND DRIVING.—One coachman will

hustle along a heavy, lazy team, that another equally good can scarcely keep his time with ; but give a team of regular larking, fly-away devils to the latter, he will keep them together, in temper and pace, better than the former, who would per- haps be too rude with them. He could drive all sorts : so they both could, but neither of them all sorts equally well. So in riding, one man excels on a light-mouthed, nervous, fidgetty horse : he will coax him across country, and prevent him taking too much.out of himself. This can only be done by sitting quite still on him, having fine delicate hands, patience, and temper that nothing can disturb. Another shines on a violent, restive, determined horse : here a man must have a seat firm as a Centaur, arms and shoulders of cast iron, and resolution and courage that nothing can daunt. He must also keep his temper, or, what is bad to begin with, he will render it quite un- manageable before his business is done. Temper is also a sine qua non in a coachman : it is even more necessary than in a horseman, for the sake of others. An irritated horse bolts off with his rider, or throws him, or both ; he alone pays the penalty of his fault : but an irritated horse in harness, particularly in a light private carriage, is perfectly awful. We may and can manage him as a wheeler to a coach ; the weight and his com- panions will hold him ; but, in a light carriage, let me tell very young coachmen who may think they are in little danger, that no man living can hold two horses determined to run away ; and as to four all in the same mind, they are no more to be held than a locomotive engine, for which reason we should never get their steam up too high.—

Stable-talk and Table-talk.

The general order against smoking in the army has occasioned a deep sensation in every mess-room in the kingdom, and created such a panic in the cigar market, that good sheroots were down at an unusually low figure and the Manillas were down at a penny, which had been command- ing threehalfpence, with a fair sprinkling of buyers, for the last eight months. The cabbage growers are in despair, for the young officers had been the chief consumers of the hardy winter savoy, which must now be sold as food for the lower classes, instead of being packed in ivory cases for mess-room tables, as the best Havan- nahs, imported direct from Havannah by the Hammersmith 'bus. As to the military them- selves, meetings are being called in every regi- ment to consider whether the officers shall coolly submit to allow the Duke of Wellington to put all their pipes out. The Duke of Wellington has blown a cloud over the whole of the army by his inconsiderate endeavour to banish the cigar from the mess-room. The officers naturally ask what they are to do when they meet, for they are to be restrained from boxing, wrestling, leap-frog, blind-man's-buff; as well as prohibited from smoking, and they dread the possibility of being thrown upon their conversational resources, which must have a most dreary effect. Under their

present trying position we can offer no consolation to the inmates of the barracks, except such as they may derive from taking it by turns to read Punch aloud to the whole mess.—Punch.

Why is a temperance pledge like an umbrella ? —Because it protects you from heavy wet.

KEEPING FOWLS.—Hens will lay eggs perpe- tuaily, if treated in the following manner ;—Keep no roosters, give the hens fresh meat, chopped like fine sausage meat, once a day to each hen, during the winter, or from the time insects dis- appear in the fall, till they appear again in th« spring. Never allow any eggs to remain In the nest for what is called nest eggs. When the roosters do not run with the hens, and no eggs in the nest, the hens will not cease laying after the production of twelve or fifteen eggs, as they al- ways do when roosters and the nest eggs are al- lowed ; but continue laying perpetually. My hens lay all winter, and from seventy-five to one hun- dred eggs in succession. If the foregoing plan was generally followed, eggs would be just as plentiful in winter as in summer. The only reason why hens do not lay in winter as freely as in sum- mer, is the want of animal food, which they get in summer in abundance in the form of insects. I have, for several winters, reduced my theory to practice, and proved its entire correctness. It must be observed that the presence of the male is not necessary for the production of eggs, as they are formed whether the male be present or not. Of course such eggs will not produce chickens. When chickens are wanted, the roosters must of course run with the hens.—Alban Cultivator.

WANT OF AFFECTION AMONG THE NEW ZEA- LANDERS.—Instances of attachment or friendship are very rarely to be seen amongst the New Zea- landers. Occasionally there are some manifesta- tions of this in young girls towards each other, but I have not seen any instance of it in the other sex. They show much general kindness of man- ner towards each other, but no warmth of attach- ment worthy the name of friendship. Indeed, they evince the same degree of kindness towards stran- gers as they do to individuals of their own tribe, or members of their own family. It is more com- mon to perceive attachments between them and their dogs and pigs ; the latter arc frequently great favourites, especially with old women, who may often be seen caressing and talking with them in the most affectionate manner. Perhaps it-'would not be overstating their character to say, that, as a people, they are totally devoid of natural affection. Their custom of abandoning their sick, although this, no doubt, proceeds greatly from the superstitious belief that they are fated to die, still evinces a great want of natural affection, or they could not do so. The same thing is seen even in children, who as soon as they are able, cease to have the dependence upon their parents, and cultivate a piece of ground for their own sub- sistence. Should the parents, on the other hand, be in want, they will have fully an equal, if not a better chance of being assisted by some other in- dividuals of the tribe than by their own children ; and would thus owe to general kindness that which should flow from parental affection — Browns New Zealand and its Aborigines.

A GENUINE PHILANTHROPIST.—" Patrick Mac- Kever, a poor Irishman in Philadelphia, was many years ago sentenced to be hung for burglary. For some reason or other he was reprieved at the foot of the gallows, and his sentence changed to ten years' imprisonment. He was a man of few words, and hope seemed almost dead withim him ; but when Friend Hooper, who became inspector during the latter part of his term, talked to Him like a brother, his heart was evidently touched by

the voice of kindness. After his release he re- turned to his trade, and conducted himself in a very sober, exemplary manner. The inspector often met him, and spoke words of friendly en- couragement. Things were going on very satis- factorily, when a robbery was committed in tha neighbourhood, and Patrick was immediately arrested. His friend went to the Mayor, and enquired what proof there was that he committed the robbery. ' No proof ; but he is an old con- vict, and that is enough to condemn him," was the answer. ' Nay, it is not enough,' replied Friend Hooper : " he has suffered severely for the crime he did commit, and since he has shown the most sincere desire to reform, it never ought be mentioned against him : I think I know his stite of mind, and I will take the responsibility of maintaining that he is not guilty.' But to all his urgent representations, he received the answer, ' He is an old convict, and that is enough.' The poor fellow hung down his head, and said in tones of despair, ' Well, then, I must make up my mind to spend the remainder of my days in pri- son.' 'Thou wert not concerned in this robbery, wert thou ?' said Isaac, looking earnestly in his face. ' Indeed, I was not : God be my witness, I want to lead an honest life, and be at peace with all men—but what good will that do? They will all say, He is an old convict, and that is enough.' Friend Hooper told him he would stand by him. He did so ; and offered to be bail for his appear- ance. The gratitude of the poor fellow was over- whelming—he sobbed like a child. His innocence was afterwards proved, and to the day of his death, he continued a virtuous and useful citizen. Wh it would have been his fate, if no friend had appeared for him ?—if every human heart had refused to trust him ?"—Mrs. Child's Letters.

THE CHINESE CHARACTER.—The more the Chinese come to mix with us, and to be acquainted with our character, the more they seem to fall into our ways ; and we cannot but think that, at no distant period, amicable relations will be es- tablished without difficulty, upon an intimate footing. It has often been remarked, that in many respects they resemble Englishmen in their mercantile habits, their ingenuity and their readi- ness to combine together for useful purposes ; their independent spirit, and their love of argu- ment. They differ materially from all other east- ern nations with which we have hitherto come in contact.—Voyage of the Nemesis.

Each advertisement will be charged at the rate of three shillings an inch, and one shilling for every additional inch, each insertion. articleText:
COLONIAL ABSTRACT.

The Hobart Town Courier states, that the best labourers are still hurrying away from the colony. The 51st regiment embarked for India on the 8th ultimo, in the ships China and Agincourt—The blacks at Port Albert, in Gipps' Land, have of late been very troublesome, and have killed a number of horses for the sake of their flesh, of which they are very fond. A horse belonging to Mr. Oak- den, imported at a cost of 450 guineas had been thus destroyed.—The £5 scrip of the Burra Burra mines, in South Australia, was quoted at £80 on the 11th August.—A company, for the smelting of copper ore, with a capital of £10,000, has been formed at Adelaide.—A national system of educa- tion has been introduced into Western Australia. —The township of Burra Burra, in South Austra- lia, where the mines are situated, already numbers twenty-two houses, built of stone.—Hops are raised at Mypunga, South Australia, said to be equal to English grown ; the price paid for English hops is £400 per ton, whilst the native grown can be raised for £50.—Sixty natives of New Zealand are said to have been killed by a sudden eruption of lava about sixty miles north of Cook's Straits.-A nephew of a Mr. Jervis, forming one of a party en route to Adelaide, with cattle, from the Lower Murrumbidgee, has been murdered by the blacks near the Darling. On the circumstance becoming known to his companions, who were in advance, the whole party returned to the scene of the mur- der, when they found the blacks glutting their savage thirst for blood by mutilating the body. About fifty of the natives presented a front to the Europeans, and with a pusillanimity which can only encourage the savages to renew the tragedy on the next party that passes, they contented them

selves with the recovery of the disfigured and bloody corpse.—4½ acres of Geelong town land, put up at the late land sale at Melbourne, realised the sum of £2275, or an average of £610 per acre.—Some of the aborigines in the native mounted police in the district of Port Phillip are spoken of as models of symmetry, and maintain a most soldier-like bearing.—A report was current in Wellington that Nene had attacked Heki in his pah, and had been defeated, the greater part of his tribe being killed, and he himself taken prison- er.—Twenty-two of the mutineers at Norfolk Island have been tried, and two had received sen- tence of death ; and death had also been recorded against three others ; the remainder were sentenced to different terms of imprisonment. Twenty-six were still to be tried : sixteen on the charge of wilful murder, and ten for aiding and abetting them.—On the 31st ultimo, a public meeting was held in the market place, in Sydney, for the pur- pose of raising funds for alleviating the appalling

distress at present existing in Ireland. The sum of £400 was subscribed. A meeting for a similar purpose had been held in Melbourne, where the subscription list already amounted to £500. Among the local improvements progressing in Melbourne, may be named the new church of St. Peter; and a reservoir, capable of containing 20,000 tons of water, about to be formed at an expense of £1000. Among the new efforts of a commercial kind, is the establishment of a salt refinery ; and the building of a ship of 350 tons.— Mr. La Trobe, the Superintendent of Port Phillip, arrived in Sydney on the 27th ult, to pay his re- spects to the Governor.—Lady Mary Fitzroy gave her first public party at Government House, on Tuesday, the 25th ult. The party was a numerous one ; and nearly all who had been honoured with invitations attended.—A gentleman from Corn- wall, recently arrived at Port Phillip, has brought out a first-rate thorough-bred horse, six thorough- bred pigs, and two thorough-bred bull dogs.— About two tons of copper ore, from the Rev. Mr. Bobart's estate at Wellington, had been received in Sydney, and was about to be smelted in order to see what it would yield.—It is stated that the French authorities are in treaty with Messrs. Boyd and Co. for the purchase of the steamer Juno; should the contract be completed, she will be com- missioned for service at Tahiti.—A petition to His Excellency is in progress in Melbourne, praying that steps may be taken for a survey of the River Yarra, with a view to deepening, so as to allow of its free navigation by vessels of any burden.

THE " DUKE" AND HIS AUTOGRAPH. — Field-

Marshal the Duke of Wellington—although he beat Napoleon—is a simple, ingenuous soul, con- tinually duped by a gang of ladies and gentlemen, and others who—with a morbid taste for ink and paper—pursue men of mark for their autographs. As the duke is known to answer every letter—no matter its import—addressed to him, all kinds of epistles are sent to him, for the sole purpose of drawing his Grace of his autograph. We have seen many of the duke's answers, and give a few :—" Field-Marshal the Duke of Wellington informs Michael Wiggins that the coat he wore on the field of Waterloo was not the original model of the present D'Orsay paletot. The Comte D'Orsay is much too honourable a man to steal anything from the Duke of Wellington, or—as the Duke firmly believes—from anybody else."—"The Duke of Wellington desires Peter Snout to take note that he is Commander-in-Chief of the Army, and not a hatter. Therefore it is not the Duke's business to see that the wig of the statue of George the Fourth, Trafalgar-square, should be covered."—" Field Marshal the Duke of Wellington has received John Jones' letter. The late Duke of York's debts may be paid, and they may not. The Duke of Wel- lington informs John Jones that he will not pay them." And in this shameful manner is the

courtesy of the noble duke every day played upon. The Irish papers give the last instance of these intrusions upon his Grace's time, with, of course, the answer it provoked. Somebody called the duke's attention to the new cotton shirts adopted by the army, and to the potatoe sickness. The duke went at once into the shirts, but would not touch the potatoes :—" Upon the other parts of Mr.——'s letter, that is, the state of distress exist- ing in the neighbourhood of ——, consequent on what is called the potatoe disease, the Duke of Wellington begs to suggest to Mr.——, that he is the Commander-in-chief of the Army." And, therefore, as Mr. —— ought to have known, is not compelled to cry " eyes right" to the potatoes,, But Mr. —— already knew as much. All he wanted was the duke's autograph, and he got it.

—Punch.

EXCISE DUTIES.—The tales levied on articles of consumption produced within the kingdom. The word is derived from excido, to cut out, and means that a good slice is taken out of everything affected by the excise duties. They commenced in the reign of Charles the First by a tax on beer, and Oliver Cromwell, being a brewer, was no doubt excited to rebellion by this attack on his double X. If he had been a milkman, and there had been a duty on chalk, he would probably have been equally refractory. Among exciseable ar- ticles we find soap, which was felt to be such a grievance that " How are you off for soap? " has become a common mode of salutation among the poorer classes of society. There is a heavy excise

duty on hackney coaches, but the heaviest duty of all falls on the animals employed in drawing the vehicles. In these cases, however, there is a tremendous drawback of which nobody gets the benefit.—Punch's Political Dictionary.

articleText:
MR. CAUDLE'S BREAKFAST TALK.

Showing how Caudle, having lost money at

cards, determines to-abridge the house ex- penses.

" I don’t know how it is, my dear, but when I remember that there’s only you and myself—just two of us, and I eat and drink next to nothing— and when I see what other people do with half our money, I do think you might be a little more careful. I’m sure I spend no money on myself— none. Nobody can be more watchful of every sixpence ; but of course, a man can save but little when he knows—or, that is, when he fears he knows—that everything’s going to waste at home. Besides, it's a woman's place—particularly a woman’s place—to save. Women were designed for it. Economy is one of the noblest virtues bound up with matrimony. There can be very little real love, Mrs. Caudle, where economy’s ne- glected. A woman can’t truly care for a man’s heart, unless she has an equal regard for his pocket ; the things go together, and always did

from the first.

"No, Mrs. Caudle, I did not lose at my whist club last night—that is, only next to nothing ; in other words, nothing to speak of. Now, that's like your sex. You always set about hunting for some foolish, shabby motive for whatever your husbands complain about. Because I lose at cards, I don’t want to get the money back out of the cupboard. No : I want to save money, that, should I be taken from you—and life at all times is uncertain, Mrs. Caudle—you might be left snug and comfortable—that’s my object. But I never knew any woman yet—except one, rest her sainted soul !—who had the mind or the generosity to allow a truly noble motive to what her husband should do ; that is, if it went against herself. You can’t help it—poor things !—nevertheless, when a man is depriving himself of every little enjoyment that he may lay by something for a rainy day, it is hard—a little hard, I think—to have a woman

spend what you do in housekeeping.

" Now, Mrs. Caudle, be rational ; and, for the thousandth time, let me beg of you not to cry. You only waste your trouble and your tears. Both are thrown away upon me : I’m not one of the people, I tell you again, to be melted with a little soft water. My expenses, that is, your expenses, are dreadful. Your grocer’s bill—and when I never taste sugar in my tea—is preposterous ; enough to ruin a man of ten thousand a year. What ? I take sugar in my grog, and so do my friends ? Scarcely any—nothing to speak of ; not worth naming.

" And then look at your butcher for the last fortnight. Well ? I know I won’t eat cold joints. I had enough of them with my first—that is, I can’t bear ’em. Besides, with half the money you have, a cold joint’s an insult to any man.

" And finally, Mrs. Caudle,—for you know I hate this talk at breakfast ; it’s a meal of all others I like to enjoy if I can—finally, I have made a calculation, and in the next month, come what will, your cupboard must do with ten pounds less. It’s for your good, I tell you, when I’m gone, and ten pounds I must have of you."

GOING OUT TO A PARTY.—Exquisite—Aw! Dri-vaw !—Have you a good horse ? Cabman Yes, sir. A werry good oss. Exquisite—Aw ! then dra-ive me to next door.—Punch.

WHAT DO YOU GENERALLY THINK.—1. When you ask if any one is at home, and the servant tells you he don't know, but will go and see, asking your name, and then comes back and answers in the negative ?—2. When a man at an evening party says he does not waltz, “because his head won’t stand it ?"—3. When you find a broken dish behind the dresser, and the cook says “the cat did it ?"—4. When a friend presses you to come and see him very soon, " any day, he al- ways dines at five," but don’t state a day ?—5. When a married couple are more than usually affectionate, and use endearing terms in public ? 6. When a lady, holding out her glass for wine at supper, says, " Oh, really ; the least drop in the world, Mr. Smith ; stop, stop !"—7. When, at a small country party, the lemonade and negus get gradually weaker towards the end of the evening ? —8. When a man does not pay his newspaper

account after it has been three times tendered to him ?

FITTING OPPORTUNITY.—When concession is inevitable, it is wise to concede before necessity destroys both freedom of thought and dignity of

movement.

A DROP TOO MUCH.—A New York paper states that a man named Neville is in custody for taking " a drop too much"—namely, for marrying Miss Amelia Drop whilst he had another wife living.

CHOICE ITEMS IN A LAWYER’S BILL.—The fol- lowing charges were extracted, a short time ago, from two bills delivered by a gentleman in the practice of the law in Pembrokeshire : Attending you when I agreed to sell

you thirty Winchesters of oats .... £0 6 8 Writing to my servant at R— to

deliver same. 0 5 0 Attending when I agreed to lend you

10s., and drawing memorandum for

same. 0 6 8

Unable to attend to business this day,

in consequence of fatigue occasioned

by my late rapid travelling. . . . . . . 3 3 0 Punch’s late specimen of a bill of costs was a fool to these charges.

articleText:
COLONIAL ABSTRACT.

Four blacks of the Gipps Land tribe had under- taken to bring in and deliver up the white woman detained by the blacks, on receiving a certain number of tomahawks and blankets. The offer had been accepted, and the aborigines had started en route.-Three aborigines attacked an American black, who was a shepherd at Weiraby, for the purpose of getting his sheep ; but the gallant

fellow made so firm a resistance as to drive his

opponents from the field.-Mr. Surveyor Wade, assistant-surveyor, formerly of Brisbane, Moreton Bay, has started for the western frontiers to mark out the boundary between Port Phillip and South

Australia.-The remains of one of Mr. McKinnon's

shepherds, near Lake Mundy, Portland district, who had been missing upwards of three weeks, were found against a tree. His faithful dog, nearly dead from hunger, was found crouching at his side.-The lambing season in the Portland district has been remarkably prolific. One proprietor has as much as 110 per cent, increase.-The three blacks in custody for the murder of Mr. Andrew Beveridge, of the Murray River, have been fully committed to take their trials for that offence.

The copper ore sold at Swansea, in July, was from the Kapunda, Montacute, and Burra mines, South Australia. The first produced fron 22 1/2 per cent, to 30 3/4, and realised from £16 6s. to £23 13s. per ton. The second was in two lots, producing 22 3/4 and 24 per cent. ,and fetched £16 3s. and £17 2s. 6d. Of the Burra there were four lots, which were sold as follows:-That producing 14 3/4, at £10 16s. ; 40 1/4, at £30 11s. ; 41 1/2, at £31 9s. A fall in prices may be anticipated, as the largeness of the supply has already affected the market to the extent of £3 per ton.-In the Port Phillip district, there was a total apathy on the question of the re- newal of transportation. Neither the press nor the people appeared to take any notice of the matter, though a meeting on the subject of immigration had been convened.-There has been a fearful mortality amongst the young lambs in the district of New England this year, some of the wool growers having hardly saved a tithe of this year's produce, owing to the continued rains.-Letters state that there will be but little wool sent down by the Clarence this year, as the road is not yet open, and all are fearful of being the first to push along the tract with their teams.-" Figaro," a race-horse lately imported from Van Diemen's Land, was sold the other day to M. Dalmahoy Campbell, of Melbourne, for £150.-His Honor Mr. La Trobe had been making enquiries into the merits and demerits of the probation system throughout Van Diemen's Land, in accordance with his instructions from the Home Government. -The hull of the James Watt was sold in Sydney for £800.-The caterpillars have lately committed great devastation in the gardens in the neighbour- hood of Sydney, more especially amongst the potatoe crops.-At a sale of sheep by auction in Melbourne, the other day, realising in total £11,450, the average price was 9s. 5 1/2d. per head.

articleText:
CAPE OF GOOD HOPE.

By private letters from the Cape of Good Hope, bearing date the 17th July, we observe that the Kaffir war had terminated, the savages having retired beyond the boundary, carrying with them an enormous booty. In a skirmish which took place shortly before their departure with the British Regulars and auxiliaries, they were sig- nally defeated, leaving five hundred dead upon the field, besides an immense number of wounded and prisoners. All the supplies with which the colo- nists had aided the Government, were being paid for, which gave general satisfaction. A very severe drought throughout the colony had caused provisions to raise to a high figure, which was severely felt by all classes of the colonists. Argus, November 12.

RATHER MYSTERIOUS.-" Now, Jack," said the printer of a country newspaper, in giving direc- tions to his apprentice, " put the Irish Attorney General and the state prosecutors into the galleys and lock them up; let the two members for Liverpool have larger heads ; distribute the army in Ireland ; take up a line and finish Ferrand and the Anti-Corn-Law League ; make the Prince of Wales to run on with the Dowager Duchess of Lyttleton. Move the Melton Mowbray hunt out of the chase; get your stick, and conclude the horrid murder that Tom began last night ; after which come in to dinner, and see that all the pie is cleared up." An OEdipus may be found in any printing office to explain this enigma.

Fleas are small insects, but one will move a person that weighs two hundred pounds, and keep him moving all night.

LAW.-We shall not attempt to describe what law is, for we are afraid it would beggar descrip- tion, as it beggars many of those who are involved in it. Law, in the strict sense, is said to be the command of one intelligent being to another intel- ligent being ; but this can be hardly said of a thing that is often utterly unintelligible, not only to those who are to obey the law, but even to those who have had a share in making it. Law is some- time called positive law, a great part of which is often most superlative nonsense, The proper end of positive law is said to be the promotion of hap- piness. Every one is no doubt happy to see the end of law ; but when once he goes into law, it is quite impossible to see the end of it.-Punch's

Political Dictionary.

KING.-The head of a state, and in France a target for regicides. In constitutional monarchies the king is nominally supreme, but really power- less. He has the choice of his ministers - but this is always Hobson's choice ; for he is obliged to select those who are supported by the Parlia- ment. The king is the fountain of honour, and supplies several pumps, who get their honour laid on direct from the fountain. He can declare war ; but he is not worth powder and shot to carry it on, unless he has the consent of Parliament.

Though he is obliged to put his name to every bill, in order to give it value, and accepts every one that is laid before him, he is not responsible. It is a maxim that the king can do no wrong, and that he never dies - two important facts, of which Charles the first failed to take the benefit. The King of a free country, like a King in the game of

chess, may always be subjected to a check, when he lays himself open to it. Though his course may be eccentric, and he may move in any and every direction, he can only take one step at a time ; so that he cannot go far astray, and may be checked immediately. - Punch's Political Dictionary.
