articleText:
COLON I AL ABSTRACT.

Mr. Tyers, the Commissioner for Gipps' Land, having examined the coast about Cape Howe, and made a survey of the Island of Gabo, which is at the extreme end of the Cape, has recom- mended that a lighthouse should be erected on that island.—The action of libel brought by Mr. R. Cooper, senior, against Mr. Welch, the proprietor of the Atlas newspaper, was tried on Saturday the 30th ultimo. The damages were laid at £1000. The result was in favour of the defendant. Mr. Welch was not, however, equally successful in a similar action brought by Mr. Laughton, acting head master of Sydney College, who obtained forty shillings damages, which amount will carry costs. —The population of Western Australia although represented at 5000, does not exceed 3500. It has a little commerce with the Isle of France, to which place it exports live stock and provisions. Its pastoral resources are extremely confined, for the reason that the squatters of the neighbouring colonies have been able to find no route by which they could supply its unoccupied lands with the increase of their flocks and herds.—A considerable portion .of Van Diemen's Land is, it appears, flooded, in consequence of heavy rain having fallen there.—The seat of Government, whether it is to be Auckland or Wellington, still- continued a questio vexata, and it did not seem improbable but that Captain Grey would have to give a de- cision on the subject.—It is reported that the scarcity of labour in Port Phillip (which has in- duced the settlers to incur great trouble and cost to obtain supplies from Van Diemen's Land) can be partially relieved by importations from a some- what purer source ; Captain Rolls, of the Augustus, recently from New Zealand, states that he could easily obtain four hundred labourers from Nelson, so eager are the residents of that settlement to change their quarters : the expense would be £4 per head.—The price of fuel has risen to such a height in Melbourne as to cause absolute distress to the lower classes, and importations of coal are loudly called for.—A public meeting, numerously and respectably attended, had been hold at Port Phillip for the purpose of procuring the extension of the £30 Jurisdiction of Courts of Requests to the district of Port Phillip. We hope shortly to witness a meeting for a similar purpose at Bris- bane.—The four brokers in Launceston had come to an arrangement to charge an uniform rate of interest on moneys lent, namely, one penny per week for each shilling, or at the rate of 415 per cent, per annum.—Of the total number of males in the town of Melbourne and the County of Bourke above twenty-one years of age, one-fifth, or 1100 are incapable of reading or writing, and one-third of the adult females are placed on the same list.—The emigration from Hobart Town, principally to Port Phillip and South Australia, during the last week in May amounted to upwards of three hundred individuals.—The rules adopted by the newly-formed Maitland Racing Club are those of the Australian Jockey Club ; these are formed upon the model of the English Newmarket Club.—Port Phillip seems to be in a prosperous state, both as regards the pastoral and mercantile interests. There is no business whatever before the Insolvent Court; the markets are steady, trade brisk, and money plentiful. Wages are high, and from the fact of two classes of artizans having struck for wages, seem to have an upward tendency.—The Port Phillip papers are agitating the question of the necessity of defences from foreign aggression at Melbourne.—Wattle gum from South Australia has recently been sold in London at 47s. 6d. It would have gone higher, but reports had been spread that 150 tons more were coming from the colony.

BOLD AS A LION.—A southern Adonis, no way celebrated for his personal attractions, on com- pleting a somewhat protracted toilet one morning, turned to his servant, and inquired—" How do I look, Caesar ?', " 'Plendid, massa, 'plendid," was Ebony's delightful answer. " Do you think I'll do, Ceasar ?" giving him a piece of silver. " Guy, massa, never see you look so fierce in all my life ; you look jis' as bold as a lion." " Why what do you know about a lion ? You never saw one, Caesar." "Nebber see a lion massa ? Guy, I see massa Peyton's Jim ride one ober to de mill ebery day." " No, you fool, that's a donkey." " Can't help dat, massa-you look jis' like him !"

articleText:
COLONIAL ABSTRACT.

By a late Government Gazette, we observe that His Excellency the Governor has performed an act of grace to the prison population now in the colony. All former regulations for granting in- dulgences have been rescinded, and the following have been promulgated :- That any convict who may have served three entire years without any record of misconduct appearing against him, will be eligible for a ticket-of-leave ; that for three years of continued good conduct, a ticket-of-leave holder, recommended by three magistrates, or other persons of known respectability, will ho eligible for a conditional pardon. - In the year 1843, New South Wales imported 248,170 lbs. of butter and cheese, valued at 9,497l. In 1844, 60,701 lbs., valued at 1184l. In 1845, 22,216 lbs., valued at 579l. In 1843, the export was 81,173 lbs., valued at 3,488. In 1844, 188,171 lbs., valued at 3,717l. In 1845, 172,368 lbs., valued at 4,313l. The saving to the colony effected by the increased production of these articles ex- ceeds 13,000l. - The export of horses during the year 1845 amounted to 1159; of horned cattle, 3972 ; of sheep, 33,657 ; valued at 53,438l. The number of horses shipped in 1844 was 489, and the total value of the Stock exported the same year amounted to 40,374l. - In 1843, the value of hides and leather imported into the colony was 36,185l ; in 1844, 19,844; and in 1845, 14,124l. In 1843, the export of the same articles amounted to 10,305l ; in 1841, to 22,285l .; in 1845, to 40,866l. The saving to the colony, as compared with 1843, is over 53,000l., and as compared with 1844, about 24,000l.

In this country we own no sovereigns, except the ladies - God bless them ! and every man ought to have one of them. - American paper. - What's more, if a man has one of these sovereigns any length of time small change will come of itself.

IRISH EVIDENCE. - "Pray, my good man," said a Judge to an Irishman, who was a witness on a trial, "what did pass between you and the pri- soner?" "Oh, then, plase your Lordship," says Pat, "sure I sees Phelim a top of the wall. 'Paddy,' says he ; 'What?' says I ; 'Here,' says he ; 'Where?' says I ; 'Whist!" says he ; 'Hush!' says I ; and that's all, plase your Lordship.

A MINISTERIAL QUARTET. - The following little classical quartet was sung just before the tempo- rary dissolution of the ministry. Lord Stanley, who took a part in the quartet, destroyed the har- mony, and ultimately put an end to the concert. He would not agree to subdue his voice sufficiently, or, in other words, to sing small, and he was con- sequently kept out of the arrangements when the Ministerial Sons of Harmony met again for the purpose of practising the new tunes, and adopting

the airs and variations of the Premier. But we

are losing sight of the quartet, which ran as

follows :-

LORD STANLEY (andantino). Corn must go up, up, up.

SIR. R. PEEL, (con expressione).

Corn must come down, down, down.

THE DUKE OF WELLINGTON, (con strepito).

Here we go backwards and forwards.

SIR R. PEEL, (vivace allegro). I shall go round, round, round.

After giving this line with unusual emphasis, Sir R. Peel looking round him, exclaimed, with considerable meaning, "Now then chorus, gen- tlemen, if you please ; let me hear you all siug out plainly after me,

" I shall go round, round, round."

Lord Stanley positively refused to do so, ob- serving that it was quite out of his compass, and he had not sufficient flexibility to get over the difficulty. A long discussion ensued, which ended in the entire destruction of the concert, and the total sacrifice of harmony. After a little re- hearsal, however, the difficulty has been got over by nearly all the principals, who now sing

"Here we go round, round, round."

with as much energy as the Premier himself could desire to throw into it. - Punch.

articleText:
IMPORTANT INDIAN NEWS.

Two great battles have been fought in India since our last accounts. After the battles of Moodkee and Ferozeshur, in December, the Sikhs contrived to detach a force and attack and destroy the great military station of Loodihana, in which they were completely successful, as they plundered the station and then set it on fire. Major-General Sir Harry Smith was sent with six thousand men to save Loodihana, but was too late ; but on the 20th January he came up with the enemy, com- puted at thirty thousand strong, and after a smart engagement, completely routed them. Our loss was four hundred killed and wounded, including among the former an officer well known here, Captain Grimes, H. M. 50th foot. This engage- ment is called the battle of Aliwal. On the 11th February there was a general engagement between the Sikhs and the British, in which we gained a glorious victory. The loss, however, was very heavy, particularly in officers of high rank. Col. Ryan and Captain Tew, of the 50th, were among the killed. On the 12th February, after the victory, the British crossed the Sutledge, en route to Lahore, and from that day the downfall of the Punjaub as an independent state may be dated.— Sydney Herald.

Who was the first patron of Newspapers ?— Cain ; he took A-Bel's Life.

Why are poor attorneys like rheumatic old ladies ?—Because they often complain of their poor fee-taking (feet aching.)

Why is a doctor out of luck like a woman out of temper ?—Because he has lost his patients (patience).

A HAREM SCENE.—In his palace of Kizil- Ermak, the red river, Djezar passed the greater portion of the day, extended upon cushions at the feet of his beautiful slave, smoking the roses of Taif and Adrianople, mixed with the tobacco of Malatia and Latakia, adding occasionally a leaf of Naschick, a grain of opium, or even of arsenic (?), to exalt his imagination. Sometimes Baila put her lips to the pookah, and as they both re- clined there, plunged in a sort of waking dream, educed by the juices of the Indian weed and poppy of Aboutig : the one had visions of the eternal houri, and the other of the audacious stranger ; while the lion Haider, drawing in his claws, stretched himself familiarly among them. Baila leant negligently on the neck of the formidable animal, while the Pasha dropt his head upon her knees ; and it was a strange picture, that of this graceful young creature, clad in gauze, reposing quietly between two ferocious animals. She had long ceased to fear either the one or the other. Both the lion and the man had been tamed.—The Pasha's Slave.

MOZART.—The boy was always extremely ani- mated and intelligent. Before he applied himself to music he entered into the usual pastimes of childhood with such interest, that over a pleasant game he would forget everything, even his meals ; but afterward he lost much of his relish for these recreations, or liked them only in proportion as they were mixed with music. One of the great favourites of Wolfgang, and his especial playmate, was Andreas Schachtner, the principal trumpeter in the archbishop's band ; a man of cultivated mind and considerable talent in poetry, the inti- mate friend of the family. Whenever the play- things were removed from one chamber to another, if this companion were, with him, it must be done to music ; and who carried nothing must play or sing a march. Such was the ascendancy that the art had gained.—Holmes's Life of Mozart.

articleText:
MR. CAUDLE'S BREAKFAST TALK.

Showing how Mr. Caudle could go out and

enjoy himself.

"By the bye, Sarah, just put half-a-dozen shirts, and all that sort of thing, in my portman- teau. I'm going-There you are with your black looks again! I can never go anywhere, just a little to enjoy myself, but you look like thunder. What! l might sometimes take you out. Non- sense; women-that is, women when there mar- ried-are best at home. What can they want to go out for? It's quite enough for them to go out to hunt for husbands: when they've caught 'em, let 'em sit at home, and sing with the kettle and the cat; their best place is their fireside.

"Half-a-dozen shirts, I say, and my shaving tackle. Do you hear me, Mrs. Caudle? Perhaps, when you've done counting the legs of that fly on the ceiling, you'll attend to me. Eh? I think you never want to go out? Quite the contrary; it's my belief you'd always be out. If you wanted to go about like a June-fly, why did you marry?

"I should have told you where I was going; but as you've shown your temper, I won't tell you a syllable. No; nor I shan't tell you who I'm going with, nor when I shall be back. When you see me, then you may expect me, and not before. And mind all the buttons are on my shirts

that's all.

"It's miserable always being left by yourself? Yourself, indeed! Arn't there books in the house? There's capital company on the shelves if you'd only get acquainted with them. I'm sure you'd be none the worse for 'em. Besides, there's the Cookery Book: read that. A wife can't study anything better.

"The fact is, Mrs. Caudle, I've indulged you too much-I've made a fool of you. No, I hav'nt? Well, then, who has? If I hav'nt, somebody has, it's plain. Going out, indeed ! I've no opinion of any woman who wants to go out at all. Women were never intended to go out; only the fact is, we've let you have your own way Ha! they manage these matters much better in the East.

"I'm generally a pretty quiet man, Mrs. Cau- dle, and you know it. Nevertheless, I have a little of the lion in me-just a little. Don't rouse it, that's all.

"There you are with the pocket-handkerchief again. Always hoisting that signal of distress. No, no; I'm not made of sugar, like a twelfth cake image; I'm not to be "melted with tears, let them be as many and as hot as they will. Besides, as I say, you can all do it when you like-every mother's soul of you. But I'm not to be washed off my legs by any river of the sort.

"All I say to you is,-stay at home. You've a needle and thread hav'nt you? and I'll be sworn for it, plenty of things to make or to mend. And if you hav'nt, cut holes, and sew 'em up again.

"Now, see when I come home that my port- manteau's ready. What's o'clock? You want five minutes to-? No doubt; the old story; you're always wanting something."

There is a very fair bon mot current-an eminent legal functionary being asked by one of his Whig brethren of the robe how it was that Peel could not now manage to drive a team which he had so long held completely in hand, replied "He gave 'em too much corn to begin with."

UNREMITTING KINDNESS.-A comedian went to America, and remained there two years, leaving his wife dependent on her relatives. Mrs. F--tt expatiating in the green-room on the cruelty of such conduct, the comedian found a warm advo- cate in a well known dramatist. "I have heard," says the latter, "that he is the kindest of men, and I know he writes to his wife every packet." "Yes, he writes," replied Mrs. F., "a parcel of flummery about the agony of absence, but he has never remitted her a shilling. Do you call that kindness?" "Decidedly," replied the author, "unremitting kindness."-Globe.

The wise continueth to live from his first period; the fool is always beginning.

articleText:
MR. CAUDLE'S BREAKFAST TALK.

Showing how Caudle thought " that bill" settled

a long time ago.

" If now I were to leave you, Mrs. Caudle-if I were to do what I really ought to do as a hus- band-break up the establishment and go myself into chambers, just giving you enough to live upon--of course, the world-the world that never can judge between man and wife, but always will poke its nose in between 'em whenever they sepa- rate-the world, I've no doubt, would begin to abuse me. What's the matter ? Matter enough, I think ! I'm called out, from my breakfast too, and this, Mrs. Caudle, this little bit of paper put into my hand. What have you the face to ask, Mrs. Caudle ? What of it ? Don't 1 know I owe it ? Why, of course not ! I could have laid my life that that bill was paid long ago ! I could

have sworn it.'

How was it to be paid ? You ask that ! Why, with money, of course. But 1 never gave you the money ? Nonsense ! You're enough to drive a man mad, Mrs. Caudle. I must have given you the money ; of course, I must. Else where can all the money go to ? When did I give it ? Well, if you are not the most outrageous, per- plexing woman ! When did I give it, indeed ! As if, with what I have on my mind, I can ex- actly recollect the day, and the hour, and the place when I gave you the money for that bill ! I, who am always giving you money for bills. Do you think I'm a calculating machine, Mrs. Caudle-to remember everything, and with what I have in my head ? All I know is-and that's enough for any reasonable man-all I know is, I must have given you the money. The bill's been delivered a month ago, the man told me: and you're not the woman, I know, to let me remain quiet for a bill so long. No, indeed ; for if there's anything in the world that gives you pleasure, it is continually coming to my pocket. And you must think I've got a gold mine there ; to dip as you do into it.

" There you are ! Crying again ! That's the mean advantage you women always try to take of your husbands. What ! You wish I'd common feelings, and you wish you were in your grave? Of course. A man can't open his mouth, can't make the slightest remonstrance, when a woman let's money matters go all wrong, but he wants feelings. Ha ! He'd better want a few feelings than want money. And I'm sure, Mrs. Caudle, that's your opinion if you spoke the truth. And then again, you must always be scratching your grave up before me ! And only because I just speak about a bill. Of course, you've paid away the money for something else-some new gowns, perhaps-and forgot it.

" However, Mrs. Caudle, it's not worth quar- relling about-certainly not. Besides, I hate quarrelling. However, this I have to say : as I'm convinced that I've given you the money for the bill once, I'm not going to pay it a second time. You must save it out of something else. What are you to save it out of? Anything : cat's-meat and canary seed !-but I don't pay

twice.

articleText:
MR. CAUDLE'S BREAKFAST TALK.

Showing how Mr. Caudle, objected to Mrs. Caudle's female friend, a visitor for a month.

" When a husband comes home to what he ex-

pects to find a comfortable house, it is a little-I

say a little annoying to him-to break his shins, over a heap of portmanteaus in the hall, and find, too, he's saddled with a visitor,-some stupid Miss or the other, with all her boarding-school starch; about her. Eh, what ? You told me you'd in- vited dear Miss Loveday? You took an ad- vantage of me, then ; and told me when I was asleep. I don't recollect it. And now I shall be stunned to death by her for three months-for of course she plays the piano ; and I shouldn't won- der if she's brought a guitar besides with her. For three precious months ! What ? She's only invited for one month ? Humph ! Then she'll stay three, of course : they always do.

" Nice breakfasts I shall have now-for she'll not always stay in her own room ; she won't al- ways be tired travelling. Nice breakfasts I'm doomed to ! What ? How will the dear soul hurt me ? Oh, in the gentlest way possible-I know. She'll always be reading the play-house advertisements in the paper, and always be want- ing to go to the opera, or a concert, or fireworks, or some show of that sort. I know the sideway talk of such girls very well. But understand, Mrs. Caudle, I'm not hampered with her. As you say she was yonr schoolfellow once-I suppose I suppose I shall have all Minerva House here in their turn-you alone must be troubled with her. I shall behave as civil as I can-but don't expect that I'll take her out, or spend money upon her ; that's your affair, not mine.

" No, I don't forget when I'd my three friends here altogether : not at all ; I was too happy ever to forget it. Jack Stokes-noble fellow ! What a song he sang, and what punch he made : Tom Ryder-the best fellow he, at whist and a chorus ; and Sam Slab, who gave such a licking to the coal-heaver. Ha ! they were something like people to have in one's house. What ? You never complained of them, and why can't you have a friend ? That's a different thing. Be- sides, as I say, women never have friendship one among another-they don't know what it means. No, indeed ; I don't think friendship's a thing of cigars and brandy-and-water-not but what all three are a very pretty mixture. They were something like rights we had. You never got to sleep till four while my friends were here ? What's that to do with it ? Is that any reason you should bring a lot of visitors to my house who can't say " bo" to a goose ? And when you know, too, how I like to enjoy the comfort of my fireside alone ! How I hate that we should have anybody to disturb us ! And if you loved me really, you'd hate it too-but it's a bad business to have all the love of one side ; I feel that."

THE RULING PASSION.-The lawyers have had

a part of Lincoln's Inn Square laid out as a garden ; simply because, as lawyers, they like to make the most of all that's green.

articleText:
COLONIAL ABSTRACT.

An imported sheep from the county of Kent, which had unfortunately been killed by the dogs,

was melted down at Messrs. Watson and Wright's, establishment, in the Swamp, near Melbourne,and yielded sixty pounds of tallow, which, with seven pounds of wool taken from the skin, made the net produce of the animal amount to twenty-three shillings.—The contract for the improvement of the harbour at Port Fairy, by the construction of a breakwater, had been taken at the sum of £5000. —Fossil remains of an extinct race of animals, apparently a gigantic species of the kangaroo, had been discovered in the neighbourhood of Geelong.—Among the Bills to be proposed to the

Legislature of Van Diemen's Land during the present session, is one to restrain the practice of kangaroo-hunting, by which great damage has been done to flocks. No person is to hunt kangaroo except on his own ground, without obtaining a yearly license fee of £1, uuder penalty of a fine of £10, or imprison- ment. Exception is made in favour of packs of hounds, but the keepers must be licensed.—Arti- cles of jewellery, both costly and elegant, are manufactured at Adelaide from native materials ; the soil being fruitful, not only in precious metals, but in many descriptions of ornamental stones.— Many of the trades at Adelaide had struck for an increase of wages.—The purchase-money for the special survey of 20,000 acres at Mount Remark- able, South Australia, (£20,000) had been paid into the Treasury.—It is calculated that the public works in South Australia to be commenced within the next seven months will eventually cost above £70,000.—Mr. Horrocks, who proposes to un- dertake an expedition of discovery into the interior of South Australia, intends to take with him a camel which he possesses, in order to test the qualifications of these animals for traversing the deserts of Australia.—The late lambing in the Geelong district was remarkable for the fecundity of the ewes in many instances ; the actual increase being a hundred and twenty and a hundred and thirty per cent, arising of course from double lambings ; the average increase may be taken at ninety per cent.—The population of the different settlements at New Zealand is as follows : Wel- lington and the whaling stations, 4998 ; Wanga- nui, 186 ; Taraniki, 1155 ; Nelson, 2933 ; Port Cooper and the east coast of Middle Island, 1187 ; the southern settlements, 9272 ; Auckland and

County of Edcn, 3635.—A Mr. Campbell and a Mr. Sprott, of Port Phillip, had token the trouble to ride four hundred miles (into South Australia) to fight a duel, which they were at length com- pelled to do with pocket-pistols ; shots were ex- changed, and of course no one was hurt.—Tenders for conveying five hundred labourers from Van Diemen's Land to Geelong are called for in the Port Phillip papers.—The Geelong Advertiser

states that "the Government have refused to re- ceive the assessment and license fees in the district of Port Phillip."

NORFOLK ISLAND.—The Launceston papers, contain accounts from this settlement up to the latter part of May, which are of a gloomy charac- ter. The sultriness of the weather had occasioned

considerable indisposition amongst the civil resi- dents. The number of prisoners on the island was 1800, of them about 200 are the most reckless and abandoned of characters, and in consequence of a laxity of discipline on the part of the civil authori- ties, were in a state of general insubordination. An outbreak had occurred, which was only pre- vented from becoming serious by the determined conduct of the officer commanding the detachment of the 11th Regiment on duty, who was on the occasion called upon by the Civil Commandant to exercise his authority. During the month of February the prisoners were very insubordinate, and on the 25th of that month about 800 of the worst of them assembled, locked themselves up in the Lumber Yard, refused to work, and defied the authority of their superintendents. The Stipen- diary Magistrate and Civil Commandant being unsuccessful in their attempts to enforce obedience,

called in the military. Major Harold, at the head of a strong detachment of the 11th, then called upon them to go to work. This order being dis- obeyed, the gate was forced in, and the military being marched in took up proper positions. The Major then called upon them, in the name of the Queen, to go to work immediately, or force would be used. An attempt was made to hold a parley, which was abruptly broken off by the officer in- forming them that if they did not at once evacuate the place, he would fire upon them ; at the same moment, he gave the word "ready" to the men under his command, and the click of about sixty muskets coming to position, recalled the insur- gents to a sense of their danger, and they hastily left the yard and went to work. - Sydney Morning

Herald.

Another Exploring Expedition. - Our

readers may remember that, a short time ago, we very strenuously urged the trial of the route into the interior by the high lands west of Lake Tor- rens, seen by Messrs. Eyre and Darke. We little then thought that this route was destined to be so soon tested, and that by the best of all means of testing the inland steppes of Australia - by a camel. Our satisfaction is increased by the know- ledge that the expedition will be conducted by men of such activity and intelligence as Messrs. Hor- rocks and Theakstone, the latter of whom was the faithful assistant of Mr. Darke, and the conductor of the party in their retreat, after that explorer's lamented death. We earnestly trust that the Council may grant the petition of Mr. Horrocks ; for even, if not altogether successful, it must be a very small item of information that they will be able to give if it is not worth to the colonists a great deal more than £80. The only drawback to the sanction and encouragement of such au expedition by the Council is the smallness of the party ; but if such an experienced explorer as Capt. Sturt approves, even this objection cannot be urged. - South Australian, June 26.

" Recollect, sir," said a tavern-keeper to a gen- tleman who was about leaving his house without paying his reckoning, " recollect, sir, if you lose your purse you did'nt pull it out here."

articleText:
COLONIAL ABSTRACT.

The sum of £5000 has been forwarded from England to Van Diemen's Land, for the purpose of supporting missionaries in the bush. The donor transmitted the money anonymously through the Bishop of Ripon.—In the Legislative Council of South Australia, on the 13th ultimo, Capt. Bagot presented a petition from Andrew John Murray, supported by several merchants, praying for the introduction of a Bill to secure to the petitioner the patent right of an invention, by which a large increase of mechanical power is obtained.—On the 11th instant a Government sale of town and suburban lots took place at Melbourne, the pro- ceeds of which amounted to £4224 14s. 10d. The Pentonvilles per ship Maitland were readily securing engagements at Melbourne, some at from £16 to £20, whilst others had the modesty to ask £30.-Nearly 400 drays are at present employed in carting ore to Port Adelaide.—At a special general meeting of the Melbourne Mechanics' In- stitution the number of members was stated to be upwards of 400. The meeting was called to make final arrangements for obtaining a loan from the Port Phillip Savings' Bank.-The late master of the ship Tory, who was tried and convicted in England, is amongst the exiles by the ship Mait- land.-A labouring man at Burenyong was bitten by a snake while bathing in a pool of water, and

died in a few hours.-A new theatre was in course of erection at Adelaide for Mr. Coppin; Mrs. Coppin, so great a favourite as an actress in Sydney, had been nearly burned to death.-The native prisoners tried lately at Wellington by a court martial for being concerned in the late dis- turbances have been sentenced to be transported. -A circular has been addressed to the Magistrates of Van Diemen's Land by Mr. La Trobe, inform- ing them that in future their decisions will not be reversed, without being submitted to them for re- consideration.-On the arrival of the last lot of

exiles at Port Phillip, one hundred were engaged in the first half hour, but the remainder demanded such exorbitant wages that it was thought better to let them cool upon it.-The Government of South Australia has advanced £20,000 as a loan to Van Diemen's Land -By proclamation the Governor has divided the four districts of Port

Phillip, adjacent to and beyond the boundaries, into five, to be called the Gipps' Land, the Murray, the Western Port, the Portland Bay, and the

Wimmera districts.

THE CENSUS.-The total number of population in New South Wales on the 2nd March last, as shown by the Census returns, was 114,769 males and 74,840 females ; total, 189,609. The returns shew an increase during the preceding five years of 27,471 males and 31,282 females ; and the still greater increase of 3,811 females over the male sex. The population beyond the limits of location is, 18,763 males and 6,299 females; total, 25,062. The average annual centesimal increase for five years is, males 6.29, females 14.36.

RUMOURS OF THE DAY . - It is pretty currently reported, and generally believed, that a dissolution of the Legislative body will shortly take place. The reasons stated as likely to lead to this result, are - First, the probable separation of Port Phillip from the Middle District, and the consequent re- tirement of the Port Phillip members ; and second, the squatting and the education questions, which must, of necessity, be brought to some kind of a settlement next session, rendering it advisable to take the sense of the public by a general election on measures of so great importance to the future welfare of the colony, - Australian, Nov. 12.

THE CROWN LANDS.-Letters have been re- ceived in town from Mr. Cunninghame, the Port Phillip Delegate, mentioning that shortly before the breaking up of the Peel Ministry, Lord Lyttleton, Under Secretary of State for the Colonies, intro- duced a Bill into the House of Commons for the regulation of the occupation of Waste Lands of the Crown in the Australian colonies, which was a regular transcript of Mr. Hope's bill of the previous year, merely altered by the incorporation of Sir George Gipps's marginal notes on the measure, which Mr. C says have no tendency towards making it one whit less objectionable. Whether the Whig Ministry will take up the measure or not, was not known, but considering

in whose hands the colonial administration of the government is placed, we do not think it likely; -Argus, Nov. 10.

RESULTS OE SALES.-On the 31st October, Mr. Mort sold, in Sydney, 1000 bushels of maize at 3s. per bushel; 12 cwt. of colonial bacon and hams at 6 3/4d. per lb. ; 53 bundles of New Zealand flax, at £17 per ton ; 5 bales of wool in grease at 7d. per lb. ; 8 bales and 1778 sheepskins at 5 3/4d: per lb. ; 21 hides at from 7s. 9d. to 9s. 3d. each ; and 2 casks of beef tallow at £28- 10s; per ton.

THE REVENUE.-The revenue of this district of the colony, amounted, in the quarter ending September 30th, 1846, to £6800, being a decrease on the corresponding quarter of 1845, of nearly £13,000. The principal items of decrease were duties on spirits imported, from £15,908 to £10,944 ; duties on spirits distilled in the colony, from £6702 to £5463 ; and assessment on stock, from £8310 to £2148-the Act authorising the assessment having expired on the 30th June. The largest item of increase, is that of licenses to depasture stock, from £12,618 to £13,889. The other items we shall defer until we give our usual analysis of the entire abstract. For the district of Port Phillip, the revenue for the quarter was £32,263, a decrease on1 the corresponding quarter of 468. The assessment on stock shows a balance against the district of £5817, buff the land sales yielded an increase of £5700, which presents the same proportion of decrease that is exhibited in the Sydney account.-Sydney Herald.

Commissariat Department.-The following notice appears in the Government Gazette :- " The Lords Commissioners of Her Majesty's Treasury having ordered the abolition of the De-

partment of Accounts in New South Wales : His

Excellency the Governor directs it to be notified, for the information and guidance of departments, that henceforth all accounts, abstracts, and other documents, hitherto forwarded to the Assistant Commissary-General of Accounts, Sydney, by the Convict Establishments, should be sent to the Deputy Commissary-General, to undergo the necessary examination before being passed in

warrant."

HOW TO KNOW WHETHER YOU ARE DRUNK OR SOBER.-Whenever you go to bed, look at the bed-posts. If they are standing still, conclude that you are sober ; but if they seem to be dancing the polka, you may reasonably suspect that you

are drunk.

SHORT RECKONINGS MAKE LONG FRIENDS.-We

asked a pretty girl the other day to give us a kiss, but she couldn't afford it ; she said she would lend us one, provided we would return it. We borrowed the article and returned it promptly.-American

paper.

A gentleman of New Orleans was agreeably surprised the other day to find a plump turkey served up for his dinner, and inquired of his servant how it was obtained, " Why, Sa," replied Blackie, " dat ar turkey is been roostin on our fence tree nites ; so dis mornin I sieze him for the rent ob the fence."

A wag says, Prince Louis Napoleon cut from

Ham to save his bacon.

VIRGIL'S line of advice for young smokers : Sick juvat ire sub umbras.

Many people take newspapers, but few preserve them, yet the most interesting thing imaginable is a file of newspapers. It brings up the very age with all its bustle and every day affairs, and marks its genius and its spirit more than the most laboured description of the historian.

WONDERFUL INSTINCT.-A cat having lost her kittens, followed a mutton-pie man.

A GOOD ONE.-A western editor gave the fol- lowing, as the most approved way of killing fleas in those parts :-Place the animal on a small pine board, and hedge him with putty ; then read him an account of all the railroad and steamboat acci- dents which happened the last twelve months. As soon as he becomes frightened, so as not to be able to stir, draw out his teeth, and he will be starved to death.

What is the essential difference between India

and Ireland ? In India the ryots make paddy, and in Ireland it is Paddy who makes the riots.

Though a man without money is poor, a man with nothing but money is poorer.

AN EDITOR WITH A RACE-HORSE.-An editor in America has bought a race-horse, for which he paid two hundred dollars. On being asked what an editor had to do with a race-horse, he replied, that " he was to be used in catching runaway

subscribers."

LORD ELLENBOROUGHAND THE NAVY.-Lord

Ellenborough has been making a speech at the Royal Navy School Festival, in which he declared his predilection for naval society. He sneered at people serving their country in the study, and

came to the conclusion that a man was much better

employed when " blazing away" in the field of battle. We understand that his lordship carries his love of naval habits to such an extent that his

dining-room is fitted up like the cabin of a ship ; he is waited on by men dressed as tars ; and he gives his orders in nautical phraseology. " Shove the marling spike athwart the ribs of that stove," is the form of expression he adopts when he wishes his servant to poke the fire ; and, " come, rig my main top," is the style in which he requests the assistance of his valet in the arrangement of his hair for dinner ; " clear the decks" means " take away the breakfast things;" and when he cuts down some wood on his estate, his lordship gives instructions that a certain portion of his timbers shall be immediately shivered. The little experi- ment of the Belleropon is repeated every now and then in his own mansion ; all the furniture of which is carried out of all the rooms, thrown into the backyard, and replaced with the utmost rapidity. All the bells in his establishment are sometimes set ringing at once, for no purpose but to test the rapidity with which they can be answer- ed. In fact, Lord Ellenborough is a much better seaman at home than out of doors, where he is sometimes rather at fault for Want of experience.

-Punch.

Saturday morning. The terms of subscription, are 10s. per quarter, payable in advance : the quarters ending 30tli September, 31st Decem- ber, 31st March, and 30th June, in each year respectively. articleText:
COLONIAL ABSTRACT.

All charges, in the shape of harbour dues or pilotage, have been abolished by the Government of Western Australia.—The expedition under the command of Mr. Horrocks, the object of which is to explore the unknown country northward to the ranges of Mount Arden, had started from Adelaide. —Mr. G. Arden's new journal, to be published at Geelong, Port Phillip, is to be entitled the Austral Gazette, and is to be published semi-weekly.— During the late.attack on the Hutt post in New

Zealand, some of the assailants, armed with toma- hawks, entered the hut of Sergeant Norton, occu- pied his wife and five little children. The natives ordered Mrs. Norton off with threats, but with true motherly devotion, she refused to go, not being able to carry, her poor infants with her. She also threw what little money she had on the ground before them, and stood over the children.

Even these savages were so charmed with her

spirit that they left the hut without injuring any

of the family.—The tender for 2000 gallons of rum, five per cent, under proof, for the Commis- sariat in Hobart Town, has been taken by Mr. Johnson, of the Wharf at 7s. 6d. per gallon.— Some samples of seed-wheat grown at a farm, on the river Plenty, in Port Phillip, readily sold in Scotland, in February last, at from ten to fifteen shillings per bushel. Changing seed is all the rage with the home farmers, and Australian wheat, at the above mentioned prices, is often and eagerly sought after in the market.—An Adelaide paper gives information that Mr. Pro-

tector Robinson, who was advertised for by his Honor the Superintendent, in the Port Phillip Government Gazette, was met, in company with a Mr. Jones and a Mr. Hancock, on the Adelaide side of Lake Bonney, and was expected, to arrive in Adelaide shortly.

HORSE STUD.—A splendid stud-horse, called "Royal William, had recently been imported into Port Phillip by a Mr. Tilly. Royal William is by Royal Oak, a descendant of Marske, the sire of the celebrated Eclipse. His dam is Princess Royal, a descendant of Childers. He was bred by Mr. William Edwards, of Newmarket, who re- fused a thousand guineas for him when a three year old.

HONI HEKI, A TIPPERARY MAN.—An Irish paper, the Tipperary Vindicator, gravely in- forms its readers, on the authority, we presume, of some waggish correpondent, that " it is curious, but, at the same time, an undoubted fact, that Heki is a Tipperary man—a native of the town- land of Lisbony, in the parish, of Nenagh, where all his family reside. He was originally a private in the 5th Dragoon Guards, but having been harshly treated, he deserted, and was adopted chief and general by the natives, to the daughter of whose king he is married." This is exceed- ingly rich, but, we must confess—only equalled by the observation of a Port Phillip contemporary, who, in presenting the above to his readers, commends the Vindicator as " a highly re spectable journal, able to throw some light upon the subject." Long life to the Tipperary Vindi- cator, say we. Perhaps our Melbourne friend will be courteous enough to inform us, whether the 5th Dragoon Guards are still stationed at New

Zealand ?

THE PRESENT POSITION OF THE SQUATTERS.— On the 30th of June expires the Act of Council 2nd Vict. No. 27, together with the 5th Vict. No. 9, continuing and enlarging the provisions of the former. The refusal of the Council to renew these obnoxious measures, and the subsequent adjourn- ment and prorogation of the House, of necessity prevent any temporary enactment, touching the administration of Crown lands, beyond the boun- daries ; and accordingly we shall, in a few days, be in the same situation as respects these lands, as that which we held before either of the above mentioned enactments became law. The days of Crown Land Commissioners are numbered, and on the 30th of the month, they will one and all breathe their last official sigh. The first of July will dawn upon a colony suddenly relieved from the pressure of as offensive and un-English a system of land administration as could have well been devised by the most ingeniously despotic mind ; and the previous day's mortality of Crown Land Commissioners being considered, it is likely that the squatters will for some time find it diffi- cult to analyze their sensations. No more Com misioner visitations,—no more Commissioner im- poundings,—no more Commissioner three-half- penny, or three-penny assessments, as the case may be,-no more Commissioner's distresses, and sales,-no more Commissioner progresses through their districts, as Equestrian Courts of Equity,— no more basking in Commissioner smiles; or terror at Commissioner frowns. The squatters will doubtless reflect upon, and pass to the credit of their condition, these important and interesting considerations ; but they will naturally also en- quire whether there are any and what other con- siderations, to place on the opposite side of the account. And here they will probably, in the first instance, think of the Attorney-General, and of his late facetious discourse in the Legislative Council, touching writs of intrusion : and will perhaps fruitlessly puzzle themselves in the effort to understand, how far, and how effectually, he may be able to bring his legal engines to bear upon the gentle shepherds beyond the boundaries. In the late debate the Attorneys-General, as if—it appeared to us—to catch a few squatter votes, through squatters' fears, intimated that the re- newal of the Act was of little consequence to the Government, as compared with its importance to the squatters themselves ; that the Crown had such things as writs of intrusion, and writs of entry, and an Attorney-General who could use them ; and that although the squatters, like Mr. Paul Pry, might, under the circumstances, " hope they did'nt intrude," they would in point of law and fact be all intruders together ; and would perhaps be dealt with accordingly. Hence a question, at present an interesting one— Are, the squatters in a position in respect to the Government rendering them liable, to be pro- ceeded against as for intrusion ? We appre- hend not. Intrusion, according to the legal authorities of Coke upon Littleton, 277, and Fitz herbert's Natura Brevium, 203, 204, appears to be a very different case from that of the occu- pation of land by a squatter, after the expiration of an Act, under which he was at first lawfully let into possession. Intrusion is a wrongful entry where the possession is vacant .. as where a tenant for life dies seized of certain lands and tenements, and a stranger enters after the death of the tenant, and before any entry by the person in remainder or reversion. The. entry of the squatter having been originally lawful, the ut- most that could be contended would be that he detained after the expiration of the period for which he was justified in holding the land ; and this case much more strongly resembles the kind of ouster called a deforcement, than an intrusion. For intrusion, no doubt the summary remedy by a writ of entry would lie ; but for deforcement the remedy must be by action : and either course

would not be a very, respectable one for a govern- ment to take against its own people, if either course were less than wild and impracticable, which it is not. The army of bailiffs required to, be in possession, in the different scarcely-defined locations of an unsurveyed country, was happily ridiculed by Mr. Lowe in the course .of his speech. In short, the assault by Don Quixote upon the windmills was not followed by a more disastrous result, than would attend a general attack on the squatters, by our legal Quixote, even if aided by his own Sancho, the Civil Crown Solicitor. We have much too high an opinion of the Attorney- General's judgment, to believe that he, would seriously attempt to put in practice a suggestion that might be well enough thrown out, quantum valeat, in the course of a debate. The squatters must, we conceive, remain undisturbed until the arrival of Mr. Hope's Bill, or until, at the next meeting of the Council, a measure can be framed and passed for the regulation of their interests. But meanwhile, what will be their position, as re- spects their rights and liberties, should they be disturbed in their possession by strangers ? Could they turn off disturbers, or maintain tresspass against them ? There is no doubt they could do so, as effectually as during the existence of the Act ; the only difference being, that there would be no preliminary adjudication by a Crown Land Commissioner, first to be obtained, We believe that before the passing of either of the Acts men- tioned at the beginning of this article, actions of tresspass by squatters against disturbers of their possession were by no means unfrequent, and ver- dicts were recovered, upon the common legal axiom that possession alone is sufficient to support an action of tresspass against a wrong doer.— Sydney Morning Herald.

CPE OF GOOD HOPE.—A private letter from the Cape, of 30th April, published in the South Australian Gazette, contains the latest news yet received. The writer says—"There is nothing else talked of in Cape Town, but the war with the Kaffirs, and the dearness of provisions. The frontier mail is better than thirty hours overdue, and it is supposed that the Kaffirs have shot the guard and destroyed the mail. The last accounts

from the frontier were, that our Governor was nearly taken prisoner, and that the Kaffirs had taken fifty baggage waggons, but not the am- munition. Wheat is at present selling here for 17 rix dollars per muid (one rix dollar is equal to 1s. 6d.—a muid is about three bushels,) and is expected to rise much more. Martial law is pro- claimed all about Graham's Town, and report has it that the next accounts will be that martial law Hill be in Cape Town and the district "

GLORIOUS TIMES FOR THE LADIES.—In the reign of Queen Margaret, of Scotland, the Par- liament passed an act, that any maiden lady, of high or low degree, should have liberty to choose for a husband the man on whom she set her fancy. If the man refused to marry her, he was heavily fined, according to the value of his worldly pos- sessions. The only ground of exemption was previous betrothal.

CHANGE OF PHRASE.—The extent of Railway Surveying has caused a certain popular query to be superseded. Instead of, "Has your mother sold her mangle?" the boys in the streets now ask, " Has your father Sold his theodolite ?" Another specimen of refinement has been recently practised; the well-known expression of "He goes the whole hog," has been changed to " He locomotes the entire swine,"

A VOICE FROM THE BOURDOIR, ON BERLIN WOOL.—We are sure the ladies of England are very glad to hear that Sir R. Peel, like a good creature, is going to take off the duty, or tariff, or whatever it is called, from foreign lace and Leghorns, and French shoes, and other things that they are always wanting. They are charmed with dear Sir Robert-a duck of a Premier !- for not having all his mind taken up with that Ire- land, and those Corn Laws, and the stupid agri- cultural interest ; but for attending a little to their own interest, which must be granted to be the most interesting of any. But there is one thing that he must do, or else they shall not like him half so well as they otherwise should. He positively must take the tax off Berlin Wool. They regret to learn that he does not mean to repeal this tax, be- cause he thinks it a tax on luxury. Berlin wool a luxury ! They never heard of such a thing. The grant that pine-apples and other foreign fruit —Champagne, Constantia, Noyeau, and wines and liqueurs of that kind—such a rarity, for instance, as parfait amour—are luxuries. They will ad- mit that cigars are luxuries, though they cannot conceive how; but they never will admit that Berlin wool can be viewed in that light. They own that they make little elegancies out of it, but if it is to be taxed on that account, they suppose curl-papers will be taxed next. Sir Robert should consider what a save it is in a family to have cushions and stools, and netting for chairs, worked at home. The ladies hope that he is still enough of a protectionist to appreciate the value of a kettle holder, marked with the warning, " Mind-, it boils !" otherwise they will not be sorry should he burn his fingers for the want of one. Things of this kind surely, they maintain, are not luxu- ries, for what could they do without them ? So they hope Sir Robert Peel will not be an obstinate and a stupid, but will give up the Berlin wool tax along with the other plaguy taxes, or else they shall be very cross with him, and will give him a good scolding.—Punch.

Saturday morning. The terms of subscription are 10s. per quarter, payable in advancer the quarters ending 30th September, 31st Decem- ber, 31st March, and 30th June, in each year respectively. Each advertisement will be charged at the rate of three shillings an inch, and one shilling for every additional inch, each insertion. articleText:
FACTS WORTH KNOWING.

Animalcules are not to be found in all fluids ; none are to be found in wines, or any other fer- mented liquor which has not passed into the state of vinegar, or which has not become completely vapid, neither are they to be found in distilled or spring water.-The itch, according to Willan, is caused by an insect, white, with eight reddish legs, to the four hind ones of which is appended a bristle ; it may be distinguished with the mi- croscope in the vesicles of the joints which ac- company the disorder. On the same authority we learn that most of the diseases of the skin are occasioned by other insects.-Ninety millions of eggs of the cheese mite are not so large as one pigeon's egg.-Sponges are believed to consist of excitable flesh, full of small mouths, by which they absorb and eject water.-The phosphoric light seen in the ocean is believed to be caused by innumerable quantities of phosphoric insects. Ambergrease is an internal production of diseased. spermaceti whales; spermaceti is produced from the head of the cachelot. and ambergrease is the excrement of its intestines.-The bones of birds are hollow, and filled with air instead Of marrow. -In serpents and fish both jaws are moveable. All hair is hollow and cylindrical.-An elm tree is full grown in 150 years, and it lives 500 or 600 years ; ash is full grown in 100 years and oak in 200 years.-The seeds of plants are their eggs ; a sunflower produces 4000, a poppy 30,000, a tobacco plant from 300,000 to 400,000, and spleenwort, a million ; some, as the sea-pink, have but one seed, umbelliferous flowers, two, and the sparge and ranunculas, three ; the capsule of the white poppy contains 8000 seeds.-Some seeds germinate after boiling.-The fibrous tissue of silk, is said to be visible in the white mulberry, on which the worms feed.-A Cingalese family live at ease on the produce of a dozen cocoanut; trees, with three or four juck-trees.-The coaco- tree supplies the Indians with almost whatever they stand in need of; as bread, water, wine, vinegar, brandy, milk, oil, honey, sugar, needles, clothes, thread, cups, spoons, basins, baskets, paper, masts for ships, sails, cordage, nails, co- vering for houses, &c., &c.-Tea was introduced into England about the year 1660.-Hops entwine to the left, and convolvulus to the right; tendrils bend to the left and back again.-No insect will live near the sandal-tree, and iron will not rust near it.-Potatoes and tobacco were introduced

into Ireland in 1603.-Most seeds pass unchanged through the intestines of animals.-Vegetable butter is in general use in some parts of Africa, and potted for preserving.-An acre of ground will contain 43,560 plants at 12 inches apart; 19,360 at 18 inches: 10,890 at 2 feet: and of course 4,840 a yard asunder ; 2,722 at 4 feet ; at 10 feet but 435, and at 20 feet but 108.-The

heart of the aloes tree sells in India for its weight

in gold, under the name of tambac-Assafoetida is the product of the root of a Persian plant. The average crop of an orange tree is from 6,000 to 8,000.-Otto of Roses is the oil which swims at top in the distillation of rose-water. Plants

are poisonous when the fruit is a berry, the flower a single petal, And when the fructification consists of five stamens and one pistillum.-Soy is not made, as commonly asserted, from cockroaches, but from the beans of the dolichos soja, a native of Japan, pickled and fermented with salt.-The' disease in rye called spur or ergot, affords a black powder, useful in quickening parturition-There are five species of quartz ; amethyst, rock chrystal, milk quartz, common quartz, and praise.-Mica is found in such large plates, in many mountains, as to be used as a substitute for glass, being semi- transparent, tough, flexible, and elastic ; in Si- beria some specimens are 2 1/2 yards square, and sold in India and used as glass.-In 3 1/2 years mortar regains its definite proportion as carbonate of lime, or 63 per cent, from the carbonic acid gas in the atmosphere.-Earth is eaten as bread in some parts of the world ; near Moscow, a hill furnishes earth of this description, which will ferment when mixed with flour ; in Louisiana the Indians eat a white earth with salt ; and the In- dians on the Oronooko eat a certain unctious earth in like manner. - The Welsh mountains are com- posed of trap, limestone, and dimstone; they were covered with forests, and burnt down by Edward 1.-Rock salt is found in Cheshire, in England, at a depth of from 28 to 50 yards, and the beds are from one to forty yards thick, separated by clay or slag stones ; the colour is reddish, and it is so hard as to require to be blasted with gun- powder ; the largest mine is 330 feet deep and 20 feet high, supported by pillars of the salt.-The sea, if desicated would afford a bed of salt 500 feet thich, 100 for every mile.-A cubic foot of coal weighs from 75 lbs. to 80 lbs., and 27 are equal to a ton per cubic yard, or 4,840 tons to an acre, of one yard thick.-Some chrystalized salts con- tain above half their weight in water, yet are dry to the touch.-Common salt dissolved in viscid liquids chrystalizes like the leaves and branches of fir.-Diamonds are imitated by combining one half red or white lead with silex, potash, or some borax or arsenic-.The hundred-thousandth part of a grain of gold may be seen by the naked eye, and a cube of gold, whose side is but the hundredth part of an inch, has 2,433 millions of visible parts. -A cylinder of silver, covered with gold leaf, may be drawn out 350 miles long, and yet the gold will cover it. -Gold leaf can be reduced to the three-hundredth-thousandth part of an inch ; and gilding to the ten millionth. Silver leaf to the 170 thousandth., The specific gravities are 193 to 105.-Lace gilding is the millionth of an inch thick ; gold leaf the 200 thousandth.-Pla- tina wire may be the 50,000th of an inch -Five hundred inches of gold wire has been drawn out from one grain.-Tin foil is the one-thousandth of an inch ; that is, 200 gold leaves are only equal in thickness to one of tin foil.-One grain of gold will cover 7 1/4 inches each way, or 52 square inches, or be fifteen hundred times thinner than writing paper, viz., a sheet of writing paper would be 1,500 leaves.-A mass of pure gold has been found in Siberia.-Silver leaf breaks at the 169,000th part of an inch, or three times the thickness of a gold leaf. It tarnishes from sul- phur, and dissolves in sulphuric and nitric acid. -Silver can be beat into plates, of which 110,000 make an inch, and drawn into wire of which the thirtieth of an inch will sustain 137 lbs.-The weight of an ingot of silver is from 50 lbs. to 70 lbs , and the weight of an ingot of gold is 15 lbs. troy.-Copper wire, the thirteenth of an inch, will sustain 302 lbs. ; a tin wire the thirteenth of an inch, sustains but 34 lbs. 7 oz.-Gun metal is 12 lbs. of tin, and 100 lbs. of copper.-Granite mountains are rugged and precipitous, gneiss less so, and slate smooth and round.-Most mountains present their precipitous faces to the sea, and their slopes to the land.-In the plains around the Table Mountain in South Carolina, there are found enormous bones of unknown animals, the ribs of which are six feet long, the teeth above eight inches, three and a half wide, and near a foot in the root.-About two hundred active volcanoes are recorded, of which eighty-nine are in islands. -Stones of immense size have been thrown up at the eruptions of Mount Etna to the height of 7000 feet ; and others have fallen at 100 miles distant.-The river Mississippi is navigable 4000 ; the Amazon, 2300 ; the Hoang in China, 3260 ; the Yangtse, 3060 ; the Nile, 2690 ; La Plata, 2215 ; the Volga, 2100 ; the Euphrates, 2020 ; the Danube, 1790 ; the Indus, 1770 ; the Ganges, 1650 ; the Oronoko, 1500 ; the St. Lawrence, 1230 ; the Niger, 1900 ; the Senegal above 1000, the Rhine and the Gambia, 800.-In icebergs only one-seventh is out of the water.-In the river Menan the tide runs seventeen miles an hour.-The whole earth as 1000 parts, is 726 water and 274 land. The southern hemisphere as 500 parts, is 64 land and 436 water; the northern hemisphere, of 500 parts, is 210 land

and 290 water.

PROFESSIONAL -At an examination of the College of Surgeons, a candidate was asked by Abernethy what he would do if a man were blown up by gunpowder ? " Why," coolly answered the tyro, " wait till he came down again." " Then," said Abernethy, " suppose I kicked you for such an impertinent reply, what muscle should be put in motion ?" " Why," replied the young man, " the flexors and extensors of my arm, for I should floor you directly."

The following toast was given at the anniver- sary of the New England Society at New Orleans : " The daughters of Louisana- attracted by their bright eyes, enchained by their sweet smiles, the sons of the pilgrims only await their assent to be- come pilgrim fathers."

articleText:
COLONIAL.

CAPTAIN STOKES'S DISCOVERIES.-In various

articles upon the northern parts of New Holland, directed as they have been, in part, to illustration

of the discoveries of Leichhardt, we have called the attention of our brother colonists to the vast fields for enterprise and labour, at present unoc- cupied, which are merely awaiting the processes of occupation and culture to furnish an abundant

increase to our national wealth. Our inducement now to return to the subject is twofold. Leich- hardt has again set forth, upon his exploration, and is already many miles from Sydney, in his progress towards his new destination ; and the result of Captain Stokes's discoveries has just come into our bands. .As much that is contained in the works of the latter gentleman, independent of its positive value, is of relative use to us in appreciating the energy and truthfulness of the former, we propose, therefore, to examine some of the contents of Captain Stokes's volumes. It may also be of service to Dr. Leichhardt, should he be able which we think he will, before he quits the settled districts, to get sight of our columns, to see how encouragingly (as it were) for the future, Captain Stokes's confirms what he has al- ready published respecting that part of his route which bordered on the ground investigated by the enthusiastic commander of the Beagle. In order to carry out our views, we shall not observe any consecutive order in our notice of the work before us, but refer at once to such portions of it as bear on the subject of our anxieties. The first fact deserving of our notice is, to use Captain Stokes's words, that either in the Percy Islands or in the Nothumberland Islands (lat. 21* S., not more than 360 miles due north of Moreton Bay.) " sandal wood has been found of late and taken by a Tasmanian vessel to the China market." If this be the case, we have a valuable article of commerce much more easily accessible than was supposed. It has been suggested that the river Burdekin, which, by its continuation into the Clarke, must drain the water of the Carpentaria ranges, disembogues somewhere near Halifax Bay ; and the officers of H.M.S. Fly spoke often of a river entering the ocean close to Cape Upstart, and but a few miles to the southward of the Bay. As this is a point of some importance, we will quote Captain Stokes's words-" On sweeping the western shore with a spyglass, I discovered the mouth of a river about a mile to the north of a hillock marked in Captain King's chart. This river was made the object of an exploring party, and next day, Captain Wickham and Lieutenant Eden went on that interesting service. It has two entrances, both very shallow, and is of little importance, being on a lee-shore and fronted by a bar, which seems to break at all times of the tide. However, as there is such very safe anchorage near, the discovery may hereafter prove of some value. Captain Wickham found it fresh ten miles from the entrance ; but at that point it is nearly lost in the sands, and so very shallow that the natives have a fishing weir across it The land, which appears to be much cut up with creeks, is very flat on both sides, and is subject to inundations. This was evident from the signs of drift, to the height of six feet, on the trees that grew along the banks, themselves not more than a couple of yards above high water mark." (Vol. 1, p. 330.) Of Halifax Bay, the author says but little. But he sums up what he has to say in very significant terms. " It is the general opinion of every voyager who has sailed along the coast of Halifax Bay, that it is the most interesting portion of the north-east side of the continent, as com- bining the several facts we have given." [These are the picturesque character of the mountainous termination of the Cordillera, as the dividing ranges are now called, the signs of abundant native population, &c] " We have every reason to believe that the discovery of fertile, and there- fore valuable, land will one day reward the labours of the explorer." It is to Halifax Bay that we have always pointed as the centre of location of a new colony, as being fairly within the tropic, commanding the quiet waters inside the Great Barrier, and so well situated with respect to the York Peninsula, the Gulf of Carpentaria, and the splendid country discovered by Leichhardt to the southward of the Burdekin. Our impression is so strong on this point, that we would venture to suggest that the Legislative Council should take up the subject, appoint a committee to enquire and report, and then petition the Home Govern- ment to colonise that interesting district. It was not far from Halifax Bay, in lat. 19* 54', that Leichhardt found a fine limestone ; and his ge- neral account of the country westward of the coast confirms all our conjectures as to its avail- able character. As we have no alternative, we must now pass at once to the country bounding the Gulf of Carpentaria, where many important discoveries were made by Captain Stokes. This author remarks, as Leichhardt has done, on the abundance of rivers and creeks which flow into

the Gulf ; on the fineness of the country for grazing purposes ; on the abundance of wild fowl and birds of all kinds, and on the peculiarities of temperature, and of the coolness of the wind. Amongst the rivers mentioned by Leichhardt is the Yappar, which he afterwards considered as the Flinders of Captain Stokes. He made it in lat. 17* 49', where it was salt ; and he gives the long. 140* 45' E. Captain Stokes lays down the Flin- ders in lat. 17* 36' to 17' 52', and in long. 140* 40'. Leichhardt, therefore, passed the Flinders near the spot where Stokes ceased his exploration. As Captain Stokes ascended the river thus far in a boat, the natives, one of whose dead was found by him laid out in a tree, must have been ac- quainted with Europeans ; and we find Leichhardt in his report stating, " the country is well in- habited by blackfellows ; we had three times in- tercourse with them-the third time (at the Yap par) they were friendly, and it was evident they had seen either Malays or white men before us." As Leichhardt could not follow down to their mouths any of the rivers he crossed, and it may be interesting to our readers to know what is the nature of those rivers, we will borrow an account of the Flinders or Yappar from Stokes. He places its mouth in lat. 17* 36' 40" S., and long. 8* 27' E. of Port Essington. A channel of two feet through the flat at low water, marks the entrance: The river has near its entrance a depth of from three to five fathoms, with a breadth of about one hundred and twenty yards, and is well marked from the offing by abundance of trees dotted on the low grounds. The tides occur only once in twenty-four hours, a phenomenon common to the Gulf. The upward courses of the

«Discoveries in Australia, with an account of the coasts and rivers explored and surveyed du- ring the voyage of H.M.S. Beagle, in the years 1837-38-39-40-41-42-43. By command of the Lords Commissioners of the Admiralty. Also, a narrative of Captain Owen Stanley's visit to the Islands of the Arafura Sea. By J. L. Stokes, Commander, R.N. 2 vols. London. Boone, 1846.

rivers wore southerly, with tortuous snake-like reaches. Numerous banks impeded the course and reduced the depth ; plains dotted with trees or dense jungle, filled with vampyres (Qy., " fly- ing foxes?" one of Leichhardts dainties,) and whistling ducks, alternated beyond the water's edge. About twelve miles from the mouth sunken trees were numerous, indicating " how fierce a torrent had borne them thither." Fine sheets of limpid water, low grassy islets, native shrubberies, and sandy beaches, with grassy banks sloping into the stream, and masses of luxuriant creepers, were the general features. An engraving represents a beautiful scene at the spot where the dead body was found. The ground here was higher than, the country in general, perhaps thirty-five feet in elevation above the sea ; the plains were covered with rose-coloured cockatoos. Beyond Burial Reach the river bifurcates, one branch tending easterly. The furthest position was thirty miles from the entrance, in lat. 17* 51', or just two miles above where Leichhardt crossed one of the branches. Abundance of smoke and fire marked the presence of natives. It is really delightful to see how accurately Captain Stoke's account tallies with that of our enterprising friend, now again on the wide ocean of adventure. In our farther notices of the work before us, we shall have other examples of his fidelity to record, and we are sure it will be gratifying to his friends throughout the colony to know that though his means were limited; he was enabled to make observations which have been confirmed by an eminent nautical surveyor, and that his accounts of the country, are by no means exaggerated. These facts, in themselves valuable, have a further value,. They justify the claim for strict regard to truth, which Leichhardt's character has established with those who know him, and will be the best guarantee of his reputa- tion against all questioners. In his report he mentions that he passed between the Yappar (Flinders), 140* 45' E. approx., and the Nichol- son, 138* 55' E., which river he crossed in 138* 55' E., -" three big salt water rivers, one fine running creek, which I called Beames's Brook, and several chains of fresh water lagoons." It was a subject of some surprise, when we first read Leichhardt's account, that we found no mention of the Albert River, the discovery of which by Stokes made some noise at the time, as it was said to have led him to within 400 miles of the centre of the continent. On comparing his map with our friend's journal, we find apparently the great- est accuracy ; and there is no doubt that Beames's Brook of Leichhardt is the head of one branch of the Albert of Stokes ; and this fact shows the extreme skill and judgment with which that in- trepid traveller calculated his distances. Although we cannot now allude to the Albert further, yet we cannot resist comparing the statements of these two explorers. Beames's Brook was crossed by Leichhardt in 17* 57' S., where it was, he says, " twenty yards broad; its water was fresh, but affected by the tide. At the crossing place, (about eight miles lower down), it was three yards broad, very deep in some places, shallow in others, A full flowing little stream, with magnificent oak trees, and palms, and pandanus, and flooded gum along its banks. We never had met, nor did we meet another brook like it again." " Holding," says Stokes, speaking of the Albert, " our west course, we made the river again at the end of another mile. Its size was reduced to a, mere rivulet, being scarcely fifteen yards wide, with a depth of five feet. Yet it had a greater velocity than we had before observed, running at the rate of a mile an hour, a clear babbling brook, over which acacias and drooping gums formed a leafy tunnel ; its course was still from the south." " My position was in lat. 17* 58 1/2' S., and long. 139. 25 E. Consequently, Leichhardt crossed the Albert about one and a half mile distant from Stokes's furthest point, just as he had crossed the Flinders in the same manner. The " three big salt water rivers" seem not to be so clearly made out in the chart of the southern part of the gulph ; but Disaster Inlet, Morning Inlet, and the salt water arm of the Albert to the eastward, may be the three sites of Leichhardt's rivers. If this arrangement be correct, then the river Nicholson must disembogue at Pascoe's Inlet. Leichhardt gives the breadth of the salt water rivers as 150, 200, and 300 yards. Now Stokes says the Albeit varied in breadth from 200 to 250 yards ; an ac- cidental testimony of another kind to Leichhardt's general accuracy. We shall have somewhat to say about the Albert hereafter.-Sydney Morning

Herald.

ENQUIRY.-The Governor has received a private communication from Mr. Gladstone, wherein it is stated that it is due to Sir Eardley Wilmot to in- form him, that reports so injurious to his private character had reached Mr. Gladstone, that it would be impossible to give him any other appointment unless he could satisfactorily disprove those re- ports, Sir E. Wilmot intends, therefore, to request the members of the Executive Council, the Chief Justice, Rev. J. Lillie, and Archdeacon Marryatt, to act as a committee of enquiry, and is willing to submit to the strictest investigation concerning his private conduct since his arrival here. Sir Eardley states, that if he stood in the presence of God he would declare that he had never, in any one instance, passed the boundary of the strictest propriety. If Mr. Gladstone has acted on mere private report, it cannot be right, otherwise no man is safe. At any rate, the Governor deserves credit for calling an enquiry-he gives them per- fect leave to examine his servants and all about him, and we hope the vile imputations we never credited, will be conclusively shown to be as false as they were cowardly.-Launceston Examiner.
