articleText:
IMMIGRATION.

On the motion of Mr. Francis Scott, last year's Report of the Committee of the Legislative Council on Immigration has been printed by order of the House of Commons, together with the evidence of the witnesses, and various appendices, including a number of " statements of immigrants" collected by Mrs. C. Chisholm. The circulation of this document in England must be productive of benefit to the colony, although, until the session of Par- liament was closed, which would be about the end of August, the press would not be able to pay much attention to it. The report is preceded by the following truly Gippsianic despatch :

Copy of a despatch from Governor Sir George

Gipps to Lord Stanley.

Government House, Sydney,

27th October, 1846 My Lord,

I have the honour to forward herewith a copy of a Report during the course of the present session by a Committee of the Legislative Council of this colony, appointed on the 22nd August, 1845, to take into consideration and report on the subject of immigration.

I also enclose a copy of an Address from the Legislative Council, in which I have been re- quested to transmit this Report to your Lordship.

I agree with the two principal points mooted in the address, namely, 1st., that immigration to the colony should now be resumed ; and 2ndly, that the Crown lands, if properly administered, afford adequate means for paying the interest of a mo- derate loan. I cannot, however, recommend the raising of a loan unless it be guaranteed by her Majesty's Government; nor can I recommend her Majesty's Government to guarantee it, unless a full and efficient Parliamentary guarantee be previously given, that the lands of the colony shall not be kept in perpetuity by those who may be the first to seize on them, (!!!) and that for the use of the unsold lands of the Crown, a moderate annual payment shall be made.

1 also feel it necessary to state, that, without attempting to controvert or refute the general

nature of the evidence taken by the Committee. I can scarcely join in recommending so extensive an immigration as that mentioned in the address. With the consequences, indeed, fresh in my memory, which resulted from my having yielded too readily in the years 1839 and 1840 to the pressure which was then brought to bear upon me in respect to immigration, I feel it necessary to guard myself by saying, that I cannot advise the adoption of any immediate measures for the re- sumption of immigration, to an extent greater than about one-third of what is mentioned by the Committee, or that the expense (to be borne by the colony) should exceed about £75,000 per annum.

I have, &c.,

(Signed) GEO. GIPPS.

NEW ZEALAND.

A number of armed natives, belonging to dif- ferent tribes, chiefly from the interior, to the number of from one hundred to one hundred and fifty, have visited Wanganui under Nopera and Maketu, two chiefs of that district, who were acting with Rangihaeata during the late rebellion. The settlers, who were in no condition to defend them- selves from this invasion, fully expected that their property, and perhaps their lives, would be sacri- ficed to the wanton violence of these savages, and they were probably only saved from all the hor-

rors which would have resulted from the unchecked

gratification of the inflamed passions of these marauders, by the timely and efficient aid of the missionary natives of Putiki, who firmly resisted any attempt at violence, and declared their inten- tion of assisting the settlers to the utmost in the event of any decided act of hostility on the part of

the taua towards them. A report prevailed at one time, that the steamer would arrive with troops for the protection of the settlers, on which a party of the taua posted themselves in ambush in the fern near the mouth of the river, with the intention of cutting off any reinforcements which might at- tempt to proceed in boats to the assistance of the settlers. After remaining some days in the settle- ment, during which they threatened all sorts of violence, which it required the greatest prudence and caution on the part of the settlers to prevent from being carried into effect, the taua dispersed on the 26th instant (October), part of them joining Ran- gihaeata, while the greater number proceeded up the river in their canoes. On their departure, they threatened to return in great numbers in two months' time, and warned the settlers in the inter- val to leave the settlement. A public meeting of the settlers was held, at which many of the Putiki chiefs were present, and a memorial to the Go- vernor was adopted, praying for efficient protec- tion. Intelligence has also been received from Manawatu of acts of robbery and violence com- mitted by Rangihaeata's followers on the settlers

in that district and at Oahu. The Catherine Ann

has returned without being able to land her cargo. Rangihaeata has warned the settlers to leave in a few days, threatening, in the event of their refusal, to attack them. The settlers for the present have returned to their dwellings from the assurances of the natives resident at Manawatu of their deter- mination to unite in protecting them from Ran- gihaeata's violence ; but unless something more is done we may shortly expect to find these out settlers forced to abandon the field of their labours, and consult their own safety by retreating to Wellington, as there is no doubt that he will carry his threats into execution.-Wellington Spectator,

October 31.

LONDON WOOL MARKETS.

(From the Times, City Article, 28th July. )

The second series of Wool sales did not conclude so well as was generally expected. Some of the circulars issued by the trade speak of an average reduction in rates of from 7½ to 10 per cent, since the sales of last May. A numerous attendance of buyers was observed throughout the whole of the auctions, but as they exercised caution in their transactions, prices did not receive much support. The various descriptions, with the rates obtained, may be thus classified :-Australian, 8d to 2s 6d per lb. ; Van Diemen's Land, 7d to 2s ; Port Phillip, 7 ½d to 2s ; South Australian, 7d to 1s 4½d ; Swan River, (which do not include " un- washed fleeces,") 1s 7d to 1s 10d ; and Cape, 6d to 1s 7d. East India, from grey and mixed to good white, brought 4d to 9½d per lb.

London, 26th July, 1846.

We never recollect to have seen a more numer- ous attendance of buyers, of all classes, than has been present during these sales. At the com- mencement, and indeed until the later days of this series, a marked disinclination to stock was mani- fest, except at very reduced rates ; but at the esta- blished reduction the trade were steady buyers.

Fine clothing flocks, in good condition, from Sydney and Port Phillip, were in most demand ; but for combing wools from the latter colony and Van Diemen's Land, very, low rates were sub- mitted to. Lower quality and heavy conditioned wools suffered a more material decline than was apparent on better conditioned parcels from all the colonies : on the former we consider a reduc- tion has taken place about equivalent to that on Adelaide wools in May last, and on the latter the reduction has been rather smaller.

Lambs' wool has been in as animated request as in May last.

Some of the flocks from Port Phillip show a lamentable falling off in quality ; but the exceptions are numerous in which great pains have been suc- cessfully taken, both in the breed and condition. The former remark may be applied to several usually fine flocks from Sydney, in which a rather injudicious use has been made of the Leicester

cross.

Since our last report, the result of the German wool fairs has been ascertained, at which a re- duction of 15 to 30 per cent, on last year's rates was established. The operations for English ac-

count were not so extensive as usual.

It is at present too early to pronounce an opinion on the probable result of the late politico-com- mercial changes ; but looking to the largely in- creasing supplies of our staple article from all parts of the world, it is a satisfactory feature of the wool trade, that so large a quantity should have found buyers with the certainty of a nearly similar quantity being brought forward in about six weeks from the present time.

East India wools sold at about late rates for better qualities, but on lower classes and inferior a reduction was submitted to.

C. &. J. D. Jacomb,

Brokers.

In the Maitland Mercury, we find the following extract from Bell's Messenger of the 3rd August, being a corrected list of prices realised at the July

sales :

Australian.-Superior combing, 1s 9d, 2s 2½d ; fair, 1s 6d, 1s 9d ; superior clothing, 1s 9d, 2s. 4d ; average, 1s 5d, 1s 8d ; scoured, 1s 4d, 2s 7½ ; lambs', good 2s, 2s 2½d ; fair average, 1s 6d,

1s 10d; inferior, 1s 3d, 1s 5d ; hand-washed. 1s 5d, 2s 3d ; skin, &c, 7d, 1s 8d per lb.

Van Diemen's Land.-Combing, 1s 4d, 1a 10d ; clothing, 1s 2d, 1s 10d ; scoured, 1s 6d, 2s 2d ; average flocks, 1s 4d, 1s 8d ; inferior and greasy, 7d, 1s 4d ; lambs', good, 1s 10½d, 2s 5d ; ordinary and fair, 1s 4d, 1s 9d per lb.

Port Phillip.-Good flocks, 1s 6d, 2s 1d ; average, 1s. 3d, 1s 5d ; lambs', 1s 4d, 2s 3d per lb.

Swan River.-Average flocks, none ; inferior 10d, 1s 2d per lb.

South Australian.-Average, 1s 1d, 1s 6½d ; inferior, 11d. 1s 2d per lb.

Cape of Good Hope.-Prize fleeces, 1s 8d, 2s 11d ; good flocks. 1s 3d, 1s. 6d ; fair average, 1s 1d, 1s 3d; low 5½d, 11d. per lb.

East India.-Good, 8d, 9½d ; inferior 6d, 7½d ; low 3½d, 5d per lb.

About 20,000 bales of colonial wools, already imported, are entered for the next September sales -by that month this quantity will be greatly in-

creased.

Sale of 810 bales of wool, by Messrs. J. T, Simes and Co., on the 15th July :

A coquette is said to be a perfect incarnation of Cupid. Cos vy ? She keeps her beau in a quiver.

Why are the flowers such severe creditors ? Because they are always sure to get their dews.

Who is the general pew-opener in the metropo-

litan churches ? -One Bob.

Why is a soldier in the ranks ten years ago, and in the ranks now, liable to seizure by the Excise ? - Because he is a private still.

Why is a passionate man like a lighted candle ?

-Because he is hot-headed.

Why is bribery like a beehive?-Because it

contains B's.

Why is pepper like pease-soup ?-Because there

are P's in it.

What smells most in a doctor's shop ? -The nose.

articleText:
NORTH AUSTRALIA.

HOUSE OF LORDS May 19.

Earl Grey wished to ask Her Majesty's Govern- ment whether any measures had been taken for the establishment of a new colony, which was, he believed to be called North Australia : for it ap- peared from papers that had been laid before the House, that a new colony was to be founded, con- sisting almost exclusively of persons who had undergone the sentence of the law, and who were, in New South Wales language, emancipated.

Lord Lyttleton said, undoubtedly the scheme to which the noble earl had referred had been carried on to a great degree ; but he was a little surprised at his noble friend bringing the question forward at that time, because he must have seen from the papers that the intention of the Government to institute a new colony was made known eighteen months ago. No objection had ever been raised to that scheme, and the arrangements connected with it had been carried through to a great extent : as to the description of the settlement, it was not quite such as his noble friend stated. It was to

be a new colony to the north of the settlements in New South Wales, and it was not necessarily to consist of emancipated convicts. Those persons who had gone through their punishments in Van Diemen's Land were certainly to have facilities given to them to proceed to that settlement ; but

it was also intended to give facilities to the poorer, classes of this country who wished to proceed

thither.

NEW ZEALAND.

The latest accounts from New Zealand state that the rebels have at last met with a severe check. Sixteen chiefs have been taken prisoners, and are at present in safe keeping on board H. M. S. Calliope. Everything had assumed a most satis- factory aspect, and a line of posts had been com- pleted at Porirua, so as to effectually prevent any return of the rebels to the district of the Hutt. Everything was quiet in the north.

RESERVATIONS IN GRANTS OF LAND.

South Australia was colonised with the distinct understanding, and, to the best of our recollection, with a distinct pledge on the part of the Home Government, that its waste lands should he con- veyed to purchasers in the completest and most absolute form in which a freehold could be created, including not only the surface of the earth, but all above and all below it. After the lapse of about ten years, however, when private enterprise has discovered the existence of mineral treasures, the Crown invidiously steps in with its claims to a royalty of minerals dug up, and with its re- servation of such as are still dormant in thier native beds.

And so in New South Wales, the Government

began to grant in the spirit of liberality, and eventually fell under the spell of avarice. On looking back to the time, now two-and-twenty years ago, when the practice of selling out waste lands was first introduced, we find no mention whatever of reservations of any kind. The ear- liest code of land regulations, dated Colonial office, Downing-street, November, 1824, contains this clause :—' On payment of the money, a grant will be made in fee-simple to the purchaser, at the nominal quit-rent of a pepper-corn.' The same stipulation is repeated in the code of 1825, and several subsequent years. Indeed, we can dis- cover no trace of reservation in lands disposed of by sale, prior to the 1st of July, 1831, when the system of grants without purchase was abolished. In the regulations of that date there is the follow- ing clause :—' The Crown reserves to itself the right of making and constructing such roads and bridges as may be necessary for public pur- poses, in all lands purchased as above ; and also to all indigenous timber, stone, and other mate- rials, the produce of the land, as may be required for making and keeping the said roads and bridges in repair, and for any other public works. The Crown further reserves to itself all mines of precious metals and coals.' In a subsequent edition of these regulations, two additional reser- vations are introduced ; namely—' all lands within one hundred feet of high water mark on the sea coast, creeks, harbours, and inlets ;' and also the

right of taking and removing such indigenous timber and other materials, the produce of the land, as may be required at any time for naval purposes.'

The whole of these very large and formidable reservations continue, we believe, to be inserted in deeds of grant to the present day. They are not expressly authorised by the Land Act, 5 and 6 Victoria, cap. 36 ; but whether they are so by implication, we are not learned enough to hazard an opinion. The measure of discretion vested in the Government by the 5th section of that statute, as to the terms of conveyance, is defined thus : ' Which conveyances or alienations shall be made in such forms and with such solemnities as shall from time to time be prescribed by Her Majesty.' Whether the power to prescribe 'forms and solemnities' can or cannot be legally construed to include the power of making the above men- tioned reservations, is a question which we should like to see discussed by some of our correspondents ' learned in the law.' It would be a fine discovery to find that all such reservations, in deeds executed since the year 1842, are of, non-effect !—Sydney Morning Herald, September 21.

SWAN RIVER. —It must be known to some of our commercial fellow-colonists that the Dutch government employs a national steamer for the conveyance of overland and ordinary mails and passengers from Batavia, in the island of Java, to and from Singapore. This arrangement the government of Western Australia has resolved to attempt the rendering available to the purposes of a speedy transit between the mother-country and that colony. In furtherance of this determination, the Legislative Council has voted the expenses, and the government schooner Champion has been employed to carry a gentleman (Mr. Singleton) to Batavia, where he will endeavour to make suit- able arrangements with the Dutch government, such arrangements being intended to include not only the conveyance of Perth or other Australian mails from Singapore to Batavia, the capital of Java, but to forward them to Angier Point, in that island, where it is intended to land and take on board the mails entrusted to such conveyance to and from Australia. Persons fully competent to give an opinion have pronounced upon the possibility of English overland mails addressed to the capital of Western Australia being received there in fifty days, provided the Champion, or a fast-sailing packet shall be (as intended) at An- gier Point awaiting the arrival of the mails. South Australian Register.

Sir Charles will be a liberal patron of the turf in this colony. He is very anxious to procure good cattle for his own stable, personally inspect- ing those offered for his acceptance. The other day His Excellency inquired of the Colonial Sec- retary if there were many persons here who sported four-in-hand, and whether any of his vice-regal predecessors had indulged in being his own Jehu behind four horses. On being answered in the negative, Sir Charles said, that from a boy, he had always had a taste for the " ribbons," and that he contemplated recreating himself in this innocent way while in New South Wales—good humouredly remarking that, " surely there could be no impropriety in that." At all events, His Excellency has a good precedent-George the IV., when Prince Regent, especially plumed him- self on his qualifications in this respect.—Corres- pondent to the Port Phillip Patriot.

THE MURRAY.—A gentleman lately returned from the Murray has given us the following in- formation, the correctness of which may be relied on, although unaccompanied by names :—A small party, consisting of six men, one of whom had but one arm, conducting about 250 head of cattle, had arrived near the Darling, when two bullocks having strayed, the owner of the stock and one of his men went on horseback to seek them. During their absence some blacks came to the dray and asked for meat, which was given them ; they went away, and soon returned and asked for more, which being refused by the son- in-law of the owner, one of the blacks threw a spear which pierced his heart ; the other instantly fled, and the blacks plundered the dray. The cattle of course escaped. On the return of the old man he found the empty dray and a dog remaining by it, which appearing desirous of drawing him into the scrub, he followed, and the animal began to scratch at a heap of bushes, under which he found the body of his son-in-law. These persons travelled for a long way without provisions, till relieved when almost starving at one of the Murray stations. The party had six guns and seven charges of powder and shot amongst them. — South Australian Register, August 19.

DR. LEICHHARDT.—Mr. Bunce, the botanist, residing at Melbourne, Port Phillip, has received the following interesting letter from this intrepid explorer, which may give the un- initiated in bush travelling some faint ideas of a few of the difficulties attendant upon a tour of discovery into the interior of New South

Wales :—

" Sydney, 17th August.

" Dear Sir,—When I received your first com- munication with Mr. Coleman, in which you expressed your wish to accompany me on my next expedition as botanical collector, I explained to Mr. Coleman how it was impossible for me to take any gentleman for one particular business, and how necessary it was that every one who went with me should share equally in the general work. I told Mr. Coleman how harrassing and fatiguing this work frequently was, the loading and unload- ing of bullocks, which became frequently restive and upset their load during the day's stage, the saddling, hobbling, tethering of horses, the watch- ing at night, collecting firewood, the killing of bullocks, cutting up their meat, drying it by the frequent turning, the mendings of saddles and pack-saddles, and many other little things, every one of which in a tropical climate becomes trouble- some and fatiguing. There is even the chance of increased difficulties, as we take four different kinds of animals, goats, bullocks, horses, and mules, every one of which has its peculiar habits and requires attention. l am, moreover, not in- clined to take a large provision of flour, having found, during my last journey, that an entirely animal food agreed well with our constitutions, though there was of course a constant longing for bread or damper. I shall also take very little sugar, in order to save room for more valuable articles. You have, therefore, to expect nothing but tea and meat for the greatest part of the jour- ney, and you have to examine yourself well, whether you will be able to bear such a privation cheerfully. Our botanical collection will consist principally of seeds, and there is no doubt that the length of time during which we shall be on our journey (probably two years) will enable us to make a large collection. I am most willing to allow you an equal share of the seeds we gather, but as I shall probably be prevented from taking more than about half one ream of paper with me, it will scarcely be possible to collect more than one or two sets of specimens. Of very rare plants I am willing to take more, perhaps five or six, and you are welcome to the triplicates pp. I am not so familiar with the flora of Swan River as with that of the east coast, and that of the tropics I have travelled over during my last expedition, and I fear that we shall consider many plants new which

are common at Swan River.

" I think that three pairs of strong moleskin trousers, three red flannel shirts, three cotton shirts, three pairs of shoes, stockings ad libitum, towels, one strong cabbage-tree hat, some combs, tooth brushes, a housewife, scissors, and a blanket will be sufficient for every man.

" I advise you to consider all these points well, and to remember that the fatigues of our solitary bush life will render us taciturn and morose; every one wants a good stock of good humour and cheerfulness ; but more than this is the interest in the success of our expedition, and the perfect will- ingness to submit to everything which is required for that purpose. Do never think of joining such an expedition if you find it difficult to obey ; you would render yourself as well as the whole party miserable. Believe me ! for I have made a most disgusting experience !

" I shall start at the commencement of October,

if I can finish my preparations to that time. If is very probable that we start from Port Stephens, and travel over New England to Darling Downs, from whence we shall take our final departure

from civilization.

" I beg you once more to reflect on the mode of life which you have to expect, and on the length of time which is required to come to our journey, and then to answer my letter.

" Believe me ever to be, dear Sir,

" Your obedient humble servant,

" LUDWIG LEICHHARDT." —Port Phillip Herald.

articleText:
COLONIAL.

CAPE OF GOOD HOPE.

Via Western Australia we have South African papers to the 24th April.

Letters dated April 11th had just been received from Sir Peregrine Maitland at Graham's Town, stating that the troops had entered Kaffirland in three divisions ; and subsequent advices made known that his Excellency the Governor had reached Port Victoria with the reserve force ; whilst Colonel Somerset with his division had crossed the Keiskamma without encountering any

resistance.

It is impossible to form any opinion here as to the extent, duration, or consequences of the Kaffir war; but the total interruption of peaceful pur- suits and a wide-spread alarm amongst the frontier settlers are manifest enough, and the Missionaries have mostly withdrawn from the remoter scenes

of their labours.

The Rev. G. Green, Wesleyan Missionary at Mount Coke, appears to have made his escape out of Caffirland to Fort Peddie with great difficulty.

He saw several bodies of Caffirs armed and mounted, and who seemed bent on mischief. A span of oxen sent forward to assist him were taken, and the driver wounded. It was only by the assistance of several Kaffirs, who proved un- shakingly faithful, that he succeeded in reaching his destination in safety. All his property had been left at his station, and which was surrounded by armed men, and would have been plundered, but for the interference of the chief Zeta. The Rev. J. Brownlee, missionary to Jan Tzatzoe, had also reached Fort Peddie in safety.

The only quotation of Cape imports likely to be interesting here are the following:—Adelaide wheat put at a price equal to 7s. 6d. per imperial bushel; Countess slates, £9 per 1000; Duchess ditto, £16 per ditto.—South Australian Register.

WESTERN AUSTRALIA.

By the Lightning, which touched at Freemantle, we have Perth papers to July 1st. Their contents are as speculative as usual. But amongst other doings, the local Government had wisely deter- mined to abolish all charges in the shape of har- bour dues or pilotage, and thus to make the ports

of Western Australia as free as our own.

A branch steam line from Ceylon is the favourite project with the Western Australians ; whose schooner Champion has more than once made the voyage in twenty-five days, and back in thirty days.

The returns of land under cultivation exhibit the following meagre results : wheat, 1,265 acres; barley, 305 acres ; miscellaneous crops, 89 acres. The sheep and cattle returns exhibit a remarkable contrast, and are as follows: sheep, 67,749 ; horned cattle, 2,298 ; horses, 744 ; and pigs, 1,116.

On the 21st May, Don Rosendo Salvado, one of the Roman Catholic Missionaries, gave a Soiree Musicale at the Court House, Perth, in aid of the funds for his mission to convert and civilize the aborigines of that territory ; the zealous mis- sionary having devoted himself to this task, and already taken up his abode in the bush, in the neigbourhood of the Moore River. The enter-

tainment was limited to Don Rosendo's own per- formances on the pianoforte, with the addition of one Spanish national song, which he gave with a spirit and finish which were much admired. Don Rosendo proved himself a very fine performer, having a command over his instrument such as is only possessed by first-rate players.—South

Australian Register.

SINGLETON.

(From the Sydney Atlas.)

" Persuade me not, Sir Hugh; he shall not abuse

Robert Shallow, Esq., Justice of the Peace and coram—ay, and ratolorum, too."

Law, said Sir Walter Scott, is like laudanum, much readier to be abused by a quack than by a skilful physician. The sacred duty of adminis- tering impartial justice should be exercised by men only who have enjoyed the advantages of a good education : who possess at least the moderate independence of fortune, as well as of feelings, and who also unite with these qualities a competent knowledge of their country's laws, thus enabling them to fulfil with ability the duties of a magistrate. But this qualification is too often conferred simply as an honorary title, without the least regard to the principles of justice and equity. Those who can ingratiate themselves with a Colonial Secretary, or men high in authority, may obtain this dignity at a cheap rate; indeed, so cheap is the title held by public estimation, that, in some cases, the abbreviation, J.P., conveys an idea of imbecility, and frequently also of servility.

"A tool

That men make use of, called a fool."

Not that it is intended to say thus far in all cases; there are magistrates who confer a dignity on their appointments, and who are a blessing to the district which enjoys their administration. It is the abuse of this important office by men wholly incompetent, which derogates from the character of their high vocation, notwithstanding the rapid advance of intelligence among the people, their evident dislike to monopolies, and partiality for free trade principles—their superiors in authority, like staunch Tories of old, remain unmoved, unconvinced, unconverted. They will not cast off their old slough, and, unwilling to see, pretend near-sightedness—pretend ? no, but see everything through a distorted medium, suiting their own interest or love of power.

These reflections have originated by witnessing proceedings of late occurrence, at a certain bench not many miles from Singleton. The magistracy seem determined to support monopoly in all its crippling tendencies, although the very spirit of commercial industry is freedom from legislative enactments—shackle it, you destroy its powers— permit enterprise to enjoy the wholesome breezes of liberty, it gathers strength—strives for vigor- ous existence, and sends forth roots and branches in every point of the compass. One word solves this riddle, it is competition; fair field and no favour, talent, genius, capital, industry, all spring up, no more fettered by injudicious bondage; they will shine forth, bestowing light, life, and re- generation to the available resources of the colony. Such are the principles which actuate the enlight- ened British statesman. But import them not, we beseech all and sundry, into the Apostolic regions of New South Wales; and tell it not in Sydney, publish it not in Albion, that the magistracy of any bench refuse to a man of reputation a victual- ler's license, without even deigning to offer a shadow of reason why it was refused. Some one observed that reason is the soul of law—ergo, the law should be the quintessence of reason; unfor- tunately there are no general rules without ex- ceptions, and in this instance the exception was particular. The unanswerable arguments why the prayer of the applicant should have been granted are thus briefly stated:

First, a good character and sufficient capital; secondly, suitable premises and advantageous si- tuation; and, thirdly, a right to extensive pad- docks for public accommodation, either of cattle, horses or sheep, teams, &c., &c.,—a convenience which is every day becoming more requisite, none being in the vicinity, nor on all the line of road from Newcastle to Murrurundi, Wright's, near Maitland, only excepted, to which place the one under consideration has a striking analogy.

The origin of all victualling houses may be traced to an imperative call of strangers or tra- vellers to some public houtelrie or place of accom- modation; the law took the licensing department into its own hand, ostensibly for the purpose of regulating the business, so that none but men of good name should hold the responsible situation— a situation where roguery could be practised, and immorality in various hideous forms secretly per- mitted, for the sake of unlawful gain.

With every requisite qualification the petition was rejected, notwithstanding the observation made some time ago, not only in the Legislative Coun- cil, but also by the late Governor, in favour of all such applications. The conduct of the bench re- minds us of another circumstance; viz., that want of courtesy shown to the hon. member for Northumberland, who was present on the occasion. Mr. Dangar is the representative of a large county, and, by virtue of his high office, is entitled to some show of respect, even from the talent, rank,' and ability comprising the bench referred to; but courtesy appears to be beneath the notice of the august body, for while some J.P. chrysalite, or one in infant training adorns the bench, our member is left to hold his station at the Court- house door, amongst constables and cow-boys.

Surely it is time that the Government should give up fixing those talismanic letters, J.P., on parties, as a mark of patronage, rather than in

consideration of the importance of the office to the public; even the letters themselves feel degraded, for they see that by their indiscriminate use, the contempt of their brethren of the alphabet has been brought upon them. It is time that a change took place here from the clerk upwards—the Augean stable must be cleaned.

SIR CHARLES FITZROY.—During an interview

between Sir Charles Fitzroy and a deputation ap- pointed by the public meeting held in Sydney a short time since to facilitate the introduction of railways into this colony, Sir Charles expressed himself friendly to the object, and observed that he had come to the colony unprejudiced and un- biassed on all questions, and that he was deter- mined to judge for himself. He also stated that he did not feel that he was bound to carry out the views of Sir George Gipps, either with respect to the railway, or any other question.

WILSON THE BUSHRANGER.—Amongst the tra- velling equipage of the notorious bushranger Wilson was found a small library; history and romance formed the largest portion of it, and in the latter class was Bulwer's Paul Clifford, which bore the mark of having been twice as often read as any other work in the collection. Wilson, previous to his death, told where he had planted several watches and some plate, which he had taken in the course of his predatory expeditions. —Sydney Morning Herald Correspondent.

ELOPEMENT.—The lovers of scandal have had a first-rate bit of gossip to occupy them during two or three days past in the elopement of the daughter of a wealthy Israelite with the son of a government officer of rank, who has long solicited the hand of the fair Sydney "Jessica." The loving couple, after two days absence, were dis- covered in their retreat, and the lady, who is under age, was torn from the arms of her dis- consolate inamorato. Her father obstinately with- holds his consent to their being legitimately united, and refuses either to see or pardon his daughter. He cannot conceive that her lover was influenced

by any motive than a love for his money bags, although the acquaintance has existed for many months with the knowledge of her family. Ac- cording to report, the father of the gentleman greatly benefitted the state of his funds by an alliance with a Hebrew widow in the West Indies, thereby diverting a considerable property from its legitimate and expected channel of descent to a celebrated musical professor of this metropolis. The eloping pair are the son of Col. Gibbes, aged twenty-five, and the daughter of James Simmons, Esq., of Pitt-street. It is said that they were married by a Scotch Clergyman, on Sunday. Notwithstanding they had passed two nights to- gether. Simmons refuses his consent to their marriage. The affair is no secret.—Port Phillip Herald Correspondent.

MURDER.—A most atrocious murder has been committed by an aborigine at the heifer station of Mr. Ward Stephens, on the Richmond River. The victim was a recently arrived immigrant, from Scotland, named Connel, and who was employed as hutkeeper at the station where the outrage occurred. Connel is represented to have been a man of the mildest disposition, and had always treated with marked kindness his murderer, a black of the name of Jemmy Jemmy, and who had been for some time employed at the station in cutting wood, carrying water, and making him- self generally useful, and for which services he was well fed and clothed. The circumstances attending the murder, as far as can be gleaned, are that Connel was sitting alone in his hut mend- ing a tin pot, and that Jemmy Jemmy must have come behind him and struck him down, and sub- sequently murdered him with a tomahawk. Con- nel's body was frightfully mutilated. The only possible inciting cause that can be surmised is

the possession of a damper and the tomahawk, as these were found to be missing from the hut. When the murder was discovered, which was shortly after its commission, Jemmy Jemmy had fled, and it is to be deeply regretted that up to the time of the steamer's leaving no trace of him could be discovered.—Sydney Morning Herald.

NEW WORK.—A very singular and interesting work has lately issued from the pen of Miss Flinders, (daughter of the celebrated Captain Flinders, who explored the coast of New South Wales and the islands in Bass' Straits), in which all existing forms of religion are most ingeniously traced up to the Mythology of the ancient world. There is a remarkable coincidence in some of the arguments and inferences of this distinguished literary lady, with those advanced by the "Re- marks on the origin and antiquity of the natives of New South Wales," now issuing from our Press, and which, we doubt not, will much interest the reading public in Great Britain, particularly that numerous class of persons who have philanthropic interest in the welfare of the aborigines of Austra-

lia.—Australian.

GOVERNMENT APPOINTMENTS.—His Excellency the Governor has been in this colony sixteen days, and we are informed that he has already a list of upwards of one hundred applicants for situations under Government, most of whom would take any- thing between a Custom-house clerkship and a Commissionership of Crown lands, and few of whom have any other claim for Government sup- port than a want of sufficient energy, self-respect, and ability, to obtain a livelihood in their respect- tive stations of life.—Sydney Morning Herald.

THE MORETON BAY COURIER is published every

and one shilling for every additional inch, each, insertion. The number of insertions must be specified on each advertisement, or they will be continued until countermanded by a written

notice.

articleText:
QUALITY, COMPOSITION, AND PRESER-

VATION OF BUTTER.

( From Johnston's Elements of Agricultural

Chemistry,)

1. The quality of butter varies with numerous circumstances. The kind of natural pasture or of artificial food upon which the cow is fed, the season of the year, the breed and individual con- stitution of the animal, all affect the quality of the

butter.

But from the same cow fed on the same food, a richer butter and a finer and higher flavour will be obtained by churning the last drawn portions of the milk. So the first cream that rises gives the finest flavoured butter,-while any cream or milk will give a butter of better quality if it be properly soured before it is churned, and be then churned slowly and at a low temperature.

2. The Composition of Butter.-Butter, as it usually brought to the market, contains more or less of all the ingredients of milk. It consists, however, essentially of the fat of milk intimately mixed with about one-sixth of its weight of water, and a small quantity of casein, of saline matter, and of the sugar of milk. The quantity of casein, cheesy matter, or curd, seldom amounts to one per cent, of the whole weight of the butter.

If the butter be melted in hot water several times, shaken with renewed portions of water as long as they become milky, and left then to repose, it will collect on the surface in the form of a fluid

yellow oil, which will concrete or harden as it cools. If when cold it be put into a linen bag, and be submitted to strong pressure in a hydraulic or other press, at the temperature of 60* F., a slightly yellow transparent oil will flow out, and a solid white fat will remain behind in the linen

cloth. The solid fat is known by the name of margarine, and is identical with the solid fat of the human body, with that of the goose, and with that which causes the thickness of olive oil when exposed to the cold. It is very similar also to the solid fat of palm oil. The liquid, or butter oil, is a peculiar kind of fat not hitherto discovered in any other substance.

The proportion of these two kinds of fat in butter varies very much, and hence the different degrees of hardness which different samples of butter pre- sent. The solid fat is said to abound more in winter, the liquid fat in summer. A winter and summer butter manufactured in the Vosges, were found to contain per cent, respectively of

Summer. Winter. Solid fat or margarine. 40 65 Liquid fat or butter oil. 60 35

100 100

These proportions, however, will be found to vary more or less in almost every sample of butter

we examine.

3. The Preservation of Butter.-Fresh butter cannot be kept for any length of time without be- coming rancid. The fats themselves undergo a change, and the same is the case with the small quantity of milk sugar which the butter contains. The main cause of this change is the casein or curd which is usually left in the butter. The pro-

portion of this cheesy matter I have found in two samples of fresh butter to vary from one-half to three-fourths of a per cent., or from half a pound to three-quarters of a pound in 100 pounds of butter, and yet this small quantity is sufficient, if the, butter be exposed to the air, to induce these chemi- cal decompositions to which the disagreeable smell

and taste of rancid butter are owing.

I do not enter here into the theory of the action of this casein, nor into any explanation of the nature of the chemical changes themselves. It is sufficient to state, that this evil action of the cheesy matter may be entirely prevented.

a. By salting immediately after the butter is made, and before the cheesy matter has had time to become altered by exposure to the air.

b. By taking care that any water which may remain in or around the butter be always kept per- fectly saturated with salt.

c. By carefully excluding the air from the casks or other vessels in which the butter is packed.

So long as the cheesy matter is kept from the air, and in a saturated solution of salt, it will neither undergo and rapid alteration itself, nor will it soon induce any offensive alteration in the

butter.

About half a pound of salt is used to 12 or 14 lbs. of butter, and though many wash their butter, it is a rule with others never to wash it or dip it into water when intended to be salted, but to work it with cool hands till the milk is thoroughly squeezed out, and then to proceed with the salting. Theoretically, I should consider this latter as the best plan, since it exposes the cheesy matter less to the air, and consequently to less risk of incipient decomposition

Some fancy they cure their butter better by dis- solving the salt in the cream before churning, while many consider its preservation and good quality to depend much upon the quality of the salt that is employed.

NATIVE BREAD.-An interesting paper on this singular esculent, the Gastrodia Sessamoides of Linnaeus has been handed to us. it is the pro- duction of Mr. J. W. Graves, jun., and consists of a series of observations on this portion of our indigenous Flora, the result of long and careful attention to its mode of growth, and of an im- pression that its culture may be turned to profita-

ble account. Mr. Graves states that the native bread, as an esculent, continued to be preferred by the aborigines, to potatoes and other edible roots, and that they possessed some instinctive means of discovering it at will. With respect to its habits, Mr. Graves adds, that it seems to prefer loamy soil on low or sloping ground, and that the first indications of its vegetation are in the spring season, when a whitish bulb will appear on the sward. This bulb is of a hemispherical shape, and about the size of a small egg. The dusky white covering of this will be found to resemble a fine white net, and within it is a pellucid gelatin- ous substance. Again, within this latter, is a firm kernel, about as large as a Spanish nut, and from this a fine fibrous root descends into the soil. The spots where these appearances have been ob- served, Mr. Graves has marked, and on digging a few months afterwards, has invariably found the native bread in perfection. While Mr. Graves deserves ample praise for a series of remarks and a minuteness of attention that would do credit to a scientific botanist, we much fear that his sug- gestions may not prove susceptible of the practica- ble application he would wish. The Gastrodia, or native bread, is, we believe, a parasitic plant, and, in common with its cogenus, would pro- bably be found difficult of systematic cultivation. Whether, in any other way, the abundant self propagation of this peculiar plant might be ren- dered available, we are unable to say. We shall, however, be happy to receive any communication

either from Mr. Graves or others who have de-

voted to it observation or experiment.-Hobart

Town Courier.

TRISTAN DE ACUNHA.-The following interest- ing particulars are extracted from the log of Captain Salmon of the Reward:—" On the 18th September, 1845, we sighted the island of Tristan de Acunha, in the latitude of 37°5' South, long. 12°3' West, at six o'clock in the morning ; its snow-capped top was visible above the clouds, it being 8326 feet above the level of the sea, and throughout the year covered with snow on its summit. The wind being favourable, and the weather fine, and knowing there were inhabitants on it, 1 steered direct for it, passing an island to the southward called Inaccessible, where the ship Blendon Hall, of London, was lost in the year 1821, by running on to it in a thick fog, The inhabitants of Tristan de Acunha were aware that a vessel had been lost near the islands, or on them, for a long while before a boat came from Inaccessible Island, by the drifting of pieces of wreck on the shores and rocks of Tristan de Acunha. The Acunahites never venture over to the other islands, having nothing but whale-boats. The population of this island amounts in all to ninety souls, as stated to me by Mr. Glass—who has fifteen children living, and one of them is married to an American of the name of Dellay. Mr. Glass is now in the seventy-second year of his age, and has been thirty years on the island ; he is one of those who were sent by the British Government at the time of Napoleon's imprison- ment at the Island of St. Helena. The appearance of Tristan de Acunha on the north side, was an isolated piece of land and rock, of about two miles in extent, and about 100 feet above the level of the sea. On our near approach to the island we were surprised, first, to get in view large white build- ings and corn-fields all laid out in neat order and enclosed ; next, to see a large green plain with cattle grazing, and flocks of sheep in different enclosures, and patches of green on the sides of the hill, which we were told were gardens, filled with cabbages, turnips, and all other vege- tables, which grow in abundance. Wheat grows well, and about 60 acres of land are in a good state of cultivation for corn, if they had ships calling off for supplies they would grow more. About five ships, American whalers, call here an- nually to take in supplies, and in return give clothing, coffee, and tea, but two English vessels have called there for the last year. Coarse cotton or sheeting is very much wanted by the Islanders for the females, as they have to make such neces- sary things out of slop cotton shirts, as very few ships have any cotton or sheeting not made up. I could have supplied them with silk or fine goods,

but these articles were useless to them, at all events they had no money to purchase them.

There are on the island, out of the whole popu- lation of 90 souls, 66 females ; 20 are from 12 to

26. years of age, 7 are from 55 to 64 years of age, and the others are of younger years—some only a few months old ; and they have no means of getting suitable clothing for them. The boys are wearing sheep-skins, and the men get coarse canvass from the ships. On getting close in with the Island, with the English ensign at the main royal mast head, we saw the inhabitants moving in all directions towards the shore ; and close in to the great water course from the hills, (which flows down from the rocks, of 100 feet, on the beach,) we saw the whale boat taken and dragged towards the surf ; a person, with a dark dress, was then put in and seated in her stern ; those who were to compose her crew got ready, and with the assistance of those on shore she was pushed in through the surf, of which, in a short time, we saw her clear. We then hove the ship to, and made preparations to receive the Governor on board, by getting the ladder over the side ; the boat was rowed by four men at the oars and one to steer ; in the stern sat a person dressed in a hair cap, with a pilot coat over-all ; when he came on deck I asked him if Governor Glass was living ? he said he was the person ; he then asked the usual questions of where from, and whither bound, and the news ; but he did not ask for his Des- patches from the British Government. He had never received any relief or support since he has been on the Island, although he has several times been promised that his forlorn case should be re- presented to the Secretary for the Colonies. Sir George Gipps landed at the Island on his passage out to New South Wales, about January, 1838, and promised to lay his case before the British Government, but this has met with the proverbial fate of " putting faith in Princes," &c. Similar promises have frequently been made to Governor Glass during the last twenty-five years, and with the same result. Tristan de Acunha being a little out of the usual track of ships to the east, but few British ships have ever called there since the Island was inhabited, though many pass in sight of it ; if the American whale ships were not to visit it occasionally, the inhabitants would be in a very bad state for clothing. For the last two years there has not been so many vessels calling at the Island, as the seal and whale have nearly disappeared from this locality ; only two of H. M. ships have been there for the last twenty years. After Mr. Glass had heard what news I had to report, he wished to know if I wanted any supplies. I said I was in want of potatoes, if they had any on the Island ; he expressed his readiness to supply me with any quantity. It being now four o'clock in the afternoon, he took his departure to the shore, and returned again in about an hour and a half with as many potatoes as I had ordered ; in return for which I gave him coffee, tea, and rice. I presented him with some small children's books ; he was very much in want of some catechisms and question books. He had about 2000 lbs. of wool for disposal, it being the clip for two years of his flock of sheep,.which numbers about 400. He formerly sold his wool to the American whale ships, when they were homeward bound, but none of them have since called when bound home, and consequently it has lain on his hands. I would have purchased it from him, but as night had overtaken us, and not wishing to stop until the next day, we bade fare- well to Governor Glass, made sail on our voyage, and, like many more, promised to call on our next voyage to the Eastern Hemisphere, (should we be spared,) and, if possible, raise a small subscription when in London to the amount of one hundred pounds, so as to purchase such articles as they stated to me they were in great need of ; their agricultural implements are in a bad state, and they are much in need of a mill to grind corn, and other articles, (too numerous to mention). 1 am happy to state that the children are all taught to read and attend religious worship ; Mr. Glass is their instructor, he told me that he had taught them all, and that a blessing was offered at every meal, and prayers at night in every family, and on the Sabbath Day he did the duty of minister for the whole ; he said he was everything to them, but he is quite feeble and not fit for such a task ; could a good person be found, of or about the age of fifty, who would wish to go to such a place, and be their instructor, he would be gladly re- ceived by them, and would find a good home, away from the cares of this busy life. The pre- sent adults are comparatively ignorant, and on the death of Governor Glass there will be some one wanting to instruct and govern them. They have every necessary that is wanting as food for the body, but food for the soul, they have none. If any of the Missionary Societies would send out a minister to them, he would be gladly received. I am at a loss to conjecture for what reason the

John Williams omitted to call at this island on

her passage out last year, to visit the various Islands in the South Sea. I conclude this brief narrative of an Island but little known or heard of in any quarter of the Globe, (but in which, probably, more true happiness, virtue, and con- tent, live, than in any other locality I know of,) in the hope to arouse public attention to the wants of these people, and that those who are " clothed in purple and fine-linen, and fare sumptuously every day," in Great Britain, will come forward to charitably assist the spiritual and bodily ne- cessities of that portion of their fellow creatures who need it so seriously, as the inhabitants of Tristan de Acunha."

THE MORETON BAY COURIER is published every

Saturday morning. The terms of subscription are 10s. per quarter, payable in advance: the quarters ending 30th September, 31st Decem- ber, 31st March, and 30th June, in each year respectively. Each advertisement will be charged at the rate of three shillings an inch. and one shilling for every additional inch, each insertion. The number of insertions must be specified on each advertisement, or they will be continued until countermanded by a written

notice.

Printed and Published by the Proprietor, ARTHUR

SIDNEY LYON, at the General Printing Office, Albert-street, North Brisbane, in the Colony of New South Wales. Orders and communications (in all cases pre-paid) to be addressed to the

Proprietor.

articleText:
LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.

DR. LEICHHARDT.—A correspondent informs us that Dr. Leichhardt and party are encamped about twenty miles north from Mr. Stevens' sta- tion, near the. Condamine River, where they have been detained in consequence of the mules and bullocks having strayed. Mr. Hely is waiting at the Springs for the mail, in order to get intelli- gence respecting Sir Thomas Mitchell's expediton.

THE FERRY TOLLS.—The ferries were put up at auction on Wednesday ; and after spirited com- petition, the North and South Brisbane Ferry was let at the comparatively large sum of £240 That between North Brisbane and Kangaroo Point was

let at £32.

THE " EXPERIMENT."—We regret to learn that this steamer is to be laid up for seven or eight days, in order that the boilers may be repaired.

TICKETS-OF-LEAVE. — The undermentioned

prisoners of the Crown have obtained tickets-of- leave since our last publication :—Josias Clarke, Emma Eugenia ; Patrick Neill, Heier ; William Thompson, Charles Kerr.

PORT CURTIS. — The following remarks are published in an octavo volume, called " The Pic- ture of Australia," published in 1829, page 22 :- "Breaksea-spit is a reef of broken coral and sand, extending about twenty miles north of a long and narrow point-on the east side of which is Indian Head, the easternmost cape of New Holland. Within this point and the Spit there is Hervey's Bay, a considerable opening. This bay affords an anchorage ; but the land at the head of it is low-though hills appear in the distance. The part on the east is barren and there does not appear to be any considerable rivers. The shore con-

tinues of the same character as on the west side

of Hervey's Bay till Port Curtis a little north of lat. 24 be reached. Port Curtis is protected from the sea by Fairy Island, which is of considerable size, but barren, and with little or no fresh water. In general indeed the shores of the bay are not of the most promising nature. The trees are stunted, and the hills stony and barren. There is one mountain stream, the "Boyne," upon the banks of which, a little into the interior, there are a few patches of fertile land, but they are not of any considerable extent. Northward of Port Curtis, and immediately under the tropic of Capricorn, there is another opening, Keppel's Bay, the head of which is connected by a channel with that of Port Curtis, but the channel is so shallow as to be dry at low water. The shores of both these openings are in general so thick with mangroves, that no landing can be effected, and though it produces some trees and grass, is apparently so stony as not to be fit for agricultural purposes. Captain King, who examined this shore with more minuteness than any other navigator, gives it as his opinion that there is little to be sought for south of the 17th degree."

The NEW COLONY.-The following is the sub- stance of the evidence given by Colonel Barney, before the Select Committee of the Legislative Council, on the renewal of transportation, re- specting the new settlement of North Australia : -It is to be composed first of all of persons from the Penitentiary at Pentonville who have gone through their probation. The first party, con- sisting of between 200 and 300 men with their families, is expected to arrive about the middle of January ; they will be the lighter class of of- fenders. A similar class are to be sent from Van Diemen's Land. (It was quite notorious in Eng- land, that people committed petty crimes for the sake of getting into the penitentiaries.) Upon landing they will be put into tents till they can build huts for themselves. They are to be put in possession of an allotment of five acres of land ; or not exceeding ten acres, to those who have large families. This land they are to hold for three years, free of expense ; and at the expiration of that time they are to determine whether they will become permanent possessors of the land or not ; if they become settlers, they are (as we stated in this journal some time ago) to purchase the land at the rate of £1 per acre ; which is to be paid for in half-yearly instalments spread over a period of ten years. The government is to supply them with provisions, clothing, tools, seed, and stock, but not after the first year. There is to be no restriction as to leaving the settlement if they wish to do so, and in fact it may be con- sidered as a labour depot for this colony. There would be no objection to the people of Moreton Bay sending for a supply of these men. He fur- ther states, that he has had many applications from parties in Sydney to be allowed to go down and settle there, with the view of becoming store- keepers, and to engage in various pursuits. There is no positive limitation as to going within the limits of the tropics. He thinks that the men coming from Pentonville will be in a better posi- tion as regards moral character than the great mass of immigrants-they will have had the be- nefits of religious instruction, have acquired habits of industry, and become masters of various trades ; but they will not have learned that which would suit them best for North Australia, the art of tilling the ground. In the event of the loss of the crops, or of inveterate idleness, it may be ne- cessary to furnish some of the people with food for more than a year. In the case of loss of crops the

Government must assist them. It is not con-

templated to have free mechanics to build stores or houses at the new settlement, as the services of the people sent there will be at the disposal of the Government during the year for which they are provisioned. These men will not be paid over

and above their rations in such cases. Colonel Barney confirms a statement we made some time since, that the Guardians of the Poor in England are now making arrangements with Government for sending out the wives and families of the convicts, and the paupers who may be willing to proceed to this colony. Such are the most im- portant facts elicited by his evidence before the Council. He is of opinion that the people with families will be inclined to remain at the settle- ment ; because they will during the first year, when they receive provisions, build their huts, get their gardens in order, and have their pigs and poultry ; and under such circumstances will not, he thinks, be disposed to move. Of course each person will be allowed to purchase more than ten acres, if they choose, provided they have the

means.

PROTECTION OF THE ABORIGINES.-The follow- ing is an extract from a private letter from More- ton Bay :- "Some parties went out last week into the bush, and fired at a crowd of blacks in their camp, hoping to shoot one of those for whom a reward is offered, as the murderer of Mr. Gregor. They brought in one black, Millbong Jemmy, quite dead, having driven three balls through him, and they received the reward. I have heard it

whispered that the blacks have been shot in all directions, and that some persons in authority are conniving at it. The Government ought to give the aborigines some protection, else they will be soon swept away in this district. The Moreton Bay Courier advocates their utter destruction ! !" -Sydney Chronicle.-[Who this veracious cor- respondent ( anguis in herba ) may be, we know not, neither do we care; we are quite certain, however, that " he is a butcher of the truth, and an assassin of facts." When we tell this man that we hate liars, we hope he will believe us.-ED. M. B. C. ]

THE WEATHER AND THE ROADS.-During the past week we have had some splendid weather. The abundant rains of the last few weeks have produced a rapid growth amongst the green crops, which become fresher and greener every day. At the same time the powerful sun and drying winds are bringing the maize crops towards maturity. There is every prospect of a continuance of fine weather. As a drawback, however, to the fore- going, we must state that the roads are still nearly in an impassable state for the wool-teams, many of which have been detained five weeks between

Ipswich and the Main Range. A great deal of the wool is in a very wet state, and will have to be repacked previous to shipment. Those persons who had not foresight enough to provide tarpaw- lings for their drays, will be subjected to serious loss by the depreciation that must necessarily take place in the value of the wool, and the expenses of putting it in a fit state for shipment. Nearly all the bridges over the creeks have been carried away by the floods, and it is absolutely necessary that something should be done by the Government, im- mediately, to repair these disasters. In the mean- time, the squatters rest quietly on their oars, and, we presume, are too much absorbed in shearing to allow of their urging their claims for assistance on the Executive Government. They must, as soon as they can possibly spare the time, meet for this purpose ; if they neglect to take proper steps, we fear that the communication between the in- terior and the port will become more difficult and dangerous every day. None but the strongest and most energetic remonstrances will induce our precious Government to concede to us our un- doubted right to a proportion of the sum voted by the Council for the repairs of the roads through- out the colony. Let the squatters, then, look to it. The Government know our weakness, and un- generously take advantage of it. We shall have a word to say to Mr. McLeay by and bye.

A GENUINE PHILANTHROPIST.-We learn with sincere regret that Mr. Robert Little, of the late firm of Little & Phelan, and one of the oldest commercial settlers in this district, is about to leave this place for Sydney. Mr. Little during his residence in Brisbane has gained the esteem and regard of every one anxious for the moral well-doing of the

rising generation, by his unceasing endeavours to promote education, and to propagate religious principles amongst the youth of both sexes. It was during the second year of his residence in this town, that he determined upon erecting a suitable building, at his own expense, to be devoted to educational and religious purposes. He was urged to do this by observing the utter destitution of the children, who without supervision and con- trol, and placed under no moral restraint, were permitted to rove about the town, and contract habits of the most immoral and irreligious kind, owing to their being no teachers at that time in the township. To the credit of the inhabitants be it recorded, Mr. Little's endeavours were crowned with success, and he has the satisfaction of being the first individual who established a Sunday School in the district. We have the tes- timony of many of the parents of the children frequenting the school, that they have profited greatly by their attendance, and that the scholars

are the best-behaved children in the town. Mr. Little's conduct is the more to be admired, because it is disinterested. Unassuming and retired in his habits, with the one idea always uppermost in his mind-the moral welfare of his youthful pupils -he deserves all the praise that we have it in our power to bestow. The sceptic may perhaps smile, and the libertine laugh at this encomium ; but those who are acquainted with the real worth, and Christian qualities of the man, will appreciate the justness of our remarks, and join with us in wishing him every success in whatever place he may hereafter take up his residence. We are not in the habit of stepping out of our way to notice the acts of private individuals ; but in this instance we have been impelled by a sense of justice to record the meritorious conduct of Mr. Little, in the hope that many others will be induced to walk in his footsteps, and follow his bright example. We understand that on Tuesday evening Mr. Little gave a juvenile tea party to his scholars at the School-house, and that upwards of sixty chil- dren, accompanied by many of their parents, were present on the occasion. After partaking of the hospitality of their entertainer, several valedictory speeches were delivered, to which Mr. Little gave suitable replies. The party then separated, impressed with a grateful sense of Mr. Little's kindness, and unfeigned regret at his projected departure from the district.

RESULT OF SALES.-Mr. T. Dowse effected the following sale of landed property and cattle at Ipswich on the 21st instant .--allotment No. 3 of section No. ;1, 32 perches, having a frontage to East-street, £16 10s. ; ditto No. 7 of section No. 2, 32 perches, frontage to Bell-street, £15 ; ditto No. 9 of section No. 2, 32 perches, frontage to Bell-street, £18 ; ditto No. 3 of section No. 3, 32 perches, frontage to Brisbane-street, £12; ditto No. 4 of section No. 3, 32 perches, frontage to Brisbane and Bell-street, £18 10s. ; ditto No. 16 of section No. 2, 32 perches, frontage to Bremer street, £27 ; one acre garden allotment at Little Ipswich, £8 10s. : a lot of cows with calves ave- raged £3 3s. per head ; and some steers and heifers 32s. per head.

CONDITIONAL PARDONS.-Colonial Secretary's Office, Sydney, 2nd December, 1846.-His Ex- cellency the Governor directs it to be notified, that it has been decided by Her Majesty's Government to qualify, in the pardons granted to convicts in Australia, that condition which confined the effect of the pardon to the Australian colonies, and to give to the convict, either colonial or British, the power of removing to any place which he may desire, provided he should not return to the coun- try or colony from which he had been transported. Conditional pardons granted hereafter will, there- fore, be available every where save in the country or colony from which the parties to whom they may be issued may have been transported. It is further notified, that this arrangement is to have a retrospective effect, and that all persons who now hold exceptive absolute pardons, available

every where except in Europe, or conditional par- dons, available either in the Australian colonies, or in New South Wales only, will have extended to them the benefit of this regulation, provided they have not disqualified themselves for receiving this indulgence by any colonial offence subsequent to the issue of their former pardons. Those per- sons who are desirous of obtaining new pardons will apply, in writing, to the Principal Superin- tendent of Convicts, enclosing, at the same time, the pardons they now hold.-Government Gazette.

CAUTION.-At the Police Office, on Tuesday, William Clarke, bootmaker, of North Brisbane, was summoned before the Magistrates, to answer the complaint of the Chief Constable for employ- ing a prisoner of the Crown in plastering and building certain premises belonging to him. The case was fully made out, and the Bench fined him

£l and costs.

ABUSIVE LANGUAGE.- On Tuesday, at the Police Office, a man named Donald D'Donald, a ticket-of-leave holder, appeared before the Bench to answer a charge preferred against him by Mr. North for making use of abusive language, and improper conduct, on his station. The Magistrates sentenced him to be confined in the solitary cells for fourteen days, and then to be returned to Syd- ney, with the view of having his ticket cancelled.

ABSENT WITHOUT LEAVE -On Tuesday a prisoner of the Crown, named James McKillegate, was ordered by the Magistrates to be confined forty-eight hours in the cells for being absent from his quarters without leave.

LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL. - By a proclamation which appears in the Government Gazette, his Excellency the Governor has further prorogued the Legislative Council until Tuesday, the 26th of January next.

THE GOVENOR.-His Excellency the Governor arrived in Sydney on Friday the 11th instant, from his trip to the westward. Both he and Lady Fitz Roy are in good health and spirits. We be- lieve his Excellency was much gratified with the appearance of the country, and the hospitable re- ception he met with everywhere on his tour.
heading: LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.
