articleText:
NORFOLK ISLAND.

We have been recently favoured with important intelligence from this island, and as it is but rarely any of the doings of that unhappy spot reach the public ear or eye, we are glad to have it in our power to communicate an account of the late pro- ceedings, upon which our readers may full rely. A more melancholy one can scarcely be imagined, and if to what we now publish we were to add other enormities with which we have heen made ac- quainted, we can scarcely doubt but that the whole community would indignantly protest against the continuance of a system which, it may be feared, will sooner or later call down the vengeance of God, as of old, upon the nation which can tolerate such a festering mass of wickedness. The late Commandant, it was universally confessed, was unfitted in every possible way for the duties most unaccountably entrusted to him.

The following may be relied upon as a correct outline of the late transactions, and of the incen- tives which terminated in so frightful and fatal a tragedy.

From a state of really quiet obedience, the island, from the time the prisoners (who are not slow to appreciate character) began to perceive the weakness of the Superintendent, fell into. a gradu- ally increasing state of insubordination. Some of the prisoners cringed, others plotted, ;and more bullied him. Temporary expedients were resorted to, in order to keep them quiet, but all discipline was relaxed, and when the difficulty of managing them became daily greater, and the various officers remonstrated, their conplaints were either treated with rudeness, or altogether evaded. To make matters worse, an increasing number of desperate ruffians began to be landed from Van Diemen's Land, who soon rendered the English prisoners as mischievous as themselves. What a state of things ! An absolute ruler ! yet thoroughly in- capable ; at 'war with almost every officer in the island, bearded by the convicts, and at length in open day knocked down by one of them It would occupy too much time to tell of the progressive steps by which the total insubordination of the convicts, and the disorganization of all system were brought about.

Mutinous disturbances began towards the close of last year. The ration of the prisoners has al- ways been notoriously bad at Norfolk Island throughout the year they have salt beef and maize meal only, so that but for the indulgence (always allowed them) of growing a few sweet potatoes in plots of ground marked out for their use and cul- tivated by them on Saturday afternoons, their fare would have been positively destructive of life, as indeed it frequently proved to the freshly arrived prisoners, before they could grow potatoes for themselves. On the 1st of January, a public order was posted to the effect, that all their garden plots was henceforth to be taken away from them. It is difficult for a person unacquainted with the island

to conceive the commotion this occasioned. The prisoners refused to work unless some equivalent were given for the potatoes, and after some hesi- tation, which only rendered matters worse, a half pint of peas was promised to each man daily. At the end of three or four days the peas were said to be all issued, and there was another row. The Superintendent then promised to have 8 oz. of 12 per cent. flour served out in lieu of the peas. To add to this unhappy state of affairs, a resident Police Magistrate had been appointed from Van Diemen's Land, who very soon rendered himself an object of vengeance. The flogging became perfectly furious, from 500 to nearly 2000 lashes were inflicted of a morning, until the ground about the triangles was literally soaked with human blood.

Matters daily grew worse, the wretched men by this sort of alternate rage and peevish vacillation gradually grew more and more exasperated and insubordinate. About the commencement of June

the store of flour was reported by the Commis- sariat officer to be nearly exhausted, and as a

matter of course the 8 oz. of flour were discon- tinued. The men became more clamorous than

ever. By an order published in May, 1845, and forming part of the Van Diemen's Land Regula- tions for Norfolk Island, it had been announced that the gardens being no longer allowed, 2 lbs. of sweet potatoes should form a part of the daily ration to each prisoner. It will scarcely be credited that Major Childs caused this order to be posted up at every station on the island ; yet knowing at the time he did so, that it was impossible to furnish the men with a single oz. daily of sweet potatoe ! During fourteen months this order had been hang- ing up before the men's eyes ; they read it, and again and again demanded their allowance of vegetables, they promised, but withheld from them ; but when at length they became furious and riot- ously clamorous, they were told that it had been determined by a board that 2 oz. of salt pork was equivalent to 8 oz. of flour ! (the ration issued instead of peas) ; and that this would accordingly be issued to them instead of the 2 lbs. of sweet potatoes, to which, under the regulations, they

were entitled.

It is utterly impossible to conceive the state of mind in which the men are described to have been at this time ; such trifling had really goaded them to the point of madness ; they were ready for any desperate deed, and deed alas ! was too soon effected. Ever since the time of Major Anderson the prisoners had been allowed for each mess a tin pot to cook their potatoes, &c, in. It was sug- gested by the stipendiary magistrate that it would form a powerful effect on the morals of the men- . a new stage in our penal science-in short, power- fully reformatory in every way, if these abomina- ble kettles, (in which more mischief was supposed to be brewed than even Macbeth's Witches ever dreamt of) were taken away, and therefore simul-

taneously with an order, announcing that at length the long expected 2 lbs. of potatoes would be issued ; if was added that on the evening previous to the 1st July, all their kettles would be

seized.

This order was acted upon in a manner which showed the men that the hand of authority trem- bled in the execution of its duty. When all the prisoners were shut up in their wards, except the few who attended school, the police went into the lumber yard and took away the obnoxious kettles, and every thing belonging to the prisoners they could find. At this time "Jackey Jackey" (William Westwood, of some notoriety in this colony) was sitting in school, about seven o'clock, when a hand-cart came rattling into the barrack yard, and a crash of tin vessels was heard. Jackey Jackey was busy in the intricacies of a sum at this moment, he suddenly paused-lifted up his hand with the pencil in it, held it elevated for a few seconds, as it listening and hesitating then dashed down the pencil-pushed the slate off the table with a violent movement-and deliber- ately folding his arms, as if he had finally made up his mind, remained buried in thought the rest of the evening. Every man followed his example, and sat whispering until the school broke up.

The following morning the men were all mus- tered for prayers-a practice but recently intro- duced-(nothing can be more disgraceful than the former neligence in this respect)-, and during the service a murmuring sort of sound was heard passing from bench to bench. It has since been surmised that this was a signal for the indiscri- minate slaughter of the officers present ; but no- thing was at that time attempted. After prayers they all went into the lumber-yard and found the tins gone. A short pause ensued, and then they all marched back again, five or six deep, to the Barrack-yard, in perfect silence-broke into the store, took out every vessel in it, and returned in the same manner to the lumber-yard. As they approached, Jackey Jackey addressed his followers in a speech. " Now, my men," said he, " I've made up my mind to bear this oppression no longer ; but remember, I'm going to the gallows, if any man therefore funks, let him stand but of the way ! Come on." A loud cheer followed from his desperate followers. A policeman, named Morris was in the archway, Jackey Jackey with an immense bludgeon, others with sticks, one man with a reaping-hook, and another with a pitch- fork, rushed -upon the unfortunate man, and knocked him down-he struggled, and got into the room behind him ; Jackey Jackey followed him, and beat his head to pieces. The men, furious by the taste of blood, then proceeded to the cook- house, where Stephen Smith, the police runner, was. The same murderous villain rushed on him also, when poor Smith, who was formerly much liked by the prisoners, cried out most piteously, " for God's sake don't hurt me Jackey ! remember my poor wife and children !" " D-n your wife and children," was the horrible reply, accom- panied by a blow which beat in poor Smith's eye, and the side of his face. His shrieks for help were terrific ; but in a second or two his cries were over for ever. From the cook-house they proceeded towards the Police-house at the Barrack gate. At the corner of the road, Price, overseer of work, and a man named Ingram, were standing -Jackey Jackey mate a furious rush at Price, and aimed a deadly blow at him, but Price stooped, and the blow fell upon Ingram, nearly killing him. The mob came rushing on with such violence that Westwood was pushed forward, and Price escaped he knows not how, and ran for the soldiers.

The great object of the mob at this time seems to have been to seize the stipendiary magistrate, Mr. Barrow, who usually sat at six o'clock every morning to try cases.

Most providentially he was this morning on a board of survey, and so escaped. The beach guard seeing the mob approaching, advanced, and form- ing near the gaol, drove the rioters back. They then ran towards Government House, and on their way Westwood stopped at the lime-kiln, and enter- ed the hut there with an axe, which he had by this time obtained. Two policemen, Dinon and Saxton, were in bed. The former was actually asleep when the cowardly villain drove in his skull by a blow of the axe, and Saxton only opened his eyes to see his death-blow fall from the hand of the same monster ; the wounds were most appalling ones-the walls of the room were scattered with brains and blood.

Westwood, after this atrocity, coolly lighted his pipe, and after a few puffs, shouted out, " Now for the Christ killer," and a cry was immediately raised, " To Barrow's, to Barrow's" Happily the alarm given by Price had roused the military, who were now under arms, and at this critical juncture, the soldiers were seen running down the Water-road ; the rioters instantly retreated to the Lumber-yard-Westwood loudly denouncing their cowardice. The place was surrounded, and after much difficulty and delay, the ringleaders were seized, and about sixty left to be tried by a special Court of Criminal Sessions.

So rests for the present this fearful tragedy, unparalleled in heartless atrocity. How much of its guilt may be justly traced to the hands and heads to which the supreme authority was en- trusted, it is hard to say ; but never was a greater blunder committed, or one which has been followed by more disastrous consequences, than the ap- pointment of the late Superintendent to a post requiring so much intelligence and firmness, tempered indeed by an enlightened humanity. We ardently hope that discipline may be restored, and sounder principles be acted upon. Without ex- tenuating in the most remote degree the enormities of which the diabolical perpetrators of these atro- cities have been guilty, we must still commiserate the fate of better men whose feelings have been insulted, who have been bullied and trifled with, harassed and cheated by men who may boast of their savings, but who will not soon shake off the odium of their doings. We trust again, we say, that order may be established in this after all most horrible plague spot ; but it is to be feared, that like the tiger which has once drunk blood, it will be long before these wretched men, cooped up so unnaturally, and lacerated in mind and body, will forget the power for mischief they have discerned by these acts they really possess.-S. M. Herald.

INSOLVENT.- From in, not ; and solvere, to dissolve, which form together the word " insol- vent"-namely, a debtor who cannot or will not liquidate. The worst insolvent is he of whom the most has been recorded to his credit;--Punch Po litical Dictionary.

INNS OF COURT.-Places where students for the bar are compelled to eat a certain number Of din- ners-a custom which renders the term " inns"

perfectly appropriate. A traveller in pursuit of the legal profession has only to put up at one of these inns, and pay the somewhat heavy bill he must incur, and will be forwarded to the end of his journey.-Punch's Political Dictionary.

INTESTACY. - Dying without a will; Some people never have a will of their own until after

their death, and have therefore been intestate all their lives ; though upon their demise it is other- wise. The song-writer who said, " My heart's my own, my will is free," evidently knew nothing of law ; for though his heart might be his own, his will could not be free, as wills are always subject to the probate duty.-Punch's Political Dictionary.

JURY.-An assembly of twelve honest men, appointed to decide on disputes among their fellow subjects. As the honest men are liable to be locked up without food or candle, when they can- not agree, it is customary to toss up, or play at odd man, in order to arrive at a verdict. When the jury quarrel among themselves, it is usual to deprive them of coals, which, if given, would only be adding fuel to fire. Juries are of very ancient origin ; but, in the present day, they are divided into two kinds-Grand and Petty. In order to prevent the latter from being actuated by petty feelings, they are liable to be challenged by either party. This challenging consists of calling them out of the box, when there is no chance of their giving satisfaction. Juries are empannelled, and challenging them is called going through the panel ; but, as going through the panel might open the door to injustice, no one but the Sove- reign is allowed to object to more than thirty-five', without assigning a good reason. - Punch's Political Dictionary.

COMETS AND WOMEN. - Comets, doubtless, answer some wise and good purpose in the crea- tion ; so do women. Comets are incomprehensi- ble, beautiful, and eccentric ; so are women. Comets shine with peculiar splendour, but at night appear most brilliant ; so do women. Comets confound the most learned when they at- tempt to ascertain their nature; so do Women. Comets equally excite the admiration of the phi- losopher and the clod of the valley ; so do women. Comets and women, therefore, are closely analo- gous ; but the nature of each being inscrutable, all that remains for us to do, is to view with ad- miration the one, and admire and love the other. -American paper.

Over the garden fence of a ladies' seminary, in the neighbourhood of the metropolis, there is painted in large characters, " Man traps set on these premises." A wag who was passing chalked beneath the notice, " Vir Gins," whereupon he was taken before a magistrate by a police officer. Being put upon his defence for thus defacing the wall of a respectable establishment, he argued

" that vir was the Latin for man, and gin the English for trap ; ergo, virgin was only another word for man trap." He was discharged with a

caution.

EDITORIAL LIFE.-We know of no class of the community from whom so much disinterested be- nevolence and thankless labour is expected as from editors of newspapers. They are expected to feel for every one but themselves-to correct public abuses and private ones also, without giving any offence ; to sustain the difficulties of others, with- out regard to their own ; to condemn improper measures, of every one and no one at the same time. They are expected to note everything that is important or extraordinary ; notwithstanding the diversity of men's opinions, their notice must be calculated to please every one, and at the same time no one. They are expected to regard and promote the interests of every one but themselves ; and to live themselves on air. They are expected to labour day and night for the promotion of the public interest, and while they accord with others in opinion, a naked expression of opinion may be bestowed upon them, and even that poor conso- lation is very frequently withheld from them. They are also expected to be independent, and at the same time servile tools of every man they meet. They are expected to be honest and open in the expression of their opinions of public measures, and to approve every thing. If they are industrious in their professions, they are dan- gerous firebrands ; if they write nothing they are stupid drones, unworthy of support, and should betake themselves to the shovel or hoe for a living. But should they be active and industrious, should their labours be approved of, and should they succeed in the promotion of a particular object, those who have been interested in that object may rejoice in their success, but they must not reap any advantage from it. The benefits are reserved for other hands, and other, too, who, if they had not at one time or other been engaged in doing everything in their power to retard that object, have at least done nothing to promote it, And after many years of unabated toil and unceasing difficulty, if an editor should chance to err in judgment, he meets no indulgence. His innocent expressions are carefully collected, and trans- formed into a thousand shapes and figures he never dreamed of ; they are thrown into mountain clouds to threaten him with a tempest ; and that by men who wear faces towards him beaming with kindness ; with honey and oil upon their tongues, and lips apparently too good for butter to rest upon them. Like Joab, they inquire, " Art thou in health, my brother ?" while a deadly dagger is concealed under cloak.-Noah (U.S.).

The Moreton Bay Courier is published every

Saturday morning. The terms of subscription are 10s. per quarter, payable in advance ; the quarters ending 30th September, 31st Decem- ber, 31st March, and 30th June, in each year respectively. Each advertisement will be charged at the rate of three shillings an inch, and one shilling for every additional inch, each insertion. The number of insertions must be specified on each advertisement, or they will be continued until countermanded by a written

notice.

Printed and Published by the Proprietor, ARTHUR

SIDNEY LYON, at the General Printing Office, Albert-street, North Brisbane, in the Colony of New South Wales. Orders and communications (in all cases pre-paid) to be addressed to the Proprietor.
heading: NORFOLK ISLAND.
snippet: We have been recently favoured with important intelligence from this island, and as it is but rarely any of the doings of that unhappy spot reach the public ear or eye, we are glad to have it in our

TO BE SOLD,

A PARCEL of Land in the parish of South

Brisbane, adapted for building purposes— being Allotment No. 20 in Section 1. For fur- ther particulars apply at the office of this paper.

TO BE SOLD,

AN Agricultural Farm of 47 acres, situated

within five miles of North Brisbane, and containing some of the best land for garden and small farm produce in the district. Further par- ticulars can be obtained at the office of this paper, where the plan can be seen.

WANTED—£70, on security of several valu-

able Buildings, situate in the Town of Brisbane, erected upon freehold ground, under

Grant from the Crown.

Application to be made to the Office of the Moreton Bay Courier. Letter X.

NEW STORE,

OPPOSITE ROWLAND'S HOTEL,

SOUTH BRISBANE

THE Undersigned has for Sale, ex late arrivals,

an extensive and useful assortment of goods,

articleText:
REDUCTION OF FARES TO SYDNEY, by the Hunter River Company's Packet

T A M A R :

Saloon . . . . . . . . . . . £4 0 0

Steerage . . . . . . . . . .2 0 0 H. R. S. N. Co.'s Wharf,

South Brisbane.

STEAM TO SYDNEY,

BY the Hunter River

Steam Navigation Co.'s Packet T A M A R :

On THURSDAY, 10th SEPTEMBER,

And on every alternate Thursday during the

Season.

H. R. S. N. Co.'s Wharf,

South Brisbane.

" EXPERIMENT."

THE STEAMER EXPERIMENT,

A. Campbell, master, will in future leave Ipswich every

Monday and Thursday morn- ing, at 9 o'clock precisely ; and Brisbane, every Tuesday and Saturday, at the same hour, ex- cepting in cases where the arrival of the Sydney Steamer may prevent it.

Refreshments provided on board at moderate

charges.

The following is the corrected List of Fares, Freight, and Storage, viz. :—

CABIN PASSAGE, 6s. ; STEERAGE, 4s.

s. d.

Dray ................................... 20 0

Dead weight, per ton.......... 10 0 Pipe, butt, or puncheon ....... 6 0

Pair wheels ......................... 5 0

Hogshead ............................4 0

Barrel ..................................2 3 Three dozen cask or case.. 2 0

Wool, per bale ....................2 0 Quarter-cask ..................... 2 0

Ten-gallon keg .................. 1 6

Five-gallon keg ................. 1 3

Chest tea .......................... 1 0 Sheep-skins, per bundle of 25 ..... 0 9 Half and quarter chests tea ......... 0 9

For every dozen extra ..................0 3

STORAGE PER WEEK,

Fourteen days being allowed free,

Measurement goods .................... 2 0 Cartage, per ton ........................... 2 0

Dead weight, per ton .................... 1 6 Pipes, butt, or puncheon ............... 1 0 Hogshead and quarter-cask ...........0 6 Teas and small packages .............. 0 3

TO BE SOLD BY PUBLIC AUCTION AT BRISBANE.

MR. T. DOWSE

WILL SELL by PUBLIC AUCTION, on

THURSDAY, the 15th OCTOBER,

A Herd of CATTLE, late the property of Ernest E. Dalrymple, Esq., deceased—consisting of

163 Cows

64 Heifers 4 Bulls

42 Bullocks

83 Steers

356 Head, more or less.

Calves under six months' old given in.

The above-mentioned Cattle are running at Killarney and Glen- Logan, on the Station of Messrs. Walter & George Leslie, Canning Downs,

Terms—Ten per cent. cash deposit, and the remainder by an approved endorsed Bill at three months from day of sale.

The Cattle must be removed by the purchaser

on or before the 15th November next.

For further particulars, apply to George F. Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

WHEREAS PATRICK GANGHAN, under agreement for twelve months, has absconded from his hired service at Tooloom, Clarence River, after having lost 23 sheep, and received goods to more than the amount of wages due to him,—all persons are hereby cautioned against harbouring

him, or giving him employment ; and a reward of Five Pounds will be paid to any person who will give such information as will lead to his being apprehended and lodged in gaol.

He is an Irishman, about 5 feet 10 inches in height, pale complexion, and speaks with a strong accent. He holds a discharge from his former

employer, H. Bean, Esq., which was omitted to be taken from him on his re-engaging as a shepherd at Tooloom.

TO BE SOLD BY PRIVATE BARGAIN.

THE following HORSE STOCK, late the pro- perty of Ernest E. Dalrymple, Esq., de- ceased— 9 Mares

1 Gelding

1 Colt, rising 3 years old

3 Colts, ,, 2 ,, ,, 2 Fillies, ,, 2 ,, ,, 2 Colts, ,, 1 ,, ,,

1 Filly, ,, 1 ,, ,, 19 Head.

The above-mentioned Horses are mostly the produce of first-rate mares, by thorough-bred

horses, and are now running on the Station of Messrs. Walter and George Leslie, Canning Downs.

The mares are in foal to thorough-bred horses.

For further particulars apply to George F. Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

STORE AND DWELLING-HOUSE TO LET. THOSE commodious PREMISES, situated in Queen-street, North Brisbane, lately occupied by Mr. Wm. Pickering.

ALSO,

The adjoining DWELLING-HOUSE, contain- ing Six Rooms, with good Kitchen and Yard.

Any person desirous of purchasing the above premises, will be treated with by the undersigned. For further particulars, apply to

WM. CONNOLLY,

14th August, 1846. South Brisbane.

IN consequence of the splendid discovery of a

new line of road from the Upper Brisbane, a large portion of the Wool and supplies for that district and the Boyne will have to be shipped at North Brisbane, the Undersigned begs to inform his friends that he has provided a large Store, capable of holding 500 bales of Wool, and is prepared to receive and ship all Goods that may be consigned to his care at the following rates :—

Wool, including cartage and shipping, 1s. per

bale.

Supplies from Sydney, including cartage, 1s. 6d.

per ton per week.

G. S. LE BRETON.

PETERSON'S

BRISBANE STORE.

DANIEL PETERSON will store WOOL for

any period during the Wool Season, and will Cart the same to the Wharf and ship and consign it for one shilling per Bale. He will also Store goods brought by sailing vessels (in- cluding cartage from Wharf) for one shilling and sixpence per ton per week ; A.1. vessels provided for the transit of the same to Sydney on moderate terms.

N.B.—A General. Assortment of Goods always on hand, and for sale, on very reasonable terms.

TOBACCO.

THE Undersigned has always on hand every

description of AMERICAN MANUFAC- TURED TOBACCO—the best selected stock in Sydney.

The only house in town for a good old Manilla cigar. W. H. ALDIS,

Tobacco Merchant.

JACOB CHARLES COHEN,

GEORGE-STREET, SYDNEY,

Opposite the Old Treasury,

BEGS respectfully to inform the inhabitants of Moreton Bay that he has always on hand an extensive and excellent assortment of Watches and Jewellery, which he can offer at reasonable prices.

Country orders punctually attended to. All kinds of watch work and jewellery repaired at strictly moderate charges.

SPECTACLES TO SUIT ALL SIGHTS.

ADELPHI HOTEL,

YORK-STREET, SYDNEY.

THOMAS MURPHY begs most respectfully to acquaint, the inhabitants of the Moreton Bay District that when visiting the Metropolis they may at all times rely upon meeting with

FIRST-RATE ENTERTAINMENT,

together with civil and well-qualified attendants,

AT MODERATE CHARGES.

Dinners andSuppers for private parties pro- vided on the shortest notice, for which well-fur- nished and suitable apartments will be found in

the establishment.

T. M. takes this opportunity to acknowledge the liberal support he has received from the gen- tlemen residing in the district, and begs to assure them that he will spare neither cost nor labour to ensure the approval of those who may honour the Hotel with their company.

The wines and spirits are of first-class quality,

and the stables equal to any in Sydney.

HENRY RALPH ELKINS, I HEREBY give you notice, that if you do not immediately deliver up to me all my property, and all books, invoices, bills, receipts, letters, papers, and documents of every sort, relating to my Store, I will take legal means to compel you.

R. HAMPDEN. South Brisbane, 5th September, 1846.

CAUTION.

MY late Servant, HENRY RALPH ELKINS,

having refused to pay me over my money re- ceived by him for the sale of my goods in my Store, and having been in consequence dismissed by me, I hereby particularly request and caution the Public not to deal with the said Henry Ralph Elkins on my account, the said Henry Ralph Elkins being no longer authorised, to transact my business.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 5th September, 1846.

WITH reference to R. HAMPDEN'S advertise-

ment, inserted in the Moreton Bay Courier, and dated 23rd August, 1846, threatening to com- mence legal proceedings against Henry Ralph Elkins, for not delivering up all books, invoices, and other property belonging to him, we, the undersigned, do hereby state, that the books, in- voices, &c., &c., are detained by our desire, and with the knowledge of Mr. Hampden, till such time as he, the said R. Hampden, shall complete the award given by us in the said H. R. Elkin's

favour.

G. S. LE BRETON,

P. W. WELSH, } Arbitrators.

I certify that the above is correct.

THOS. ADAMS,

Attorney for R. Hampden, in the

above-mentioned arbitration. Brisbane, 28th August, 1846.

ÏN answer to the advertisement, signed G. S. Le Breton, P. W. Welsh, Arbitrators, certified by Thos. Adams, Brisbane, 28th August, 1846, in the last Moreton Bay Courier, I hereby state that all books, invoices, and other property," do not belong to Henry Ralph Elkins, as stated by the said G. S. Le Breton, P. W. Welsh, and Thos. Adams, but to me,—that the said Henry Ralph Elkins sent the sum of £85 2s. 8d., (eighty-five pounds, two shillings, and eightpence, sterling,) my money, to his friend, William Joyner, the Clerk in the Australian General Assurance Com- pany's Office, George-street, Sydney, the 15th and 30th June last, per steamer Tamar, for which I have never received value, and which has never been accounted for to me by the said Henry Ralph Elkins, or the said William Joyner ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins has other property of mine now in his possession ; that I now hold a pro- missory note, dated Sydney, 22nd May, 1846, payable on demand, made by the said Henry Ralph Elkins in my favour, for the sum of £17, (seventeen pounds sterling), with ten-per cent, interest ; that several other debts are now due to me by the said Henry Ralph Elkins since the 8th April last ; that the award of the said Arbitrators, G. S. Le Breton and P. W. Welsh, is illegal, unfair, and unjust towards me in every respect, and that I will commence legal proceedings to set it aside.

R. HAMPDEN. South Brisbane, 5th Sept., 1846.

NOTICE.

MESSRS. G. S. LE BRETON AND P. W. WELSH,

ARBITRATORS.

I HEREBY give you notice, that if you do not immediately deliver up to me all " the books, invoices, &c., &c.," belonging to me, and relating to my Store, now in your custody, possession, or power, I will institute proceedings to compel you, and to recover damages for the injury I have sustained by your illegal detention of my property for so long a period.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 5th Sept., 1846.

STOCKHOLDERS in the Northern Districts are respectfully informed that the Steaming and Salting Establishment at Kangaroo Point, Brisbane, Moreton Bay, is now in full operation, where gentlemen can have their stock converted into tallow or beef, as may best suit their purposes, upon reasonable terms.

Stockholders on the Severn, McIntire, and Barwin Rivers, will find it greatly to their ad- vantage to boil down their cattle at Moreton Bay, as the distance from Messrs. Dights' station, on the lower McIntire River, does not exceed one

hundred and eighty miles, along a road abounding in grass and water ; while the distance from the same station to Maitland is four hundred miles,

and often deficient in both.

JOHN CAMPBELL.

Cattle or sheep, in any quantity, purchased, if good, at fair prices.

Sheep boiled down at 6d. per head. Kangaroo Point, May 25th, 1846.

J. RICHARDSON begs to inform the Settlers

in the District of Moreton Bay, that he has just received from Scotland, a large stock of Wool Packs, which he is selling at such prices as will prevent their purchasing in Sydney. He has also on hand, a large Stock of almost all other kinds of

Goods.

J. R. is also making advances on Wool, Tallow, and Hides.

TENDERS FOR A BRICK COTTAGE.

PERSONS desirous of Contracting for the

building of a Brick Cottage on the Hunter River Steam Navigation Company's ground, in South Brisbane, will be pleased to send in Tenders for the same on or before the 8th September next.

Plan and specifications may be seen at the resi- dence of the undersigned.

W. CONNOLLY. South Brisbane, Aug., 29, 1846.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

AT CANNING DOWNS,

THE following STALLIONS, the property of

Messrs. W. and G. Leslie.—

RNAVE OF CLUBS—a brown-black Horse,

standing 16½ hands high, got by the thorough- bred horse Tros, (imported by H. H. Kater, Esq., in 1839) ; dam, Lady Mary (imported in 1839) by Bedlamite—her dam by Woful, grand dam by Orville, out of Trumpetta by Trumpator.

Terms—Five Guineas a Mare.

EAGLE—a bay Horse, standing 16 hands 1 inch

high ; foaled in 1843 ; got by the thorough- bred imported horse St. George—dam by Old Whicker, her dam by Steeltrap, out of a mare by Hector.

ST. ANDREW—a roan Horse, foaled in 1841 ;

stands 15 hands 3 inches high ; got by St.

George—dam by Stride, her dam by Champion —g. dam by Sheik, out of an imported mare.

Terms—£2 12s. 6d. a Mare.

CONSERVATIVE — a dark-brown Horse ;

foaled in 1839 ; got by Gratis—dam by Theo- rem, her dam by Cammerton—g. dam by Champion, gt. g. dam by Sheik, out of an im- ported mare.

Terms—£1 2s. 6d. a Mare.

Every attention will be paid to Mares sent, but the proprietors will not hold themselves responsi-

ble for accidents or losses.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

1846,

AT GLENGALLAN, DARLING DOWNS,

THE pure-bred imported ARAB HORSE,

BEEZA.

Beeza was imported in the British Sovereign, in November, 1841, is one of the highest caste Arabs ever imported to the colony, and the winner of several races in India. His stock is much ad- mired, and allowed by competent judges to be just the style of animal for the Indian market.

Terms—£3 each Mare, and 3s. Groomage.

SAINT PATRICK,

A rich Bay, with black points, rising four years old, 16 hands high, and shows good racing points. Saint Patrick was got by the thorough-bred imported horse Saint George out of Papsteel.

Terms—£2 10s. each Mare.

GLANCER,

A powerful dark-grey Draught Horse, got by the celebrated imported Clydesdale horse, Briton out of a favourite Hector mare. Glancer stands 16 hands high,and inherits the sound constitution and good temper of his sires ; he is well worthy the attention of breeders for draught.

Terms—£2 each Mare.

Every attention will be paid to the Mares, and large and well watered Paddocks provided, but the Proprietor will not be be responsible for any loss

or accident.

All payments to be made before the removal of

the Mares.

COLIN CAMPBELL. Glengallan, 10th July, 1846.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

THE CELEBRATED HORSE

" T O S S."

Got by the imported Horse Toss, out of a

Hector Mare.

THIS HORSE is a bright bay, with black points, rising seven years old, ascertained to be a sure foal-getter, and his stock is well known to be fit for the Indian market.

He will stand at the premises of the proprietor, C. Peacock, at Ipswich, until the 10th October.

Terms—One Mare, £2 2s.; two, or more, £1 10s. each. Payment to be made, on delivery each mare, on or before the 1st January, 1847.

A good Paddock provided, but no responsibility

incurred.

ALTERATION IN THE DAYS OF SAILING

OF THE

TAMAR.

R. GRAHAM, Agent. H. R.S.N. Co.'s Wharf,

And sundry other Articles.

MR. T. DOWSE

At 12 o'clock, on the Wharf,

residue.

And a variety of Goods, too numerous to mention in an advertisement, to be had at the Stores of the undersigned, at the lowest Prices, for Cash.

R. DAVIDSON,

Kangaroo Point.

FOR SALE,

200 RAMS. Parties wishing to purchase choice TUPS for the ensuing season, can inspect the above-with their fleeces on-by applying to the undersigned, any time before the

end of December next.

ALSO,

Cressbrook, October 17, 1846.

GEORGE THORNE, of the QUEEN'S ARMS, begs to acquaint his many friends, that he intends to keep the same description of Establish- ment as heretofore, and will deal with all travellers upon the same liberal principle. The best accom- modation will be afforded at the shortest notice. Breakfasts, Dinners, Suppers, and every other refreshment, in five minutes ; together with Wine, Spirits, and Stabling, equal to any in the colony.

I hope you will not cough, but the New Line of Road is rather a blank ; for, but 7 3/4d. is left with me for its improvement.

Ipswich, 23rd October, 1846.

WILLIAM HANDCOCK, General Store keeper, begs to acquaint his friends, that he intends to sell at the smallest advance on Sydney Prices, every description of article, from a " Needle to an Anchor," and all of the very best quality, as he conceives that the nimble penny quickly turns the pound ; and all goods direct from Home, will be disposed of at the Sydney

Prices.

What do you think of the Bone ? Ipswich is still going a-head,-it will yet be the downfall of

Paris.

Ipswich, 23rd October, 1846.

In the Supreme Court of

New South Wales.

MAWSON v. KEMBLE AND OTHERS.

ON MONDAY, the 26th day of October next, at 12 o'clock, at South Brisbane, Moreton Bay, the Sheriff will cause to be sold by Public Auction, under and by virtue of the authority to him given by an Act of Council, 5 Victoria, No. 9, sec. 31, the equity of redemption, and all the right, title, and interest of the defendant, Walter Roxburgh Kemble, being two-thirds in and to 4290 Sheep, or thereabouts, running at the station of, and in the charge of Mr. Charles Coxen, near the Condamine River, in the District of Darling Downs, with the bullocks, drays, harness, &c, unless this Execution is previously satisfied.

JOHN CONNOLLY,

Special Bailiff. 2lst September, 1846.

MAWSON v. KEMBLE AND OTHERS.

WITH reference to an advertisement, inserted

in the Government Gazette of the 25th September, headed as above, in which it is stated " On Monday, the 26th day of October next, at South Brisbane, Moreton Bay, the Sheriff will cause to be sold by Public Auction, under and by virtue of the authority to him given by an Act of Council, 5 Victoria, No. 9, section 31, the equity of redemption, and all other the right, title, and interest of the defendant, Walter Roxburgh Kem- ble, being two-thirds in and to 4290 Sheep, or thereabouts, running at the station of and in the the charge of Mr. Charles Coxen, near the Conda- mine River, in the District of Darling Downs, with the bullocks, drays, harness, &c, unless this this Execution is previously satisfied."

All parties are hereby cautioned not to purchase any assumed right of the defendant or defendants therein, the said Walter Roxburgh Kemble having no right, title, or interest whatever, in the said sheep, bullocks, drays, harness, &c, so advertised

for sale.

NICHOLAS JAMES. Sydney, 15th October, 1846.

In the Supreme Court of

New South Wales.

MAWSON v. KEMBLE AND OTHERS.

THE Plaintiff in the above case having strong

reasons to believe that an advertisement will

be published in the Moreton Bay Courier, pur- porting to be a caution to all parties from purchas- ing then Defendants' right, title, and interest in and to about 3113 Sheep, now in the charge of Mr. Charles Coxen, on the Condamine River, I hereby give notice, that the interest of the De- fendant, and all others, in the above-mentioned stock, will nevertheless be sold (subject to a mort- gage of about £800) on the day named in the Government Gazette ; and an order will be given to the purchaser for the delivery of the same.

GEORGE MAWSON 23rd October, 1846.

IN answer to the advertisement, signed '. G. S. Le

Breton, P. W. Welsh, Arbitrators," certified by , " Thos. Adams, Brisbane,28th August,'1848," in I the Moreton Bay Courier, "i hereby state, in

spiffof the over-bearing, contemptible conduct, and bounce of the said G. S. Le Breton and P. W. Welsh, to me, in my house, the 8th and llth ultimo, and the .. Action for Defamation,*' which my late Servant, Henry Ralph Elkins '« has in- structed his Solicitor in Sydney to commence against me," that " all the books, invoices, and other property," do hot belong to the said Henry Ralph Elkins, as falsely stated by the said George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Pa- ir icius William Welsh, but to me, having been bought and paid for with my money,--that my late servant, the said Henry Ralph Elkins, sent the sum of £85 2s. 8d., (eighty-five pounds, two shillings, and eightpence, sterling,) my money, to his friend, William Joyner, the Clerk in the Australian General Assurance Company's Office, George-street, Sydney, the 15th and 30th June last, per steamer Tamar, for which,I have never received value, or invoices, and which has never been accounted for to me by my said servant, Henry Ralph Elkins,~or.by the said clerk, William Joy other moneys for the sale of my goods in my store, which he has never yet accounted for to me ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins has other property of mine now in his possession ; that I now hold a promissory note, dated Sydney, 22nd May, 1846, payable on demand, drawn by the said Henry Ralph Elkins in my favour, for the sum of £17, (seventeen pounds sterling), with ten per cent, interest, money lent by me to the said Henry Ralph Elkins to pay the board, lodging, and washing, &c. , 8tc., of the said Henry Ralph Elkins, in Sydney; that several other debts are now due to me by the said Henry Ralph Elkins since the 8th April last ; the said Henry Ralph Elkins having been clothed, fed, housed, and supported by me, from the said 8th April to.the il5th July last past ; that the award of the said Arbitrators, George ^pottUwoode Le Breton, and^Fatriciui William Welsh, is illegal, unfair, and unjust to- wards me in every respect, and that I have com- menced legal proceedings to set it aside.

R. HAMPDEN South Brisbane, 31st October, 131a.

N.B.-Mr. Mort will be happy to make cash advances on receipt of the Wool into Store, and also to purchase supplies for the return teams if required.

STEAM COMMUNICATION

BETWEEN

MORETON BAY AND SYDNEY.

PROPOSED Days of Sailing of the Steam-

Packet

TAMAR.

FROM MORETON BAY. FROM SYDNEY.

On Tuesday, 1st Dec. On Tuesday, 8th Dec.

Ditto 15th ditto Ditto 22nd ditto Ditto 29th ditto Ditto 5th Jan. Ditto 12th Jan. Ditto 19th ditto

And so on every Tuesday alternately, from

Sydney and Moreton Bay. H. R. S. N-Co.'s Wharf,

South Brisbane.

THE STEAM - PACKET

WILLIAM IV.,

Captain Wiseman, will be laid on as a REGULAR TRADER between

THIS DISTRICT AND SYDNEY,

commencing her Trips early this month, at the following reduced Rates :

Cabin. £2 10 0 Steerage ...... 1 10 0

Goods shipped by her from Sydney, will be landed at North or South Brisbane, and Kangaroo Point-at the latter place, all Goods from Sydney, or Produce for shipment to Sydney, will be re- ceived and stored at CAMPBELL WHARF, free of all charge.

GEORGE WATSON,

Agent.

STEAMER " EXPERIMENT. "

THE Undersigned, in calling attention to the advertisement which appeared in the Courier, on the 24th ultimo, begs to inform the residents in Brisbane and Ipswich, that in future the freight for all Goods forwarded by the Steamer, must be paid when they are shipped ; and passage money will be required from parties before leaving

the vessel.

A. CAMPBELL. Brisbane, 6th Nov., 1846.

WOOL VESSEL FOR LONDON

DIRECT.

SHOULD sufficient encouragement be given,

the undersigned will procure a first class vessel in Sydney, to load from this Port direct to

London.

Parties requiring advances in their shipments, can receive the same on the terms usually charged in Sydney.

A list of intended shippers lies at the office of P. W. Welsh, South Brisbane ; John Richardson, North Brisbane ; Colin Campbell, Esq., Darling Downs ; Mr. Thomas Alford's, Post Office, Dar- ling Downs; and at my office, Custom House,

North Brisbane.

GEO. WATSON,

Custom House Agent

NOTICE.

THE Undersigned particularly requests, that no person-particularly Publicans-will give any credit whatsoever on his account, without a written order from himself or W. Wilkes,-with- out such order, no account will be paid.

GEO. S. LE BRETON.

£40 REWARD.

SUBSCRIPTION FOR THE APPREHENSION OF

THE FOUR BLACKS WHO MURDERED MR. GREGOR AND MRS. SHANNON.

PARTIES who approve of the above object, are

politely requested to forward their Subscriptions

immediately to

J. RICHARDSON,

North Brisbane.

TO POL1CEMEN, CONSTABLES, & OTHERS.

£1 REWARD.

GEORGE WANTFIELD having absconded

from my Station, at Rose Valley, the above

reward will be given to any Policeman or Con- stable who shall lodge him in the Lock-up ; and all persons are hereby cautioned against hiring or harbouring him-a warrant having been issued for his apprehension.

DESCRIPTION :-Ruddy complexion ; about 5 feet 6 inches in height; light hair ; and has only

one arm.

JOHN ROSS.

Rose Valley, 3rd Nov., 1846.

AT a PUBLIC MEETING of the Inhabitants of North and South Brisbane, held at the Court House, North Brisbane, on Thursday, the 19th day of November, 1846 ;

Present

Captain Coley, in the Chair ; Mr. J. Richardson Mr. R. Gill

W. Kent W. Fitzpatrick W. Pickering T. Gray T. Dowse A. Petrie

D. Bow J. Burgess J. Kent R. E. Dix

R. F. Phelan A. McIntyre W. A. Duncan A. McLean W. Thornton D. Buntin

L. F. Layard &c,, &c, &c.

J. Harris

Proposed by Mr. Pickering ; seconded by Mr.

Phelan -

1st. That this meeting has heard with consider- able surprise that the Colonial Secretary is re- ported to have expressed the following words, in his place, in the Legislative Council, upon the dis- cussion of the erection, of a Custom-house at this port-" The site, it appeared, had not been deter- mined upon, and there were conflicting opinions. At Moreton Bay, there were some who wished to have the Custom-house at Brisbane-others at Cleveland Point. The Police Magistrate, however, who was known as a marine surveyor, was at pre- sent engaged in fixing the site of a commercial town ; for Brisbane could not long be a commer- cial town, in consequence of the bar, which pre- vented vessels of any size going up. At Cleveland Point, however, there was deep water and very good shelter for shipping." Because upon the faith of the Government having previously fixed upon Brisbane as the seat of Government for these northern districts, large sums have been laid out by us in the purchase of land, and erecting build- ings thereon, and now view with apprehension any attempt to remove the Government Establish- ment to any other locality.-Carried.

Proposed by Mr. Richardson ; seconded by Mr.

Bow

2nd. That it being the opinion of this meeting, in conjunction with several practical persons, well acquainted with the port of Moreton Bay, the present town of Brisbane is in every point of view the most eligible site for the shipping port of these districts ; and, therefore, resolve that a Memorial be drawn up, and presented to His Excellency the Governor, praying that the proposed Custom- house be erected at Brisbane.-Carried.

The following Memorial was then submitted to the meeting, for their approval :-

To His Excellency Sir Charles Augustus

Fitz Roy, Knight, Governor-in-Chief of the Colony of New South Wales, and its dependencies,

The respectful Memorial of the Inhabi-

tants of North and South Brisbane, in the County of Stanley, Humbly Sheweth -

That since the Proclamation, published in Janu- ary, 1842, throwing the district of Moreton Bay open for location, and the first Government Land Sale, in July of that year, town and suburban allotments in North and South Brisbane, have been purchased from the Government, to the amount of about £20,000, the occupiers of which have, upon the Government having established Brisbane as the seat of the Government, and the shipping port of Moreton Bay, laid out considerable sums in buildings, and other improvements.

In the Sydney Morning Herald, of the 18th of October last, the honorable the Colonial Secretary is reported to have made a speech, in his place in the Legislative Council, to the following effect, in reference to the Custom-house, at Moreton Bay, viz. :-" That the site, it appeared, had not been determined upon, and there were conflicting opinions. At Moreton Bay, there were some who wished to have the Custom-house at Brisbane - others at Cleveland Point. The Police Magistrate, however, who was known as a marine surveyor, was .at present engaged in fixing the site for a commercial town ; for Brisbane could not long be the commercial town, in consequence of the Bar which prevented vessels of any size going up. At Cleveland Point, however, there was deep water, and very good shelter for shipping." With re- ference to the previous assertions, your memorial- ists would most earnestly beg to contradict such erroneous opinions. The inhabitants of Brisbane being unanimous that Brisbane is the most eligible shipping port ; neither is the Police Magistrate employed laying out the site of any other commer- cial town ; and so far from the present town of Brisbane being abandoned as a commercial port, every day brings out more fully its advantages for commercial purposes.

Your memorialists would, therefore, under these circumstances, beg most respectfully to state the following facts, for your Excellency's mature consideration, in refutation of such assertions :

First. That two large townships have been laid out in North and South Brisbane, a considerable portion of which has been sold, and an estimated sum of £30,000 laid out upon buildings and other improvements.

Secondly. That the situations of the townships, on the north and South banks of the river, have been most judiciously selected for commercial purposes, there being deep water close to the shore, and clear anchorage in the stream for every description of vessel.

Thirdly. The only impediment to the navigation

of this fine river, the bar which, in the opinion of practical men, could easily be removed by the aid of a dredging machine, as there is at present upwards of ten feet six inches at high water spring tides, and which bar could be easily deepened at comparatively small expense. That until this object can be effected, the best anchorage in Moreton Bay, for vessels shipping wool, is at the mouth of the Brisbane River, where from the year 1832, the whole of the supplies for the Penal Establishment of Moreton Bay, were transhipped from the Government vessels, and a large quantity of maize shipped for Sydney and Norfolk Island, as also wool for England, while lying at the anchorage known as the " White Buoy," at the mouth of the river-and that no instance of loss, or damage of such goods and cargo, has at any

time occurred.

Fourthly. That the capital required for the erection of wharves, .stores, Government offices, &c at Cleveland Point for the convenience of shipping would be enormous, a comparatively small portion of which sum expended in deepening the Bar would make Brisbane a most available shipping port, where Military Barracks and large Government Buildings are already erected-like- wise suitable buildings for trade-and stores and wharves for the convenience of shipping.

Fifthly. That the anchorage at the mouth of the river is the best in Moreton Bay, and the most central position for the shipment of wool, while the roadstead at Cleveland Point is greatly ex- posed to the north-east winds which prevail during the shipping season, and is also greatly affected by a strong adverse tide-a combination of cir- cumstances which would render shipment of produce from thence both dangerous and difficult.

Sixthly. That the waters of the Brisbane are now navigated by steam to the distance of seventy miles from the entrance of the river; and the townships of North and South Brisbane, from their eligible position, must eventually become the seat of commerce for the increasing districts of Moreton Bay, Darling Downs, the Boyne, and the Heads of the Clarence.

That your memorialists in stating the above facts to Your Excellency, would beg most respect- fully to pray that Your Excellency will be pleased to take this representation into consideration, with the view to a full enquiry into the statements contained in this memorial ; and we feel confident that in such case, the weight of evidence will be in favour of retaining the Customs and other Government Establishments at Brisbane, the re- moval of which elsewhere will be the total ruin of your memorialists.

And your memorialists further pray that Your Excellency will direct that a Custom-house may be built as early as practicable at Brisbane.

And your memorialists as in duty bound will

ever pray, &c.

Proposed by Mr. Harris ; seconded by. Mr.

Petrie-

3rd; That the Memorial now read be adopted by this meeting ; and that the same be placed before every householder in these townships for their signatures, and afterwards transmitted to His Ex- cellency the Governor.-Carried.

Proposed by Mr. Gill ; seconded by Mr. Richardson-

4th. That the proceedings of this meeting be

advertised in the Moreton Bay Courier and Sydney Morning Herald.-Carried.

RICHARD J. COLEY,

Chairman. LOUIS F. LAYARD,

Hon. Secretary.

NEW ROAD.

IN consequence of the splendid discovery of a new line of road from the Upper Brisbane, a large portion of the Wool and supplies for that district and the Boyne will have to be shipped at North Brisbane, the Undersigned begs to inform his friends that he has provided a large Store, capable of holding 500 bales of Wool, and is prepared to receive and ship all Goods that may be consigned to his care, at the following rates : Wool, including cartage and shipping, 1s. per

bale.

Supplies from Sydney, including cartage, 1s. 6d.

per ton per week.

G. S. LE BRETON.

NOTICE.

THE Undersigned beg to inform the residents

in Moreton Bay and Darling Downs that a Partnership having been this day entered upon between Mr. J. L Montefiore and Mr. Robert Graham, the business of the late firms of J. L. Montefiore and Co. and of Robert Graham, will in future be carried on under the style of Monte- fiore, Graham, and Co.

(Signed) MONTEFIORE, GRAHAM, & CO. Sydney, 2nd November, 1846.

FOR SALE,

THE CARGO of FLOUR, ex Ann, from Sydney, consisting of Fine and Seconds ; also a quantity of Van Diemen's Land Oats, Maize, and Bran. Apply to

ROBERT GRAHAM.

North and South Brisbane.

TO THE SETTLERS, STOREKEEPERS,

AND PUBLIC GENERALLY

IN THE DISTRICT OF MORETON BAY.

DAVID JONES AND CO. beg to apprise their numerous friends, and the public generally, in the district of Moreton Bay, that that their stock of Slops and General Clothing having lately been increased by several large importations, is at present replete with every article required, both for the bush and private

families.

Settlers and others are reminded that the Slops, Clothing, &c, which are made in England ex- pressly to Messrs. Jones' orders, are of a quality and workmanship infinitely superior to those generally sold in this market.

Subjoined is a partial list of Slops, &c, with the prices attached. The public will please to observe, that the prices of such articles only as can be recommended are quoted-inferior qualities can be obtained :-

Moleskin Trowsers and Jackets Ditto Strapped ditto

Worsted Cord ditto

Scotch Twilled Shirts Regatta ditto Ditto superior ditto, got up in boxes of 1 dozen

each for gents.

Striped Cotton Shirts

Guernsey and Yarn Frocks,

Shepherd's and Stockmen's Great Coats Pea and Monkey Jackets

Silk, Plush, and Scarlet-sleeved Vests

Light and Dark Vests of all qualities

Silk and Cotton Handkerchiefs

Ticking and Osnaburgh

Diaper Rugs Coloured Counterpanes

Manila, Cabbage-tree, and other Hats, from 2s.

and upwards

Stockmen's Boots, &c, &c.

D. J. and Co. would particularly direct the attention of purchasers to their stock of Yorkshire, Witney, and Army Blankets, in all sizes, from 7s 4d to 12s 4d. GENERAL DRAPERY AND FANCY GOODS.

Under this head will be found every article re- quired for family and domestic use ; and none but the best fabrics are offered. Ladies who have not visited Sydney lately, will be surprised at the extent, variety, and elegance, of the Stock com- prised in these departments.

George-street, Sydney.

UNDER THE DISTINGUISHED PATRONAGE OP THE

MORETON BAY SQUATTERS, AND THE PUBLIC

IN GENERAL.

THE ADELPHI HOTEL,

YORK-STREET, SYDNEY.

" COMFORT, ECONOMY, AND HOSPITALITY."

THOMAS MURPHY begs most respectfully to tender his grateful acknowledgments to his patrons and the public generally for the very liberal support he has received since he opened the above establishment, and hopes by renewed exertion for the comfort of his guests, and by charges the most moderate in Sydney, will ensure for him a return in the ensuing wool season of

the support of his friends.

Excellent Livery Stables, with abundance of good supplies, and every care taken of horses, good accommodation for servants, carriages, gigs,

wool, &c.

TO SETTLERS, STOREKEEPERS, PUBLI-

CANS, AND OTHERS.

THE Undersigned begs to inform his friends

that he has on hand, as usual, a large and

well selected stock of

Mauritius, Manilla, and Loaf Sugar Hyson-skin, Congou, and Pouchong Teas

Hyson, Gunpowder, Pekoe, and Souchong, in

boxes

Coffee, raw and roasted, of the best qualities

London Starch, Blue, Pickles, Sauces, and every

article usually kept in a Grocery and Italian

Warehouse

Sperm and Black Oil

Corrosive Sublimate, Arsenic, Bluestone, &c.,8cc.

In his Cellars will be found

Martell's Brandy, first quality ; Champagne

Brandy, in cases ; Hollands, in cases and half cases ; Altona, Lowndes, prime old Tom, West India and strong Rum ; Champagne, Hock, Claret, Madeira, Port, Sherry, Marsala, Tene- riffe, and Cape Wines.

Bottled Ale and Stout—" Byass' " and other.

The system which the Undersigned has always adopted, will be strictly adhered to, (viz., to sell good and genuine articles, at the lowest possible price, and to conduct his business in a fair and honourable manner, not professing to sell articles lower than the market price, nor charge more than such price, will supply a good article, give just weight, and not seek his profit by the trickery and cheating, which must be resorted to by those who pretend to sell at prices lower than the

market value.

RICHARD PEEK. 452, George-street; Sydney,

near the Post Office.

articleText:
STEAM COMMUNICATION

BETWEEN

MORETON BAY AND SYDNEY.

PROPOSED Days of Sailing of the Steam

Packet

TAMAR:

FROM MORETON BAY. FROM SYDNEY.

On Tuesday, 3rd Nov. On Tuesday, 10th Nov.

Ditto

17th ditto

Ditto

24th ditto Ditto

1st Dec.

Ditto

8th Dec. Ditto

15th ditto

Ditto

22nd ditto Ditto

29th ditto

Ditto

5th Jan. Ditto

12th Jan.

Ditto

19th ditto

And so on every Tuesday alternately, from

Sydney and Moreton Bay. H. R. S. N. Co.'s Wharf,

South Brisbane.

THE STEAM - PACKET

WILLIAM IV.,

Captain Wiseman, will be laid on as a REGULAR TRADER

between

THIS DISTRICT AND SYDNEY,

commencing her Trips early in the ensuing month, at the following reduced Rates :

Cabin. £2 10 0 Steerage. 1 10 0

Goods shipped by her from Sydney, will be landed at North or South Brisbane, and Kangaroo Point-at the latter place, all Goods from Sydney, or Produce for shipment to Sydney, will be re- ceived and stored at CAMPBELL WHARF, tree of all charge.

GEORGE WATSON,

Agent.

STEAMER "EXPERIMENT."

THE Proprietor begs to inform his friends and

the public, that in future he finds it necessary to make up the accounts for freight monthly, instead of quarterly as heretofore ; and that an early adjustment of them is essentially necessary

to the continuance of the vessel in the trade.

Brisbane, 9th Oct., 1846.

WOOL VESSEL FOR LONDON

DIRECT.

SHOULD sufficient encouragement be given, the undersigned will procure a first class vessel in Sydney, to load from this Port direct to London.

Parties requiring advances in their shipments, can receive the same on the terms usually charged in Sydney.

A list of intended shippers lies at the office of P. W. Welsh, South Brisbane ; John Richardson, North Brisbane ; Colin Campbell, Esq., Darling Downs ; Mr. Thomas Alford's, Post Office, Dar- ling Downs; and at my office, Custom House,

North Brisbane.

GEO. WATSON,

Custom House Agent.

ALE AND PORTER.

'THE Undersigned receives fresh supplies of the above, in Hogsheads and Barrels, by every opportunity.

South Brisbane 9th Sept., 1846.

J. HARRIS. WINES.

AT the STORES of the Undersigned

Superior old Port, at 30s. per dozen Fine rich Sherry, from 24s. to 28s. ditto

Marsella, best brand, from 16s. to 18s. ditto Best White Wine Vinegar, at 12s. ditto Good strong ditto, at 9s. ditto

Colonial Ale and Porter, at the Sydney price of

6s. 6d., with freight and expenses added Red Case Gin, White and Brown Sugar Wine Corks, best Jamaica Ginger

P. W. WELSH.

Wharf, South Brisbane.

N.B.-One Shilling a dozen allowed for empty

Wine Bottles.

BRICKS.

IN consequence of the inconvenience and useless

expense I have been put to in not being able to purchase Bricks in North Brisbane, when in want of them, and seeing no parties likely to open a Brickyard to supply the public generally, I beg to inform the public that I have opened a Brickyard, and shall be very happy to supply parties wanting Bricks or Paving Tiles, in lots from 100 to

100,000.

D. SKYRING,

Bricklayer. Brickfield-hill, North Brisbane.

IN answer to the advertisement, signed " G. S. Le * Breton, P. W. Welsh, Arbitrators," certified-by - "Thos. Adams, Brisbane, 28th August, 1846," in the Moreton Bay Courier, I hereby state, in spite of the over-bearing, contemptible conduct, and bounce of the said G. S. Le Breton and P. W. Welsh, to me, in my house, the 8th and 11th ultimo, and the " Action for Defamation," which my late servant, Henry Ralph Elkins " has in- structed his Solicitor in Sydney to commence against me," that " all the books, invoices, and other property," do not belong to the said Henry Ralph Elkins, as falsely stated by the said George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Pa tricius William Welsh, but to me, having been bought and paid for with my money,-that my late servant, the said Henry Ralph Elkins, sent the sum of £85 2s. 8d., (eighty-five pounds, two shillings, and eightpence, sterling,) my money, to his friend, William Joyner, the Clerk in the Australian General Assurance Company's Office, George-street, Sydney, the 15th and 30th June last, per steamer Tamar, for which I have never received value, or invoices, and which has never been accounted for to me by my said servant, Henry Ralph Elkins, or by the said clerk, William Joy- ner ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins received other moneys for the sale of my goods in my store, which he has never yet accounted for to me ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins has other property of mine now in his possession ; that I now hold a promissory note, dated Sydney, 22nd May, 1846, payable on demand, drawn by the said Henry Ralph Elkins in my favour, for the sum of £11, {seventeen pounds sterling), with ten per cent, interest, money lent by me to the said Henry Ralph Elkins to pay the board, lodging, and washing, &c., &c., of the said Henry Ralph Elkins, in Sydney; that several other debts are now due to me by the said Henry Ralph Elkins since the 8th April last ; the said Henry Ralph Elkins having been clothed, fed, housed, and supported by me, from the said 8th April to the 15th July last

past ; that the award of tire said Arbitiators, George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Patricius William Welsh, is illegal, unfair, and unjust to- wards me in every respect, and that I have com- menced legal proceedings to set it aside.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 17th October, 1846.

WOOL.

THE Undersigned is authorised to make cash advances on Wool consigned to Capt. Towns, Sydney, for sale there, or shipment through him to Robert Brooks, Esq., London.

Wool, washed and unwashed, Hides, and Sheep- skins, purchased. Apply at the Wharf, South

Brisbane.

P. W. WELSH.

NEW ROAD.

1N consequence of the splendid discovery of a new line of road from the Upper Brisbane, a large portion of the Wool and supplies for that district and the Boyne will have to be shipped at North Brisbane, the Undersigned begs to inform his friends that he has provided a large Store, capable of holding 500 bales of Wool, and is prepared to receive and ship all Goods that may be consigned to his care, at the following rates : Wool, including cartage and shipping, Is. per

bale.

Supplies from Sydney, including cartage, Is. 6d.

per ton per week.

G. S. LE BRETON. ,

A WEATHER - BOARDED VERANDAH COTTAGE, pleasantly situated on the bauk of the River, at Kangaroo Point, and containing Six Rooms, in an excellent state of repair, with plenty of back ground attached, part of which is enclosed as a Garden. There are also a Fowl- house, temporary Stockyard, &c, on the premises, and the rent, to a good tenant, will be extremely

small.

Apply at the Stores of the undersigned.

G. S. LE BRETON.

North Brisbane, Sept. 19,1846.

TO THE WOOL-GROWERS IN THE

MORETON BAY DISTRICT.

THE Undersigned begs to inform his friends,

and the Wool-growers generally, that he is prepared this season to assort and repack Wool, suitable for the London and Liverpool Markets.

Parties shearing in the grease, can be acommo- dated by having their Wool assorted and hand washed ; and samples may be seen by applying to

WM. CARTER,

Kangaroo Point. JOHN SMITH,

BELL-STREET, IPSWICH,

GENERAL STORE,

TAKES the earliest opportunity afforded by the establishment of a local newspaper to thank his friends and the public generally for the liberal support he has been favoured with ; and to ap- prise them that the prices of articles at his store will be such as to give satisfaction, and cause recommendation. A large assortment of Slops and Groceries always on hand. Orders from the nterior punctually attended to.

CAUTION.

My late servant, HENRY RALPH ELKINS, having refused to pay me over my money

received by him for the sale of my goods in my Store, and having been in consequence dismissed by me, I hereby caution the Public not to deal with, or pay any money to the said Henry Ralph Elkins on my account, the said Henry Ralph Elkins being no longer authorised to transact my

business.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 17th October, 184S.

CAUTION.

THE public are hereby cautioned against hiring

WILLIAM BARCKLEY, he having ab- sconded from my hired service on the 22nd of September last.

WILLIAM BARKER.

Logan River, 5th Oct. 1846.

£15 REWARD.

WHEREAS it having been represented to me,

by parties of good repute, that neighbours of mine are creating a conspiracy against me in my Business--it having been stated that they would be with me before long ; and one of the parties having publicly stated, that they never intend being beaten at Court.

The above reward will be paid to any party giving such information as will lead to the prose- sution and conviction of the parties or party con-

cerned in the above villainous affair.

JOHN SMITH.

Limestone, 14th October, 1846.

TO POLICEMEN, CONSTABLES & OTHERS.

£5 REWARD.

THE following individuals having absconded from my Station, the above reward will be given to any Policeman or Constable who shall lodge them in the lock-up, and all ???? hereby cautioned against hiring or harbouring them, warrants having been granted for their apprehension, viz. :

JOHN WRIGHT, absconded in May last ; he is about 5 feet 8 inches in height; complexion fair and ruddy ; stout made, and a butcher by trade. Age, about 25 years.

WILLIAM BUBIER, absconded on the 3rd nstant ; he is about 5 feet 6 inches in height, ather slender, no beard, and rather fair com- lexion . Supposed to have gone to the Clarence.

COLIN J. MACKENZIE. Kilcoy, 16th October, 1846.

TO POLICEMEN, CONSTABLES & OTHERS.

£2 REWARD.

THE following individuals having absconded

from my Station, the above reward will be given to any-Policeman or Constable who shall lodge them in the lock-up, either at Darling Downs or Brisbane ; and all parties are hereby cautioned against hiring or harbouring them warrants having been granted for their appre-

hension, viz. :

JOHN JONES, hired for six months, on the 8th September, 1846 ; absconded on Friday night, the 2nd October ; a short man, with freckled face and hands, talks very fine-brought a cha- racter from John McNab, Mount Macedon, Port Phillip.

JOSEPH JENKINS, hired on the 27th August, 1846, for six months, absconded on the night of Wednesday, the 30th September-rather thick- set, about 5 feet 8 inches high, or more.

J. C. PEARCE.

Helidon. Lockyers Creek,

October 1, 1846.

TO WOOL-GROWERS AND STOREKEEPERS. 'THE undersigned is empowered to make Cash

Advances on Wool, consigned to the House of Messrs. Evans; Brothers, London ; or in his capacity of Wool Broker and General Agent, will obtain the highest market rates in Sydney, if entrusted to him for Sale, and effect prompt returns faithfully in cash, or supplies, as required. Commission charge, 1 1/2 per cent.

B. S. LLOYD.

10, Bridge-street, Sydney.

TO BE SOLD BY PRIVATE BARGAIN.

THE following HORSE STOCK, late the pro-

perty of Ernest E. Dalrymple, Esq., de-

ceased—

9 Mares

1 Gelding

1 Colt, rising 3 years old

3 Colts, " 2 " "

2 Fillies, " 2 " "

2 Colts, " 1 " "

1 Filly, " 1 " "

19 Head.

The above-mentioned Horses are mostly the produce of first-rate mares by thorough-bred horses, and are now running on the Station of Messrs. Walter and George Leslie, Canning

Downs.

The mares are in foal to thorough-bred horses. For further particulars apply to George F. Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

TO THE SETTLERS, STOREKEEPERS,

AND PUBLIC GENERALLY, IN THE DISTRICT OF MORETON BAY.

DAVID JONES AND CO. beg to apprise their numerous friends, and the public generally, in the district of Moreton Bay, that that their stock of Slops and General Clothing having lately been increased by several large importations, is at present replete with every article required, both for the bush and private

families.

Settlers and others are reminded that the Slops, Clothing, &c, which are made in England ex- pressly to Messrs. Jones' orders, are of a quality and workmanship infinitely superior to those generally sold in this market.

Subjoined is a partial list of Slops, &c, with the prices attached. The public will please to observe, that the prices of such articles only as can be recommended are quoted-inferior qualities can be

obtained :

Moleskin Trowsers and Jackets Ditto Strapped ditto

Worsted Cord ditto Scotch Twilled Shirts Regatta ditto

Ditto superior ditto, got up in boxes of 1 dozen

each for gents.

Striped Cotton Shirts

Guernsey and Yarn Frocks Shepherd's and Stockmen's Great Coats Pea and Monkey Jackets

Silk, Plush, and Scarlet-sleeved Vests Light and Dark Vests of all qualities

Silk and Cotton Handkerchiefs

Ticking and Osnaburgh

Diaper Rugs Coloured Counterpanes

Manila, Cabbage-tree, and other Hats, from 2s.

and upwards

Stockmen's Boots, &c, &c.

D. J. and Co. would particularly direct the attention of purchasers to their stock of Yorkshire, Witney, and Army Blankets, in all sizes, from

7s. 4d. to 12s. 4d.

GENERAL DRAPERY AND FANCY GOODS.

Under this head will be found every article re- quired for family and domestic use ; and none but the best fabrics are offered. Ladies who have not visited Sydney lately, will be surprised at the extent, variety, and elegance, of the Stock com- prised in these departments.

George-street, Sydney.

BONNETS! BONNETS! BONNETS!! MRS. KEANE begs leave to apprise the Ladies

of Moreton Bay that she has

JUST RECEIVED

by the latest arrivals, and from the well known

house of

SPURDEN AND WOOLLEY,

7 CASES OF BONNETS

selected expressly for Mrs. Keane, consisting of Tuscan, Dunstable, Rice, Rutland, Fancy Straw, and Whole Straw, suitable for Morning Bonnets, amongst which will be found a few of the much admired Pamela, and a large assortment of Gipsey

Hats.

ALSO,

Children's Tuscan, Leghorn, and Dunstable Hats, and Bands, Ladies' Riding Hats, &c., &c.

Mrs. Keane has also a FEW CASES of Tuscan and Dunstable PLAIT. Ladies can have any shape, bonnet, or hat, made to order.

The trade supplied with Plait, Wire, Binding,

Wire Thread, &c, &c, at

MRS. J. KEANE'S.

115, King-street East, Sydney,

2 doors from Pitt-street.

N.B.-Bonnets turned and altered at the SHORTEST NOTICE, and on the most REASONABLE

TERMS.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

AT CANNING DOWNS,

(In addition to the Horses already advertised, the

property of Messrs. W. and G. Leslie),

AN ARAB HORSE, of the purest caste, just

arrived from India.

Terms-Three Guineas each Mare.

TO STAND,

AT THE MESSRS. BIGGE'S STATION,

BRISBANE RIVER,

THE THOROUGH -BRED HORSE CAIN. Cain by Vagabond, out of Cuttysark (imported by Captain Jamb) by Oxford, out of a Fidget mare. Fidget by Florizel, out of a Matchem

mare.

Vagabond by Cain, out of Gabrielle by Parti- zan, her dam Coquette by Dick Andrews, by Joe Andrews by Eclipse.

Terms-£3 3s. each Mare,-a reduction made on three Mares and upwards.

Large and well-watered Paddocks provided, but no responsibility incurred
