articleText:
STEAM TO SYDNEY,

BY the Hunter River

Steam Navigation Com- pany's Packet TAMAR:

ON TUESDAY, 8TH DECEMBER,

And on every alternate Tuesday during the

Season.

FARES :

Saloon... £4 0 0 Steerage...2 0 0 H. R. S. N. Co's Wharf,

South Brisbane, Nov. 28, 1846.

WOOL VESSEL FOR LONDON

DIRECT.

SHOULD sufficient encouragement be given, the undersigned will procure a first class vessel in Sydney, to load from this Port direct to

London.

Parties requiring advances in their shipments, can receive the same on the terms usually charged in Sydney.

A list of intended shippers lies at the office of P. W. Welsh, South Brisbane ; John Richardson, North Brisbane ; Colin Campbell, Esq., Darling Downs ; Mr. Thomas Alford's, Post Office, Dar- ling Downs; and at my office, Custom House,

North Brisbane.

GEO. WATSON,

Custom House Agent

£40 REWARD.

SUBSCRIPTION FOR THE APPREHENSION OF

THE THREE BLACKS WHO MURDERED MR. GREGOR AND MRS. SHANNON ; AND ALSO FOR THE APPREHENSION OF THE PRINCIPAL IN THE MURDER OF MR. UHR.

A REWARD of £10 for each Black will be

given to any party who apprehends the following Aboriginal Natives, viz. : - Jackey Jackey, Dick Ben, and Moggy Moggy, the mur- derers of the late Mr. Gregor and Mrs. Shannon ; and Horse Jemmy, the principal in the murder of

the late Mr. Uhr.

Persons who approve of the above objects, are politely requested to forward their Subscriptions to

J. RICHARDSON,

North Brisbane. November 27, 1846.

ON SALE by the undersigned, FINE FLOUR,

at moderate prices.

EBEN. ORR.

South Brisbane, Nov. 28, 1846.

THE Undersigned has for Sale, at the SOUTH BRISBANE STORES --

Port and Sherry, in quarter-casks

Ditto ditto, in 3 dozen cases

Martell's Brandy Jamaica Rum

Case Gin

Mould Candles, in 1 cwt. or 1/2 cwt. boxes

Dunbar's bottled Ale and Porter Hyson-skin and Congou Teas Manilla Sugar

A great variety of Soft Goods

Earthenware and Glass

Flour, at Sydney prices

T. H. GREEN.

ON S A L E - MARTELL'S BRANDY Jamaica Rum

Gin, in 4 gallon cases

Port Wine, in 3 dozen cases

Sherry, in 3 dozen cases Ditto, in draught

Champagne, in 1 dozen cases Byass Ale} in 3 dozen cases Lewtas' Porter, }

Ale and Porter, in hhds. and barrels.

J. HARRIS;

South Brisbane.

FOR SALE,

THE CARGO of FLOUR, ex Ann, from Sydney, consisting of Fine and Seconds; also a quantity of Van Diemen's Land Oats, Maize, and Bran. Apply to

ROBERT GRAHAM.

North and South Brisbane.

NEW ROAD.

IN consequence of the splendid discovery of a new line of road from the Upper Brisbane, a large portion of the Wool and supplies for that district and the Boyne will have to be shipped at North Brisbane, the Undersigned begs to inform his friends that he has provided a large Store, capable of holding 500 bales of Wool, and is prepared to receive and ship all Goods that may be consigned to his care, at the following rates : Wool, including cartage and shipping, 1s. per

bale.

Supplies from Sydney, including cartage, 1s 6d.

per ton per week;

G. S. LE BRETON.

AT a PUBLIC MEETING of the inhabitants

of North and South Brisbane, held at the Court House, North Brisbane, on Thursday, the 19th day of November, 1846 ;

Present-

Captain Coley, in the Chair ; Mr. J. Richardson Mr. R. Gill

W. Kent W. Fitzpatrick W. Pickering T. Gray T. Dowse A. Petrie

D. Bow J. Burgess J. Kent , R. E. Dix

R. F. Phelan A. McIntyre W. A. Duncan v A. McLean W. Thornton . D. Buntin

L. F. Layard &c. , &c., &c.

J. Harris

Proposed by Mr. Pickering ; seconded by Mr.

Phelan

1st. That this meeting has heard with consider- able surprise that the Colonial Secretary is re- ported to have expressed the following words, in his place, in the Legislative Council, upon the dis- cussion of the erection of a Custom-house at this port-" The site, it appeared, had not been deter- mined upon, and there were conflicting opinions. At Moreton Bay, there were some who wished to have the Custom-house at Brisbane-others at Cleveland Point. The Police Magistrate, however,

who was known as a marine surveyor, was at pre- sent engaged in fixing the site of a commercial town ; for Brisbane could not long be a commer- cial town, in consequence of the bar, which pre- vented vessels of any size going up. At Cleveland Point, however, there was deep water and very good shelter for shipping." Because upon the faith of the Government having previously fixed upon Brisbane as the seat of Government for these northern districts, large sums have been laid out by us in the purchase of land, and erecting build- ings thereon, and now view with apprehension any attempt to remove the Government Establish- ment to any other locality.-Carried.

Proposed by Mr. Richardson ; seconded by Mr. 2nd. That it being the opinion of this meeting, in conjunction with several practical persons, well acquainted with the port of Moreton Bay, the present town of Brisbane is in every point of view the most eligible site for the shipping port of these districts ; and, therefore, resolve that a Memorial be drawn up, and presented to His Excellency the Governor, praying that the proposed Custom-

house be erected at Brisbane.-Carried.

The following Memorial was then submitted to the meeting, for their approval :

To His Excellency Sir Charles Augustus

Fitz Roy, Knight, Governor-in-Chief of the Colony of .New South Wales, and its dependencies,

The respectful Memorial of the Inhabi-

tants of North and South Brisbane, in the County of Stanley, Humbly Sheweth -

That since the Proclamation, published in Janu- ary, 1842, throwing the district of Moreton Bay open for location, and the first Government Land Sale, in July of that year, town and suburban allotments in North and South Brisbane, have been purchased from the Government, to the amount of about £20,000, the occupiers of which have, upon the Government having established Brisbane as the seat of the Government, and the shipping port of Moreton Bay, laid out considerable sums in buildings, and other improvements.

In the Sydney Morning Herald, of the 18th of October last, the honorable the Colonial Secretary is reported to have made a speech, in his place in tile Legislative Council, to the following effect, in reference to the Custom-house, at Moreton Bay, viz. :-" That the site, it appeared, had not been determined upon, and there were conflicting opinions. At Moreton Bay, there were some who wished to have the Custom-house at Brisbane others at Cleveland Point. The Police Magistrate, however, who was known as a marine surveyor, was at present engaged in fixing the site for a commercial town ; for Brisbane could not long be

the commercial town, in consequence of the Bar which prevented vessels of any size going up. At Cleveland Point, however, there was deep water, and very good shelter for shipping." With re- ference to the previous assertions, your memorial- ists would most earnestly beg to contradict such erroneous opinions. The inhabitants of Brisbane being unanimous that Brisbane is the most eligible shipping port ; neither is the Police Magistrate employed laying out the site of any other commer- cial town ; and so far from the present town of Brisbane being abandoned as a commercial port, every day brings out more fully its advantages for commercial purposes.

Your memorialists would, therefore, under these circumstances, beg most respectfully to state the following facts, for your Excellency's mature

consideration, in refutation of such assertions :

First. That two large townships have been laid out in North and South Brisbane, a considerable portion of which has been sold, and an estimated sum of £30,000 laid out upon buildings and other

improvements.

Secondly. That the situations of the townships, on the north and south banks of the river, have been most judiciously selected for commercial purposes, there being deep water close to the shore, and clear anchorage in the stream for every description of vessel.

Thirdly. The only impediment to the navigation

of this fine river, is a bar which, in the opinion of - practical men, could easily be removed by the aid of a dredging machine, as there is at present upwards of ten feet six inches at high water spring tides, and which bar could be easily deepened at comparatively small expense. That until this object can be effected, the best, anchorage in Moreton Bay, for vessels shipping wool, is at the mouth of the Brisbane River, where from the year 1832, the whole of the supplies for the Penal Establishment of Moreton Bay, were transhipped from the Government vessels, and large quantity of maize shipped for Sydney and Norfolk Island, as also wool for England, while lying at the anchorage known as the " White Buoy," at the mouth of the river and that no instance of loss, or damage of such goods and cargo, has at any

time occurred.

Fourthly. That the capital required for the

erection of wharves, stores, Government offices, &c. at Cleveland Point for the convenience of Shipping would -be enormous, a comparatively small portion of which sum expended in deepening the Bar would make Brisbane a most available shipping port, where Military Barracks and large Government Buildings are already erected-like- wise suitable buildings for trade-and stores and wharves for the convenience of shipping.

Fifthly. That the anchorage at the mouth of the river is the best in Moreton Bay, and the most central position for the shipment of wool, while the roadstead at Cleveland Point is greatly ex- posed to the north-east winds which prevail during the shipping season, and is also greatly affected by a strong adverse tide-a combination of cir- cumstances which would render shipment of produce from thence both dangerous and difficult.

Sixthly. That the waters of the Brisbane are now navigated by steam to the distance of seventy miles from the entrance of the river; and the townships of North and South Brisbane, from their eligible position, must eventually become the seat of commerce for the increasing districts of Moreton Bay, Darling Downs, the Boyne, and

the heads of the Clarence.

That your memorialists in Stating the above facts to Your Excellency, would beg most respect- fully to pray that Your Excellency will be pleased to take this representation into consideration, with the view to a full enquiry into the statements contained in this memorial ; and we feel confident that in such case, the weight of evidence will be in favour of retaining tile Customs and other Government Establishments at Brisbane, the re- moval of which elsewhere will be the total ruin of your memorialists.

And your memorialists further pray that Your Excellency will direct that a Custom-house may be built as early as practicable at Brisbane.

And your memorialists as in duty bound will

ever pray, &c.

Proposed by Mr. Harris ; seconded by Mr.

Petrie-

3rd. That the Memorial now read be adopted by this meeting ; and that the same be placed before every householder in these townships for their signatures, and afterwards transmitted to His Ex- cellency the Governor.-Carried.

Proposed by Mr. Gill ; seconded by Mr.

Richardson

4th. That the proceedings of this meeting be advertised in the Moreton Bay Courier and Sydney Morning Herald.-Carried.

RICHARD J. COLEY,

Chairman. LOUIS F. LAYARD,

Hon. Secretary.

TO THE WOOL-GROWERS

IN THE MORETON BAY DISTRICT.

'THE Undersigned begs to inform his friends, and the Wool-growers generally, that he is prepared this season to assort and repack Wool, suitable for the London and Liverpool Markets.

Parties shearing in the grease, can be accom- modated by having their Wool assorted and hand washed ; and samples may be seen by applying to

WM. CARTER,

Kangaroo Point.

TO WOOL-GROWERS AND STOREKEEPERS. THE undersigned is empowered to make Cash Advances on Wool, consigned to the House of Messrs. Evans, Brothers, London ; or in his capacity of Wool Broker and General Agent, will obtain the highest market rates in Sydney, if entrusted to him for Sale, and effect prompt returns faithfully in cash, or supplies, as required. Commission charge, 1 1/2 per cent.

B. S. LLOYD.

10, Bridge-street, Sydney.

SOUTH BRISBANE

READING ROOMS.

THE SUBSCRIBERS to the above are informed that their Temporary Rooms will be open on Wednesday, the 4th November. The following newspapers have been procured .'-Moreton Bay, Sydney, Melbourne, Geelong, Launceston, Hobart Town, Adelaide, and New Zealand ; others will be added when a sufficient number of Subscribers have been procured. Subscription, Two Guineas per annum-one-half in advance.

THE Undersigned is a purchaser of Wool,

Tallow, or other produce , or will, as usual, make advances on the same, if consigned to his correspondents either in London or Liverpool.

ROBERT GRAHAM. Brisbane, 4th Nov., 1846.

NOTICE.

THE Undersigned particularly requests, that

no person-particularly Publicans-will give any credit whatsoever on his account, without a written order from himself or W. Wilkes,-with- out such order, no account will be paid.

GEO. S. LE BRETON.

TAKE NOTICE.

ALL parties are hereby cautioned against hiring ROBERT SMITH, late in the employ of Mr. John Campbell, of Kangaroo Point, as he has

absconded from his hired service, having no written discharge.

GEO. FLETCHER.

New Farm, 17th Nov., 1846.

TO THE SETTLERS, STOREKEEPERS,

AND PUBLIC GENERALLY,

IN THE DISTRICT OF MORETON BAY. DAVID JONES AND CO. beg to apprise

their numerous friends, and the public generally, in the district of Moreton Bay, that that their stock of Slops and General Clothing having lately been increased by several large importations, is at present replete with every article required, both for the bush and,private, families.

Settlers and others are reminded that the Slops, Clothing, &c., which are made in England ex- pressly to Messrs. Jones' orders, are of a quality and workmanship infinitely superior to those generally sold in this market.

Subjoined is a partial list of slops &c., with the prices attached. The public will please to observe

that the prices of such articles only as can be recommended are quoted-inferior qualities can be

obtained :

Moleskin Trowsers and Jackets

Ditto Strapped ditto

Worsted Cord ditto

Scotch Twilled Shirts

Regatta ditto

Ditto superior ditto, got up in boxes of 1 dozen

each for gents. Striped Cotton Shirts

Guernsey and Yam Frocks

Shepherd's and Stockmen's Great Coats Pea and Monkey Jackets Silk, Plush, and Scarlet-sleeved Vests

Light and Dark Vests of all qualities

Silk and Cotton Handkerchiefs Ticking and Osnaburgh Diaper Rugs

Coloured Counterpanes

Manila, Cabbage-tree, and other Hats, from 2s.

and upwards

Stockmen's Boots, &c., &c.

D. J. and Co. would particularly direct the attention of purchasers to their stock of Yorkshire,

Witney, and Army Blankets, in all sizes, from

7s. 4d. to 12s. 4d.

GENERAL DRAPERY AND FANCY GOODS.

Under this head will be found every article re- quired for family and domestic use; and none but the best fabrics are offered. Ladies who have not visited Sydney lately, will be surprised at the extent, variety, and elegance, of the Stock com- prised in these departments.

George-street, Sydney.

TO THE SETTLERS IN THE DISTRICT OF

MORETON BAY.

MR. MORT'S PRODUCE SALES.

MR. MORT

BEGS to inform the Woolgrowers, Merchants,

and others of the colony interested in the Sale of Wool, Tallow, &c, that he intends, during the ensuing season, to hold Auction Sales of

Produce

EVERY WEDNESDAY AND SATURDAY, in lieu of Saturday only, as heretofore.

In soliciting a continuance of the support which his weekly sales have received, Mr. Mort would call attention to the very low scale of charges now adopted, and further to the fact, that from the competition created by the attendance of all classes of buyers, this mode of sale possesses advantages over any other, and at all times ensures the ex-

treme market rates of the day ; besides enabling the settler to close his transactions on an average within twenty-four hours of the arrival of his

Wool and Tallow.

The Stores at the rear of the Rooms, will be always open to receive produce, but Wool intended

for Wednesday's sale must be delivered or be- fore Tuesday, and that for Saturday not later than Friday, in order to give proper time for arrange-

ment and inspection.

N.B.—Mr. Mort will be happy to make cash advances on receipt of the Wool into Store, and also to purchase supplies for the return teams if required.

SALE BY AUCTION.

FOUR FIRST-RATE ALLOTMENTS

AT THE POINT.

TVflR. T. DOWSE has much pleasure in an ?*.*?*. nouncing a Sale by Public Auction, on

THURSDAY, THE 8TH OCTOBER NEXT.

At 12 o'clock,

ON THE GROUND,

Of Four beautiful Allotments of BUILDING GROUND, situated at Kangaroo Point-described

as under :

LOT I-A corner allotment, having a frontage to

The Allotments are well situated for business, being in the vicinity of the Salting Establishment and Public Wharf ; and when the fact is pretty well known, that a second steamer will, in a short time, be laid on between this port and Sydney, and that Kangaroo Point must, from its commanding situation, become the starting place of the opposi- tion boat,-land must, as. a natural consequence, rise immensely in value. The industrious mechanic and working, man should, therefore, not let an opportunity like this pass them for laying by their savings.

The whole of the allotment is fenced in, and is, without excep- tion, a first-rate property for an industrious man to lay out his money upon.'

QTOCKHOLDERS in the NORTHERN DISTRICTS

^ are respectfully informed that the Steaming and Salting Establishment at Kangaroo Point, Brisbane, Moreton Bay, is now in full operation, where gentlemen can have their stock converted into tallow or beef, as may,best suit their purposes, upon reasonable terms.

Stockholders on the Severn, M'Intire, and Barwin Rivers, will find it greatly to their ad- vantage to boil down their cattle at Moreton Bay, as the distance from Messrs. Dights' station, on the lower M'Intire River, does not exceed one hundred and eighty miles, along a road abounding in grass and water ; while the distance from the same station to Maitland is four hundred miles, and often deficient in both.

JOHN CAMPBELL.

Cattle or sheep, in any quantity, purchased, if good, at fair prices.

Sheep boiled down at 6d. per head. Kangaroo Point, May 25th, 1846. s

CAUTION.

"XJÍY late Servant, HENRY RALPH ELKINS, **?*?'? having refused to pay me over my money re- eved by him for the sale of my goods in my Store, and having been in consequence dismissed by me, I hereby caution the Public not to deal with, or pay any money to the said Henry Ralph Elkins on my account, the said Henry Ralph Elkins being no longer authorised to transact my

business.

South Brisbane, 2öth September, 1846.

WITHIN FIFTY MILES FROM BRISBANE. rTO parties wishing to engage in the above, by

Brisbane, 12th Sept., 1846.

TN answer to the advertisement, signed " G. S. Le * Breton, P. W. Welsh, Arbitrators," certified by " Thos. Adams, Brisbane, 28th August, 1846," in the Moreton Bay Courier, I hereby state, in spite of the over-bearing, contemptible conduct, and bounce of the said G. S. Le Breton and P. W. Welsh, to me, in my house, the~8th and 11th instant, and the " Action for Defamation," which my late servant, Henry Ralph Elkins " has in- structed his Solicitor in Sydney to commence against me," that " all the books, invoices, and other property," do not belong to the said Henry Ralph Elkins, as falsely stated by the said George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Pa tricius William Welsh, but to me, having been bought and paid for with my money,-that my late servant, the said Henry Ralph Elkins, sent the sum of £85 2s. 8d., (eighty-five pounds, two shillings, and eightpence, sterling,) my money, to his friend, William Joyner, the Clerk in the Australian General Assurance Company's Office, George-street, Sydney, the 15th and 30th June last, per steamer Tamar, for which I have never received value, or invoices, and which has never been accounted for to me by my said servant, Henry Ralph Elkins, or by the said clerk, William Joy« ner ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins received other moneys for the sale of my goods in my store, which he has never yet accounted for, to me ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins has other property of mine now in his possession ; that I now hold a promissory note, datei' Sydney, 22nd May, 1846, payable on demand, drawn by the said Henry Ralph Elkins in my favour, for the sum of £17, (seventeen pounds sterling), with ten per cent, .interest, money lent by me to the said Henry Ralph Elkins to pay the board, lodging, and. washing, &c., &c., of the said Henry Ralph Elkins, in Sydney; that several other debts are now due to me by the said Henry Ralph Elkins since the 8th April last ; the said Henry Ralph Elkins having becn clothed, fed, housed, and supported by me, from the said 8th April to the 15th July last past; that the award of the said Arbitrators, George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Patricius William Welsh, is illegal, unfair, and unjust to- wards me in every respect, and that I have com- menced legal proceedings to set it aside.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 26th Sept., 1846.

NOTICE. ,

GEORGE" SPOTTISWOODE LE BRETON, PATRICIUS

WILLIAM WELSH, ARBITRATORS.

T HEREBY give you notice; that if you do not

?? immediately deliver up to me all " the books,\ invoices, &c, Hie, detained by your desire," be- longing to me, and relating to my Store, now in your custody, possession, or power, I will institute proceedings to compel you, and to recover dam- ages for the injury I have sustained by your illegal, unprincipled, and unjust detention of my property, and the keys of my Store, for so long a period.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 26th Sept., 1846.

_i_,

JACOB CHARLES COHEN,

GEORGE-STREET, SYDNEY,

Opposite the Old Treasury,

prices.

YORK-STREET, SYDNEY.

'THOMAS MURPHY begs most respectfully to

?*. acquaint the inhabitants of the Moreton Bay District that when visiting the Metropolis they may at all times rely upon meeting with

FIRST-RATE ENTERTAINMENT,

together with civil and well-qualified attendants,

AT MODERATE CHARGES.

Dinners and Suppers for private parties pro- vided on the shortest notice, for which well-fur- nished and suitable apartments will be found in

the establishment,

T. M. takes this opportunity to acknowledge the liberal support he has received from the gen- tlemen residing in the district, and begs to assure them that he will spare neither cost nor labour to ensure the approval of those who may honour the Hotel with their company.

The wines and spirits are of first-class quality, and the stabler equal to any in.S^dneyv * -J

Dead weight, per ton . . . . . . . . . . . 1 6 Measurement goods . . . . . . . . . . .. 2 0 Pipes, butt, or puncheon .. . . . . . . . 1 0 Hogshead and quarter-cask . . . . . . 0 6 Teas and small packages . . . . . . . . 0 3

FOR HOBART TOWN DIRECT.

The Brig SKERNE, Captain

Love, immediately on her arrival from Sydney, will sail for Hobart Town with such freight as may be offered. She will return direct to Brisbane with labourers. A supercargo will proceed in her for the purpose of engaging and selecting them. The undersigned, on application, will furnish every information to parties requiring men, and will enter into the necessary engagements on

behalf of the charterer.

GEORGE WATSON,

Custom House and General Agent. North Brisbane, June 27, 1846.

IN THE INSOLVENT ESTATE OF WILLIAM

HOLMAN BERRY, LATE OF KANGAROO POINT, INNKEEPER.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN, that Clark Irving, Official Assignee of the Estate and Effects of the above-named Insolvent, has disposed of all the Assets to the undersigned.

All persons who are indebted, or who have any of the property or effects of the Insolvent, are required to pay or deliver the same to me forth-

with.

Dated this 25th day of June, 1846.

THOMAS ADAMS,

Solicitor. North Brisbane.

SALE BY AUCTION.

HOUSEHOLD FURNITURE, KITCHEN

UTENSILS, GLASS, CROCKERY, SADDLE

HORSE, BOAT, &c, &c.

MR. T. DOWSE has received instructions from

H. Wade, Esq., to sell without the least re- serve, at North Brisbane, in consequence of that gentleman being about to leave the district,

IN ABOUT A MONTH FROM THIS DATE,

some very superior Furniture, consisting of Couches, Tables, Chairs, Chests of Drawers, Glass, Crockery, Kitchen Utensils, &c.

ALSO,

A first-rate Saddle Horse, and a light-pulling boat, with oars, &c, complete.

Terms—Cash. Brisbane, 27th June, 1846

TO BE SOLD.

A PARCEL of Land in the parish of South Brisbane

Brisbane, adapted for building purposes— being allotment No. 20 in Section 1. For further particulars apply at the office of this paper.

TO BE SOLD,

AN Agricultural Farm of 47 acres, situated

within five miles of North-Brisbane, and containing some of the best land for garden and small farm produce in the district. Further par- ticulars can be obtained at the office of this paper, where the plan can be seen.

DAVID BOW begs to inform gentlemen ar- riving in Brisbane that the

" VICTORIA HOTEL"

still continues to possess those advantages, as respects attention and accommodation, that has gained him so many friends. Every effort is made to have the daily spread second to none in the District; the Wines, Spirits, &c. are war- ranted the best brands imported. The Billiard Room is fitted up so as to ensure comfort ; and civility and attention will be at all times afforded to the public patronising the Victoria.

NEW STORE,

OPPOSITE ROWLAND'S HOTEL,

S O U T H B R I S B A N E .

THE Undersigned has for Sale, ex late arrivals,

an extensive and useful assortment of goods,

viz.—

Tea Raisins

Sugar Muscatells Loaf sugar Currants Negrohead tobacco Figs

Soap Candied peel Starch Spices

Blue Pickles

Washing soda Sauces

Pitch Mustard

Rosin Candle Wick

Vinegar Composition candles Pepper Carbonate soda Bath bricks Tartaric acid

Epsom Salts and a Variety of Drugs.

Blankets Chesterfield wrapping, Rugs, shooting, and other

Moleskin coats

Tweed , Serge shirts

Calico sheeting and Guernsey ditto

shirting, Wool ditto

Unbleached calico White shirts

Bed tick Regatta shirts Union check Check ditto Jean stripe for shirts ,Twilled ditto

Brown holland, glazed Moleskin and fancy

and unglazed trowsers

Flannel Fancy vests

Diaper towelling Cabbage tree, Manilla, Navy blue and leaf hats

Fancy print dresses Women's shoes Mouseline de laine dresses Half hose

Victoria check dresses Reel cotton

Merino dresses Whited-brown, black, Coloured silk and cotton and assorted colour-

handkerchiefs ed threads

Cotton braces Buttons, tape, pins, Strong ditto Black ribbon

Men's strong boots Hooks and eyes, &c. Combs and brushes Bridles, Halters

Tooth brushes Hobble and tether ropes Nail ditto Tinware, padlocks Side combs Shot, powder, caps

Small combs Knives and scissors Small tooth combs

Shoemakers' knives, hemp, flax, nails, and materials of all kinds ; and many other articles too numerous to particularize. The whole of which having been selected with great care, and purchased for cash, will be sold, wholesale or retail, on most advantageous terms.

R. HAMPDEN.

TO BE LET OR SOLD,

ALL that plot, piece or parcel of LAND, situate at Kangaroo Point, being part of certain Government Suburban Allotments pur- chased by Sir Evan Mackenzie from the Crown, commonly known as Lot No. 2, containing a frontage to the high road of 37 feet 6 inches by a depth of 82 feet. Apply to

MICHAEL SHEEHAN,

North Brisbane ; or to JOHN OCOCK, Solicitor,

South Brisbane.

TO BE LET OR SOLD,

ALL that plot, piece or, parcel of LAND, situate at Kangaroo Point, being part of certain Government Suburban Allotments pur- chased by Sir Evan Mackenzie from the Crown, commonly known as Lot No. 3, containing a frontage to the high road of 37 feet 6 inches by a depth of 82 feet. Apply to

MICHAEL SHEEHAN,

North Brisbane ;

or to JOHN OCOCK, Solicitor,

South Brisbane.

KANGAROO POINT. TO BE LET, the Cottage lately occupied by ???? M. Cronun.

Apply to

THOMAS ADAMS,

Solicitor, Brisbane, 24th June, 1846.

ADVANCES ON PRODUCE.

THE Undersigned makes advances on Wool,

Hides, and Tallow, consigned to his cor- respondents, Messrs. P. and C. Van Notten and Co., London.

WILLIAM PICKERING.

Moreton Bay, 20th June, 1846.

WILLIAM KENT,

CHEMIST AND DRUGGIST,

QUEEN-STREET, NORTH BRISBANE,

BEGS to inform the inhabitants the District of Moreton Bay that he has always on hand a large supply of Drugs and Chemicals, of the best quality.

Physicians' Prescriptions and Family Recipes carefully prepared.

FLOUR.

1 ST. and 2nd. Flour for sale, at the lowest re- munerating price for cash, at

R. J. COLEY'S,

North Brisbane.

J. P. SMITH,

QUEEN-STREET, NORTH BRISBANE,

TIN AND IRON-PLATE WORKER,

BY MACHINERY.

The American Reflecting Oven, with every description of Tin Goods, at low prices.

Japanned, Bronzed, and Crystallized Work, Stove Pipeing, Guttering, &c, &c.

JACOB CHARLES COHEN,

GEORGE-STREET, SYDNEY,

Opposite the Old Treasury,

BEGS respectfully to inform the inhabitants of Moreton Bay that he has always on hand

an extensive and excellent assortment of Watches and Jewellery, which he can offer at reasonable

prices.

Country orders punctually attended to. All kinds of watch work and jewellery repaired at strictly moderate charges.

SPECTACLES TO SUIT ALL SIGHTS.

TOBACCO.

THE Undersigned has always on hand every

description of AMERICAN MANUFAC- TURED TOBACCO—the best selected stock in Sydney.

The only house in town for a good old Manilla cigar.

W. H. ALDIS,

Tobacco Merchant.

PETERSON'S

BRISBANE STORE .

DANIEL PETERSON will store WOOL for

any period during the Wool Season, and will Cart the same to the Wharf and ship and consign it for one shilling per Bale. He will also Store goods brought by sailing vessels (in- cluding cartage from Wharf) for one shilling and sixpence per ton per week ; A.1. vessels provided for the transit of the same to Sydney on moderate terms

N.B.—A General Assortment of Goods always on hand, and for sale, on very reasonable terms.

A D E L P H I H O T E L

YORK-STREET, SYDNEY.

THOMAS MURPHY begs most respectfully to

acquaint the inhabitants of the Moreton Bay District that when visiting the Metropolis they may at all times rely upon meeting with

FIRST-RATE ENTERTAINMENT,

together with civil and well-qualified attendants,

AT MODERATE CHARGES.

Dinners and Suppers for private parties provided on the shortest notice, for which well-fur- nished and suitable apartments will be found in

the establishment.

W. M. takes this opportunity to acknowledge the liberal support he has received from the gen- tlemen residing in the district, and begs to assure them that he will spare neither cost nor labour to ensure the approval of those who may honour the Hotel with their company.

The wines and spirits are of first-class quality, and the stables equal to any in Sydney.

NOTICE.

MR. ADAMS, Solicitor, has removed his offices to the premises adjoining the POLICE -

OFFICE.

Brisbane, 1st June, 1846

A LAD of about fourteen years of age, to be apprenticed to a Wheelwright. Apply to Alexander Macintyre, South Brisbane.

June 26, 1846.

WANTED—£70, on security of several valu-

able Buildings, situate in the Town of Brisbane, erected upon freehold ground, under

Grant from the Crown.

Application to be made to the Office of the Moreton Bay Courier. Letter X.

LITTLE AND PHELAN,

CORNER OF QUEEN AND ALBERT STREETS,

HAVE CONSTANTLY ON HAND

A GENERAL assortment of Haberdashery, Grocery, Ironmongery,

PAINTS, OILS, &c., &c.,

which they offer to the public on reasonable terms. The highest price given for Sheep-skins and

Tallow.

North Brisbane, 1st June, 1846.

THE Undersigned, in returning thanks for the liberal support he has received since he com- menced business in Brisbane, begs to inform his patrons and the public in general that he has now on hand an excellent assortment of Goods, com- prising Jockey and Hunting Whips, Bits, Spurs, Girths, Princes' Check and Kersey Saddle Cloths, Headstall and Plain Bridles, both English and Colonial; Horse Brushes, Curry and Mane Combs, Breaking Tackle, Hunting Saddles, English and

Colonial, Harness, and every other article neces- sary for either the road or the field.

RICHARD GILL,

South Brisbane.

TO PUBLICANS AND OTHERS.

THE Undersigned has constantly on Sale at his residence, South Brisbane—

RUM, BRANDY, AND GIN, of the best quality, and at the lowest possible price.

Also, R. and E. Tooth's Ale and Porter, in hhds. and barrels, at Sydney prices.

J. HARRIS.

ON SALE at the Stores of the Undersigned

Tea ,Ironmongery

Flour, Tinware

Sugar , Leather

Tobacco , Grindery Groceries , Slops

Wines , Manufactures

Spirits , Smallwares

Ale and Porter , Woolpacks and every article required on a station.

The slops and manufactures, being direct im- , ports, are offered at a moderate advance upon the English invoices.

The Hysonskin Tea is the best in the market.

Wool and Tallow taken in exchange for goods, or purchased at market prices.

WM. PICKERING. North Brisbane,

20th June, 1846.

THE Undersigned has on Sale—

Hyson Skin and Congou Tea

Manilla and Loaf Sugar

London Soap Patna Rice Negrohead Tobacco Sperm and Black Oil Brandy, "Martell's" Jamaica Rum, 16 O.P. Slops of all descriptions

EBEN. ORR,

South Brisbane.

N.B.—Hides, Tallow and Sheepskins taken in

exchange.

TO BE LET,

THE SOUTH BRISBANE HOTEL, now in

the occupation of Mr. R. Rowland. For particulars apply to

H. E. ISAAC,

Kangaroo Point.

LIVERY STABLES.

E BERKELEY begs leave to inform the

residents in Moreton Bay that he has stabling for twenty horses, and a large paddock

for the accommodation of those gentlemen who may favour him with their support. Parties visiting the settlement from Darling Downs, de- sirous of entrusting their horses to his care, will be able to do so without inconvenience, in conse- quence of the Punt being ready to convey their horses to North Brisbane at any hour of the day. No attention on his part will be wanting to merit

a continuance of their favours.

N.B.—Gentlemen requiring veterinary advice will find it to their advantage to consult E. B., as his charges are extremely moderate.

E. BERKELEY, V.S.

North Brisbane,

1st June, 1846.

articleText:
STEAM TO SYDNEY,

BY the Hunter River Steam Navigation Co.'s

Packet

TAMAR :

On THURSDAY, 24TH SEPTEMBER,

And on every alternate Thursday during the

Season.

FARES :

Saloon ..... £4 0 0 Steerage ..... 2 0 0 H. R. S. N. Co.'s Wharf,

South Brisbane.

WOOL VESSEL FOR LONDON

D I R E C T,

SHOULD sufficient encouragement be given,

the undersigned will procure a first class vessel in Sydney, to load from this Port direct to

London.

Parties requiring advances in their shipments, can receive the same on the terms usually charged in Sydney.

A list of intended shippers lies at the office of P. W. Welsh, South Brisbane ; John Richardson, North Brisbane ; Colin Campbell, Esq., Darling Downs ; Mr. Thomas Alford's, Post Office, Dar- ling Downs; and at my office, Custom House,

North Brisbane.

GEO. WATSON,

Custom House Agent.

SALE BY AUCTION.

FOUR FIRST-RATE ALLOTMENTS

AT THE POINT.

MR. T. DOWSE has much pleasure in an nouncing a Sale by Public Auction, on

THURSDAY, THE 8TH OCTOBER NEXT.

At 12 o'clock,

ON THE GROUND,

Of Four beautiful Allotments of BUILDING GROUND, situated at Kangaroo.Point-described

as under :

LOT 1-A corner allotment, having a frontage to

High-street of 40 feet, by a depth to Campbell-street of 100 feet.

LOT 2-Adjoining the above, having a similar

frontage to High-street, by a depth of

100 feet.

LOT 3-Has a frontage to Campbell-street of 65

feet, by a depth of 80 feet.

LOT 4-Adjoining Lot 3, with similar frontage

and depth.

The Allotments are well situated for business, being in the vicinity of the Salting Establishment and Public Wharf; and when the fact is pretty well known, that a second steamer will, in a short time, be laid on between this port and Sydney, and that Kangaroo Point must, from its commanding situation, become the starting place of the opposi- tion boat,-land must, as a natural consequence, rise immensely in value. The industrious mechanic and working man should, therefore, not let an opportunity like this pass them for laying by their savings.

The terms will be liberal.

SALE BY AUCTION,

TO THE INDUSTRIOUS CLASSES.

MR. DOWSE has been instructed to Sell by

Public Auction,

ON THE 8TH OCTOBER NEXT,

at the same time as the other Allotments for Sale on that day, at

KANGAROO POINT,

A neat substantial COTTAGE and GROUND, situate in Jane-street, Kangaroo Point, being Allotment No. 9, as sold at Auction by Sir Evan Mackenzie, on the 6th May last. The whole of the allotment is fenced in, and is, without excep- tion, a first-rate property for an industrious man to lay out his money upon.

Terms made known at the time of Sale.

The deed, &c, can be seen at the office of T. Adams, Esq., solicitor.

TO BE SOLD BY PUBLIC AUCTION AT

BRISBANE.

MR. T. DOWSE

WILL SELL by PUBLIC AUCTION, on

THURSDAY, THE 15TH OCTOBER,

A Herd of CATTLE, late the property of Ernest E. Dalrymple, Esq., deceased-consisting of

163 Cows

64 Heifers

4 Bulls

42 Bullocks 83 Steers

356 Head, more or less.

Calves under six months' old given in.

The above-mentioned Cattle are running at Killarney and Glen Logan, on the Station of Messrs. Walter & George Leslie, Canning Downs.

Terms-Ten per cent, cash deposit, and the remainder by an approved endorsed Bill at three months from day of sale.

The Cattle must be removed by the purchaser on or before the 15th November next.

For further particulars, apply to George F. Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

TENDERS for the erection of a COTTAGE at

Limestone, are required. The Plan may be seen at the residence of Mr. Isaac, Kangaroo Point.

NEW ROAD.

1N consequence of the splendid discovery of a new line of road from the Upper Brisbane, a large portion of the Wool and supplies for that district and the Boyne will have to be shipped at North Brisbane, the Undersigned begs to inform his friends that he has provided a large Store, capable of holding 500 bales of Wool, and is prepared to receive and ship all Goods that may be consigned to his care, at the following rates : Wool, including cartage and shipping, 1s. per

bale.

Supplies from Sydney, including cartage, 1s. 6d.

per ton per week.

G. S. LE BRETON.

WINES.

AT the STORES of the Undersigned -

Superior old Port, at 30s. per dozen

Fine rich Sherry, from 24s. to 28s. ditto

Marsella, best brand, from 16s. to 18s. ditto Best White Wine Vinegar, at 12s. ditto Good strong ditto, at 9s. ditto

Colonial Ale and Porter, at the Sydney price of

6s. 6d., with freight and expenses added Red Case Gin, White and Brown Sugar Wine Corks, best Jamaica Ginger

P. W. WELSH. Wharf, South Brisbane.

N.B.-One Shilling a dozen allowed for empty

Wine Bottles.

ALE AND PORTER.

THE Undersigned receives fresh supplies of the above, in Hogsheads and Barrels, by every opportunity.

J. HARRIS. South Brisbane, 9th Sept., 1846.

ALE.

THE Undersigned has for Sale BLAXLAND'S ALE, in twenty-gallon casks.

This Ale is well suited for the country trade, and since its introduction has been highly approved by the residents in the district.

A large stock always on hand.

DAVID BOW. Queen-street,

North Brisbane, 11th Sept., 1847.

WOOL.

THE Undersigned is authorised to make cash advances on Wool consigned to Capt. Towns, Sydney, for sale there, or shipment through him to Robert Brooks, Esq., London.

Wool washed and unwashed, Hides, and Sheep- skins, purchased. Apply at the Wharf, South

Brisbane.

P. W. WELSH.

TWENTY TONS of SECOND FLOUR for

Sale, at a small advance on the Sydney prices, at

R. J. COLEY'S,

North Brisbane.

R. J. C. begs to inform the Settlers, that he intends keeping a good stock of Second Flour always on hand-sufficient to meet any demand.

September 8th, 1846.

TWENTY POUNDS REWARD.

SLANDER.

CERTAIN malicious, libelous reports having

been circulated respecting the undersigned, he hereby offers the above reward to any person who will prove the originator ; or a reward of £10 to any person who will prove to conviction any subsequent promulgator of the said reports, which are base, malicious, and unfounded, and never existed but in the mind of some despicable

malicious villian.

JACOB GOODE.

South Brisbane, Sept. 11, 1846.

ONE POUND REWARD,

STRAYED from Kangaroo Point, a Chesnut Horse, with ball face, branded RP on near shoulder, 128 on off shoulder. The above reward will be paid to any person who will deliver him to Mr. John Stevens, Woogaroo, or the subscriber at Kangaroo Point.

JOHN CAMPBELL.

Sept. 4th, 1846.

ONE POUND REWARD.

LOST, from Cooper's Plains, a Bay Horse, black points, small star in forehead, small white snip on the nose, branded CC on the neck, S+ on the shoulder. The above reward will be paid to any person who will deliver him to

JOHN STEVENS,

Woogaroo. September 4th, 1846.

IN answer to the advertisement, signed " G. S. Le Breton, P. W. Welsh, Arbitrators," certified by "Thos. Adams, Brisbane, 28th August, 1846," in

the Moreton Bay Courier, I hereby state, in spite of the over-bearing, contemptible conduct, and bounce of the said G. S. Le Breton and P. W. Welsh, to me, in my house, the 8th and 11th instant, and the " Action for Defamation," which my late servant, Henry Ralph Elkins " has in- structed his Solicitor in Sydney to commence against me," that " all the books, invoices, and other property," do not belong to the said Henry Ralph Elkins, as falsely stated by the said George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Pa- tricius William Welsh, but to me, having been bought and paid for with my money,-that my late servant, the said Henry Ralph Elkins sent the sum of £85 2s. 8d., (eighty-five pounds, two shillings, and eightpence, sterling,) my money, to his friend, William Joyner, the Clerk in the Australian General Assurance Company's Office, George-street, Sydney, the 15th and 30th June last, per steamer Tamar, for which I have never received value, or invoices, and which has never been accounted for to me by my said servant, Henry Ralph Elkins, or by the said clerk, William Joy- ner ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins received other moneys for the sale of my goods in my store, which he has never yet accounted for to me ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins has other property of mine; now in his possession ; that I now hold a promissory note, dated Sydney, 22nd May, 1846, payable on demand, drawn by the said Henry Ralph Elkins in my favour, for the sum of £17, (seventeen pounds sterling), with ten per cent, interest, money lent by me to the said Henry Ralph Elkins to pay the board, lodging, and washing, &c, &c.,of the said Henry Ralph Elkins, in Sydney; that several other debts are now due to me by the said Henry Ralph Elkins since the 8th April last ; that the award of the said Arbitrators, George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Patricius William Welsh, is illegal, unfair, and unjust to- wards me in every respect, and that I have com- menced legal proceedings to set it aside.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 19th Sept., 1846.

NOTICE.

GEORGE SPOTTISWOODE LE BRETON, PATRICIUS

WILLIAM WELSH, ARBITRATORS.

I HEREBY give you notice, that if you do not immediately deliver up to me all " the books, invoices, &c, &c., detained by your desire," be- longing to me, and relating to my Store, now in your custody, possession, or power, I will institute proceedings to compel you, and to recover dam- ages for the injury I have sustained by your illegal, unprincipled, and unjust detention of my property, and the keys of my Store, for so long a period.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 19th Sept., 1846.

ADELPHI HOTEL,

YORK-STREET, SYDNEY.

THOMAS MURPHY begs most respectfully to

acquaint the inhabitants of the Moreton Bay District that when visiting the Metropolis they may at all times rely upon meeting with

FIRST-RATE ENTERTAINMENT,

together with civil and well-qualified attendants,

AT MODERATE CHARGES.

Dinners and Suppers for private parties pro- vided on the shortest notice, for which well-fur nished and suitable apartments will be found in

the establishment.

T. M. takes this opportunity to acknowledge the liberal support he has received from the gen- tlemen residing in the district, and begs to assure them that he will spare neither cost nor labour to ensure the approval of those who may honour the Hotel with their company.

The wines and spirits are of first-class quality, and the stables equal to any in Sydney.

TOBACCO.

THE Undersigned has always on hand every

description of AMERICAN MANUFAC- TURED TOBACCO-the best selected stock in Sydney.

*** The only house in town for a good old

Manilla cigar.

W. H. ALDIS,

Tobacco Merchant.

JACOB CHARLES COHEN,

GEORGE-STREET, SYDNEY,

Opposite the Old Treasury,

BEGS respectfully to inform the inhabitants of Moreton Bay that he has always on hand an extensive and excellent assortment of Watches and Jewellery, which he can offer at reasonable prices.

Country orders punctually attended to. All kinds of watch work and jewellery repaired at strictly moderate charges,

SPECTACLES TO SUIT ALL SIGHTS.

CAUTION.

MY late Servant, HENRY RALPH ELKINS,

having refused to pay me over my money re- ceived by him for the sale of my goods in my Store, and having been in consequence dismissed by me, I hereby caution the Public not to deal with, or pay any money to the said Henry Ralph Elkins on my account, the said Henry Ralph Elkins being no longer authorised to transact my

business,

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 19th September, 1846.

HENRY RALPH ELKINS,

I HEREBY give you notice, that if you do not immediately deliver up to me all my property, and all books, invoices, bills, receipts, letters, papers, and documents, of every sort, relating to my Store, I will take legal means to compel you.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 19th September, 1846.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

AT CANNING DOWNS,

THE following STALLIONS, the property of

Messrs. W. and G. Leslie.

KNAVE OF CLUBS-a, brown-black Horse,

standing 16 1/2 hands high, got by the thorough- bred horse Tros, (imported by H. H. Kater, Esq., in 1839) ; dam, Lady Mary (imported in 1839) by Bedlamite-her dam by Woful, grand dam by Orville, out of Trumpetta by

Trumpator.

Terms-Five Guineas a Mare.

EAGLE-a bay Horse, standing 16 hands 1 inch

high ; foaled in 1843 ; got by the thorough- bred imported horse St. George-dam by Old Whisker, her dam by Steeltrap. out of a mare by Hector.

Terms-Four Guineas a Mare.

ST. ANDREW- a roan Horse; foaled in 1841 ;

stands 15 hands 3 inches high; got by St. George-dam by Stride, her dam by Champion -g. dam by Sheik, out of an imported mare.

Terms-£2 12s. 6d. a Mare.

CONSERVATIVE- a dark-brown Horse;

foaled in 1839 ; got by Gratis-dam by Theo- rem, her dam by Cammerton-g. dam by Champion, gt. g. dam by Sheik, out of an im ported mare.

Terms-£1 2s. 6d. a Mare.

Every attention will be paid to Mares sent, but the proprietors will not hold themselves responsi-

ble tor accidents or losses.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

1846,

AT GLENGALLAN. DARLING DOWNS,

THE pure-bred imported ARAB HORSE, BEEZA.

Beeza was imported in the British Sovereign, in November, 1841, is one of the highest caste Arabs ever imported to the colony, and the winner of several races in India. His stock is much ad- mired, and allowed by competent judges to be just the style of animal for the Indian market.

Terms-£3 each Mare, and 3s. Groomage.

SAINT PATRICK,

A rich Bay, with black points, rising four years old, 16 hands high, and shows good racing points. Saint Patrick was got by the thorough-bred imported horse Saint George out of Papsteel.

Terms-£2 10s. each Mare. .

GLANCER,

A powerful dark-grey Draught Horse, got by the celebrated imported Clydesdale horse, Briton out of a favourite Hector mare. Glancer stands 16 hands high, and inherits the sound constitution and good temper of his sires ; he is well worthy the attention of breeders for draught.

Terms-£2 each Mare.

Every attention will be paid to the Mares, and large and well watered Paddocks provided, but the Proprietor will not be be responsible for any loss

or accident.

All payments to be made before the removal of

the Mares.

COLIN CAMPBELL. Glengallan, 10th July, 1846.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

THE CELEBRATED HORSE

"TOSS."

Got by the imported Horse Toss, out of a

Hector Mare.

THIS HORSE is a bright bay, with black points, rising seven years old, ascertained to be a sure foal-getter, and his stock is well known to be fit for the Indian market.

He will stand at the premises of the proprietor, C. Peacock, at Ipswich, until the 10th October.

Terms--One Mare, £2 2s. ; two or more, £1 10s. each. Payment to be made on delivery of each mare, on or before the 1st January, 1847.

A good Paddock provided, but no responsibility incurred.

articleText:
STEAM TO SYDNEY,

By the Hunter River Steam Navigation Co.'s

Packet

TAMAR

ON THURSDAY, 8TH OCTOBER,

And on every alternate Thursday during the

Season.

FARES :

Saloon. £4 0 0 Steerage. 2 0 0 H. R.S. N. Co.'s Wharf,

South Brisbane.

"EXPERIMENT."

THE STEAMER

EXPERIMENT,

A. Campbell, master, will in future leave Ipswich every

^__^___ Monday and Thursday morn ingTat 9 o'clock precisely ; and Brisbane, every Tuesday and Saturday, at the same hour, ex- cepting in cases where the arrival of the Sydney

Steamer may prevent it.

Refreshments provided on board at moderate

FOUR FIRST-RATE ALLOTMENTS

AT THE POINT.

MR. T. DOWSE has much pleasure in an-

nouncing a Sale by Public Auction, on

THURSDAY, THE 8TH OCTOBER NEXT.

At 12 o'clock,

ON THE GROUND,

Of Four beautiful Allotments of BUILDING GROUND, situated at Kangaroo Point-described^

as under :

LOT 1-A corner allotment, having a frontage to

High-street of 40 feet, by a depth to Campbell-street of 100 feet.

LOT 2-Adjoining the above, having a similar

frontage to High-slreet, by a depth of

100 feet.

LOT 3-Has a frontage to Campbell-street of 65

feet, by a depth of 80 teet.

LOT 4-Adjoining Lot 3, with similar frontage

and depth.

The Allotments are well situated for business, being in the vicinity of the Salting Establishment and Public Wharf ; and when the fact is pretty well known, that a second steamer will, in a short time, be kid on between this port and Sydney, and that Kangaroo Point must, horn its commanding situation, become the starting pkco of the opposi- tion boat,-land must, as a natural consequence, rise immensely in value. The industiious mechanic and working man should, therefore, not let an opportunity like this pass them for laying by their savings.

The terms will be liberal.

IN answer to the advertisement, signed * G. S. Le Breton, P. W. Welsh, Arbitrators," certified by "Thos. Adams,Brisbane,28th August, 1846," in the Moreton Bay Courier, I hereby state, in spite of the over-bearing, contemptible conduct, and bounce of the said G. S. Le Breton and P. W. Welsh, to me, in my house, the 8th and 11th ultimo, and the " Action for Defamation," which my late servant, Henry Ralph Elkins "has in- structed his Solicitor in Sydney to commence against me," that " all the books, invoices, and other property," do not belong to the said Henry Ralph Elkins, as falsely stated by the said George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Pa-» tricius William Welsh, but to me, having been bought and paid for with my money,-that my late servant, the said Henry Ralph Elkins, sent the sum of £85 2s. 8d., (eighty-five pounds, two shillings, and eightpence, sterling,) my money, to his friend, William Joyner, the Clerk in the Australian General Assurance Company's Office, George-street, Sydney, the 15th and 30th June last, per steamer Tamar, for which I have never received value, or invoices, and which has never been accounted for to me by my said servant, Henry Ralph Elkins, or by the said clerk, William Joy ner ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins received other moneys for the sale of my goods in my store, which he has never yet accounted for to me ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins has other property of mine now in his possession ; that I now hold a promissory note, dated Sydney, 22nd May, 1846, payable on demand, drawn by the said Henry Ralph Elkins in my favour, for the sum of £17, (seventeen pounds sterling), with ten per cent, interest, money lent by me to the said Henry Ralph Elkins to pay the board, lodging, and

washing, &c, &c.,of the said Henry Ralph Elkins, in Sydney; that several other debts are now due to me by the said Henry Ralph Elkins since the 8th April last ; the said Henry Ralph Elkins having been clothed, fed, housed, and supported by me, from the said 8th April to the 15th July last past ; that the award of the said Arbitrators, George Spottiswoode Le Breton, and Patricius William Welsh, is illegal, unfair, and unjust to

wards-tne in every respect, and that I have com menced legal proceedings to put it aside.

R.HAMPDEN, South Brisbane, Oct. 3, 1846

NOTICE.

GEORGE SPOTTISWOODE LE BRETON, PATRICIUS

WILLIAM WELSH, ARBITRATORS.

I HEREBY give you notice, that if you do not immediately deliver up to me all " the books, invoices, &c, &c, detained by your desire," be longing to me, and relating to my Store, now in your custody, possession, or power, I will institute proceedings to compel you, and to recover dam- ages for the injury I have sustained by your illegal, unprincipled, and unjust detention of my property, and the keys of my Store, for so long a

period.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, Oct. 3, 1845.

By Toss out of Penelope.

TV/TENTOR is a Bay with black points, >and a ?*-*.?. sure foal getter. His performances on the Turf are too well known to need any lengthened description, he having beaten the crack horses of the day, viz., Jorrocks, Blue Bonnet, Thn Colonel, Zephyrine, &c.

Terms-One Mare, £3 10s. ; three Mares, £3

each.

Every attention paid to Mares, but no respon- sibility incurred.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

THE CELEBRATED HORSE

«TOSS."

Got by the imported Horse Toss, out of s ,

Hector Mare.

'THIS HORSE is a bright bay, with black

* points, rising seven years old, ascertained to be a sure foal-getter, and his stock is well known

to be fit for the Indian market.

He will stand at the premises of the proprietor, C. Peacock, at Ipswich, until the 10th October.

Terms-One Mare, £2 2s. ; two or more, £1 10s. each. Payment to be made on delivery of each mare, on or before the 1st Jauuary, 1847.

A good Paddock provided, but no responsibility

incurred.

TO STAND,

AT THE MESSRS. BIGGES STATION,

BRISBANE RIVER,

THE THOROUGH - BRED HORSE 1 CAIN.

Cain by Vagabond, out of Cuttysark (imported by Captain Lamb) by Oxford, out of a Fidget mare. Fidget by Florizel, out of a Matchem

mare.

Vagabond by Cain, out of Gabrielle by Parti zan, her dam Coquette by Dick Andrews, by Joe Andrews by Eclipse.

Terms--£3 3s. each Mare,-a reduction made on three Mares and upwards.

large and well-watered Paddocks provided, but no responsibility incurred , r'[
heading: Classified Advertising
