articleText:
STEAMER "EXPERIMENT."

SHIPPERS of GOODS by the Experiment to Ipswich, are informed that all Freights must in future be paid prior to being received on board.

ROBERT GRAHAM & CO..,

Agents.

Brisbane, 18th Dec, 1846.

ON SALE by the undersigned, FINE FLOUR,

at moderate prices.

EBEN. ORR. South Brisbane, Nov. 28, 1846.

CAUTION.

THE PUBLIC are cautioned against hiring or

harbouring the undermentioned, he having absconded from my Station ten days ago :-

Name-RICHARD NASH ; height-about 5 feet 8 inches ; complexion-sallow ; long sharp nose, and bald head. He has got a discharge, signed by Mr. Deuchar, dated about six months

ago.

WILLIAM TURNER,

15th December, 1846. Tarome.

NOTICE.

THE undermentioned ORDERS having been

STOLEN, all parties are cautioned against

receiving them :-

J. M. Andrew, favour Harrington, on R. Camp-

bell,- £1 10s.

W. and G. Leslie, favour Fox, on Bank of Aus-

tralasia-£3.

Pitts and Bonifant, favour McDowall, on R.

Graham-£5.

Mackay, favour Wilkins, on Mackay-£3 3s.

Payment has been stopped, and a Reward of Five Shillings in the Pound will be paid by the undersigned on their being restored.

G. S. LE BRETON.

NOTICE.

A BAY HORSE, with Black Points, branded GR with LL over, is now astray on my Station, and will be delivered to the owner on his paying for this advertisement.

JOHN ROSS.

Rose-Valley, 18th Dec, 1846.

NOTICE.

ALL persons are hereby cautioned against purchasing certain Allotments in the Town of IPSWICH and its vicinity, the undersigned having bought the same from Mr. Edward Lord, in July, 1845. The property consists of one tow n and two suburban allotments, for which cash was paid by

JOHN ROSS.

Rose Valley, 18th Dec, 1846.

NOTICE is hereby Given, that the Undersigned will not be responsible for any Debts con- tracted on account of .the Steamer Experiment, ?excepting by the written authority of

ROBERT GRAHAM & CO.,

Agents. J. C. PEARCE.

Owner.

Brisbane, 7th Dec., 1846.

THE PARTNERSHIP subsisting between George Little and Richard Fitz Gerald

Phelan, of North Brisbane, under the firm of Little and Phelan, is from this date dissolved.

The business will be wound up by Mr. Phelan, who is authorised to receive the amount of all debts due to the above Firm, and who will dis- charge all claims against the same.

All persons indebted to the said Firm will please pay their accounts before the commencement of the new year.

RICHARD F. G. PHELAN. Dated, Brisbane, 1st. December, 1846.

TO BE SOLD BY PRIVATE CONTRACT. A VERY CAPITAL COTTAGE, at Kangaroo

Point. Apply to

D. BOW.

Victoria Hotel. North Brisbane, Dec. 12, 1846.

TO BUILDERS.

TENDERS are required for BUILDING a

COTTAGE in North Brisbane. Plans and specifications to be seen at Wright's Hotel.

ROBERT LITTLE,

18th Dec, 1846. Solicitor.

TO BUILDERS.

TENDERS are required for building a Cottage. Plans and specifications can be seen at the

office of

MR. OCOCK,

Solicitor.

South Brisbane, 11th Dec, 1846.

N0T1CE is hereby Given, that ROBERT COULSON, of Kingbah, in the District of Moreton Bay, in the Colony of New South Wales, hath, by Deed of Assignment, duly executed, assigned, and made over, all his Stock of Sheep, Cattle, and Horses, at present, depasturing at Kingbah, together with the right of Station there- at, and all other his personal property whatsoever, (except as by said Deed is excepted), to John Rankin and John Cameron, both of Fassifern, in the district and colony aforesaid, Trustees, in trust for the purposes in said Deed mentioned.

Dated this 10th day of December, 1846.

WITH reference to an advertisement which appeared in the Moreton Bay Courier of

Saturday, December the 12th instant, notifying that Robert Coulson, of Kingbah, had assigned and made over all his stock of Sheep, Cattle, and Horses at present depasturing at Kingbah, to- gether with the right of Station thereat, and all other his personal property whatsoever (except as by said deed is excepted) : NOW I, the under- signed Robert Coulson, being the person alluded to, beg to observe that I have not assigned over

all my stock of Sheep, but have reserved sufficient to form a new Station, which I intend to do im- mediately. As witness my hand, this 17th day of December, 1846.

ROBERT COULSON. Witness,

Thomas Adams,

Attorney, Brisbane.

FOR SALE,

THE CARGO of FLOUR, ex Ann, from

Sydney, consisting of

Fine and Seconds

Van Diemen's Land Oats Maize Bran

Pickles

Sauces

Mustard

Tea Rum

Cigars, &c, &c. Apply to

ROBERT GRAHAM & CO. North and South Brisbane.

FOR SALE, by the Undersigned, a few Tons

DAIRY and LIVERPOOL SALTS.

P. D. PRANKERD.

Boiling House,

Kangaroo Point, Dec. 18, 1846.

CATTLE, SHEEP, AND A SELBY

MARE,

FOR SALE, BY PRIVATE CONTRACT.

THE Undersigned has received instructions

from the Proprietor to dispose of the under- mentioned Stock, in charge of Major North, J.P., at his Station, on the Brisbane River, viz., as per muster, 25th March last :-

430 Ewes-have now lambs by their side 133 Two-year old

232 Weaned Lambs

5 Rams

800 Fine woolled ; warranted sound, and -- never to have been diseased.

The purchaser to be entitled lo half wool and

half increase.

96 Cows-nearly all broken to bail

49 Heifers

57 Bullocks 32 Steers

12 Male Calves

5 Female ditto 2 Bulls

253 Head. All the Cattle, are quiet and well - bred, and branded with the figure of

a Bell.

1 Selby Mare, four years old-stinted. For further particulars, enquire of

P. D. PRANKERD. Boiling House,

Kangaroo Point, Dec. 18. 1846.

TO THE WOOL-GROWERS

IN THE MORETON BAY DISTRICT.

THE Undersigned begs to inform his friends,

and the Wool-growers generally, that he is prepared this season to assort and repack Wool, suitable for the London and Liverpool Markets.

Parties shearing in the grease, can be accom- modated by having their Wool assorted and hand cashed ; and samples may be seen by applying to

WM. CARTER,

Kangaroo Point. TO WOOL-GROWERS and STOREKEEPERS.

THE undersigned is empowered to make Cash

Advances on Wool, consigned to the House of Messrs. Evans, Brothers, London ; or in his capacity of Wool Broker and General Agent, will obtain the highest market rates in Sydney, if entrusted to him for Sale, and effect prompt returns faithfully in cash, or supplies, as required. Commission charge, 1 1/2 per cent.

B. S. LLOYD

10, Bridge-street, .Sydney.

SALE BY PUBLIC AUCTION.

TO GRAZIERS, DAIRYMEN, and OTHERS,

IMPORTANT SALE OF

THOROUGH-BRED CATTLE. MR. T. DOWSE

HAS much pleasure in informing the Stock holders of these districts, that he has been instructed to submit to Public,Auction, at the Victoria Hotel, Brisbane,

On the 18th JANUARY NEXT,

At 12 o'clock,

All the under-mentioned PURE BRED STOCK,

viz. :

CANOVA-Light roan Bull ; calved June 3rd, 1840 ; bred by Earl Spencer. Imported in De- cember, 1841. Sire-Roman (2561) ; Dam-Earl Spencer's No. 25, (vol. 3, page 538, the dam by Wiseton, 8cc),by Richard (1376), dam by Jupi- ter (342), g. g. dam by Charles (127), g. g. g. dam by Windsor (698), g. g. g. g. dam by Chil- ton (136), g.g g. g. g. by Colonel, This Bull is of Lord Spencer's best breed.

KEIGHLEY-Red and white Bull; calved

Dec 30th, 1840 ; bred by J. Parkinson, Esq., Newark. Imported in December, 1841. Sire Mowthorpe (2343) ; Dam-Kersey * by Rinaldo (a son of Norfolk, 2377, from Mr. Whittaker's Robina), g. dam Kitty Fisher t by Favourite

(1028), from Clio by Crispin (174), g. g. dam by Margaret (392), g. g. g. dam by Fisher's red

bull (2022), g. g. g. g. dam by Purnell's red bull

(1536), g. g. g. g. g. dam by Foster's bull (2031).

CRESSBROOK-White and red Bull ; calved Feb. 1, 1843; bred by D. C. McConnel, Esq., Brisbane River. Dam-Crocus, imported cow, described below; Sire-Tallyho, imported Dec, 1841, got by Don John ‡ dam Princetta § (vol. 3, page 547) by Prince William (1344), g. dam Priscilla by Corinthian Tom (921)* g. g. dam Princess by Young Pilot (497), g. g. g. dam Venus by Constellation (l63), g. g. g. g. dam Nancy by Alfred (23), g. g. g. g. g. dam by Windsor (698), g. g. g. g. g. g. dam by Cupid (177), g. g. g. g. g. g. g. dam by Mr. Baker's bull of Layton.

ROVER-Large roan Bull ; calved May, 1839 ; bred by the Australian Agricultural Company.

ALBERT-Rod and white Bull ; calved May, 1841 ; bred by R. and H. Scott, Glendon. Sire - Wetherall ; Dam-Annie. Both imported.

THE MILLER-White Bull ; calved July, 1841 ; bred by R. and H Scott, Glendon. Sire - Wetherall ; Dam-Mermaid. Both imported.

LAUREL-Light roan Bull; calved Sept., 1841 ; bred by R. and H. Scott, Glendon. Sire Wetherall ; Dam-Lily. Both imported.

SALADIN-Red roan and white Bull ; calved March, 1845 ; bred by D. and F. McConnel, Brisbane River. Sire - Keighley, mentioned above ; Dim-Rose, mentioned below.

CROCUS-White and Rod Cow ; calved May 3rd, 1840 ; bred by J. Parkinson, Esq , Newark. Imported Dec, 1841. Sire-Cossack || (1880) ; Dam-Columbine by Prince Cornet ¶ (1342), g. dam by Cornet (170), g. g. by Constellation (163). g. g. g. dam by Major (397), g. g. g. g. dam by Prince of Waterloo (528), &c. Crocus is now in calf to The Miller, mentioned above.

ALSTRAL1A-Strawberry Heifer; calved Dec. 10th, 1843 ; bred by D and F. McConnel. Bris- bane River. Sire-Keighley ; Dam-Crocus, described above. This heifer is in calf to The Miller.

DAISY-White and red Heifer ; calved May 1st, 1846 ; bred by D. and F. McConnel, Brisbane River. Sire-The Miller; Dam-Crocus, described

above.

VIRGINIA-Red Heifer; calved Feb. 27, 1842 ; bred by H. H. Kater, Esq., Wellington Sire-Frederick, a roan bull, imported per Lady Macnaughten in 1841 : his dam, Old Martha by Thomson's bull, son of North Star (151), dam by Sir Joseph, by Major Rudd's Sir Peter (vol. 1) ; g. dam by Coate's bull, bred by C. Collins, Esq. Frederick was got by Mr. John Chapman's bull of Norton, a descendant of Old Wellington. Dam Gaiety by Caliph (1774), dam by Sir Walter (2637), g. dam by Hotspur (1117), g. g. dam by Midas (435). Imported in 1841.

GRACE-White Cow; Calved March, 1842 ; bred by H. H. Kater, Esq., Wellington. Sire - Young Pirate ; Dam-Modesty by Sir Charles (E), g. dam by Pirate (500), g. g. dam by Mr. Husband's bull of Rock Castle, g. g. g. dam by Mr. Charge's bull, son of Cornet, g. g. g g. dam by Ledberry (1424). Imported per Mary Ban- natyne, 1841. In calf now to Rodorie, whose sire is Tallyho, and dam Crocus, described above.

ROSE-Red and white Cow ; calved April 2nd, 1842 ; bred by H. H. Kater, Esq, Wellington. Sire-Windsor ; Dam, Juliet ; bred by Mr. Wil-

* Kersey took the premium at the Ollerton Show, in 1839, as the best two-year-old heifer.

† Kitty Fisher took the premium as the best Milch Cow at the Chesterfield Show, in 1835; the premium as the best Milch Cow at the Nottingham Show, in 1838 ; the silver medal at the Ollerton Show, in 1839, as the best beast there shown ; the premium at the Nottingham Show, in 1839, as the best fat cow; and also a premium at the Smithfield Club Show, Lon- don, 1839. Maria, the dam of Mowthorpe, is the dam of Rockingham (2550), for which 300 guineas was refused, and of Gauth'orpe (2049), which sold for 100 guineas when nine year old ; he is the sire of Malibran, sold for 300 guineas.

‡ Don John (bred by Mr. Oatley) by Pluto (2433), dam Carnation by Bedford Junior (1701), g. dam Pink by Isaac (1129), g. g. dam Carna- tion by Young Jupiter (1145), g. g, g. dam by White Cornet (1583), g. g. g. g. dam Young Rose by Mr. Wright's grandson of Favourite, g. g. g. g. g. dam by Charge's grey bull (872).

§ Princetta, the dam of Hazlewood, sold for 100 guineas, and of Dalrymple, the winner of a pre- mium at the Otly Show, and of a premium and sweepstakes at the Wetherby Show, 1840, as the best yearling.

Cossack took the premium as the best bull at the following shows:-Lincoln, 1836 ; Ollerton, 1838; Ollerton and Retford, 1840. He is the sire of Clementi and Collard, which were sold for 200 guineas each when under one year old.

¶ Prince Cornet is very nearly related to Fair- fax (the sire of Miss Fairfax), the winner of the premium for the best bull at Leeds, 1839 ; and Miss Fairfax is the dam of the celebrated bull, Sir Thomas Fairfax, the winner of seven premi- ums, and was never beaten.

son, of Althorne, and imported per Alfred, Jan.,

1841. Rose is now in calf to Roderic.

LADY EMILY -Red and white Cow ; carved April 7th, 1842 ; bred by H. H. Kater, Esq., Wellington. Sire-Windsor ; Dam-Peeress by Eclipse, g. dam Phobe (500), by Memnon (135), g. g. dam by Wonderful (700). Memnon won the head prize at Manchester, Liverpool, and three other places, in one year. He was bred by Thos. Harrison, Esq., Stut House, Durham. Eclipse by Highflier (16), dam by Blucher (page 25). Peeress was imported per Resource, 1841. Lady Emily is now in calf to Roderic.

CONSTANCY-Heifer, red roan ; calved Jan. 23rd, 1845 ; bred by D. and F, McConnel, Bris- bane River. Sire-Tallyho ; Dam-Grace.

ZOE-Strawberry Heifer; calved March 31st, 1845; bred by D. and F. McConnel, Brisbane River. Sire-Keighley; Dam-Lady Emily.

MODESTY-Roan and white Heifer ; calved Dec 23rd, 1845 ; bred by D. and F. McConnel, Brisbane River. Sire-The Miller; Dam-Grace.

VIOLET-Roan or Strawberry Heifer ; calved March, 1846 ; bred by D. and F. McConnel, Brisbane River. Sire-Tallyho ; Dam-Rose.

COUNTESS-Roan Heifer ; calved June, 1846 ; bred by D. and F. McConnel, Brisbane River. Sire-The Miller ; Dam-Lady Emily,

The whole of the above are pure bred Cattle, and are in excellent condition, and can be seen by applying to H. Mort, Esq., Cressbrook, Brisbane

River.

ALSO,

A ROAN BULL, three-parts bred, 18 months'

old.

SALE BY AUCTION.

MR. DOWSE

WILL SELL by Public Auction, at the

POST OFFICE, Brisbane,

On WEDNESDAY NEXT,

Immediately after the Sale of the Ferries on that

day,

A double-barrelled FOWLING PIECE, and sundry articles of WEARING APPAREL, the property of the late H. Moon.

MR. T. DOWSE.

WILL Sell by Public Auction, at his Rooms, Queen-street,

On the 4th of JANUARY next,

At 12 o'clock,

An Allotment of LAND, situate at Kangaroo Point, adjoining Hobson's (fenced) Allotment and Well, having a frontage of 50 feet by a depth of

100 feet

Terms at Sale.

WANTED

TO PURCHASE, a small Allotment of Ground, having a frontage to Queen-street, for which ready money will be paid. Apply at the office of this journal.

North Brisbane, 10th Dec , 1846.

FOR SALE,

SEVERAL Allotments of LAND, at South, Brisbane. Terms liberal. Apply to

MR. OCOCK,

Solicitor. South Brisbane.

ON SALE- MARTELL'S BRANDY Jamaica Rum

Gin, in 4 gallon cases

Port Wine, in 3 dozen eases Sherry, in 3 dozen cases Ditto, in draught

Champagne, in 1 dozen cases

Byass Ale } in 3 dozen cases

Lewtas' Porter, }

Ale and Porter, in hhds. and barrels.

J. HARRIS,

South Brisbane.

TO THE SETTLERS, STOREKEEPERS.

AND PUBLIC GENERALLY,

IN THE DISTRICT OF MORETON BAY;

DAVID JONES AND CO. beg to apprise

their numerous friends, and the public generally, in the district of Moreton Bay, that that their stock of Slops and General Clothing having lately been increased by several large importations, is at present replete with every article required, both for the bush and private

families.

Settlers and others are reminded that the Slops, Clothing, &c, which are made in England ex- pressly to Messrs. Jones' orders, are of a quality and workmanship infinitely superior to those generally sold in this market.

Subjoined is a partial list of Slops, &c, with the prices attached. The public will please to observe, that the prices of such articles only as can be recommended are quoted-inferior qualities can be

obtained :- . *'* n

Moleskin Trowsers and Jackets Ditto Strapped ditto Worsted Cord ditto

Scotch Twilled Shirts

Regatta ditto

Ditto superior ditto, got up in boxes of 1 dozen

each for gents.

Striped Cotton Shirts

Guernsey and Yarn Frocks Shepherd's and Stockmen's Great Coats Pea and Monkey Jackets

Silk, Plush, and Scarlet-sleeved Vesta

Light and Dark Vests of all qualities

Silk and Cotton Handkerchiefs Ticking and Osnaburgh

Diaper Rugs

Coloured Counterpanes Manila, Cabbage-tree, and other Hats, from 2s.

and upwards Stockmen's Boots, &c, &c.

D. J. and Co. would particularly direct the attention of purchasers to their stock of Yorkshire, Witney, and Army Blankets, in all sizes, from

7s. 4d. to 12s. 4d.

GENERAL DRAPERY and FANCY GOODS. * Under this head will be found every article re- quired for family and domestic use ; and none but the best fabrics are offered. Ladies who have

not visited Sydney lately, will be surprised at the extent, variety, and elegance, of the Stock com-

prised in these departments.

George-street, Sydney.
heading: Classified Advertising
title: {'id': '14', 'value': 'The Moreton Bay Courier (Brisbane, Qld. : 1846 - 1861)'}

articleText:
STEAM TO SYDNEY,

BY the Hunter River Steam Navigation Co.'s

Packet

TAMAR:

ON THURSDAY, 22nd OCTOBER,

And on every alternate Thursday during the

Season.

FARES :

Saloon. £4 0 0 Steerage. 2 0 0. H. R. S. N. Co.'s Wharf,

South Brisbane.

STEAMER "EXPERIMENT."

THE Proprietor begs to inform his friends and

the public, that in future he finds it necessary to make up the accounts for freight monthly, instead of quarterly as heretofore ; and that an early adjustment of them is essentially necessary to the continuance of the vessel in the trade.

Brisbane, 9th Oct., 1846.

WOOL VESSEL FOR LONDON

DIRECT.

SHOULD sufficient encouragement be given, the undersigned will procure a first class vessel in Sydney, to load from this Port direct to

London.

Parties requiring advances in their shipments, can receive the same on the terms usually charged in Sydney.

A list of intended shippers lies at the office of P. W. Welsh, South Brisbane ; John Richardson, North Brisbane ; Colin Campbell, Esq., Darling Downs ; Mr. Thomas Alford's, Post Office, Dar- ling Downs ; and at my office, Custom House,

North Brisbane.

GEO. WATSON,

Custom House Agent.

TO BE SOLD BY PRIVATE BARGAIN.

'THE following HORSE STOCK, late the pro-

perty of Ernest E. Dalrymple, Esq., de-

ceased—

9 Mares

1 Gelding

1 Colt, rising 3 years old 3 Colts, " 2 " " 2 Fillies, " 2 " "

2 Colts, " 1 " " 1 Filly, " 1 " "

19 Head.

The above-mentioned Horses are mostly the produce of first-rate mares by thorough-bred horses, and are now running on the Station of Messrs. Walter and George Leslie, Canning

Downs.

The mares are in foal to thorough-bred horses. For further particulars apply to George F. Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

BRICKS.

IN consequence of the inconvenience and useless expense I have been put to in not being able to purchase Bricks in North Brisbane, when in want of them, and seeing no parties likely to open a Brickyard to supply the public generally, I beg to inform the public that I have opened a Brickyard, and shall be very happy to supply parties wanting Bricks or Paving Tiles, in lots from 100 to

100,000.

D. SKYRING,

Bricklayer. Brickfield-hill, North Brisbane.

CAUTION,

THE public are hereby cautioned against hiring

WILLIAM BARCKLEY, he having ab- sconded from my hired service on the 22nd of September last.

WILLIAM BARKER. Logan River, 5th Oct. 1846.

TO POLICEMEN, CONSTABLES & OTHERS,

£2 REWARD.

THE following individuals having absconded

from my Station, the above reward will be given to any Policeman or Constable who shall lodge them in the lock-up, either at Darling Downs or Brisbane ; and all parties are hereby cautioned against hiring or harbouring them warrants having been granted for their appre-

hension, viz. :

JOHN JONES, hired for six months, on the 8th September, 1846 ; absconded on Friday night, the 2nd October ; a short man, with freckled face and hands, talks very fine-brought a cha- racter from John McNab, Mount Macedon, Port Phillip.

JOSEPH JENKINS, hired on the 27th August, 1846, for six months, absconded on the night of Wednesday, the 30th September-rather thick- set, about 5 feet 8 inches high, or more.

J. C. PEARCE.

Helidon, Lockyer's Creek,

October 1, 1846.

CAUTION.

MY late Servant, HENRY RALPH ELKINS, having refused to pay me over my money received by him for the sale of my goods in my Store, and having been in consequence dismissed by me, I hereby caution the Public not to deal with, or pay any money to the said Henry Ralph Elkins on my account, the said Henry Ralph Elkins being no longer authorised to transact my

business.

R. HAMPDEN. South Brisbane, 17th October, 1846.

TO LET,

A WEATHER - BOARDED VERANDAH COTTAGE, pleasantly situated on the bauk of the River, at Kangaroo Point, and containing Six Rooms, in an excellent state of repair, with plenty of back ground attached, part of which is enclosed as a Garden. There are also a Fowl- house, temporary Stockyard, &c, on the premises, and the rent, to a good tenant, will be extremely

small.

Apply at the Stores of the undersigned.

G. S. LE BRETON.

North Brisbane, Sept. 19, 1846.

NEW ROAD.

IN consequence of the splendid discovery of a new line of road from the Upper Brisbane, a large portion of the Wool and supplies for that district and the Boyne will have to be shipped at North Brisbane, the Undersigned begs to inform his friends that he has provided a large Store, capable of holding 500 bales of Wool, and is prepared to receive and ship all Goods that may be consigned to his care, at the following rates : Wool, including cartage and shipping, 1s. per

bale.

Supplies from Sydney, including cartage, 1s. 6d.

per ton per week.

G. S. LE BRETON.

WINES.

AT the STORES of the Undersigned Superior old Port, at 30s. per dozen Pine rich Sherry, from 24s. to 28s. ditto

Marsella, best brand, from 16s. to 18s. ditto Best White Wine Vinegar, at 12s. ditto Good strong ditto, at 9s. ditto

Colonial Ale and Porter, at the Sydney price of

6s. 6d., with freight and expenses added Red Case Gin, White and Brown Sugar Wine Corks, best Jamaica Ginger

P. W. WELSH. Wharf, South Brisbane.

N.B.-One Shilling a dozen allowed for empty

Wine Bottles.

WOOL.

THE Undersigned is authorised to make cash

advances on Wool consigned to Capt. Towns,

Sydney, for sale there, or shipment through him to Robert Brooks, Esq., London.

Wool, washed and unwashed, Hides, and Sheep- | skins, purchased. Apply at the Wharf, South

Brisbane.

P. W. WELSH.

ALE.

THE Undersigned has for Sale BLAXLANDS

ALE, in twenty-gallon casks.

This Ale is well suited for the country trade, and since its introduction has been highly approved by the residents in the district.

Orders punctually attended to on the arrival of

each steamer.

DAVID BOW. Queen-street,

North Brisbane, 11th Sept., 1847.

ALE AND PORTER.

THE Undersigned receives fresh supplies of the above, in Hogsheads and Barrels, by every opportunity.

J. HARRIS.

South Brisbane 9th Sept., 1846.

TO THE WOOL-GROWERS IN THE

MORETON BAY DISTRICT.

THE Undersigned begs to inform his friends,

and the Wool-growers generally, that he is prepared this season to assort and repack Wool, suitable for the London and Liverpool Markets.

Parties shearing in the grease, can be acommo dated by having their Wool assorted and hand- washed ; and samples may be seen by applying to

WM. CARTER,

Kangaroo Point.

JOHN SMITH,

BELL-STREET, IPSWICH,

GENERAL STORE,

TAKES the earliest opportunity afforded by the establishment of a local newspaper to thank his friends and the public generally for the liberal support he has been favoured with ; and to ap- prise them that the prices of articles at his store will be such as to give satisfaction, and cause recommendation. A large assortment of Slops and Groceries always on hand. Orders from the nterior punctually attended to.

IN answer to the advertisement, signed " G. S. Le A Breton, P. W. Welsh, Arbitrators," certified by " Thos. Adams, Brisbane, 28th August, 1846," in the Moreton Bay Courier, I hereby state, in spite of the over-bearing, contemptible conduct, and bounce of the said G. S. Le Breton and P. W. Welsh, to me, in my house, the 8th and 11th ultimo, and the " Action for Defamation," which my late servant, Henry Ralph Elkins " has in- structed his Solicitor in Sydney to commence against me," that " all the books, invoices, and other property," do not belong to the said Henry Ralph Elkins, as falsely stated by the said George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Pa tricius William Welsh, but to me, having been bought and paid for with my money,-that my late servant, the said Henry Ralph Elkins, sent the sum of £85 2s. 8d., (eighty-five pounds, two shillings, and eightpence, sterling,) my money, to his friend, William Joyner, the Clerk in the Australian General Assurance Company's Office, George-street, Sydney, the 15th and 30th June last, per steamer Tamar, for which I have never received value, or invoices, and which has never been accounted for to me by my said servant, Henry Ralph Elkins, or by the said clerk, William Joy- ner ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins received other moneys for the sale of my goods in my store, which he has never yet accounted for to me ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins has other property of mine now in his possession ; that I now hold a promissory note, dated Sydney, 22nd May, 1846, payable on demand, drawn by the said Henry Ralph Elkins in my favour, for the sum of £17, (seventeen pounds sterling), with ten per cent, interest, money lent by me to the said Henry Ralph Elkins to pay the board, lodging, and washing, &c., &c., of the said Henry Ralph Elkins, in Sydney; that several other debts are now due to me by the said Henry Ralph Elkins since the 8th April last ; the said Henry Ralph Elkins having been clothed, fed, housed, and supported by me, from the said 8th April to the 15th July last past; that the award of the said Arbitrators, George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Patricius William Welsh, is illegal, unfair, and unjust to- wards me in every respect, and that I have com- menced legal proceedings to set it aside.

R. HAMPDEN. South Brisbane, 17th October, 1846.

FOR SALE, .

SECOND FLOUR, in any quantity,

at the SYDNEY PRICE, at

R. J, COLEY'S. North Brisbane, Oct. 10, 1846.

TO THE SETTLERS, STOREKEEPERS,

AND PUBLIC GENERALLY,

IN THE DISTRICT OF MORETON BAY.

DAVID JONES AND CO. beg to apprise their numerous friends, and the public generally, in the district of Moreton Bay, that that their stock of Slops and General Clothing having lately been increased by several large importations, is at present replete with every article required, both for the bush and private

families.

Settlers and others are reminded that the Slops, Clothing, &c, which are made in England ex- pressly to Messrs. Jones' orders, are of a quality and workmanship infinitely superior to those generally sold in this market.

Subjoined is a partial list of Slops, &c, with the prices attached. The public will please to observe, that the prices of such articles only as can be recommended are quoted- inferior qualities can be

obtained :

Moleskin Trovvsers and Jackets Ditto Strapped ditto

Worsted Cord ditto

Scotch Twilled Shirts Regatta ditto

Ditto superior ditto, got up in boxes of 1 dozen

each for gents.

Striped Cotton Shirts

Guernsey and Yarn Frocks

Shepherd's and Stockmen's Great Coats Pea and Monkey Jackets

Silk, Plush, and Scarlet-sleeved Vests Light and Dark Vests of all qualities

Silk and Cotton Handkerchiefs Ticking and Osnaburgh Diaper Rugs

Coloured Counterpanes

Manila, Cabbage-tree, and other Hats, from 2s.

and upwards

Stockmen's Boots, &c, &c.

D. J. and Co. would particularly direct the attention of purchasers to their stock of Yorkshire, Witney, and Army Blankets, in all sizes, from

7s. 4d. to 12s. 4d.

GENERAL DRAPERY AND FANCY GOODS

Under this head will be found every article re- quired for family and domestic use ; and none but the best fabrics are offered. Ladies who have not visited Sydney lately, will be surprised at the extent, variety, and elegance, of the Stock com- prised in these departments.

George-street, Sydney.

TO THE SETTLERS IN THE DISTRICT OF

MORETON BAY.

MR. MORT'S PRODUCE SALES. MR. MORT

BEGS to inform the Woolgrowers, Merchants, and others of the colony interested in the Sale of Wool, Tallow, &c, that he intends, during the ensuing season, to hold Auction Sales of

Produce

EVERY WEDNESDAY AND SATURDAY, in lieu of Saturday only, as heretofore.

In soliciting a continuance of the support which his weekly sales have received, Mr. Mort would call attention to the very low scale of charges now adopted, and further to the fact, that from the competition created by the attendance of all classes of buyers, this mode of sale possesses advantages over any other, and at all times ensures the ex- treme market rates of the day ; besides enabling the settler to close his transactions on an average within twenty-four hours of the arrival of his

Wool and Tallow.

The Stores at the rear of the Rooms, will be always open to receive produce, but Wool intended for Wednesday's sale must be delivered on or be- fore Tuesday, and that for Saturday not later than Friday, in order to give proper time for arrange- ment and inspection.

N.B.-Mr. Mort will be happy to make cash advances on receipt of the Wool into Store, and also to purchase supplies for the return teams if required.

LAND SALE.

On Wednesday, the 21st October next, at eleven o'clock, the following town and suburban lots of land will be offered for sale, by public auction, at the Police Office, Brisbane, at the upset price affixed to each lot respectively. Deposit, ten per cent. :

TOWN LOTS.

1. Brisbane, 1 rood and 5 porches, allotment No. 8 of section 32. Upset price, £100 per acre.

2. Brisbane, 1 rood and 7 perches, allotment No. 9 of section 32. Upset price, £100 per acre.

3. Brisbane, 1 rood and 8 perches, allotment No. 10 of section 32. Upset price, £100 per acre.

4. Brisbane, 1 rood and 9 perches, allotment No. 11 of section 32. Upset price, £100 per acre.

5. South Brisbane, 37 perches, allotment No. 5 of section 6. Upset price, £100 per acre.

6. South Brisbane, 39 perches, allotment No. 6 of section 6. Upset price, £100 per acre.

7. South Brisbane, 39 perches, allotment No. 7 of section 6 Upset price, £100 per acre.

8. South Brisbane, 39 perches, allotment No. 8 of section 6. Upset price, £100 per acre.

9. Ipswich, 32 perches, allotment No. 15 of section 3. Upset price, £8 per acre.

10. Ipswich, 32 perches, allotment No. 16 of section 3. Upset price, £8 per acre.

11. Ipswich, 32 perches, allotment No. 17 of section 3. Upset price, £8 per acre. -

12. Ipswich, 32 perches, allotment No. 18 of section 3. Upset price, £8 per acre.

SUBURBAN LOTS-COUNTY OF STANLEY.

1. 88 acres, parish of North Brisbane, No. 53 of the eastern suburban allotments. Upset price, £1 10s. per acre.

2. 33 acres, parish of North Brisbane, No. 54 of the eastern suburban allotments. Upset price, £1 10s. per acre.

3. 22 acres 3 roods 7 perches, parish of North Brisbane, No. 56 of the eastern suburban allot- ments. Upset price, £1 10s. per acre.

4. 20 acres, parish of North Brisbane, No. 5 of the eastern suburban allotments. Upset price, £1 10s. per acre.

5. 31 acres, parish of North Brisbane, No. 58 of the eastern suburban allotments. Upset price, £1 10s. per acre.

6. 3 acres 2 roods 16 perches, parish of South Brisbane, near Brisbane, No. 22 of the western suburban allotments. Upset price, £3 per acre.

7. 3 acres 2 roods 16 perches, parish of South Brisbane, near Brisbane, No. 23 of the western suburban allotments. Upset price, £3 per acre.

8. 4 acres 2 roods, parish of South Brisbane, near Brisbane, No. 25 of the western suburban allotments Upset price, £3 per acre.

9. 2 acres 1 rood 23 perches, parish of South Brisbane, near Brisbane, No. 28 of the western suburban allotments. Upset price, 3 per acre.

10. 2 acres 11 perches, parish of South Bris- bane, near Brisbane, No. 29 of the western subur- ban allotments. Upset price, £3 per acre.

11. 3 acres 35 perches, parish of South Brisbane, near Brisbane, No. 30 of the western suburban allotments. Upset price, £3 per acre.

12. 4 acres 3 roods, parish of South Brisbane, near Brisbane, No. 31 of the western suburban allotments. Upset pi ice, £3 per acre.

13. 3 acres 2 roods, parish of South Brisbane, near Brisbane, No. 32 of the western suburban allotments. Upset price, £3 per acre.

14. 4 acres 8 perches, parish of South Brisbane, near Brisbane, No. 33 of the western suburban allotments. Upset price £3 per acre.

15. 6 acres 16 perches, parish of South Brisbane, near Brisbane. No 35 of the western suburban allotments. Upset price, £3 per acre.

16. 15 acres 2 roods 17 perches, parish of Woogoroo. Upset price, £2 per acre.

articleText:
"EXPERIMENT."

THE STEAMER

EXPERIMENT,

A. Campbell, master, will in future leave Ipswich every Monday and Thursday morn- ing", at 9 o'clock precisely; and Brisbane, every Tuesday and Saturday, at the same hour, ex- cepting in cases where the arrival of the Sydney

Steamer may prevent it.

Refreshments provided on board at moderate

charges.

The following is the corrected List of Fares, Freight, and Storage, viz. :

CABIN PASSAGE, 6s. ; STEERAGE, 4s.

s. d.

Dray. 20 0 Dead weight, per ton. 10 0 Pipe, butt, or puncheon .. 6 0 Pair wheels... .5 0 Hogshead... .. . . .4 0 Barrell... 2 3 Three dozen cask or case. ..... 2 0

Wool, per bale .,......2 0 Quarter-cask.......... 2 0 Ten-gallon keg...... 1 6 Five-gallon keg.... .. . 1 3 Chest tea... 1 0 Sheep-skins, per bundle of 25...0 9 Half and quarter chests tea... 0 9

For every dozen extra. 0 3

STORAGE PER WEEK,

Fourteen days being allowed free,

Measurement goods.. 2 0 Cartage, per ton...2 0

Dead weight, per ton... 1 6 Pipes, butt, or puncheon .....1 0 Hogshead and quarter-cask ........ 0 6 Teas and small packages. 0 3

TO BE SOLD BY PUBLIC AUCTION AT

BRISBANE.

MR. T. DOWSE

WILL SELL by PUBLIC AUCTION, on

THURSDAY, THE 15TH OCTOBER,

A Herd of CATTLE, late the property of Ernest E. Dalrymple, Esq., deceased-consisting of

163 Cows

64 Heifers 4 Bulls

42 Bullocks 83 Steers

356 Head, more or less.

Calves under six months' old given in.

The above-mentioned Catlle are running at Killarney and Glen Logan, on the Station of Messrs. Walter & George Leslie, Canning Downs.

Terms-Ten per cent, cash deposit, and the remainder by an approved endorsed Bill at three

months from day of sale.

The Cattle must be removed by the purchaser

on or before the 15th November next.

For further particulars, apply to George F. Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

TO BE SOLD BY PRIVATE BARGAIN: THE following HORSE STOCK, late the pro-

perty of Ernest E. Dalrymple, Esq., de-

ceased-

9 Mares

1 Gelding

1 Colt, rising 3 years old 3 Colts, " 2 " " 2 Fillies, " 2 " "

2 ColtS, " 1 " " :

1 Filly, " 1 " " ' ".

19 Head.

The above-mentioned Horses are mostly the produce of first-rate mares by thorough-bred

horses, and are now running on the Station of Messrs. Walter and George Leslie, Canning

Downs.

The mares are in foal to thorough-bred horses. For further particulars apply to George F. Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

NEW ROAD.

IN consequence of the splendid discovery of a new line of road from the Upper Brisbane, a large portion of the Wool and supplies for that district and the Boyne will have to be shipped at North-Brisbane, the Undersigned begs to inform his friends that he has provided a large Store, capable of holding 500 bales of Wool, and is prepared to receive and ship all Goods that may be consigned to his care, at the following rates :-- Wool, including cartage and shipping, 1s. per bale

Supplies from Sydney, including cartage, 1s. 6d.

per ton per week. G.S. BRETON

I HEREBY caution any person or persons against engaging John Hitchings, he having absconded from my hired service on the 18th inst.

JOHN STEVENS Woogaroo, Aug., 28, 1846.

WOOL VESSEL FOR LONDON

DIRECT.

SHOULD sufficient encouragement be given,

the undersigned will procure a first class vessel in Sydney, to load from this Port direct to

London.

Parties requiring advances in their shipments, can receive the same on the terms usually charged in Sydney.

A list of intended shippers lies at the office of P. W. Welsh, South Brisbane ; John Richardson, North Brisbane ; Colin Campbell, Esq., Darling Downs ; Mr. Thomas Alford's, Post Office, Dar- ling Downs; and at my office, Custom House,

North Brisbane.

GEO. WATSON,

Custom House Agent. TO LET, THAT well-known Business Stand situated, at Woogaroo,

THE SETTLERS' ARMS INN.

To an industrious couple this offers a desirable opportunity ; the premises are large and conve- nient ; the House containing ten rooms, a large Tap adjoining, a safe and commodious Store, Kitchen, and Stabling ; a large horse Paddock and Stockyard ; a cultivation Paddock, containing seven acres, together with a Garden, containing three acres, in a high state of cultivation, and which is of itself capable of producing a handsome income. To a respectable tenant, the terms will be moderate ; the furniture may be purchased at a valuation, or not, as may best suit the party coming in. Apply to Mr. John Campbell, Kan- garoo Point ; to T. Adams, Esq., Solicitor, North Brisbane ; or to the subscribe, on the premises,

JOHN STEVENS. September 4th, 1846.

STORE AND DWELLING-HOUSE TO LET. THOSE commodious PREMISES, situated in Queen-street, North Brisbane; lately occupied by Mr. Wm. Pickering.

ALSO,

The adjoining DWELLING-HOUSE, contain- ing Six Rooms, with good Kitchen and Yard.

Any person desirous of purchasing the above premises, will be treated with by the undersigned.

For further particulars, apply to

WM. CONNOLLY,

14th August, 1846. South Brisbane.

WHEREAS PATRICK GANGHAN, under agreement for twelve months, has absconded from his hired service at Tooloom, Clarence River, after having lost 23 sheep, and received goods to more than the amount of wages due to him,-all persons are hereby cautioned against harbouring him, or giving him employment; and a reward of Five Pounds will be paid to any person who will give such information as will lead to his being apprehended and lodged in gaol.

He is an Irishman, about 5 feet 10 inches in height, pale complexion, and speaks with a strong accent. He holds a discharge from his former employer, H. Bean, Esq., which was omitted to be taken from him on his re-engaging as a shepherd

at Tooloom.

NOTICE.

THE Undersigned respectfully informs the Settlers in this District, and others proceeding to the Boyne, that he will be happy to Store Goods brought up by carriers, for which the following charges will be made weekly :-

Dead weight, per ton,. 3s. 0d. Small packages, &c., . 0s. 3d.

THOMAS ALFORD.

Drayton, Darling Downs,

August 13, 1846.

LOST.

STRAYED, or stolen, from the Tarampa Station, a Bay Gelding, with white star on the forehead,

branded -I-

One pound reward will be given for the recovery thereof, or £5 if stolen, on conviction of the

offender.

C. AND D. CAMERON.

ONE POUND REWARD.

STRAYED from Kangaroo Point, a Chesnut Horse, with ball face, branded RP on near shoulder, 128 on off shoulder. The above reward will be paid to any person who will deliver him to Mr. John Stevens, Woogaroo, or the subscriber at Kangaroo Point.

JOHN CAMPBELL. Sept. 4th, 1846.

ONE POUND REWARD.

LOST, from Cooper's Plains, a Bay Horse, black points, small star in forehead, small white snip on the nose, branded CC on the neck, S~- on the shoulder., The above reward will be paid to any person who will deliver him to

JOHN STEVENS,

Woogaroo.

September 4th, 1846.

IN answer to the advertisement, signed G. S. Le Breton, P. W. Welsh, Arbitrators, certified by Thos. Adams, Brisbane, 28th August, 1846, in the last Moreton Bay Courier, I hereby state, in spite of the over-bearing, contemptible conduct, and bounce of the said G. S. Le Breton and P. W. Welsh, to me, in my house, last Tuesday, the 8th instant, and the "Action for Defamation," which Henry Ralph Elkins has instructed his Solicitor in Sydney to commence against me," that "all the books, invoices, and other property," do not belong to Henry Ralph Elkins, as falsely stated by the said George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Patricius William Welsh, but to me,- that my late servant, the said Henry Ralph Elkins sent the sum of £85 2s. 8d., (eighty-five pounds, two shillings, and eightpence, sterling,) my money, to his friend, William Joyner, the Clerk in the Australian General Assurance Company's Office, George-street, Sydney, the 15th and 30th June last, per steamer Tamar, for which I have never received value, and which has never been accounted for to me by my said servant, Henry Ralph Elkins, or the said clerk, William Joyner ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins received other moneys for the sale of my goods in my store, which he has never yet accounted for to me ; that the said Henry Ralph Elkins has other property of mine now in his possession ; that I now hold a pro- missory note, dated Sydney, 22nd May, 1846, payable on demand, drawn by the said Henry Ralph Elkins in my favour, for the sum of £17, (seventeen pounds sterling), with ten per cent, interest, money lent by me to the said Henry Ralph Elkins to pay the board, lodging, and washing, of the said Henry Ralph Elkins, in Sydney, that several other debts are now due to me by the said Henry Ralph Elkins since the 8th April last ; that the award of the said Arbitrators, George Spottiswoode Le Breton and Patricius William Welsh, is illegal, unfair, and unjust to- wards me in every respect, and that I will im- mediately commence legal proceedings to set it

R. HAMPDEN

South Brisbane, 12th Sept., 1846.

NOTICE.

GEORGE SPOTTISWOODE LE BRETON, PATRICIUS

WILLIAM WELSH, ARBITRATORS ; THOMAS ADAMS, SOLICITOR.

I HEREBY give you notice, that if you do not immediately deliver up to me all "the books, invoices, &c., &c.,, detained by your desire," be- longing to me, and relating to my Store, now in your custody, possession, or power, I will institute proceedings to compel you, and to recover dam- ages for the injury I have sustained by your illegal, unprincipled, and unjust detention of my property, and the keys of my Store, for so long a period.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 12th Sept., 1846.

GEORGE FURBER,

(LATE OF MAITLAND),

BEGS to inform his many kind friends, and the public generally, that he has re-commenced business as an innkeeper, at

THE GOLDEN FLEECE,

IPSWICH,

(the house lately occupied by Mr. R. E. Dix); where he now offers to all who may honour him with a call, the ease and comfort usually found in an English

ROAD-SIDE INN ;

combining therewith, when necessary, the luxuries

of a Town Hotel.

The strictest attention to the wants and wishes of his patrons ; good liquors-good dinners good beds, and respectful attendants will, he trusts, eventually procure for him a fair share of public favour ; meanwhile G. F. most respectfully solicits a visit : confident that the weary traveller who has once partaken of his cheer, will not after- wards, like the Levite of old, pass by on the other

side.

Good Stabling, and careful attendance for

horses.

STOCKHOLDERS in the NORTHERN DISTRICT

are respectfully informed that the Steaming and Salting Establishment at Kangaroo Point,

Brisbane, Moreton Bay, is now in full operation, where gentlemen can have their stock converted into tallow or beef, as may best suit their purposes, upon reasonable terms.

Stockholders on the Severn, M'Intire and Barwin Rivers, will find it greatly to their ad- vantage to boil down their cattle at Moreton Bay, as the distance from Messrs. Dights' station, on the lower M'Intire River, does not exceed one hundred and eighty miles, along a road abounding in grass and water ; while the distance from the same station to Maitland is four hundred miles, and often deficient in both.

JOHN CAMPBELL.

Cattle or sheep, in any quantity,.purchased, if good, at fair prices.

Sheep boiled down at 6d. per head.

Kangaroo Point, May 25th, 1846,

HENRY RALPH ELKINS,

I HEREBY give you notice, that if you do not immediately deliver up to me all my property, and, all books, invoices, bills, receipts, letters, papers, and documents of, every sort, relating to my Store, I will take legal means to compel you.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 12th September, 1846.

CAUTION.

MY late Servant, HENRY RALPH ELKINS, having refused to pay me over my money re- ceived by him for the sale of my goods in my Store, and having been in consequence dismissed by me, I hereby particularly request and caution the Public not to deal with the said Henry Ralph Elkins on my account, the said Henry Ralph Elkins being no longer authorised to transact my

business.

R. HAMPDEN.

South Brisbane, 12th September, 1846.

WOOL PACKS.

J. RICHARDSON begs to inform the Settlers

in the District of Moreton Bay, that he has just received from Scotland, a large stock of Wool Packs, which he is selling at such prices as will prevent their purchasing in Sydney. He has also on hand, a large Stock of almost all other kinds of

Goods.

J. R. is also making advances on Wool, Tallow,

and Hides.

JOHN SMITH,

BELL-STREET, IPSWICH,

GENERAL STORE,

TAKES the earliest opportunity afforded by the

establishment of a local newspaper to thank his friends and the public generally for the liberal support he has been favoured with ; and to ap- prise them that the prices of articles at his store will be such as to give satisfaction, and cause recommendation. A large assortment of Slops and Groceries always on hand. Orders from the nterior punctually attended to.

PETERSON'S

BRISBANE STORE.

DANIEL PETERSON will store WOOL for any period during the Wool Season, and will Cart the same to the Wharf and ship and consign it for one shilling per Bale. He will also Store goods brought by sailing vessels (in- cluding cartage from Wharf) for one shilling and sixpence per ton per week ; A.I. vessels provided for the transit of the same to Sydney ort moderate

terms.

N.B.-A General Assortment of Goods always on hand, and for sale, on very reasonable terms.

TOBACCO.

THE Undersigned has always on hand every

description of AMERICAN MANUFAC- , TURED TOBACCO-the best selected stockem Sydney.

*** The only house in town for a good old Manilla cigar.

W. H. ALDIS,

Tobacco Merchant.

JACOB CHARLES COHEN,

GEORGE-STREET, SYDNEY,

Opposite the Old Treasury,

BEGS respectfully to inform the inhabitants of Moreton Bay that he has, always on hand an extensive and excellent assortment of Watches and Jewellery, which he can offer at reasonable

prices.

Country orders punctually attended to. All kinds of watch work and jewellery repaired at strictly moderate charges.

SPECTACLES TO9 SUIT ALL SIGHTS.

ADELPHI HOTEL,

York-street, SYDNEY.

THOMAS MURPHY begs most respectfully to,

acquaint the inhabitants of the Moreton Bay District that when visiting the Metropolis they may at all times rely upon meeting with

FIRST-RATE ENTERTAINMENT, together with civil and well-qualified attendants,

AT MODERATE CHARGES.

Dinners and Suppers for private parties pro- vided on the shortest notice, for which well-fur-

nished and suitable apartments will be found in

the establishment.

T. M. takes this opportunity to acknowledge the liberal support he has received from the gen- tlemen residing in the district, and begs to assure them that he will spare neither cost nor labour to ensure the approval of those who may honour the Hotel with their company.

The wines and spirits are of first-class,quality, and the stables equal to any in Sydney.
heading: Classified Advertising
title: {'id': '14', 'value': 'The Moreton Bay Courier (Brisbane, Qld. : 1846 - 1861)'}

articleText:
FOR SYDNEY.

THE PACKET - SCHOONER

WILLIAM,

Freeman, master, will sail from Campbell's Wharf, Kangaroo Point, for the above port, on Thursday Next.

For freight or passage apply to the master on board ; or to

JOHN CAMPBELL,

Kangaroo Point.

TO BE SOLD BY AUCTION

FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE UNDERWRITERS.

MR. DOWSE

HAS been instructed to Sell by Auction, at the Commissariat Wharf, North Brisbane,

On TUESDAY NEXT, the 11th INSTANT, Three WHALE BOATS, with Oars, Sails, and other Gear, lately belonging to the Whaling Brigantine Dundee Merchant, and sold in con- sequence of the unfortunate loss of that vessel, for

the benefit of the Underwriters.

Two of these boats have only been built a few months, and all of them are sound serviceable boats : one of them, built by Jones, of Sydney, won the chief prize given at the last Anniversary Regatta, in Sydney. Parties wanting, a real good and safe boat, for the navigation of the Bay,

should not lose the present opportunity of pur- chasing one of these clippers.

TO BE SOLD BY PUBLIC AUCTION AT BRISBANE.

MR. T. DOWSE

WILL SELL by PUBLIC AUCTION, on THURSDAY, THE 15TH OCTOBER,

A Herd of CATTLE, late the property of Ernest E. Dalrymple, Esq., deceased—consisting of

163 Cows

64 Heifers

4 Bulls

42 Bullocks 83 Steers

356 Head, more or less.

Calves under six months' old given in.

The above-mentioned Cattle are running at Killarney and Glen Logan, on the Station of Messrs. Walter & George Leslie, Canning Downs.

Terms—Ten per cent. cash deposit, and the remainder by an approved endorsed Bill at three months from day of sale.

The Cattle must be removed by the purchaser

on or before the 15th November next.

For further particulars, apply to George F. Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

TO BE SOLD BY PRIVATE BARGAIN.

THE following HORSE STOCK, late the pro- perty of Ernest E. Dalrymple, Esq., de-

ceased—

9 Mares

1 Gelding

1 Colt, rising 3 years old

3 Colts, " 2 " "

2 Fillies, " 2 " "

2 Colts, " 1 " "

1 Filly, " 1 " "

19 Head.

The above-mentioned Horses are mostly the produce of first-rate mares by thorough-bred horses, and are now running on the Station of Messrs. Walter and George Leslie, Canning

Downs.

The mares are in foal to thorough-bred horses. For further particulars apply to George F. Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

TO BE SOLD BY PRIVATE CONTRACT,

NINETEEN head of superior HORSE STOCK,

late the property of E. E. Dalrymple, Esq., deceased, consisting of nine Mares, one Gelding, and nine Colts and Fillies of ages. The Mares are all stinted to thorough-bred Horses.

For particulars, apply to George Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

TO BE SOLD BY PRIVATE CONTRACT,

AN Allotment of LAND, in South Brisbane,

There is a very comfortable slabbed Cottage upon it, and the allotment is fenced in. It adjoins

the premises of Mr. John Williams.

For particulars apply to Mr. Thomas Adams,

Solicitor ; or to Michael Power, Auctioneer, South Brisbane.

North Brisbane, 15th July, 1846.

1000 EWES.

FOR SALE, 1000 EWES, of ages. Apply

to

MR. ADAMS, Solicitor,

North Brisbane.

SHEEP STATION FOR SALE.

WANTED a purchaser for a FINE RUN, capable of holding 4000 Sheep, or 500 head of Cattle ; it is well watered and grassed, and is situated near the Main Range, in the district of Moreton Bay. There are 100 Hurdles, and a newly-erected Hut, on the Station ; and a flock of Sheep, consisting of 1500, can be taken on terms by the party purchasing the Run. The price asked is £40. For further particulars, apply at the office of this journal.

NOTICE.

SHEEP-SKINS will be purchased by the un- signed for cash, and for which the highest market price w ill be given.

MARTIN BYRNE. Ipswich, 6th August, 1846.

WANTED TO PURCHASE FOR CASH.

FROM 1000 to 3000 strong, healthy, and

good-wooled EWES, which have never been diseased, and not above four years old, to be de- livered after shearing. Parties having such to

dispose of, are requested to apply, by letter, (post

paid) stating all particulars, addressed to A. B., at the Courier Office, Brisbane.

ONE POUND REWARD.

LOST, a Red BULLOCK, with one horn down and the other up; branded S -i- K, and something like Y with 2 underneath, on rump, and a further reward of Ten Shillings will be given for a Red Bullock, white face, cock horns, branded M C. Whoever will deliver the same to

George Edmondston, North Brisbane, will receive the above rewards.

7th August, 1846.

TO HENRY DANGAR, ESQ., M.C., NEATSFIELD, HUNTER RIVER.

TAKE NOTICE, that unless you remove your

Cattle, now in my charge, within twenty-one

days from this date, and pay expenses, they will, on Thursday, the 27th day of August next,

be Sold at Public Auction, in Brisbane Town, Moreton Bay, to pay the same.

JOHN STEVENS.

Woogaroo, Moreton Bay,

July 17th, 1846.

WOOL.

THE Undersigned is authorised to make cash advances on Wool consigned to Capt. Towns, Sydney, for sale there, or shipment through him to Robert Brooks, Esq., London.

Wool, washed and unwashed, Hides, and Sheep- skins, purchased. Apply at the Wharf, South

Brisbane.

P. W. WELSH.

TO THE INHABITANTS of MORETON BAY.

THOMAS MOORE,

OF EAST-STREET, IPSWICH,

IN returning thanks, to the Settlers, and the

public generally, for the liberal support he received while carrying on his trade, as a Black-

smith and Wheelwright, begs to announce that he has transferred the business to his son, William Moore, and John BALLSALY, his foreman, to whom he confidently recommends his late customers.

CALEDONIAN HOTEL,

East-street, Ipswich.

THOMAS MOORE

BEGS respectfully to apprise the Settlers, and

his friends generally, that he has commenced business as an Hotel-keeper, in Ipswich, and has purchased a varied stock of Wines and Spirits of the choicest quality, and of the best known brands now in the colony. He solicits a fair share of public support, and trusts by assiduity, and atten- tion to the comforts of those guests who may honour the Hotel with their company, to merit

their approval. Gentlemen travelling, will find every accommodation, at the most reasonable charge. Good stabling, and careful attendance paid to horses.

Ipswich, 21 st July, 1846.

STOCKHOLDERS in the Northern Districts

are respectfully informed that the Steaming and Salting Establishment at Kangaroo Point, Brisbane, Moreton Bay, is now in full operation, where gentlemen can have their stock converted into tallow or beef, as may best suit their purposes, upon reasonable terms.

Stockholders on the Severn, M‘Intire, and Barwin Rivers, will find it greatly to their ad- vantage to boil down their cattle at Moreton Bay, as the distance from Messrs. Dights’ station, on the lower M’lntire River, does not exceed one hundred and eighty miles, along a road abounding in grass and water ; while the distance from the same station to Maitland is four hundred miles, and often deficient in both.

JOHN CAMPBELL.

Cattle or sheep, in any quantity, purchased, if good, at fair prices.

Sheep boiled down at 6d. per head. Kangaroo Point, May 25th, 1846.
heading: Classified Advertising
title: {'id': '14', 'value': 'The Moreton Bay Courier (Brisbane, Qld. : 1846 - 1861)'}

articleText:
FOR HOBART TOWN DIRECT.

THE Brig SKERNE, Captain

Love, immediately on her arrival from Sydney, will sail for Hobart Town with such freight as may be offered. She will return direct to Brisbane with labourers. A supercargo will proceed in her for the purpose of engaging and selecting them.

The undersigned, on application, will furnish every information to parties requiring men, and will enter into the necessary engagements on

behalf of the charterer.

George Watson,

Custom House and General Agent. North Brisbane, June 27, 1846.

AUCTION SALE,

WITHOUT RESERVE.

MR. POWER will Sell by Public Auction,

without the least reserve, at his premises, in South Brisbane, on

FRIDAY NEXT, the 21 st AUGUST, At Eleven o'clock precisely,

A large quantity of HOUSEHOLD FURNI- TURE, consisting of Dining Tables, cane-bottom Chairs, Sofas, Washhand blands, Bedsteads, Dressing Tables, &c. &c.

ALSO,

A few superior Breakfast and Dinner Services, complete,-amongst these will be found some ex- cellent Services, comprising from 170 to 190 pieces each-besides a good assortment of other Crockery, in lots to suit purchasers.

AND ALSO,

An assortment of Ironmongery and Drapery

These goods may be inspected by intending purchasers at any time previous to the day of sale. N.B.- Ferry-money allowed to all purchasers.

SALE BY AUCTION.

VALUABLE FREEHOLD PROPERTY.

MR. M. POWER has received instructions to

Sell by Public Auction, on the Ground, at South Brisbane, on

FRIDAY NEXT, the 21st INSTANT, At Eleven o'clock precisely,

A very neat and commodious VERANDAH COTTAGE, with detached Kitchen, now in the occupation of Mr. John Connolly, having a front- age to Grey-street of 29 feet 3 inches, by a depth of 2 chains, 25 links, being one-half of Allotment 14, of Section 1, as described in the Grant from the Crown, bearing date the 29th Sept., 1842.

Terms made known at sale.

ALE.

THE Undersigned having been appointed Agent

for the Sale of BLAXLANDS ALE, will be happy to dispose of the same in twenty-gallon Casks, to Settlers, and others requiring a supply. This Ale is of very superior quality. A large stock always on hand.

DAVID BOW. Queen-street,

North Brisbane, 14th August, 1846.

LIST of Subscriptions paid towards a Testi- monial to Dr. Leichhardt and his party, in the District of Moreton Bay :

£. s. d.

Amount already advertised.. 65 17 6 William Bonifant. 1 1 0 C. W. Pitts. 1 1 0 D. Peterson. 0 10 0 H. Foley. 0 2 0 F. Bracken. 5 5 0

Neil Ross. 5 0 0

John Gunn. 1 0 0 John Murray..... 10 0

£80 16 6

Contributors are requested to pay up their Sub- scriptiohs to the Treasurer at their earliest con-

venience.

W. KENT,

Hon. Sec. and Treasurer.

NEW ROAD.

IN consequence of the splendid discovery of a new line of road from the Upper Brisbane, a large portion of the Wool and supplies for that district and the Boyne will have to be shipped at North Brisbane, the Undersigned begs to inform his friends that he has provided a large Store, capable of holding 500 bales of Wool, and is prepared to receive and ship all Goods that may be consigned to his care, at the following rates : Wool, including caitage and shipping, 1s. per

bale.

Supplies from Sydney, including cartage, 1s. 6d.

per ton per week.

G. S. LE BRETON.

ii

STORE AND DWELLING-HOUSE TO LET.

THOSE commodious PREMISES, situated in Queen-street, North Brisbane, Iately occupied by Mr. Wm. Pickering.

ALSO,

The adjoining DWELLING-HOUSE, contain- ing Six Rooms, with good Kitchen and Yard. For further particulars, apply to

WM. CONNOLLY,

14th August, 1846. South Brisbane.

TO SMALL CAPITALISTS-FOR SALE.

THE undersigned has for Sale, on advantageous terms, two I O U's, signed R. H. : one tor the sum of £3 0s. 3d., and the other for 18s. 2d. ; or, the above will be given in exchange for Turtle, Salt Beef, Tallow, Hides, Sheepskins, or any other colonial produce. A more eligible opportunity for investment, will not occur again.

THOMAS RICKETT. South Brisbane, 14th August 1846

WOOL.

THE Undersigned is authorised to make cash advances on Wool consigned to Capt. Towns, Sydney, for sale there, or shipment through him to Robert Brooks, Esq., London.

Wool, washed and unwashed, Hides, and Sheep- skins, purchased. Apply at the Wharf, South

Brisbane.

P. W. WELSH.

WANTED TO PURCHASE FOR CASH.

FROM 1000 to 3000 strong, healthy, and

good-wooled EWES, which have never been diseased, and not above four years old, to be de- livered after shearing. Parties having such to dispose of, are requested to apply, by letter, (post paid) stating all particulars, addressed to A. B., at the Courier Office, Brisbane.

NOTICE.

SHEEP-SKINS will be purchased by the un- signed for cash, and for which the highest

market price will be given.

MARTIN BYRNE. Ipswich, 6th August, 1846.

THE GIPPS TESTIMONIAL.

HAVING been requested by the Committee, appointed in Sydney to receive contributions for a Memorial to Sir GEORGE GIPPS, to co- operate with them in this undertaking, parties in this district who are desirous of recording their sense of the merits of this Statesman, in the manner proposed, will be pleased to intimate the same to

W. A. DUNCAN. Queen-street,

Brisbane, 14th August, 1846.

TO HENRY DANGAR, ESQ., M.C.,

NEATSFIELD, HUNTER RIVER.

TAKE NOTICE, that unless you remove your Cattle, now in my charge, within-twenty-one days from this date, and pay expenses, they will, on Thursday, the 27th day of August next, be Sold at Public Auction, in Brisbane Town, Moreton Bay, to pay the same.

JOHN STEVENS. Woogaroo, Moreton Bay,

July 17th, 1846.

BUSH INN, CUNNINGHAM'S GAP. .

JOHN PERRYMAN

BEGS most respectfully to inform Gentlemen, and others travelling the Cunningham Gap Road, that he has purchased those premises known as the BUSH INN, lately occupied by Mr. A. Young, where it will be his constant study to provide the most comfortable accommodations.

A regular supply of all kinds of Wines, Spirits, Ale, and Porter, of a superior quality, will always be kept on hand, and a well-furnished Table at all times ready for the weary Traveller, which, with attention, civility, and moderate charges, J. P. trusts will induce many more travellers to use the Gap Road than have hitherto done.

John Perryman feels confident that one call will prove the truth of what he now asserts.

N.B.-A large and well watered Paddock.

LATEST INTELLIGENCE.

H. M. Ship Carysfort having arrived, with His

Excellency Sir Charles Augustus Fitz- roy on board, TEBBUTT AND CO , Bank of Australia, Sydney, are determined that the Settlers in the district of Moreton Bay shall have the same opportunity of evincing their loyalty as their friends in Sydney ; it affords them great pleasure in offering to the loyal inhabitants

Ale and Porter, at 6s. 6d. per dozen,

of a quality superior to any other ever offered in the district ; in fact, such as cannot be procured at any other establishment.

Light Pale India Ale, 6s. 6d.-per doz., in 3 or 4

doz. cases,

Champaigne Ale, 7s. 6d. ditto, ditto.

Brown Stout, (equal to Dunbar's), 6s. 6d. ditto.

In Wines, as regards quality and price, they defy the most strenuous competition.

(prices of real wines.)

Port. 18s to 28s. Madeira .. 18s. to 30s. Sherry.... 16s. to 23s. Malaga. .. 16s. to 25s. Marsala. .. 16s. to 23s. Champagne 20s. to 50s. Bucellas .. 2ls. to 26s. Arinto . .. 21s. to 24s. Port, Sherry, Marsala, and Madeira, in draught,

from 5s. 6d. to 12s per gallon.

All the above Wines in Pipes, Butts, Hogsheads,

Quarters, Octaves, and ten-gallon Kegs.

Parties in the district requiring the above, will please write Messrs. T. and Co., stating the article and price, and by what conveyance to be delivered. Also, to enclose a remittance in c sh, or orders, which will be collected by T and Co. ; or a guarantee by a respectable party in Sydney. Should the orders be a number of days after sight, the goods will be in all cases sent, if accepted.

N.B-The above prices refer to genuine Wines, as T. and Co. do not profess to sell any other; if, however, parties "must have" Port and Sherry at 10s. 6d.-a dozen, T. and Co. will endeavour to get some manufactured sooner than disappoint.

TO THE INHABITANTS of MORETON BAY.

THOMAS MOORE,

OF EAST-STREET, IPSWICH,

IN returning thanks to the Settlers, and the public generally, for the liberal support he received while carrying on his trade, as a Black- smith and Wheelwright, begs to announce that he has transferred the business to his son, William Moore, and John Ballsaly, his foreman, to whom he confidently recommends his late customers.

CALEDONIAN HOTEL,

East-street, Ipswich.

THOMAS MOORE

BEGS respectfully to apprise the Settlers, and

his friends generally, that he has commenced business as an Hotel-keeper, in Ipswich, and has purchased a varied stock of Wines and Spirits of the choicest quality, and of the best known brands now in the colony. He solicits a fair share of public support, and trusts by assiduity, and atten- tion to the comforts of those guests who may honour the Hotel with their company, to merit their approval. Gentlemen travelling, will find every accommodation, at the most reasonable charge. Good stabling, and careful attendance paid to horses.

Ipswich, 2lst July, 1846.

"VAN DUNK,"

TO STAND THE PRESENT SEASON,

At the Livery Stables,

North Brisbane, Moreton Bay.

THE Entire Horse VAN DUNK, imported by

Charles Roberts, Esq., is a remarkable well made Cob, with great strength, and fine action, and his stock is not surpassed as roadsters by any horse in the colony.

Van Dunk has covered for the last four years in the stud of John Single, Esq., of Penrith, whose stock stands as high at any in the colony.

Terms-£2 10s. each, and 2s. 6d. Groomage.

Good Paddock provided, but no responsibility

incurred.

E. BERKELEY.

articleText:
STEAM COMMUNICATION BETWEEN MORETON BAY AND SYDNEY.

PROPOSED Days of Sailing of the Steam- Packet T A M A R : FROM MORETON BAY. FROM SYDNEY. On Tuesday, 17th Nov. On Tuesday, 24th Nov. Ditto 1st Dec. Ditton 8th Dec.

Ditto 15th ditto Ditto 22nd ditto Ditto 29th ditto Ditto 5th jan.

Ditto 12th Jan. Ditto 19th ditto And so on every Tuesday alternately, from Sydney and Moreton Bay. H. R. S. N. Co's Wharf,

South Brisbane

THE STEAM-PACKET WILLIAM IV.,

Captain Wiseman ; will be laid

on as a REGULAR TRADER between

THIS DISTRICT AND SYDNEY,

commencing her Trips early this month, at the following reduced Rates Cabin ................ £2 10 0

Steerage ............. 10 0

Goods shipped by her from Sydney, will be landed at North or South Brisbane, and Kangaroo Point—at the latter place; all Goods from Sydney or Produce for shipment to Sydney, will be re- ceived and stored at CAMPBELL WHARF, free of all charge. GEORGE WATSON,

STEAMER "EXPERIMENT."

THE Undersigned, in calling attention to the

advertisement which appeared in the Courier, on the 24th ultimo, begs to inform the residents in Brisbane and Ipswich, that in future the freight for all,Goods forwarded by the Steamer, must be paid when they are shipped ; and passage money will be required from parties before leaving

the vessel.

A. CAMPBELL.

Brisbane 6th Nov., 1846. .WOOL VESSEL FOR LONDON DIRECT.

SHOULD sufficient encouragement be given, the undersigned will procure a first class vessel in Sydney, to load from this Port direct to London.

Parties requiring advances in their shipments, can receive the same on the terms usually charged in Sydney.

A list of intended shippers lies at the office of P. W. Welsh, South Brisbane ; John Richardson, North Brisbane ; Colin Campbell, Esq., Darling Downs ; Mr. Thomas Alford's, Post Office, Dar- ling Downs ; and at my office, Custom House, North Brisbane.

GEO. WATSON

Custom House Agent.

WOOL STORE.

E. ORR will Store Wool in the capacious premises adjoining his Store, during the

Wool Season and cart the same to the Wharf, at the rate of 1s. per bale. He:will also Store Goods brought by the steamer at 1s.6d. per ton per week. N.B.—A general assortment of Stores always

on hand for Sale, on the most reasonable terms.

South Brisbane, Oct. 30, 1846.

O N S A L E—MARTELLíS .BRANDY

Jamaica Rum Gin, in 4 gallon cases

Port Wine, in 3 dozen cases

Sherry, in 3 dozen cases Ditto, in draught Champagne, in 1 dozen cases Byass' Ale } Lewtas' Porter, } in 3 dozen cases

Ale and Porter, in hhds. and barrels.

J HARRIS,

South Brisbane.

SOUTH BRISBANE,

READING ROOMS.

THE SUBSCRIBERS to the above are informed that their Temporary Rooms will be open on Wednesday the 4th November. The following newspapers have beens procured :—Moreton Bay, Sydney, Melbourne, Geelong, Launceston, Hobart

Town, Adelaide, and New Zealand ; others will be added when a sufficient number of Subscribers have been procured. Subscription, Two Guineas per annum—one-half in advance.

Gut half-pint Tumblers

Boiled Linseed Oil

Oilcloth for Table Covers

articleText:
PLEASURE EXCURSION TO WOOGAROO.

THE STEAMER

EXPERIMENT,

will leave the Government Wharf, on a PLEASURE EXCURSION to Woogaroo,

TOMORROW MORNING,

At half-past Seven, returning in the Evening.

Fares—Cabin, 3s. ; Steerage, 2s Refresh- ments provided on the most reasonable terms.

Tickets may be had of Mr. Bow, Victoria Hotel ; Mr. Dix, Sovereign Hotel ; and Mr. Burgess, Sawyers' Arms.

SALE BY AUCTION.

MR. M. POWER

WILL Sell by Public Auction, at the residence

of Mr. Davidson, in South Brisbane, on TUESDAY NEXT, THE 22ND INST.,

At 11 o'clock, A Cart and Harness

Two large Iron Boilers

Some Household Furniture, &c.

Terms-Cash.

BRISBANE SUBSCRIPTION for the POOR

in IRELAND:—

Reverend J. Hanly, North Brisbane 3 0 0 Henry Savary, ditto 0 10 0

Win. Fitzpatrick, C.C., ditto 1 0 0 Michael Shelley ditto 1 0 0

William Sheehan ditto 1 0 0 James M'Allester ditto 1 0 0 Little and Phelan ditto 0 2 6 Arthur S. Lyon ditto 1 0 0 John Solsberry ditto 0 5 0

Samuel Copperthwaite ditto 0 5 0 John Bruce ditto 0 10 0

Subscriptions will be received by the Rev. J. Hanly, and Messrs. Little and Phelan, North Brisbane; Mr. Andrew Graham, of South Bris- bane ; and Mr. M. Sheehan, of Little Ipswich.

Brisbane

ditto

NOTICE.

THE Undersigned have this day entered into

co-partnership, and will in future conduct the business of their Old Establishment, in George-street, under the firm of

ROBERT PORTER AND SAMUEL PEEK.

(Signed) ROBERT PORTER,

SAMUEL PEEK.

Sydney, 1st Sept., 1846,

THE VOICE

IN THE WILDERNESS,

Published in Sydney on the 1st and 15th of

each month; eight pages demy quarto. Price Is. 6d. per quarter.

THIS PAPER contains statements of Divine truth, doctrinal and practical ; sketches of the lives of eminent Christians ; and accounts of the various religious movements throughout the world. It is specially devoted to the exposition and defence of the great doctrines of the Headship of Christ, and the spiritual independence of His Church, as maintained by the Free Church of

Scotland.

Subscribers names will be received by the Agent for Moreton Bay.

JAMES SWAN, Printer.

Moreton Bay Courier Office, Sept. 5.

WANTED.

A PERSON who understands the Spaying of Cattle, may meet with an engagement, on

application to

H. S. RUSSELL.

Condamine River, 19th Sept., 1846.

BULLS FOR SALE.

THE Undersigned has for Sale nine first-rate Bulls, from two to six years old, the product of Mr. Robert Mackenzie's imported Stock.

H. S. RUSSELL.

Condamine, 19th Sept., 1846.

ON SALE, at the SOUTH BRISBANE

STORES

Port and Sherry, in quarter-casks

Ditto ditto, in 3 dozen cases Cape Madeira, in hogsheads and quarter-casks

Gin, Rum, and Brandy, superior qualities Barrat's Twist Tobacco Tea, ex Sophia and Annie Manilla Sugar Mould Candles Soap, in 1 cwt. and ½ cwt. boxes . 9-4, 10-4, Witney Blankets

10-4 Rugs Regatta and Striped Shirts Check Union Shirtings

Blue Serge Shirts

Millar's Drab Moleskin Jackets and Trowsers

Chesterfield, Taglioni, and Pilot Coats Valencia and Plush Vests Woolpacks and Sheepshears Five tons Van Diemens Land Fine Flour

To be sold cheap for cash.

T. H. GREEN.

PETERSON'S

BRISBANE STORE.

DANIEL PETERSON will store WOOL, for any period during the Wool Season, and will Cart the same to the Wharf and ship and consign it for one shilling per Bale. He will also Store goods brought by sailing vessels (in- cluding cartage from Wharf) for one shilling and sixpence per ton per week ; A.I. vessels provided for the transit of the same to Sydney on moderate terms.

N.B.-A General Assortment of Goods always on hand, and for sale, on very reasonable terms.

A DAIRY,

WITHIN FIFTY MILES FROM BRISBANE. TO parties wishing to engage in the above, by

applying at the Courier Newspaper Qtfice, can obtain the particulars.

Brisbane, 12th Sept., 1846.

TO BE LET,

ON BUILDING LEASES, for the term of Five Years, or under, certain Allotments, situate at Kangaroo Point, North Brisbane. For further particulars, apply to

LOUIS F. LAYARD. North Brisbane, 17th Sept., 1846.

TO LET,

A WEATHER-BOARDED VERANDAH COTTAGE, pleasantly situated on the bauk

of the River, at Kangaroo Point, and containing Six Rooms, in an excellent state of repair, with plenty of back ground attached, part of which is enclosed as a Garden. There are also a Fowl-

house, temporary Stockyard, &c, on the premises, and the rent, to a good tenant, will be extremely

small.

Apply at the Stores of the undersigned.

G. S. LE BRETON.

North Brisbane, Sept. 19, 1846.

TO LET,

FOURTEEN ACRES of LAND, with House

and Barn attached, situated at South Brisbane, adjoining the Land of Mr. Thomas Pendergrass.

The Land is of the richest description, and well adapted for agricultural purposes, and has a large Shingled Building erected thereon.

Two ploughs, two harrows, and a large roller, will be let with the above.

For particulars, apply to Mr. George Furber, Ipswich - if by letter, post paid.

TO LET,

THAT well-known Business Stand situated

at Woogaroo,

THE SETTLERS' ARMS INN.

To an industrious couple this offers a desirable opportunity ; the premises are large and conve- nient ; the House containing ten rooms, a large Tap adjoining, a safe and commodious Store, Kitchen, and Stabling ; a large horse Paddock and Stockyard;, a cultivation Paddock, containing seven acres, together with a Garden, containing three acres, in a high state of cultivation, and which is of itself capable of producing a handsome income. To a respectable tenant, the terms will be moderate ; the furniture may be purchased at a valuation, or not, as may best suit the party coming in. Apply to Mr. John Campbell, Kan- garoo Point ; to T. Adams, Esq.,Solicitor, North Brisbane ; or to the subscriber, on the premises,

JOHN STEVENS. September 4th, 1846.
