articleText:
STEAM COMMUNICATION

BETWEEN

SYDNEY AND MORETON BAY

PROPOSED DAYS of

SAILING of the Steam Packet

TAMAR :

FROM MORETON BAY. FROM SYDNEY.

On Thursday, 27th Aug. On THURDAY, 3rd Sept.

Ditto 10th Sept. Ditto 17th ditto Ditto 24th ditto Ditto 1st Oct. ditto Ditto 8th Oct. Ditto 15th ditto Ditto 22nd ditto Ditto 29th ditto And so on every Thursday, alternately from

Sydney and Moreton Bay. H. R. S. N. Co.'s Wharf,

South Brisbane, 30th July, 1846.

"EXPERIMENT."

THE STEAMER

EXPERIMENT,

A. Campbell, master, will in future leave Ipswich every Monday and Thursday morn- ing, at 9 o'clock precisely ; and Brisbane, every Tuesday and Saturday, at the same hour, ex- cepting in cases where the arrival of the Sydney

Steamer may prevent it.

Refreshments provided on board at moderate

charges.

The following is the corrected List of Fares, Freight, and Storage, vis. :-

Cabin Passage, 6s. ; Steerage, 4s.

s. d.

1 Dray .... 20 0

Dead weight, per ton. 10 0 Pipe, butt, or puncheon . 6 0

Pair wheels. 5 0 Hogshead . 4 0

Barrel...'. 2 3 Three dozen cask or case. 2 0

Wool, per bale . 2 0

Quarter-cask. 2 0 Ten-gallon keg. 1 6

Five-gallon keg. 1 3

Chest tea. 1 0 Sheep-skins, per bundle of 25 . 0 9 Half and quarter chests tea. 0 9

For every dozen extra. 0 3

STORAGE PER WEEK,

Fourteen days being allowed free,

Measurement goods . 2 0 Cartage, per ton.. 2 0

Dead Weight, per ton. 1 6 Pipes, butt, or puncheon. 1 0 Hogshead and quarter-cask. 0 6 Teas and small packages. 0 3

TO BE SOLD BY PRIVATE CONTRACT,

AN Allotment of LAND, in South Brisbane. There is a very comfortable slabbed Cottage upon it, and the allotment is fenced in. It adjoins the premises of Mr John Williams.

For particulars apply to Mr. Thomas' Adams, Solicitor ; or to Michael Power, Auctioneer, South

Brisbane.

North Brisbane, 15th July, 1846.

TO HENRY DANGAR, ESQ., M.C.,

NEATSFIELD, HUNTER RIVER

TAKE NOTICE, that unless you remove your Cattle, now in my charge, within twenty-one days from this date, and pay expenses, they will,

on Thursday, the 27th day of August next, be Sold at Public Auction, in Brisbane Town, Moreton Bay, to pay the same.

JOHN STEVENS.

Woogaroo, Moreton Bay,

July 17th, 1846.

MR. T. DOWSE

HAS received instructions to Sell by Public Auction, on the ground, on the

1st of SEPTEMBER NEXT,

Without Reserve,

Four valuable BUILDING ALLOTMENTS, situate at South Brisbane, being

Allotments No. 3, of Section 2

7, .. 2 14, .. 2 17, .. 3

as purchased at the Government Land Sale in Sydney, in July, 1842.

The whole of these Allotments are situated on the ridge, opposite Mr. D. Peterson's Store, and possess a first-rate business locality.

At the same time, the Auctioneer, with the view of enabling the industrious artisan, and others with limited means, to become the pur- chasers of a portion of this desirable freehold, the four Allotments will (if required) on the day of sale, be subdivided into eight Lots.

For particulars of title, apply to Mr. John

Ocock, Solicitor, South Brisbane.

Terms made know at sale.

SALE BY AUCTION,

(Unless disposed of by Private Contract, of which

due notice will be given),

VALUABLE FREEHOLD PROPERTY

KANGAROO POINT.

MR. DOWSE has much pleasure in announcing

to the speculative community of Moreton Bay, that he has received instructions to sell by Public Auction, on

THURSDAY, the 27th of AUGUST,

At Twelve o'clock,

ON THE GROUND,

where a Luncheon will be provided by the pro- prietor for the company,

The following choice Allotments of LAND, situated in the most commanding position for

business, at the Point.

LOT 1.

An Allotment of Land abutting on the Public

Wharf at Kangaroo Point, and upon which is erected a small weather-boarded Cottage, now let at a weekly rental, but which can be very much improved at very small outlay.

LOT 2.

All that splendid Allotment on the opposite corner,

to the Store of Mr. Davidson, upon which the former proprietor has erected nearly the whole of the Brickwork necessary for a large and commodious building, admirably adapted, from its position and judicious arrangements, for a first-rate Hotel. A very limited outlay would complete these premises, and become a source of great profit to the fortunate purchaser. At the rear of the brick building, a large Stand Store, or Stabling, has been roofed in and completed: thus, in the whole, forming a most - compact establishment for a Town Hotel - a

desideratum much wanted at the Point.

LOT 3.

An adjoining Allotment to the above, upon which

a neat Cottage has been erected, and let at a good weekly rental. To the industrious mechanic, this is an excellent opportunity in which to invest his savings.

N.B.-The proprietor would have no objection to allow a portion of the purchase money of Lot 2 to remain upon security of the premises at reason- able interest, and afford every facility and assist- ance to enable the purchasers to carry out their views in completing these premises.

The Title Will be guaranteed, and the terms of payment made easy.

The plan of the Allotments, and full particulars, Can be seen and ascertained at the office of Mr. T. Adams, solicitor, North Brisbane ; or at the Auctioneer's-either of whom are authorised to treat for sale by private contract.

TO BE SOLD BY PUBLIC AUCTION AT

BRISBANE.

MR. T. DOWSE

WILL SELL by PUBLIC AUCTION, on

THURSDAY, the 15th OCTOBER, A Herd of CATTLE, late the property of Ernest E. Dalrymple, Esq., deceased - consisting of

163 Cows 64 Heifers 4 Bulls

42 Bullocks 83 Steerss

356 Head, more or less.

Calves under six months old given in.

The 'above-mentioned Cattle are running at Killarney and Glen Logan, on the Station of Messrs. Walter & George Leslie, Canning Down's.

Terms-Ten per cent, cash deposit, and the remainder by an approved endorsed Bill at three months from day of sale.

The Cattle must be removed by the purchaser

on or before the 15th November next.

For further particulars, apply to George F. Leslie, Esq., Canning Downs.

WANTED TO PURCHASE FOR CASH.

FROM 1000 to 3000 strong, healthy, and good-wooled EWES, which have never been diseased, and not above four years old, to be de- livered after shearing. Parties having such to dispose of, are requested to apply, by letter, (post paid) stating all particulars, addressed to A. B., at the Courier Office, Brisbane.

BUSH INN, CUNNINGHAM'S GAP.

JOHN PERRYMAN

BEGS most respectfully to inform Gentlemen, and others travelling the Cunningham Gap Road, that he has purchased those premises known as the BUSH INN, lately occupied by Mr. A. Young, where it will be his constant study to provide the most comfortable accommodations.

A regular supply of all kinds of Wines, Spirits, Ale, and Porter, of a superior quality, will always be kept on hand, and a well-furnished Table at all times ready for the weary Traveller, which, with attention, civility, and moderate charges, J. P. trusts will induce many more travellers to use the Gap Road than have hitherto done.

John Perryman feels confident that one call will prove the truth of what he now asserts.

N.B.- A large and well watered Paddock.

NOTICE TO THE PUBLIC,

WITH REFERENCE TO AN ADVERTISEMENT

SIGNED R. HAMPDEN.

I THE UNDERSIGNED, having an interest

in the Store, and all Goods, Book Debts, &c., thereunto belonging, Do Hereby Give Notice to all parties indebted to the said establish- ment, not to pay any money without my receipt ; neither to give any credit, on account of the said Store, without my written authority. Also, all persons having any claim on this establishment, are requested to send in their accounts forthwith

to me.

HENRY RALPH ELKINS. New Store,

South Brisbane, 22nd Aug., 1846.

CAUTION.

MY late Servant, HENRY RALPH ELKINS, having refused to pay me over my money re- ceived by him for the sale of my goods in my Store, and having been in consequence dismissed by me, I hereby particularly request and caution the Public not to deal with the said Henry Ralph Elkins on my account, the said Henry Ralph Elkins being no longer authorised to transact my

business.

R. HAMPDEN. New Stafe,

Opposite (late) Rowland's Hotel, South Brisbane, 21st August, 1846.

NEW STORE,

Opposite Rowland's Hotel,

SOUTH BRISBANE.

THE Undersigned has on hand, ex late

arrivals :

Teas Drapery Goods Sugars Epsom Salts

Tobacco and Cigars Carbonate Soda

Salt Tartaric Acid

Groceries, &c., &c. Eau de Cologne

A few-bags real Derwent Potatoes.

JUST OPENED,

One bale extra large Witney Blankets.

R. HAMPDEN.

THE UNDERSIGNED has for SALE - Negrohead Tobacco-" Barrett's Twist" very close

A few bags Maize

Second Flour

Manilla Sugar

Musket Balls and Shot

Port and Sherry Wine Strong Vinegar

Regatta and Check Shirts Muslin and Print Dresses Knives and Forks

Bead Planes, Grindstones, &c., &c.

H. R. ELKINS.

South Brisbane, 22nd August, 1846.

PETERSON'S

BRISBANE STORE.

DANIEL PETERSON will store WOOL for

any period during the Wool Season, and will Cart the same to the Wharf and ship and consign it for one shilling per Bale. He will also Store goods brought by sailing vessels (in- cluding cartage from Wharf) for one shilling and sixpence per ton per week ; A.1. vessels provided for the transit of the same to Sydney on moderate

terms.

N.B.-A General Assortment of Goods always on hand, and for sale, on very reasonable terms.

NEW ROAD.

IN consequence of the splendid discovery of a new line of road from the Upper Brisbane, a large portion of the Wool and supplies lor that district and the Boyne will have to be shipped at North Brisbane, the Undersigned begs to inform his friends that he has provided a large Store, capable of holding 500 bales of Wool, and is prepared to receive and ship all Goods that may be consigned to his care, at the following rates : Wool, including cartage and shipping, 1s. per

bale.

Supplies from Sydney, including cartage, 1s. 6d.

per ton per week.

G. S. LE BRETON.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

THE CELEBRATED HORSE

"TOSS."

Got by the imported Horse Toss, out of a

Hector Mare.

THIS HORSE is a bright bay, with black points, rising seven years old, ascertained to be a sure foal-getter, and his stock is well known to be fit for the Indian market.

He will stand at the premises of the proprietor, C. Peacock, at Ipswich, until the 10th October.

Terms-One Mare, £2 2s. ; two or more, £1 10s. each. Payment to be made on delivery of each mare, on or before the 1st January, 1847.

A good Paddock provided, but no responsibility

incurred.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

AT KILCOY. BRISBANE RIVER.

THE THOROUGH-BRED RACE HORSE

MENTOR

By Toss out of Penelope.

MENTOR is a Bay with black points, and a sure foal getter. His performances on the Turf are too well known to need any lengthened description, he having beaten the crack horses of the day, viz., Jorrocks Blue Bonnet, The Colonel, Zephyrine, &c.

Terms-One Mare, £3 10s. ; three Mares, £3

each.

Every attention paid to Mares, but no respon- sibility incurred.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

AT MR. JOHN MCLAUGHLIN'S,

AT THE BRIDGE, IPSWICH,

THE well-known thorough-bred HORSE,

WATERLOO,

Got by Waterloo out of a Satellite Mare.

This Horse is a bright Bay, with black points, rising eight years old ; stands 15 hands 2¼ inches high ; is a sure foal-getter, and his Stock will be highly adapted for the Indian Market.

Terms-For one Mare, £2 10s. ; two or more, the property of one person, £2 each, Groomage

included.

A good and well watered Paddock provided, and every attention will be paid to the Mares, but no responsibility incurred.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

AT CANNING DOWNS,

THE following STALLIONS, the property of

Messrs. W. and G. Leslie.

KNAVE OF CLUBS- brown-black Horse,

standing 16½ hands high, got by the thorough- bred horse Tros, (imported by H. H. Kater, Esq.,in 1839) ; dam, Lady Mary (imported in 1839) by Bedlamite-her dam by Woful, grand dam by Orville, out of Trumpetta by Trumpator.

Terms-Five Guineas a Mare,

EAGLE-a bay Horse, standing 16 hands 1 inch

high ; foaled in 1843 ; got by the thorough- bred imported horse St. George-dam by Old Whisker, her dam by Steeltrap. out of a mare by Hector.

Terms-Four Guineas a Mare.

ST. ANDREW-a roan Horse; foaled in 1841 ;

stands 15 hands 3 inches high ; got by St. George-dam by Stride, her dam by Champion -g. dam by Sheik, out of an imported mare.

Terms-£2 I2s. 6d. a Mare.

CONSERVATIVE- a dark-brown Horse ;

foaled in 1839 ; got by Gratis-dam by Theo- rem, her dam by Cammerton- g. dam by Champion. gt. g. dam by Sheik, out of an im- ported mare.

Terms-£1 2s. 6d. a Mare.

Every attention will be paid to Mares sent, but the proprietors will not hold themselves responsi- ble for accidents or losses.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

1846,

AT GLENGALLAN. DARLING DOWNS,

THE pure-bred imported ARAB HORSE, BEEZA.

Beeza was imported in the British Sovereign, in November, 1841, is one of the highest caste Arabs ever imported to the colony, and the winner of several races in India. His stock is much ad-

mired, and allowed by competent judges to be just the style of animal for the Indian market.

Terms-£3 each Mare, and 3s. Groomage.

SAINT PATRICK,

A rich Bay, with black points, rising four years old, 16 hands high, and shows good racing points. Saint Patrick was got by the thorough-bred imported horse Saint George out of Papsteel.

Terms-£2 10s. each Mare.

GLANCER,

A powerful dark-grey Draught Horse, got by the celebrated imported Clydesdale horse, Briton out of a favourite Hector mare. Glancer stands 16 hands high,and inherits the sound constitution and good temper of his sires ; he is well worthy the attention of breeders for draught.

Terms-£2 each Mare.

Every attention will be paid to the Mares, and large and well watered Paddocks provided, but the Proprietor will not be be responsible for any loss

or accident.

All payments to be made before the removal of

the Mares.

COLIN CAMPBELL. Glengallan, 10th July, 1846.

NOTICE.

SHEEP-SKINS will be purchased, by the under-

signed for cash, and for which the highest market price will be given.

MARTIN BYRNE. Ipswich, 8th August, 1846.
heading: Classified Advertising
title: {'id': '14', 'value': 'The Moreton Bay Courier (Brisbane, Qld. : 1846 - 1861)'}

articleText:
WOOL VESSEL FOR LONDON

DIRECT.

SHOULD sufficient encouragement be given, the undersigned will procure a first class vessel in Sydney, to load from this Port direct to London.

Parties requiring advances, in their shipments. can receive the same on the terms usually charged

in Sydney.

A list of intended shippers lies at the office of P. W. Welsh, South Brisbane ; John Richardson, North Brisbane ; Colin Campbell, Esq., Darling Downs ; Mr. .Thomas Alford's, Post Office, Dar- ling Downs; and at my office, Custom House,

North Brisbane.

GEO. WATSON,

Custom House Agent.

SALE BY AUCTION;

MR. T. DOWSE

WILL Sell by Public Auction, at his Rooms, Queen-street, North Brisbane, on

TUESDAY NEXT, the 8th SEPTEMBER,

At 11 o'clock,

Merchandise, Wearing Apparel, and other Effects belonging to the late Mr. Kitson.

also, A quantity of Saltpetre, Annatto, (a cheese colour- ing), French Polish, Spirits of Wine, a Very use- ful Hand Cart, and other miscellaneous articles.

Terms-Cash.

MR. DOWSE

WILL Sell by Public Auction, without the

slightest reserve, on

TUESDAY NEXT, the 8th INST., One quarter-cask Martell's BRANDY.

Terms-Cash.

ONE POUND REWARD.

STRAYED from Kangaroo Point, a Chesnut Horse, with ball face, branded RP on near shoulder, 128 on off shoulder. The above reward will be paid to any person who will deliver him to Mr. John Stevens, Woogaro, or the subscriber at Kangaroo Point.

JOHN CAMPBELL. Sept. 4th, 1846.

ONE POUND REWARD.

LOST, from Copper's Plains, a Bay Horse, black points, small star in forehead, small white snip on the nose, branded CC on the neck, S 1/1 on the shoulder. The above reward will be paid to any person who will deliver him to

JOHN STEVENS, Woogaroo. September 4th, 1846.

TO LET,

THAT well-known Business Stand situated

at Woogaroo,

THE SETTLERS' ARMS INN.

To an industrious couple this offers a desirable opportunity ; the premises are large and conve- nient; the House containing ten rooms, a large Tap adjoining, a safe and commodious Store, Kitchen, and Stabling ; a large horse Paddock and Stockyard ; a cultivation Paddock, containing seven acres, together with a Garden, containing three acres, in a high state of cultivation, and which is of itself capable of producing a handsome income. To a respectable tenant, the terms will be moderate ; the furniture may be purchased at a valuation, or not, as may best suit the party coming in. Apply to Mr. John Campbell, Kan- garoo Point ; to T. Adams Esq., Solicitor, North Brisbane ; or to the subscriber, on the premises, JOHN STEVENS.

September 4th, 1846.

NOTICE

IF JOHN QUINNELL, who arrived in this

district per schooner William, about twelve months since, does not retire his Promissory Note for £6, given for his passage money, the Picture left as a collateral security, will be sold in 14 days from this date, and immediate steps taken to re- cover the balance if any due.

THOMAS DOWSE,

Commission Agent, Brisbane.

WOOL.

THE Undersigned is authorised to make cash advances on Wool consigned to Capt. Towns, Sydney; for sale there, or shipment through him to Robert Brooks, Esq., London.

Wool, washed and unwashed, Hides, and Sheep- skins, purchased. Apply at the Wharf, South Brisbane.

P. W. Welsh.

ALE.

THE Undersigned having been appointed Agent for the Sale of BLAXLANDS ALE, will

be happy to dispose of the same in twenty-gallon Casks, to Settlers, and others requiring a supply. This Ale is of very superior quality. A large stock always on hand.

DAVID BOW. Queen-street,

North Brisbane, 14th August, 1846.

DIVINE WORSHIP.

THE REV. R. TAYLOR will conduct Divine Worship, in the Court House, TO-MORROW, at 11 o'clock, a.m.

TESTIMONIAL to the Rev. R. TAYLOR :-

£ s. d.

Mr. and Mrs. Gray. 1 10 0 Mr. and Mrs. Swan. :...... 1 1 0 Mr. and Mrs. John Smith .. 1 0 0 Mr. and Mrs. John M'Intyre 1 0 0 Mr. and Mrs. Alex. M'Intyre 1 0 0 Mr, and Mrs. M'Cabe. 1 0 0 J. A. Beechy. 0 10 0 George Edmondston. 0 10 0 George W Adams. 0 10 0 Edward Mott . 0 10 0 David Bow . 0 10 0 John Stewart. 1 10 0 David Buntin ....... 1 0 0

William Farries .. 0 10 0 James Moyes ... 0 10 0 John Boyland. 0 10 0 Peter Jackson, ..,.... 0 10 0 James Kirkwood ... 0 10 0

John Mofitt...... 0 10 0

L. Maclean .. .. 0 10 0 William Kent .... 1 0 0

Leopold Zillman ......... 0 10 0 J. Richardson. 1 10 0 D. K. Ballow ..... 1 0 0 R. Cannan.. .. 0 10 0

John Kent .... 1 0 0 James Warner .. .. 1 0 0

John Brydon .. .. 0 10 0 Thomas Smith .... 0 3 0 William Stuart .. .. 0 10 0

£22 14 0

This Subscription is a Testimonial of the esteem in which the Presbyterians, and other friends of the Rev. R. Taylor, in Brisbane, Moreton Bay, have regarded him as a Christian Minister, during his few weeks' residence amongst them ; and they sincerely hope and pray that his health may be restored, and that his present and future exertions in forwarding Christ's cause in this colony may be crowned with their Redeemer's blessing and approval.

Brisbane, Sept. 4,1846.

THE VOICE

IN THE WILDERNESS,

Published in Sydney on the 1st and 15th of

each month; eight pages demy - quarto. Price 1s. 6d. per quarter.

THIS PAPER contains statements of Divine truth, doctrinal and practical; sketches of the lives of eminent Christians ; and accounts of the various religious movements throughout the world. It is specially devoted to the exposition and defence of the great doctrines of the Headship of Christ, and the spiritual independence of His Churches maintained by the Free Church of

Scotland.

Subscribers names will be received by the Agent for Moreton Bay.

JAMES SWAN, Printer. Moreton Bay Courier Office, Sept. 5.

NOTICE.

THE Undersigned respectfully informs the Settlers in this District, and others proceeding to the Boyne, that he will be happy to Store Goods brought up by carriers, for which the following charges will be made weekly :

Dead weight, per ton,. 3s. 0d. Small packages, &c, . 0s. 3d.

THOMAS ALFORD, Drayton, Darling Downs,

August 13, 1846.

NOTICE.

MR. DAVID NORTH, Wool-sorter, having arrived from Sydney, is authorised to pur- chase Wool, Sheepskins, Tallow, Hides, Bullocks' Horns, nnd Tips,- the same to be delivered to J. R. and A. F. Wilshire, George-street ; or, C. Appleton and Co., Pitt-street, Sydney.

Ipswich, August 20, 1846.

CAUTION.

I HEREBY caution any person or persons

against engaging John Hitchings, he having absconded from my hired service on the 18th inst.

JOHN STEVENS. Woogaroo, Aug., 28, 1846.

LOST.

STRAYED, or stolen, from the Tarampa Station,

a Bay Gelding, with white star on the forehead,

branded -T-

One pound reward will be given for the recovery thereof, or £5 if stolen, on conviction of the

offender.

C. AND D. CAMERON.

GEORGE FURBER,

(late of Maitland),

BEGS to inform his many kind friends, and the

public generally, that he has re-commenced business as an innkeeper, at

THE GOLDEN FLEECE,

IPSWICH,

(the house lately occupied by Mr. R. E. Dix), where he now offers to all who may honour him with a call, the ease and comfort usually found in an English

ROAD-SIDE INN ;

combining therewith, when necessary, the luxuries

of a Town Hotel.

The strictest attention to the wants and wishes of his patrons: good liquors - good dinners - good beds, and respectful attendants will, he trusts, eventually procure for him a fair share of public favour ; meanwhile G. F. most respectfully solicits a visit : confident that the weary traveller who has once partaken of his cheer, will not after- wards, like the Lévite of old, pass by on the other side.

GOOD STABLING, and careful attendance for

horses.

articleText:
STEAM TO SYDNEY.

K T H E STEAM - PACKET * l WILLIAM IV.,

will leave Kangaroo'Point for Sydney, on TUESDAY NEXT, ____is the 15lh December; and con- tinue to do so every alternate Tuesday.

fares :

Cabin..,.£2 10 0 Steerage-provisions included 1 10 0

GEO. WATSON,

Agent. Kangaroo Point, Dec. 12,1846.

FOR SYDNEY-. - - -

THE PACKET-SCHOONER

x WILLIAM,

^ä^ Freeman, master, will sail from

Campbell's Wharf, Kangaroo Point, for the above port, on THURSDAY next.

For freight or passage, apply to the master on

board.

SALE BY AUCTION.

FREEHOLD PROPERTY IN THE FLOURISHING

TOWN OF IPSWICH,

Producing a clear Rental of 25s. per week.

MR. T. DOWSE

HAS been favouted with instructions from the

Proprietor, Mr. Thomson, to Sell by Public Auction, at the Queen's Arms Hotel, Ipswich,

On MONDAY the 11th of JANUARY, 1847,

At 12 o'clock,

(if not previously disposed of by private contract,) in consequence of the proprietor being under

orders for

NORTH AUSTRALIA,

All that valuable Allotment of LAND, situate in the centre of Ipswich, and known as Allotment No. 21, Section No. 2, being a corner allotment, having a frontage of 51 feet to East-street, with 120 feet frontage to a cross street, upon which

FOUR WELL FINISHED COTTAGES

have been erected, and now let to respectable tenants at 25s. per week.

Lot 2--An Allotment of LAND, situate in Bell-street, to which it has a frontage of 51 feet by a depth of 120 feet, bounded by the cross street unnamed, and consequently presenting a double frontage for building purposes.

Any attempt on the part of the Auctioneer to overrate the value of the above splendid properties would be superfluous, their value being demon- strated in the comfortable little weekly rental deiived from the substantial Cottages erected on IjOt 1, and the conti al position tor business of Lot No. 2 ; and it is now pretty well known to the residents of these fertile districts, that Ipswich must shortly become the Maitland of Moreton Bay -from the extensive agricultural district in the vicinity of the township-and which, upon the removal of the Government Stock, will without doubt be thrown open for location

ANO

Cattle, to half the amount of the purchase money, will be taken in payment, if desiiable.

Full particulars can be obtained at the office of the Auctioneer, Brisbane; or from the Proprietor, at Ipswich.

NOTICE is hereby Given, that ROBERT ^ COULSON, of Kmgbah, in the District of Moreton Bay, in the Colony of New South Wales, hath, by Deed of Assignment, duly executed, assigned, and made over, all his Stock oí Sheep, Cattle, and Horses, at present depasturing at Kingbah, together with the right of Station there- at, and all other his personal property whatsoever, (except as by said Deed is excepttd), to ^ohn Rankin and John Cameron, both of Fassifern, in the district and colony aforesaid, Trustees, ia trust for the purposes in said Deed mentioned.

Dated this 10th day of December, 1846,

MORETON BAY DISTRICT ASSOCIATION.

TAKE NOTICE, that a Quarterly Meeting of 1 the Members of the Moreton Bay District Association will be holden at the Victoria Hotel, on THURSDAY NEXT, the 17th December inst., at Three o'clock, p.m., when all parties interested are respectfully requested to attend.

LOUIS F. LAY ARD,

Secretary. Brisbane, 11th Dec, 1846.

NOTICE is hereby Given, that the Undersigned *? ^ will not be responsible for any Debts con . tracted on account of the Steamer Experiment, excepting by the written authority of

ROBERT GRAHAM & CO.,

Agents. J. C. PEARCE.

Owner.

Brisbane, 7th Dec, 1846.

REGATTA.

TJOAT-OWNERS, and others interested in the

ensuing Regatta, are requested to meet at the Sawyers' Arms, in North Brisbane, on Wednesday Evening next, at Seven o'clock, to make the pre- liminary arrangements.

WANTED,

A MAN and his Wife, or two Females,-one to rY cook and wash, and the other to take charge of children, and to make herself generally useful.

Apply to

MRS. COLEY.

North Brisbane, Dec. 10,184fi.

WANTED,

A COUPLE of Men to take a DAIRY for such -^ part of the produce as may be agreed upon.

A six-acre cultivation Paddock can be let with the Dairy. Also, Three Hands, as Shepherds or Hut keepers and Watchmen. For particulars, enquire

at Captain Coley'a Store.

Brisbane, 4th December, 1846.

WANTED

TOt PURCHASE, a smalfÀllotment of Ground

"having a frontage to Queen-street, for which ready money will be paid. Apply at the office of

this journal.

North Brisbane, 10th Dec , 1846.

EMPLOYMENT WANTED

tí Y two Persons, who can be well recommended ?"-* by their late employer, with whom they have served four years. They perfectly understand putting up fences, huts, all kinds of bush work, and farming. One of them is married, and has two children. For further particulars as to hiring, apply at the office of this journal.

8th December, 1816.

TO BUILDERS.

rPENDERS are required for building a Cottage.

.*. Plans and specifications can be seen at the

office of

MR. OCOCK,

Solicitor.

South Brisbane, 11th Dec, 1846.

FOR SALE,

CEVERAL Allotments of LAND, at South ^ Brisbane. Terms liberal. Apply to

MR. OCOCK,

Solicitor. South Brisbane.

TO BE SOLD BY PRIVATE CONTRACT.

A VERY CAPITAL COTTAGE, at Kangaroo

Point. Apply to

North Brisbane, Dec. 12, 1846.

T. ADAMS,

Solicitor.

FOR SALE,

»THE CARGO of FLOUR, ex Ann, from

.?. Sydney, consisting of

Fine and Seconds

Van Diemen's Land Oats y Maize

Bran

Pickles Sauces

Mustard Tea Rum

Cigars, &c, 8cc. Apply to

ROBERT GRAHAM & CO. North and South Brisbane.

HTHE Undersigned are purchasers of Wool,

Tallow, or other produce ; or will, as usual, make advances on the same, if consigned to their correspondents either in London or Liverpool.

ROBERT GRAHAM & CO. Brisbane, 4th Nov., 1846.

BUNYA BUNYA PLANTS.

'T'HE Undersigned has for Sale, upwards of two

dozen Bunya Bunya Plants, in good order, which he will dispose of on reasonable terms to intending purchasers. The Plants are in thriving condition, and have been carefully attended to.

Apply to

WILLIAM FRASER,

Albert-street.

North Brisbane, 10th Doe, 1846.

r)N SALE by the undersigned, FINE FLOUR,

at moderate prices.

EBEN. ORR.

South Brisbane, Nov. 28, l810.

^TOW running al Eagle Farm, a Black COW

* -branded LC on the rump milking side, a brand resembling a half-moon on the same side. The owner can obtain the above cow, on paying for lier keep and the expense of this

advertisement. '

JOHN WESTAWAY. Eagle Farm, Dec 1, 1810.

.*.«. NOTICE. '

fHE undermentioned ORDERS having been

STOLEN, all parties are cautioned against receiving them :

J. M. Andrew, favour Harrington, on R. Camp-

bell-£9 10s.

W. and G. Leslie, favour Fox, on Bank of Aus-

tralasia-£3.

Pittsand Bonifant, favour Maddox, on R. Graham

I -£5

Mackay favour Wilkins, on Mackay-£3 3s.

Payment has been stopped, and a Reward of Five Shillings in the Pound will be paid by the undersigned on their being restored.

- G. S. LE BRETON.

^HE Undersigned has received, per William,

a large supply of

Van Diemen's Land Oaten Hay Bran, prime quality

Maize, old and sound

Besides his usual assortment of all descriptions of

Liquors and sundries.

G. S. LE BRETON.

£30 REWARD.

SUBSCRIPTION FOR THE APPREHENSION' OF

I THE THREE BLACKS W(HO MURDERED MR.

GREGOR A.ND MRS. SHANNON.

A REWARD of £10 for each Black will be "**? given to any party who apprehends the following Aboriginal Natives, viz. : - Jackey Jackey, Dick Ben, and Moggy Moggy, the mur- derers of the late Mr. Gregor and Mrs. Shannon.

Persons who approve of the above objects, are politely requested to forward their Subscriptions to

J. RICHARDSON,

North Brisbane. November 27,1846.

BRISBANE HOTEL,

SOUTH BRISBANE, MORETON BAY.

T^HE Undersigned having leased those premises, * known as the " Brisbane Hotel," begs re- spectfully to inform Gentlemen arriving from the Interior.., Sydney, and the Public generally, that hehas re-opeñecf lu^Mmw, ^»uu ~ w»u "«art^a,i stock of choice Wines, Spirits, Ales, and Porter, (bottled and draught), Champagne, Cordials, &c. No expense having been spared in cleansing and enlarging the premises, to suit the increasing wants of the Settlers, occasioned by the great influx of Sheep-owners from the Southern and other Districts, so none will be spared in furnishing the Table, and providing the best accommodation, which all those honouring this Hotel with their support will acknowledge as second to none in the

District.

Attention, civility, and moderate charges,, it is hoped, will procure for this Hotel a fair share of support from the Squatting interest, as wellas from

the residents of Brisbaiîe.

JACOB GOODE. South Brisbane, Dec. 10,1846.

TO LET,

THE SOVEREIGN HOTEL, situated in

the most eligible spot in the flourishing town of North Brisbane, and now in full trade. Any person wishing to enter into the business, will find this a first-rate opportunity-with the whole benefit of the Wool Season before them. The furniture and every requisite can be taken at a valuation, or not, and immediate possession given. The house has been put in thorough repair, and has recently been painted. Apply on

the premises.

O

N S A L E - MARTELLO BRANDY .

Jamaica Rum

Gin, in 4 gallon cases

Port Wine, in 3 dozen cases Sherry, in 3 dozen cases Ditto, in draught

Champagne, in I dozen cases

&t¿, } I» »*»»?- -

Ale and Porter* in hhds. and barrels.

J. HARRIS,

South Brisbane.

TO WOOL-GROWERS and STOREKEEPERS. THE undersigned is empowered to make Cash * Advances on Wool, consigned to the House of Messrs. Evans, Brothers, London ; or in his capacity of Wool Broker and General Agent, will obtain the highest market rates in Sydney, if entrusted to him for Sale, and effect prompt returns faithfully in cash, or supplies, as required.^ Commission charge, li per cent.

B. S. LLOYD.,

10, Bridge-street, Sydney.

TO THE WOOL-GROWERS

IN THE MORETON BAY DISTRICT.

THE Undersigned begs to inform his friends, *. and the Wool-growers generally, that he is prepared this season to assort and repack Wool, suitable for the London and Liverpool Markets.

Parties sheating in the grease, can be accom- modated by having their Wool assorted and hand washed ; 'and samples may be seen by applying to

WM. CARTER,

Kangaroo Point.

FOR SALE by PRIVATE CONTRACT, AVERY CAPITAL mixed HERD of CATTLE,

within 35 miles of Brisbane-there are about, 60 Bullocks fit for the Butcher amongst them.

Also, about 800 fine-woollcd SHEEP, at the same place, viz. :

430 Ewes, mixed ages, with lambs by their sides 133 Ditto two years old 232 Hoggets

5 Rams

800

Warranted sound, and never to have boen dis- eased. The purchaser to be entitled to half the Wool of the present season's clip, and half the increase. The Sheep will be deliverable almost

immediately.

For further particulars, apply to the Proprietor, of the Courier ; or to Mr. Adams, Solicitor,

North Brisbane, llth Dec, 1816.

articleText:
STEAM TO SYDNEY,

BY the Hunter River Steam Navigation Co.'s

Packet

T A M A R :

THIS MORNING, AND

ON THURSDAY, 24TH SEPTEMBER,

And on every alternate Thursday during the

Season.

FARES:—

Saloon.................... £4 0 0 Steerage ................ 2 0 0

H.R.S.N.Co.'s Wharf,

South Brisbane.

FOR SYDNEY.

THE PACKET-SCHOONER

WILLIAM,

Freeman, master, will sail from Campbell's Wharf, Kangaroo Point, for the above port, on WEDNESDAY next.

For freight or passage, apply to the master on board ; or to

JOHN CAMPBELL,

Kangaroo Point. SALE BY AUCTION.

MR. DOWSE

WILL Sell by Public Auction, at the quar- ters of Mr. Surveyor Burnett, on

MONDAY NEXT, THE 14TH INST.,

At 12 o'clock.

The under-mentioned articles, viz. :—

Two Drays An old Boat

Tarpawlins

Bullock Harness

Tents, Boat Sails, and other useful articles. On account of the Survey Department.

Terms—Cash.

SALE BY AUCTION.

MR. T. DOWSE

WILL Sell by Public Auction, immediately after the Sale at the Survey Office, on

MONDAY NEXT, THE 14TH SEPTEMBER,

An excellent CANVAS TENT, quite new and complete, and well worth the attention of Publicans and others, for a Booth at the Races.

Terms, Cash—it being sold to defray charges for Store-rent, &c.

SALE BY AUCTION.

FOUR FIRST-RATE ALLOTMENTS

AT THE POINT.

MR. T. DOWSE has much pleasure in an- nouncing a Sale by Public Auction, on

THURSDAY, THE 8TH OCTOBER NEXT.

At 12 o'clock,

ON THE GROUND,

Of Four beautiful Allotments of BUILDING GROUND, situated at Kangaroo Point—described

as under :—

LOT 1—A corner allotment, having a frontage to

High-street of 40 feet, by a depth to Campbell-street of 100 feet.

LOT 2—Adjoining the above, having a similar

frontage to High-street, by a depth of

100 feet.

LOT 3—Has a frontage to Campbell-street of 65

feet, by a depth of 80 feet.

LOT 4—Adjoining Lot 3, with similar frontage

and depth.

The Allotments are well situated for business, being in the vicinity of the Salting Establishment and Public Wharf ; and when the fact is pretty well known, that a second steamer will, in a short

time, be laid on between this port and Sydney, and that Kangaroo Point must, from its commanding situation, become the starting place of the opposi- tion boat,—land must, as a natural consequence, rise immensely in value. The industrious mechanic and Working man should, therefore, not let an opportunity like this pass them for laying by their savings.

The terms will be liberal.

TWENTY POUNDS REWARD.

SLANDER.

CERTAIN malicious, libelous reports having

been circulated respecting the undersigned,

he hereby offers the above reward to any person who will prove the originator ; or a renard of £10 to any person who will prove to conviction any subsequent promulgator of the said reports, which are base, malicious, and unfounded, and never existed but in the mind of some despicable malicious villian.

JACOB GOODE. South Brisbane, Sept. 11, 1846.

SALE BY AUCTION.

TO THE INDUSTRIOUS CLASSES.

MR. DOWSE has been instructed to Sell by

Public Auction, ON THE 8TH OCTOBER NEXT,

at the same time as the other Allotments for Sale on that day, at

KANGAROO POINT

A neat substantial COTTAGE and GROUND, situate in Jane-street, Kangaroo Point, being Allotment No. 9, as sold at Auction by Sir Evan Mackenzie, on the 6th May last. The whole of the allotment is fenced in, and is, without excep- tion, a first-rate property for an industrious man to lay out his money upon.

Terms made known at the time of Sale.

The deed, &c., can be seen at the office of T. Adams, Esq., solicitor.

WANTED

TO purchase, for cash, on delivery, a Team of young WORKING OXEN, and a strong

PACK HORSE.

JAMES WARNER,

Kangaroo Point.

MORETON BAY

DISTRICT ASSOCIATION.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN, that a General

Quarterly Meeting of the Members will be held on FRIDAY next, the 18th September inst. when all parties connected with the Association are respectfully requested to attend.

LOUIS F. LAYARD,

Secretary. Brisbane, 11th Sept., 1846.

A DAIRY,

WITHIN FIFTY MILES FROM BRISBANE. TO parties wishing to engage in the above, by applying at the Courier Newspaper Office, can obtain the particulars.

Brisbane, 12th Sept., 1846.

TO LET,

FOURTEEN ACRES of LAND, with House and Barn attached, situated at South Brisbane, adjoining the Land of Mr. Thomas Pendergrass.

The Land is of the richest description, and well adapted for agricultural purposes, and has a large Shingled Building erected thereon.

Two ploughs, two harrows, and a large roller,

will be let with the above.

For particulars, apply to Mr. George Furber, Ipswich—if by letter, post paid.

TENDERS for the erection of a COTTAGE at

Limestone, are required. The Plan may be seen at the residence of Mr. Isaac, Kangaroo

Point.

TWENTY TONS of SECOND FLOUR for

Sale, at a small advance on the Sydney prices, at

R. J. COLEY'S,

North Brisbane.

R. J. C. begs to inform the Settlers, that he intends keeping a good stock of Second FJour always on hand—sufficient to meet any demand.

September 8th, 1846.

WINES.

AT the STORES of the Undersigned Superior old Port, at 30s. per dozen Fine rich Sherry, from 24s. to 28s. ditto

Marsella, best brand, from 16s. to 18s. ditto Best White Wine Vinegar, at 12s. ditto Good strong ditto, at 9s. ditto

Colonial Ale and Porter, at the Sydney price of

6s. 6d., with freight and expenses added Red Case Gin, White and Brown Sugar Wine Corks, best Jamaica Ginger

P. W. WELSH. Wharf, South Brisbane.

N.B.—One Shilling a dozen allowed for empty

Wine Bottles.

NOTICE.

THE Undersigned have this day entered into

co-partnership, and will in future conduct the business of their Old Establishment, in George-street, under the firm of

ROBERT PORTER AND SAMUEL PEEK.

(Signed) ROBERT PORTER,

SAMUEL PEEK.

Sydney, 1st Sept., 1846.

TO THE SETTLERS IN THE DISTRICT OF

MORETON BAY.

MR. MORT'S PRODUCE SALES.

MR. MORT

BEGS to inform the Woolgrowers, Merchants, and others of the colony interested in the Sale of Wool, Tallow, &c., that he intends, during the ensuing season, to hold Auction Sales of

Produce

EVERY WEDNESDAY AND SATURDAY, in lieu of Saturday only, as heretofore.

In soliciting a continuance of the support which his weekly sales have received, Mr. Mort would call attention to the very low scale of charges now adopted, and further to the fact, that from the competition created by the attendance of all classes of buyers, this mode of sale possesses advantages over any other, and at all times ensures the ex- treme market rates of the day ; besides enabling the settler to close his transactions on an average within twenty-four hours of the arrival of his Wool and Tallow.

The Stores at the rear of the Rooms, will be always open to receive produce, but Wool intended for Wednesday's sale must be delivered on or be- fore Tuesday, and that for Saturday not later than Friday, in order to give proper time for arrange- ment and inspection.

N.B.—Mr. Mort will be happy to make cash advances on receipt of the Wool into Store, and also to purchase supplies for the return teams if required.

WOOL.

THE Undersigned is authorised to make cash advances on Wool consigned to Capt. Towns, Sydney for sale there, or shipment through him to Robert Brooks, Esq., London.

Wool, washed and unwashed, Hides, and Sheep- skins, purchased. Apply at the Wharf, South

Brisbane.

P. W. WELSH. .

ALE.

THE Undersigned has for Sale BLAXLANDS ALE, in twenty-gallon casks.

This Ale is well suited for the country trade, and since its introduction has been highly approved by the residents in the district.

A large stock always on hand.

DAVID BOW. Queen-street,

North Brisbane, 11th Sept., 1847.

ALE AND PORTER.

THE Undersigned receives fresh supplies of the above, in Hogsheads and Barrels, by every opportunity,

J. HARRIS. South Brisbane, 9th Sept., 1846.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

AT KILCOY, BRISBANE RIVER.

THE THOROUGH-BRED RACE HORSE

MENTOR,

By Toss out of Penelope.

MENTOR is a Bay with black points, and a sure foal getter. His performances on the Turf are too well known to need any lengthened description, he having beaten the crack horses of the day, viz., Jorrocks, Blue Bonnet, The Colonel, Zephyrine, &c.

Terms—One Mare, £3 10s. ; three Mares, £3

each.

Every attention paid to Mares, but no respon- sibility incurred.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

THE CELEBRATED HORSE

" T O S S." Got by the imported Horse Toss, out of a

Hector Mare. THIS HORSE is a bright bay, with black points, rising seven years old, ascertained to be a sure foal-getter, and his stock is well known

to be fit for the Indian market.

He will stand at the premises of the proprietor, C. Peacock, at Ipswich, until the 10th October.

Terms—One Mare, £2 2s. ; two or more, £1 10s. each. Payment to be made on delivery of each mare, on or before the 1st January, 1847.

A good Paddock provided, but no responsibility

incurred.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

1846,

AT GLENGALLAN. DARLING DOWNS,

THE pure-bred imported ARAB HORSE, BEEZA

Beeza was imported in the British Sovereign, in November, 1841, is one of the highest caste Arabs ever imported to the colony, and the winner

of several races in India. His stock is much ad- mired, and allowed by competent judges to be just the style of animal for the Indian market.

Terms—£3 each Mare, and 3s. Groomage,

SAINT PATRICK,

A rich Bay, with black points, rising four years old, 16 hands high, and shows good racing points. Samt Patrick was got by the thorough-bred imported horse Saint George out of Papsteel.

Terms—£2 10s. each Mare.

GLANCER,

A powerful dark-grey Draught Horse, got by the celebrated imported Clydesdale horse, Briton out of a favourite Hector mare. Glancer stands 16 hands high, and inherits the sound constitution and good temper of his sires; he is well worthy the attention of breeders for draught.

Terms—£2 each Mare.

Every attention will be paid to the Mares, and large and well watered Paddocks provided, but the Proprietor will not be be responsible for any losa or accident.

All payments to be made before the removal of

the Mares.

COLIN CAMPBELL. Glengallan, 10th July, 1846.

TO STAND THIS SEASON,

AT CANNING DOWNS,

THE following STALLIONS, the property of

Messrs. W. and G. Leslie.—

KNAVE OF CLUBS—a brown-black Horse,

standing 16½ hands high, got by the thorough- bred horse Tros, (imported by H. H. Kater, Esq., in 1839) ; dam, Lady Mary (imported in 1839) by Bedlamite-her dam by Wo/ul, grand dam by Orville, out of Trumpetta by Trumpator.

Terms—Five Guineas a Mare. EAGLE—a bay Horse, standing 16 hands 1 inch

high ; foaled in 1843 ; got by the thorough bred imported horse St. George—dam by Old Whisker, her dam by Steeltrap, out of a mare by Hector.

Terms—Four Guineas a Mare. ST. ANDREW—a roan Horse; foaled in 1841 ;

stands 15 hands 3 inches high ; got by St. George—dam by Stride, her dam by Champion —g. dam by Sheik, out of an imported mare.

Terms—£2 12s. 6d. a Mare.

CONSERVATIVE— a dark-brown Horse,

foaled in 1839 ; got by Gratis-dam by Theo- rem, her dam by Cammerton-g. dam by Champion, gt. g. dam by Sheik, out of an im- ported mare.

Terms—£1 2s. 6d. a Mare.

Every attention will be paid to Mares sent, but the proprietors will not hold themselves responsi-

ble for accidents or losses.
